description: Joseph S. Gruss, a financier and philanthropist who supported Jewish education and other Jewish causes, died on Saturday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Magna-Lab Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: Revenue represented interest income.The company in the year-ago period commenced operations on Feb. 10, and ended Feb. 29.

title: New Jersey Steel Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Norris Communications Corp. reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a $ 3.4 million non-cash compensation expense necessitated by the release of restricted escrow shares during the year.c-Net incomeNorris Communications said that the 28 percent revenue increase was attributable to growth of the company's contract manufacturing unit, American Surface Mounted Devices Inc. However, that unit still lost about $ 700,000 for the year.The company also said that its 74.2 percent-owned unit, Jabra Corp., formerly Norcom, accounted for $ 1.2 million of 1993's loss.

title: On West 42d, Evictions Mark Way of Progress
description: For years, West 42d Street has been caught in the bleakest of time warps. A massive redevelopment plan has been bedeviled by bureaucratic delay and hammered by economic adversity, while the condemnation of businesses to make way for the plan has pushed relentlessly forward.

title: Compromise On Rent Law Is Criticized
description: Lawmakers found themselves on the defensive today as the compromise they fashioned on Saturday night to extend rent-stabilization regulations came under attack from tenants.

title: Ryan to Return to the Mound
description: NOLAN RYAN, who has been on the disabled list since May 17, is tentatively scheduled to pitch for Texas against Milwaukee on July 19 at Arlington Stadium. Ryan has been on the disabled list with a strained left hip. Earlier in the season, he had arthroscopic surgery to repair damaged knee ligaments. Ryan has worked out daily at Arlington Stadium with TOM HOUSE, formerly the Rangers' pitching coach and now a consultant for the team. Ryan went through another throwing session off the mound Friday. (AP)

title: Jill Humphrey, John McMullen
description: Jill Patricia Humphrey, the daughter of Sandra Humphrey of Highland Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Lieut. John Warrick McMullen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. McMullen 2d of Stella, Neb. The Rev. Richard Spalding performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the World's End Reservation in Hingham, Mass.

description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned today that the United States might halt its active role in the Middle East peace talks, saying that all sides "have to want peace."

title: Puri Journal; After 600 Years, a Hindu Juggernaut Is Still Rolling
description: With her palms pressed together in prayer, Kumidini Padhi stood rapt in the crowd, peeking from the folds of her turquoise silk sari at a wooden Hindu chariot looming above 16 huge, spoked wheels.

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's financial markets will be closed today in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Government offices, most banks and many businesses will also be closed.

title: When Saving Navy Money Costs Jobs
description: When Terry Melan ponders his prospects for surviving the military cuts that will cost him his job at the Charleston Naval Shipyard, he thinks of the last disaster to hit the South Carolina city. It does not brighten his mood.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Friday misidentified real estate developments at Fisher Island, Fla. The picture at top showed Seaside Villas, not Bayside Village; the picture at right showed Seaside Village, not a former Vanderbilt estate.

title: Review/Music; Summergarden in a Latin-American Mood
description: On Saturday night the Summer garden concert series once again took up its dual mission: presenting fresh repertory played by young musicians and finding a way to make it heard above the din of mid-Manhattan. Latin-American music, this year's theme, will occupy eight more free weekend programs in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: No Headline
description: The motoring public has decided that 55 miles an hour is not a reasonable speed. Historically the public has always responded to unreasonable highway traffic control by simply ignoring it. TOM CULPEPPER, manager of safety for the American Automobile Association. [ 39:3. ]

title: Election Campaign In Japan Shadows the Summit Talks
description: This week was supposed to be the crowning moment in Kiichi Miyazawa's political life: a chance for Japan's urbane, English-speaking Prime Minister to welcome the leaders of the industrialized world -- and Boris N. Yeltsin -- to an economic powerhouse that he helped to rebuild from rubble.

title: Ready to Put Theories Into Action, Secretary Finds Ideas Are Not Allies
description: Not many Cabinet secretaries arrive in town with a billing like that of Robert B. Reich when he showed up to take over the Department of Labor.

title: Haitian General Begins a Selling Job
description: Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, Haiti's military chief and de facto ruler, today began the difficult process of selling an accord to restore democracy to his reluctant colleagues in the armed forces and to a public suspicious of his intentions.

title: In Multimedia Storm, Text Thrives
description: Wired, a magazine dedicated to the "Digital Generation," made its debut this year promising frontline reports on the communications revolution "whipping through our lives like a Bengali typhoon" and creating "social changes so profound that their only parallel is probably the discovery of fire." Then, in its second issue, it published a truly unexpected revelation from a futurist in Silicon Valley.

description: b-Included extraordinary net operating loss carryforwards of $ 134,277, or 2 cents a share.

title: Mandela and de Klerk Receive Liberty Medal in Philadelphia
description: Nelson Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa joined President Clinton at the birthplace of American democracy today, capping a day of pointed remarks on the distance each nation must travel to guarantee the fruits of freedom to all their citizens.

title: . . . 8 . . . 9 . . . 10: Garden Boxing, Hit Hard by Casinos, Is Counted Out
description: In other days, with other fighters -- with Muhammad Ali, Sugar Ray Robinson, Jake LaMotta, Joe Louis and Henry Armstrong -- it was called the Temple of Fistiana. But now, with the real fights going to casinos and the biggest headlines coming from allegations that someone named Jesse Ferguson was bribed to take a dive on an undercard, Madison Square Garden is shutting down its boxing business.

title: On Fast Wheels to a Bright Future
description: Lance Armstrong has made it to what he calls "the big show, the big deal, the Super Bowl" and what everybody else calls the Tour de France. Armstrong can be excused for his excitement because he is 21 years old and hardly anybody else in the bicycle race, including the youngster who distributes soft drinks at the finish line, is even close to being that young.

title: Editorial Notebook; 'We Hold (Some) Truths . . .'
description: Americans deem it self-evident that men and women everywhere are created equal, with the same universal right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, just as the Declaration of Independence says. But third-world countries like Indonesia say otherwise, claiming that human rights vary in place and time, and that enforcement is "the competence and responsibility of each government."

title: Anne Blumberg, Jonathan Dorfman
description: Anne Francesca Blumberg, a health-policy analyst in Boston, was married yesterday to Jonathan Michael Dorfman, a principal in the Connoisseurs Products Corporation in Woburn, Mass. Rabbi Izan Caine performed the ceremony in Oxford, England, at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Easy Prey for a Violent Criminal; Prostitutes View Murder as Just One Occupational Hazard
description: The 23-year-old prostitute, who says her name is Margie, walked the stroll off Allen Street in lower Manhattan in a baggy black halter top and baggier jeans, eyeing every passing car.

title: Sports of The Times; Men's Final: Fast Points, Slow Match
description: "JACKETS off." In the Royal Box, these are the kindest words of all. It means that by royal decree, all gentlemen and ladies are free to doff their jackets on a hot afternoon at the All England Croquet & Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Bridge
description: The European Championships, which ended nine days ago in Menton, France, included one American player. Bill Russ, who learned his bridge in New York and now lives in Zurich, qualified to represent his adopted country.

title: Schools and Churches Close, Angering Catholics
description: Discrimination among the thousands of poor European immigrants who arrived on America's shores from the mid-19th century to the early 20th drove each of the ethnic groups to build its own Roman Catholic church, often within sight of other Catholic churches.

title: Ordinary Women Receive a Tribute From Feminists
description: At the 27th annual National Organization for Women convention here this weekend, there was naturally much celebration over Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Carol Moseley Braun, Janet Reno, Donna E. Shalala and, among others, Patricia Ireland, who was overwhelmingly re-elected as NOW's president on Saturday night.

title: Uproar on TV Violence Frustrates the Networks
description: Despite the criticism of broadcast networks heard in Congressional hearings during the last several weeks, and the campaigns by interest groups to censor programming deemed too violent for young viewers, there is strong evidence that network series are less violent now than in decades.

title: Suspicions of Hatred in a Family of Artists
description: Telling a tale of parental envy and murderous spite, two scholars say they have found evidence that Charles Willson Peale, one of the fathers of American art, induced his eldest son, Raphaelle, also an accomplished artist, to poison himself. Raphaelle Peale died in 1825 at age 51.

description: What started out as a campaign gimmick -- the distribution of discount coupons for Dairy Queen treats -- has turned into a criminal investigation.

title: Sports of The Times; Drysdale Could Laugh At Himself
description: I saw Don Drysdale for the last time two months ago at a formal baseball dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. He was still looking very large at 6 feet 6 inches, about 220 pounds, large enough, strong enough, young enough, even at age 56, that in the mind's eye I could see him back on the mound, alone under the stadium lights as cool in his black tuxedo as he had ever been in his Dodger blue.

title: A Magic Formula for Cutbacks
description: Representative Dick Armey's magic formula for closing military bases has proved itself again. For the third time in five years, a nonpartisan commission has agreed on a list of bases to be closed, shrunk or, in some cases, expanded. By bucking this job to outsiders, Congress ducks its duty to make tough choices. But independent, nonpolitical decisions are clearly better than the stalemate that existed before.

title: Keep the Aid Flowing to Russia
description: Economic reform in Russia is alive and surprisingly well. Finally, the West is taking notice and moving to provide real help. Last week the International Monetary Fund handed Russia $1.5 billion. The World Bank has approved a mammoth $660 million loan to develop Russia's oil industry, and dispersed hundreds of millions to pay for medicine and other needed imports.

U.S.-Japan Trade Talks To Resume
description: The United States and Japan will resume negotiations on a new comprehensive trade agreement, officials said today, brightening the outlook for President Clinton's meeting this week with the Prime Minister of Japan, Kiichi Miyazawa.

title: A Gershwin's Album of Heady Family Memories
description: Frances Godowsky has a way with a Gershwin tune. It's not so much the voice, which is sweet and a little frail. It's a feeling for the lyrics and a vocal style that goes straight back to the 1920's and 30's. She sings the music from the inside out, so to speak, which is not really surprising, considering that she is the sister of Ira and George Gershwin.

description: b-Net incomeAir-Cure Environmental said that the higher revenues in the fourth quarter and year were primarily the result of the company's acquisition in December 1992 of Ceilcote Air Pollution Control.

title: The Race Against Father Time
description: Athletes in their 40's who find it difficult to sustain the pace of their youth should pay attention to a couple of middle-aged masters who this evening will attempt to make history in the mile.

title: Most Mutual Funds Report A Sluggish Second Quarter
description: The second quarter was a period of dull returns for most mutual funds. But gold funds, funds invested in Japanese stocks and some aggressive growth funds that guessed right did very well.

title: Bonn Aide Quits Over Handling of Shootout With the Red Army
description: Interior Minister Rudolf Seiters unexpectedly resigned today over the Government's handling of a shootout last week between officers of the special anti-terrorist police and two suspected leaders of the Red Army Faction guerrilla group.

title: Adrienne Weiss, Steven Jonas
description: Adrienne Weiss, a psychiatric social worker in Amityville, L.I., and Dr. Steven Jonas, a professor of preventive medicine at the medical school of the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Philip Bentley officiated at the Port Jefferson (L.I.) Country Club.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 81,700 on the sale of land, and a write-off of investments of $ 82,613.

description: Sasha Alpert, a documentary film maker in New York, was married yesterday in Pagosa Springs, Colo., to Todd McCarthy, a film critic in Los Angeles for Variety, the show business newspaper. Judge Bert Hyde of the Archuleta County (Colo.) Court officiated at a ranch owned by the bridegroom's parents.

description: b-Included an accounting charge of $ 59.5 million from the adoption of SFAS 109, in the quarter and year. The year also included a charge of $ 14,386,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Vacationing by Car Makes Its Comeback at Full Speed
description: With gasoline cheap and plentiful, and expected to stay that way through the summer, Americans who put off trips during the economic doldrums of the last few years are hitting the road again.

description: To the Editor:

description: Arthur Leach is $11,000 poorer since he sponsored an unsuccessful contest last year to "give away" his waterfront house to the best essayist.

title: Sun Television & Appliances Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Prost Wins French Grand Prix Alain Prost won his sixth French Grand Prix yesterday as he and Damon Hill led a 1-2 finish for the Williams-Renault team. Hill started from the pole position at Magny Cours and held the lead for the first 26 laps. Prost grabbed a lead he would never relinquish during a tire change and finished less than a second ahead of Hill. It was Prost's fifth victory of the season. Prost completed the 72-lap, 190.1-mile race in 1 hour 38 minutes 35.241 seconds, averaging 115.718 miles an hour. (AP) BASKETBALL European Title to Germany Germany, behind center Christian Welp's 3-point play with 3.9 seconds left, upset Russia, 71-70, yesterday in Munich, Germany, to win its first European Championship title. Welp, a former National Basketball Association player who once starred at the University of Washington, drove for a dunk, drew a foul and made the winning free throw. Germany had never finished better than fifth at the European Championships -- in 1985, also at home. (AP) GOLF Price Hotter Than the Weather Nick Price easily turned back Greg Norman's late challenge and scored his second consecutive victory yesterday, winning the Western Open in Lemont, Ill. Price, who won last week at Hartford, led all the way, opening the tournament with a 64, closing it with a 67 and winning by five strokes at 269, 19-under-par on the Dubsdread course at Cog Hill. Price, now challenging Nick Faldo of England as the outstanding player in the world, became the first player on the American PGA tour to win three tournaments this season. Price, who grew up in Zimbabwe and now lives in Orlando, Fla., also became the first $1 million winner of the year and the first since Davis Love 3d to win consecutive tournaments. (AP) South African Captures Senior Event: Simon Hobday of South Africa shot a five-under-par 66 to win the $850,000 Kroger Senior Classic in Mason, Ohio, by one stroke, his first victory on the senior tour. The former cattle farmer and car salesman in Zambia finished the three rounds in 11-under 202, one stroke better than that of defending champion Gibby Gilbert, Bob Reith and Mike Hill. (AP) SOCCER Argentina, Argentina, Argentina Argentina won its second straight America Cup, beating Mexico, 2-1, yesterday in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on Gabriel Batistuta's second goal of the game with 16 minutes left. After not having won an America Cup since 1959, Argentina has now claimed the title in 1991 and 1993. Mexico was trying to become the first non-South American nation to win the South American championship since it began in 1917. (AP) Zambia Returns With a Victory: Zambia's revamped soccer team, wearing black armbands in memory of comrades killed in a plane crash, returned to the field yesterday and beat Morocco, 2-1, in an African Group B qualifying game for the 1994 World Cup, at Lusaka, Zambia. It was Zambia's first international game since 18 players and 12 others were killed April 28 when their plane plunged into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Libreville, Gabon. (AP)

title: Officer Killed By Man Trying To Steal Bike
description: An off-duty housing police officer who was celebrating an anniversary with his girlfriend was fatally shot yesterday morning in Brooklyn by a man who wanted the victim's motorcycle, the police said.

Had such shares been outstanding since the beginning of the quarter, net income would have been 8 cents a share for the quarter and 14 cents a share for the 9 months.

title: Japanese Stocks Flat
description: Stocks were trading virtually unchanged here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 1.20 points, or one-hundredth of a percent, at 19,620.26.

description: b-Included write-down of $ 896,930 in software development costs.

title: Review/Fashion; In Paris, All Roads Lead to a Men's-Wear Melange
description: It is strange that a country so troubled by immigration has become such a crossroads for fashion. Designers on the calendar of men's-wear shows this season hail from Japan, Italy, Belgium, England, Holland, Austria and Spain. But here, there are no borders. Arguably the most French fashion for spring '94 was served up by the Japanese designer Kenzo, who sent out three of this city's top chefs in traditional chef's jackets made from the checked Provencal linen used for dish towels. Meanwhile, the most French fashion house, Hermes, showed raw silk Nehru jackets.

title: British Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the election campaign in Japan misstated the number of seats at stake in Parliament in some editions. There are 512 seats, with 955 candidates.

title: BRITISH UTILITY TO BUY U.S. POWER GENERATION UNIT
description: National Power P.L.C., a British electric utility, said yesterday that it would enter the United States market by buying the power generation unit of the Transco Energy Company for $:105 million, or about $158 million. The unit, the Transco Energy Ventures Company, or Tevco, has interests in seven power plants in operation or construction in the southeast United States.

title: Using the Spin of Electrons To Make the Smallest Chips Yet
description: IN the global race to make ever more powerful computer chips, designers for years have been shrinking parts and wires and creating circuits that are both faster and smaller. Today the standard circuit line is about one micron wide, a hundred times thinner than a human hair, allowing millions of transistors to be crammed onto a computer chip. On the horizon, with considerable work, lie diameters of 0.1 micron or so, which might yield devices with billions of transistors. This level of complexity has long been viewed as the likely end of the conventional electronics race, since finer transistors would burn up if subjected to requisite currents.

title: NORTHWEST AND PILOTS UNION CONTINUE TALKS
description: Northwest Airlines and its pilots' union met again yesterday in an effort to reach an agreement on concessions that would enable the nation's fourth-largest carrier to avoid filing for bankruptcy protection. Such a filing could come as early as today. Although the airline had signaled that it would either announce an agreement with its pilots today or head to bankruptcy court, people familiar with the talks said a final decision might be postponed for a few days.

title: SIEMENS PLANS NEW JOB CUTS AS PART OF COST REDUCTIONS
description: Siemens A.G., the German electronics and engineering giant, announced cost-cutting measures and further job reductions as part of a program to raise its international competitiveness. "We're talking about cutting costs by 20 percent to 30 percent within two to three years," the company's chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, said. The company also said that another 4,500 of its international jobs would be cut, the same number as were dismissed this year. By the end of September, Siemens will have cut 16,000 of its 413,000 jobs worldwide.

title: Tennis Center Expansion Receives Backing of Senate
description: The proposed expansion of the tennis complex where the United States Open is played took an important step forward tonight when the Senate voted to authorize New York City to lease an adjacent piece of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens to the tournament's organizers.

title: The Hook: No Ladder A Cherry Orchard Is Easy Pickings
description: Kneeling on the ground, Norma Saddlewire picked ripe, dark-red cherries as fast as she could from branches just pruned from heavily laden sweet cherry trees.

title: Once Again, Baseball Kicks Dirt on Its Own
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates evidently were not going to let the San Diego Padres beat them at their own game. The Pirates had lost the bulk of their good players through free agency, but here were the Padres trading away their high-priced players, not waiting for them to leave as free agents.

title: By Design; Hot-Weather Carryalls
description: In summer, tote bags need to be lightweight, airy in texture and pale. When the sidewalks steam, the standard leather bag can seem as sticky as melting tar.

title: A Transformation Stays on Hold
description: The teachers here have been working without a contract for a year, and they are steaming. The school board rejected a tentative pact this spring. A Rochester newspaper columnist pretty much captured public sentiment when he wrote that the people he called "Adam Urbanski's teachers" are coming off as "a bunch of greedy whiners."

title: Police Hunt for Body of Another Victim of Killer
description: State police investigators working with more than a half-dozen dogs today combed a Rockland County intersection for the remains of yet another victim of Joel Rifkin, the man who the police said has confessed to killing 17 women in the last three years.

title: Market Place; The Effect of Japanese Politics on Business is Likely to be Slight.
description: THE president of Toray Industries, Katsunosuke Maeda, has seen the effect of Japan's political upheaval on his company's stock. When the Government was toppled last month, foreign shareholders, fearing instability, bailed out of the stock of his chemical and fiber company.

title: Clarion Direct Wins Chase Card Account
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank in New York last week named Clarion Direct, formerly the Saugatuck Marketing Group, of Westport, Conn., to handle marketing programs for Chase credit cards aimed at students. The review on the Chase Student Services account involved Clarion and four other finalists; Kirshenbaum & Bond in New York, which handled the account for the last two and a half years, was not included. Billings were not disclosed.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CHANGES COMING FOR HOMELESS SYSTEM

title: Tough Job at Western Digital
description: Over the holiday weekend, Charles A. Haggerty scrambled around the slopes of Lassen Peak, a 10,000-foot volcano in Northern California. Today, his true exertions begin, when he formally takes over as chairman and chief executive of the Western Digital Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest seller of computer disk drives.

title: Editorial Notebook: Deconstructing 'Tommy'; Watch for the Reagan Touches
description: Fortyish man: "I hear they took out the LSD, cleaning up the show for the middle class."

title: U.S. and Europe Out of Step on Japan Trade
description: Like the United States, the European Community will continue to press Japan at this week's summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial democracies to curb its $150 billion annual worldwide trade surplus, more than a fifth of which is with Western Europe.

title: Bank Courts Growth in Marriages of Convenience
description: Edward P. Junker 3d flirts with bankers for a living. A banker himself, he is chief executive for the northwestern Pennsylvania region of the PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh. Two years ago, PNC stripped Mr. Junker and seven other regional executives of much of their operational responsibilities and told them to go out and find banks for the rapidly growing company to buy.

title: No Headline
description: "If someone is destroying your life, the worst thing you can do is just sit and let it happen. You have to find humor to be able to function during months of depression like those we've suffered here. Without this we'd all end up in an asylum." -- SASHA PETROVIC of the Surrealist Hit Parade, a Sarajevo comedy troupe. [ A4:3. ]

title: TANDEM COMPUTER WARNS IT MAY DISMISS SOME WORKERS
description: Tandem Computer Inc. of Cupertino, Calif., expecting a fiscal third-quarter loss, said it might dismiss some employees this month because of a drop in orders and a weak economy. The company, which made its announcement on Friday, would not say how big a loss it would post for the quarter that ended on Wednesday. A survey of 11 analysts by Zacks Investment Research produced a mean earnings estimate of 18 cents a share. That would have been 2 cents more than in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, when Tandem earned 16 cents.

title: People
description: * Jennifer Young was named to the new position of senior vice president at FCB Entertainment, Burbank, Calif. She was previously senior vice president of marketing at Lifetime Television, New York. * Barbara Hickey was named promotion director at Redbook magazine, New York, succeeding David Chase, who left to become promotion director at Child magazine, New York. Ms. Hickey was previously an account director at Beisler & Associates, New York.

title: Police Report Sex Assault Of Girl, 14, in Bronx Pool
description: A 14-year-old girl was sexually assaulted by a teen-ager in a crowded swimming pool in the Bronx yesterday, after she was surrounded by several young men who pulled off her bathing suit, the police said.

title: Patterns
description: Watch Out, New York

title: Lawyer Says Sheik Plans Fight Against Extradition
description: A lawyer for Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the spiritual leader of suspects in the two recent terrorist cases in New York City, said yesterday that the radical Islamic cleric intended to wage a "vigorous fight" against efforts to extradite him to Egypt, which could keep him in the United States for years.

title: Minneapolis Clinics Brace for Siege: Operation Rescue's on the Way
description: Last year it was Buffalo, two years ago it was Wichita, and now it is Minneapolis's turn. Operation Rescue is coming, and many in this city have a feeling of impending siege.

title: Investors' Quandary On Pretoria
description: Many United States institutional investors are not expected to begin immediately reinvesting in South Africa, even if Nelson Mandela calls for an end to international sanctions.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Novacek and Masur Gain Karel Novacek of the Czech Republic and Australia's Wally Masur became the first seeded players to advance yesterday at the Swiss Open in Gstaad. The third-seeded Novacek overwhelmed a Spanish qualifier, Sergio Gomez-Barrio, 6-1, 6-1, at the clay-court tournament. The fourth-seeded Masur beat David Prinosil of Germany, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2). Unseeded Carl-Uwe Steeb of Germany upset the sixth-seeded Frenchman Arnaud Boetsch, 6-4, 2-6, 6-4, and will face Marc-Kevin Goellner of Germany next. Goellner beat Amos Mansdorf of Israel, 7-6 (7-4), 6-4. (AP)

title: Business Association To Change Its Name
description: The Business/Professional Advertising Association in Alexandria, Va., is planning to change its name to the Business Marketing Association, effective Sept. 1.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Roald Hoffmann; Seeking Beauty In Atoms
description: ROALD HOFFMANN Nobel laureate, professor of chemistry at Cornell University and poet -- glanced benignly at the stream of students passing his office window along a tranquil campus street. "I love chemistry," he remarked, "because it's sort of human in scale -- infinitely complex, but always tangible, always real."

title: The Moving Electron Writes, and Moves On
description: THE WORDPERFECT CORPORATION introduced version 6.0 of its popular DOS word processing program last week at the PC Expo computer trade show, releasing what will almost certainly be the last major revision of the world's most popular writing program.

title: Temporary Workers Are on the Increase In Nation's Factories
description: Temporary workers, those Americans recruited by companies like Manpower Inc. and rented to corporate clients, have become a familiar sight in many offices. Now "temps" are being used in manufacturing jobs, too, and in such numbers that the Labor Department no longer knows how many people actually work in American factories. Their growing presence means that manufacturing will probably not offer much help in solving the country's employment problem.

title: Bledsoe Expected to Sign Contract Today
description: DREW BLEDSOE, the No. 1 pick in the draft by the New England Patriots, is set to sign a contract today that will reportedly pay the Washington State quarterback $14.5 million over six years.

title: Looking at Embryos Early in Pregnancy
description: Using a miniature scope developed for use by cardiologists, researchers are perfecting a dramatic new form of prenatal diagnosis. The technique, known as embryoscopy, has been used successfully as early as six weeks, when ultrasound is still inconclusive.

title: Accounts
description: * Huffy Corp., Dayton, Ohio, to Tatham Euro RSCG, Chicago, to handle its Huffy bicycles account, previously at Lois/U.S.A., Chicago. Tatham was awarded the account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million, after a review that also included Lois/U.S.A.; Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago, and J. Walter Thompson Detroit. * Brooks Sports, Bothell, Wash., to McCann-Erickson Seattle, to handle the athletic shoe and apparel company's account, previously at Griffin Bacal, New York. Billings were estimated at $3.5 million.

title: Two Investors Testify on Dealings in B.C.C.I. Case
description: A central charge against Robert A. Altman, the Washington lawyer charged with fraud and bribery, holds that Middle Eastern investors who purchased First American Bankshares in 1981 were front men for the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, the rogue bank that was closed by banking regulators two years ago amid evidence of vast fraud -- and that Mr. Altman knew it.

title: Finding Ways to House All Vexes Leaders at Every Level
description: President Clinton signed a little-noticed executive order in May directing his Administration to come up with a "single coordinated Federal plan for breaking the cycle of homelessness." There was no ceremony that day, no soaring oratory, no Presidential photo-op at a homeless shelter.

title: Tin Is Found in Interstellar Space
description: USING the Hubble Space Telescope, researchers at the University of Chicago have found tin in interstellar space. It is the heaviest element yet seen in the gas between the stars.

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's financial markets were closed yesterday in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. An article about trading in foreign markets appears on page D6.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: TUESDAY

title: Review/Concert; At a Music Festival in a Tent, The Importance of Being Loud
description: The Waterloo Music Festival rightly prides itself on its service to American music and to neglected works in the European tradition. But Yoav Talmi's program with the Festival Orchestra this evening, after a nod to the Fourth of July with William Schuman's "American Festival Overture," fell squarely back on standard fare: Tchaikovsky's First Piano Concerto, as overworked a war horse as there is, and Saint-Saens's "Organ" Symphony.

title: President's Safety Is Often a Woman's Work
description: It is an image made famous by countless photographs and movies: The large, steely man with dark sunglasses and dark suit who talks into his watch and stares unrelentingly into the crowd, a telltale cord curling from his ear and down his collar.

title: Longstreet Hinton Is Dead at 91; Built Morgan Fund Operations
description: Longstreet Hinton, a retired banking executive credited with building the trust and pension fund operations of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company into billions of dollars, died at his home in Locust Valley, L.I., on June 24. He was 91.

title: Sarajevo Journal; This Can't Be Bosnia, There's Too Much Laughing
description: Defying the death, destruction and despair smothering spirits across this unhappy land, seven Sarajevans -- Muslims, Serbs, Croats and combinations thereof -- have made themselves a life-support system for one of the Bosnians' most precious possessions: their sharp, self-effacing wit.

title: It Still Pays To Increase Your Word Power
description: PRACTICALLY everybody is a writer at some time. Students write papers. Managers write memos and reports. Politicians, or their aides, write speeches. Kidnappers write ransom notes. And practically everybody, except the unusually skillful or terminally arrogant, can use help.

title: Elizabeth H. Waters, Choreographer, 83
description: Elizabeth Hannah Waters, a modern dancer and choreographer who performed with Hanya Holm's company in the 1930's and who founded the dance program at the University of New Mexico, died on June 5 at her home in Echo Canyon, N.M. She was 83.

title: Tennis Wasn't Wimbledon's Show
description: Sun, stalkers, swearing and Streisand: this was not a Wimbledon that stuck to traditional themes.

title: Elderly Drivers
description: The common notion that drivers become more dangerous when they reach the age of 65 has been exaggerated based on overestimation, according to a new study.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The dedication of a small community park in Camillus, N.Y., alongside the Erie Canal turned into a Hollywood-style celebration when home-grown movie stars ALEC, WILLIAM and STEPHEN BALDWIN showed up.

title: Bonn Picks 'Law and Order' Interior Minister
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl named Manfred Kanther, a conservative, as Interior Minister today as tension grew over the unexplained killing of a suspected Red Army Faction guerrilla by a special anti-terrorist police unit.

title: SPAIN APPROVES SALE OF A SUBSIDIARY TO RJR NABISCO
description: Tabacalera S.A., the Spanish state-owned tobacco monopoly and food company, said yesterday that the sale of its Royal Brands unit to the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation had been cleared by the Council of Ministers. The approval means Tabacalera will transfer its ownership of Royal Brands to a newly created company, RJR Alimentacion. RJR Nabisco and Tabacalera will own 50 percent each. The sale was concluded at a price of 34.5 billion pesetas, or about $273 million. RJR Nabisco will have the option to buy the 50 percent it does not own within a year.

title: CLINTON PUSHING FOR JAPAN PACT
description: On the eve of his most significant foray onto the international stage to date, President Clinton cast his position on trade with Japan in a softer light today, telling a convention of school teachers that he planned to take a broader set of global economic goals to Tokyo this week.

title: Gay Pride March Should Have Made a More Positive Statement
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vast Polar Ice Sheet Mysteriously Vanishes
description: FOR three years ending in 1991 the thick sheet of ice covering Antarctica's Bellingshausen Sea almost entirely vanished.

title: Bristol-Myers Shifts 3 Brand Accounts
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company reassigned three consumer product brands among three of its agencies last week. They were among five lines previously handled by DDB Needham New York, which resigned last month, severing its 24-year tie with the company.

title: Cable TV Law Trespasses on Religious Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: In 2 Elections, Voters in Mexico Demonstrate Loyalty (to Soccer)
description: They were supposed to be elections that showed the advance of democracy in Mexico, but results announced today in gubernatorial races held in two key states on Sunday, the day Mexico played in a big international soccer match, were characterized by low turnout and cynicism.

title: Scandal Taints India's Move To Economic Liberalization
description: To re-energize its two-year program of liberalizing a stolid state-controlled economy, the Indian Government threw open the door to Westerners late last month by giving approvals for several foreign investment projects, cutting interest rates, easing agricultural credits and raising the ceiling on executive pay.

title: Police Cordon Off London's Financial Core
description: In an effort to head off further attacks, police officers have sealed off most roads leading into London's financial district and are closely monitoring all traffic that enters on remaining roads.

title: Bubbles May Have Speeded Life's Origins on Earth
description: HARDLY anything matches the evanescence of bubbles, those fragile watery spheres filled with air that have but a moment before they dissolve or burst. Time enough, though, to enchant with their iridescence in sunlight, give scented caresses in a warm bath or tickle the nose over a champagne glass. Even time, perhaps, to have set in motion chemical reactions that led to the origin of life.

title: Transactions
description: WEEKEND Baseball American League

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7 64% IN JAPAN SEE COLD U.S. TIES Nearly two-thirds of Japanese polled describe Japan's relations with the U.S. as "unfriendly," with much of the discontent apparently directed at President Clinton, who is to arrive in Tokyo soon for economic talks. A1 Mr. Clinton cast his hard line on Japan trade in a softer light. A6

title: Distinct Reality Is The One To Watch
description: Belmont Park rang down the curtain on its booming holiday weekend yesterday with the 101st running of the Tremont, a race that has launched many 2-year-old colts into the big leagues of stakes racing. And the colt who was launched this time was Distinct Reality, winning his second straight race and doing it against a field of six other juveniles with breeding, credentials and great expectations.

title: INSIDE
description: Albany Accord on Smoking

title: Kamieniecki Finally Gets One for Road; Yanks 1 Out
description: The road trip, which had produced little but despair for the Yankees so far, produced delight tonight. The road, which has produced nothing but losses for Scott Kamieniecki for almost two years, finally granted him a valuable victory.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday

title: On My Mind; Clinton: Victor and Puzzle
description: The President gave the small lunch for journalists because he wanted to talk about the Tokyo economic summit before he set off.

title: Music Notes; Violinists to Play So Youngsters Can String Along
description: The directors of Music for the World, a new foundation that sponsors music-education projects, have a theory: if Government agencies give money to the public schools for music programs, then music lovers should also chip in. To that end, Music for the World is presenting Fiddlefest, a benefit at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 25 in which 10 well-known violinists are to perform to raise money for the Opus 118 Music Center, a violin-instruction program in East Harlem, and Link Up, Carnegie's education program.

title: BRITISH MILITARY CONTRACTORS REBUT REPORT OF MERGER
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. and the General Electric Company of Britain, rival military contractors, said yesterday that they had talks that focused on "fuller collaboration" in recent months, but that they had ended with no merger. In a joint statement, the companies rebutted an article in The Sunday Times of London that reported they might join forces. G.E.C. is not related to the General Electric Company in the United States.

title: On Budget's Razor Edge, Opposites March in Step
description: They seem like an odd couple, the two committee chairman who will be the central figures in the Congressional conference that will write the final version of President Clinton's budget package.

title: Woosnam's Driving License Is Suspended
description: IAN WOOSNAM, the 1991 Masters champion, was fined $3,320 and banned from driving for one year yesterday after a London court ruled that his blood alcohol level was more than double the legal limit when he crashed his car on June 24.

title: Cable TV Law Trespasses on Religious Speech; Road to Police State
description: To the Editor:

title: New Signal Found for Wiring Brain
description: DURING the development of an animal's nervous system, special chemicals act as biological traffic signals to guide the growing axons from nerve cells to their proper destinations in the brain. Now a researcher at University College London has found evidence of a new class of traffic signal, a chemical that prevents growing axons from making connections in inappropriate regions of the brain.

title: Wilander Is Back Without Vengeance
description: Mats Wilander was bouncing. Well, he was actually sort of swaying, the movement his 4-month-old daughter, Emma, fresh from a nap and cuddled in her father's lap, appreciates most.

title: Fed Expected to Hold Line on Interest Rates
description: After nine months of predicting changes in Federal Reserve monetary policy that never occurred, investors and traders in the credit markets expect today's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee will result in an agreement by Fed officials to hold short-term rates stable.

title: No Improprieties by Bailout Agency Counsel
description: To the Editor:

title: 64% OF JAPANESE SAY U.S. RELATIONS ARE 'UNFRIENDLY'
description: As President Clinton heads to Tokyo for the Group of Seven summit meeting and his first official visit to the country he describes as America's most important partner, nearly two-thirds of Japanese polled describe their country's relations with the United States as "unfriendly."

title: Treasury Set To Sell Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes only today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

title: No. 1 in Nelson's Heart
description: It is not clear who needs a championship more, Chris Webber or Don Nelson. Webber is the Michigan man who called one too many timeouts in last April's college title game, and Nelson is the Golden State Warriors coach who has yet to call a timeout in a league final because he needs to bring a team there first.

title: Sports of The Times; The Padre 'Dangling Out There'
description: HE'S the only slugger in baseball's modern era to lead the National League and the American League in home runs. With 209 homers at age 29, he's capable of hitting 400 in his career, a milestone that might provide a Hall of Fame plaque. His 191 homers over the last six seasons are the most of any big leaguer, more than Mark McGwire, Jose Canseco or Joe Carter.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge partnerships, like marriages, often crumble. Few top American partnerships have a long history of success. The record belongs to Edgar Kaplan of Manhattan and Norman Kay of Narberth, Pa., who have played together with one break for almost 40 years.

title: In Israel, Dinkins Cites Past Support and Seeks to Build Bridges
description: When Iraqi Scud missiles were falling on Israel during the war in the Persian Gulf two years ago, Mayor David N. Dinkins came to show his support, and his Israeli hosts greeted him almost immediately with a gas mask.

title: U.N. TEAM LEAVES IRAQ IN STANDOFF OVER MISSILE SITE
description: A team of United Nations weapons inspectors withdrew from Iraq empty-handed today after being refused permission to install a monitoring camera at a missile testing site.

title: Storied, Cherished Rectangular Patch of Green
description: After Princess Diana had gone off with her mother, after Pete Sampras had gone off with his girlfriend, after Steffi Graf had gone off to the doctor with a feverish feeling that kept her from attending the Wimbledon ball in a new Harvey Nichols gown, there was still something remarkable to see here.

title: On Wheels: America at 10 M.P.H.; Converging on Nowhere With Families and Fliers
description: One distinction of this corner of the world is that when you tell residents they live in the middle of nowhere, they agree with you.

title: A Puzzle for Elegant Prague: Will Gehry Fit In?
description: Plans to erect an imaginative office building designed by the iconoclastic American architect Frank Gehry have provoked sharp opposition in Prague from those who fear that idiosyncratic contemporary architecture will deface the city's celebrated beauty.

title: 28 Romanian Foundlings to Enter U.S.
description: Alex Henn marched in circles around the grass-and-concrete backyard of the Szeged Babies' and Children's Home, waving a small, tattered photo album like a flag.

title: Clarence M. Zener, 87, Physicist And Professor at Carnegie Mellon
description: Dr. Clarence Melvin Zener, a physicist whose early hypotheses on solid-state physics contributed to modern computer circuitry decades later, died on Friday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 87.

title: As the Year's Second Half Begins, the Industry Has a Full Scoreboard of Personnel Changes.
description: MAYBE it was the long Fourth of July weekend or the arrival of the second half of the year. For whatever reason, the industry's typically frantic pace of personnel changes intensified last week.

title: CALIFORNIA COURT RULING FAVORS INTEL ON CHIPS
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. says a California appeals court has refused to reconsider restoring a ruling that gave the company permanent royalty-free rights to make clones of the Intel Corporation's 386-series computer chips. The company said over the weekend that it was not surprised by the court's refusal, announced late Friday, and said it would now appeal to the California Supreme Court. Advanced Micro Devices had petitioned the California Sixth District Court of Appeals to reconsider a June 4 decision that reversed an arbitrator's ruling giving the company the right to copy the Intel chips. Intel officials could not be reached for comment.

title: Judge Is Certain the Subject Was Thomas's Harassment of Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: A former legislator wants to honor Ella T. Grasso, the first elected female governor in the United States, by placing her image on a commemorative American postage stamp.

title: Gas Tax Feared Where Commuting Takes Longest
description: The quiet splendor of Park County, rich with towering pines and white-tailed deer, seems a long way from the screech and clatter of urban life. And it is -- especially when the alarm clock rings before sunrise, and workers begin the long journey to jobs in Denver.

title: Woman, 74, Is Beaten and Locked in Closet
description: A 74-year-old woman was found badly beaten and locked in the closet of her apartment in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Bigotry Is What's Incompatible
description: President Clinton will soon be faced again with the issue that has caused him more grief than any other: whether homosexuals can serve openly in the military.

title: Man Kills His Mother, Then Takes Own Life
description: A Washington Heights man who his neighbors said was distraught over the terminal cancer that had left his 89-year-old mother bedridden, fatally shot her in the head and then killed himself, the police said.

title: Miniature Scope Gives The Earliest Pictures Of a Developing Embryo
description: THE human embryo was just six weeks old, about half an inch long and shaped like a comma, its arms and legs still blunt buds. On ultrasound, an embryo as early as this one would be just a blur. But now, using an experimental technique, Dr. Ruben Quintero, an obstetrician at Wayne State University's Hutzel Hospital, inserted a minute viewing scope into the woman's abdomen, through a needle the diameter of one used to draw blood. With this device, Dr. Quintero examined the embryo as closely as if he had opened the woman's womb.

title: The Talk of Hollywood; Getting Ready for a Breakthrough, Two Directors Savor the Summer
description: The summer just started in the Real World, but in this town it's just about over. Summer movies, which generate 40 percent of studios' annual revenues, are appearing (and disappearing) at the local cineplex with alarming frequency.

title: 2 Caucasus Regions Sinking Deeper Into Civil War
description: Heavy shelling from Armenian forces in central Azerbaijan set off a wave of refugees and augured another Armenian advance into Azerbaijan as warfare spiraled across the Caucasus.

title: Fears Rise Over Wastes Burned in Cement Kilns
description: From industrial plants across the Great Lakes region, tanker trucks and railroad cars haul thousands of gallons of hazardous wastes to this city on Lake Huron, emptying their cargo at the nation's largest cement-making factory where it is burned as fuel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Legislator Seeks Pressure on Indians
description: An Ohio lawmaker plans to introduce legislation to block the use of public money for the Cleveland Indians' new Gateway Stadium if the team continues to use Chief Wahoo as its symbol.

title: Ships Are Culprits As Foreign Species Invade Ecosystems
description: Kudzu, the galloping green vine imported from Japan in the late 1800's, has taken over much of the American South. The zebra mussel, which arrived from Europe in the late 1980's, is on the march in the lakes and rivers of the eastern United States, clogging intake pipes and threatening to disrupt water distribution. In Australia, a tropical toad imported from America in 1935 to control sugar-cane beetles is eating everything but the beetles and has become a plague on the land.

title: America, a Great Place to Visit
description: The largest invasion of foreigners in American history is unfolding across the United States, welcomed almost everywhere. The invaders are tourists, a record 46.5 million of whom are expected this year, and they should spend about $76.9 billion while here -- another record.

title: Chess
description: The openings that begin with queenside development have a reputation for being generally more solid and less given to startling tactical play than those that feature kingside development, where the black king can well become an early target. But this is an observation best forgotten in the hurly-burly of a game's later action.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was a bizarre scene, certain to last for a long time in the annals of New York City folklore: hundreds of onlookers, reporters and cameramen crowded outside the Abu Bakr mosque on Foster Avenue on Friday, angling to find out when Sheik OMAR ABDEL RAHMAN, the blind Egyptian cleric who is accused of inspiring his followers to violence, would surrender to authorities from the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Legislators and Cuomo Agree on New Smoking Restrictions
description: Negotiators for the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo reached agreement today on a bill that would expand restrictions on smoking by prohibiting smoking in schools and limiting it in workplace lounges and cafeterias to separate, enclosed rooms.

title: Blimp Pilot Tried to Avoid Crash in City
description: The co-pilot of the blimp that crashed onto a Manhattan apartment building Sunday described the frantic final minutes of the flight yesterday, saying the craft's problems appeared suddenly, making the airship "uncontrollable" and leaving its pilot desperately trying to steer away from the city's skyline.

title: For Libyan Athletes, an Appeal to Clinton
description: World University Games officials appealed directly to PRESIDENT CLINTON yesterday to allow 79 student athletes from Libya to compete in the multisport event, which begins Thursday in Buffalo.

title: In Canada, Elderly Praise Their Health Care
description: Charlotte M. Cohan, her bones weakened by disease, curled up in a chair at the Rotary-Laughlin Center with a cup of tea and some carrot cake.

title: New Park's Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; The Dalai Lama as Boy, Man, Leader
description: Despite its overly reverent tone, "Compassion in Exile" is an engaging portrait of Tenzin Gyatso, the Dalai Lama of Tibet, who has been in exile in India since 1959, when he fled Chinese repression.

title: Like Ahab, a Venturer Pursues Destiny at Sea
description: SOMEWHERE out in Long Island Sound, exactly 11.5 miles from Thomas C. Graver's office window overlooking the New London city pier, there is an invisible line marking the end of state authority and the beginning of international waters. This is Mr. Graver's Moby Dick, his Holy Grail and his Comstock Lode all in one.

title: Q&A
description: Rice and Birds

title: Books of The Times; One Network's Trip on the Campaign Trail
description: Strange Bedfellows How Television and the Presidential Candidates Changed American Politics, 1992. By Tom Rosenstiel 368 pages. Hyperion. $24.95

title: A Court for International Outlaws
description: How to deal with a person like Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the Somali warlord who orders attacks on United Nations peacekeepers and uses women and children as shields for the killers?

title: Japan's Big Chance -- and Clinton's
description: While President Clinton is here for the economic summit meeting, which begins tomorrow, he could benefit America, Japan and the rest of the world by looking beyond the issues he has come to discuss with lackluster heads of government and by grasping an ideal opportunity to begin to create a genuine policy toward Japan.

title: A Symbol of Racial Conflict Moves Nearer Removal Again
description: After two emotional public hearings, this city has moved a step closer to again banishing a gray granite obelisk that has come to symbolize white supremacy.

title: Still Radical After All These Years; At 74, William Kunstler Defends Clients Most Lawyers Avoid
description: William Moses Kunstler stood last week in one of his favorite places, the well of a courtroom. Before business began he chatted amicably with the judge, the court clerk, the stenographer, the security guards, the press. Of everything and everyone around him that Brooklyn morning, only the words behind the bench, from Aristotle, were uncongenial.

title: Floods Force Corps of Engineers Into Balancing Act on Mississippi
description: As the rain fell again today, S. K. Nanda, the chief hydrologist at the Army Corps of Engineers district office here, punched the keyboards at a bank of computers and choreographed a watery balancing act involving three giant Iowa reservoirs along two Mississippi tributaries that weeks ago had filled to capacity.

title: Richard Tatlow 3d, 87, Leader in Engineering
description: Richard Henry Tatlow 3d, a New York engineer and leader in his profession, died on Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 87.

title: For Schourek, Opportunity. For Padres, Knocks.
description: Pete Schourek was summoned from Dallas Green's overstuffed doghouse for one evening and given the ball for an emergency start against the San Diego Padres at Shea Stadium last night.

title: All Rise! Tyson 'Appeals Court' Is in Session
description: Our judicial system has it all wrong. All those sober courtrooms with their solemn protocol are too archaic for gossipy, fin de siecle America, where we can try people if we like on TV without abiding by the rules of evidence. We need squabbling experts, a divided audience, chatty jurors and an aggressive talk show host to make the courtroom experience entertaining and interactive.

title: Observer; Haiti In the Sun
description: The news was so thin over the weekend that Haiti made the front pages in several newspapers. You can tell an editor has been looking into a bare pantry when he comes back with a Caribbean story. When Haiti is the juiciest Caribbean story going it feels as if the end of history may be more than a book by Francis Fukuyama.

title: Miscellany
description: * North American Philips Consumer Electronics, Knoxville, Tenn., will run advertisements in the October-November and December-January issues of Out magazine, New York. The ads, by Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., New York, are believed to be the first for a consumer electronics marketer in a publication aimed at gay and lesbian readers.

title: Review/Concert; The Sounds Of America, In the Park
description: What happened to Thomas Jefferson? This year is the 250th anniversary of his birth, and despite celebrations here and there, he seems elusive. America has grown remote from the semi-anarchistic collective of self-ruling republics that Jefferson once celebrated.

title: Equity Offerings Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Russell Pendergast, 57, of Rockefeller Group, Dies
description: Russell A. Pendergast, a senior executive of the Rockefeller Group in New York for the last 10 years, died on Friday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 57 years old.

title: Commodity Rise Wilts Treasuries
description: A sharp rise in commodity prices yesterday took some steam out of the Treasury bond market, where prices fell by about a quarter of a point.

title: Review/Television; The Liberal Arts: No Match for Career Training
description: If the image of liberal education is not enhanced by the four half-hour conversations that begin tonight on "Firing Line," William F. Buckley Jr. has nobody to blame but himself and his guests.

title: Accord in Albany On Clean-Air Plan
description: Faced with the threat of losing $1 billion in Federal transporation money, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders agreed on a plan intended to reduce air pollution in New York City and its suburbs sharply by 1996.

title: David Paley, a Retired Editor, Dies at 90
description: David Paley, a retired senior editor of Parade magazine and associate arts editor at The New York Herald Tribune, died on Sunday at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale. He was 90 and a resident of Manhattan before moving to Riverdale in the Bronx several months ago.

title: Apple Cutting Its Work Force 16% Worldwide
description: Under deepening pressure from its personal computer rivals, Apple Computer Inc. confirmed today that it would restructure its operations and slice its work force by 16 percent, or about 2,500 employees worldwide.

title: Divided on Inflation; Few Signs of Price Pressures, but Anxiety Among Economists Refuses to Go Away
description: Blue-chip corporations from Sears to I.B.M. are sending out pink slips by the sackful, leaving millions of qualified workers sifting the want ads for employment. Whole industries, from airlines to cigarettes to computers, are hemorrhaging cash in a struggle to attract price-conscious consumers. Why, then, are economists worried about inflation?

title: S.E.C. Said to Seek Large Prudential Fine
description: Federal regulators are seeking at least $350 million in fines and penalties from Prudential Securities to settle charges of securities law violations stemming from the firm's practices in selling limited partnerships during the 1980's, people with knowledge of the talks said.

title: Keeping the Texture, but Not the Fat, in Homemade Ice Cream
description: IN the pre-air-conditioner South where I grew up, the surest way to take the sizzle out of summer was to haul the freezer down from the pantry shelf and crank out a big batch of ice cream. Peach. Strawberry. Chocolate. We drew straws to see who would pick the flavor of the moment.

title: Gold Rush of '93
description: Gold has been growing popular lately. Some analysts point to rising commodity futures as the cause, while others argue the rise reflects uncertainty over stocks and bonds. But these times may seem less uncertain when one considers where gold was 10 years ago, despite yesterday's post-Persian Gulf war high of $391.65 an ounce (spot price).

title: Tab Products reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an accounting loss of $ 811,000 from FAS 106 and FAS 109, changes in accounting for post-retirement benefits and income taxes respectively.Year-ago results included a pretax charge of $ 1.5 million related to the sale of the company's Laser-Optic Filing Systems Division.

title: It's 8 P.M. Where Are Your Parents?
description: Parents, pediatricians and legislators ask what can be done to reduce the brutality, cruelty and carnage children see on television.

title: Sampras to Play McEnroe
description: The Wimbledon champion, PETE SAMPRAS, will play JOHN McENROE on July 18 in a special benefit exhibition preceding the Pathmark Tennis Classic in Mahwah, N.J.

title: Casino Resource Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 680,546, or 41 cents a share, from discontinued operations.Casino Resource Corp. said the National Association of Securities Dealers has approved its notice of a 1-for-2 reverse stock split to shareholders of record June 25.

title: Byrd Goes Electronic, Lands Job With CBS
description: The remarkable recovery of Dennis Byrd from partial paralysis yesterday earned the former Jets defensive end a new job as a pro football analyst for CBS Sports.

title: The Pop Life
description: Listening In on a Big Party

title: Haiti: The Secret of Success
description: Getting the Haitian military to agree to a timetable for returning President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power is a considerable achievement. The United Nations mediator, Dante Caputo, and the Clinton Administration deserve much credit.

title: Sheik Hospitalized At Federal Prison
description: Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the Islamic fundamentalist whose followers have been linked to two bombing conspiracies in New York City, was hospitalized with "higher than average" blood-sugar levels at the Federal prison where he has been held since Friday.

title: New Doubts About 'Ivan the Terrible'
description: For the first time in years of legal battling, a Federal judge finds "substantial doubt" that John Demjanjuk, who is under a death sentence in Israel, was the notorious "Ivan the Terrible" of the Treblinka death camp where nearly a million Jews were gassed to death.

title: United Stationers reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company attributed much of the third quarter sales increase to its June 1992 acquisition of Stationers Distributing Co.

title: Centennial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRONICLE
description: JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. has resigned as an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, it was announced yesterday. BARBARA THOMPSON, director of public information for the district attorney's office, said that no date for his departure had been set but that "we believe it will be in the next couple of weeks -- he will be wrapping up his cases until then."

title: A Menacing Ritual Is Called Common in New York Pools
description: They call it "the whirlpool," and pool employees and regular swimmers say it has become a common, if malevolent, ritual of these sweltering summer days at some of New York City's municipal pools.

title: John Robert Castro; C.I.A. Agent, 71
description: John Robert Castro, an electronic communications specialist and retired agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, died on Sunday at the HCA Reston Hospital in Reston, Va. He was 71 and lived in Reston.

title: Overdue Fiscal Fix for New York City
description: When the Standard & Poor's bond-rating agency told New York City officials the new city budget was too dependent on one-time savings and wishful thinking, it was hardly news. Fiscal analysts had been warning all year that balancing the fiscal 1994 budget with gimmickry would make trouble for 1995 and the years beyond. But when the warning comes from analysts who rate city bonds, City Hall listens -- and well it should.

title: Talks Resume in Strike Against Garbage Haulers
description: Representatives of striking sanitation workers and private trash hauling companies resumed talks today trying to end a six-day walkout.

title:
Market Place;
Streamlined German chemical companies could make gains.
description: GERMAN share prices have risen mildly this year, and this is an accomplishment considering that the country is in its worst recession since World War II. While the downturn is far from over, some stock market experts are seeing what may be the first glimmers of recovery, particularly in the chemical sector.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL TO SELL ITS JOHNSTOWN, PA., MILLS
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the idled Gautier rolling mills in Johnstown, Pa., to J-Pitt Steel Inc. of Pittsburgh. Terms were not disclosed. The mills were part of the former bar; rod and wire division of the company, which is based in Bethlehem, Pa. Before closing in September 1992, the Gautier mills employed 350 workers and produced rolled steel sections used for truck wheel rims, jail bars, bridge decking and farm tractor frames.

title: Detection Systems Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain from adoption of FASB 109 of $ 131,000, or 5 cents a share.Latest quarter's share earnings results was less than 1 cent a share.

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Corporate Paperwork Gets Sound and Action
description: The technology that has provided beeps and boings for thousands of personal computer games and has brought animation to children's educational software is beginning to invade the desktops of Corporate America.

title: Staff Builders (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the White House's report on the dismissal of seven employees of its travel office misattributed a statement about the investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Bureau officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said no criminal wrongdoing had been uncovered so far. Officially, the agency has not commented on the progress of the inquiry.

title: Tipper Gore Triumphs in a Personal Campaign
description: Tipper Gore holds a distinction few can claim: she lost weight during a political campaign. If you want to know how contrary to the norm that is, just ask Bill Clinton. Or his staff. Or any reporter who covers political campaigns.

title: A Mother's Third Son, Her Last Child, Dies as Did His Brothers, in a Shooting
description: Frances Davis lost her last son yesterday. He was gunned down on the same Brooklyn street where his two older brothers had been killed.

title: Amrep Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss and included an after-tax write-off of $ 2,744,000 to reduce the carrying value of certain real estate inventory and rental projects.

title: Prep Schools and Minorities: A Place at the Table
description: When Elizabeth Fernandez arrived at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., three years ago, she found some things she had never encountered -- things like cauliflower, chicken Kiev and volleyball.

title: Agency Plots Future After Account Loss
description: Martin, Davis, Omon & Partners, which opened as Omon New York Ltd. in 1989, is pondering its future after the loss of its large Toyota corporate advertising account.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 CLINTON PRESSES TRADE AND TIES President Clinton, at the start of the summit for leading industrialized nations, sought trade concessions from Japan, but then began building relationships with those trying to overthrow the ruling party. A1 Trade negotiators say they are getting closer to an agreement. A9

title: Critic's Notebook; About the New Labels On TV Violence: Meanings and Motives
description: Appropriately, the announcement last week that the nation's four broadcast networks would henceforth stick parental warnings on programs they deem excessively violent was delivered in the form of a television special. An hourlong news conference, carried by CNN, featured Thomas Murphy, who heads Capital Cities/ ABC; Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group; Warren Littlefield, the president of NBC Entertainment, and George Vrandenburg, the executive vice president of Fox Broadcasting. Together for the first time!

title: France Sees No Recovery
description: There is no sign that the recession France has been mired in since the end of last year is ending, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Business Day on Monday showing Louis Rossetto, editor and publisher of Wired magazine, carried an incorrect credit. The photographer was Diana Cheren.

title: Part of Toy Account Is Placed in Review
description: Tyco Toys said yesterday that it had placed a portion of its estimated $60 million account, now at Bozell New York, in review, by seeking a shop to handle creative assignments and media planning for some new and current products.

title: Mets Leave Johnson Feeling Uneasy
description: Howard Johnson never imagined his Mets' career reaching this point. His manager, Dallas Green, is publicly questioning his ability and his future value to this club or any other. There is no one in management he feels comfortable approaching about his current status, or his future. So many of the faces on the field are strangers, with several of his friends and former teammates having departed Shea Stadium via free agency or trades.

title: Continental Air Flights
description: Continental Airlines will begin flying from Houston to Veracruz, Mexico, on July 14 as it increases service to some Latin American destinations. The airline said today that it planned to fly four times a week between the two destinations. Veracruz becomes Continental's 10th Mexican destination. In late June the company renewed its El Paso-Mexico City route.

title: Campus Journal; A College Declared Dead Is Now Quite Clearly Not
description: When the campus bell rang 149 times in May 1974, the 300-student Cazenovia College in this lakeside hamlet near Syracuse was pronounced dead. The ringing tolled the years of existence for the two-year women's college.

title: High Court Nominee Defends Judges' Use of Broad Powers
description: Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg, President Clinton's nominee to the Supreme Court, says disputes over "judicial activism" arise when the courts are forced to resolve issues that lawmakers are too timid to handle.

title: METROPOLITAN GOLF REPORT
description: Qualifying for Puerto Rico

title: Decline in Stocks Continues As Dow Moves Down 34.04
description: After idling all morning, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped into gear -- reverse -- and resumed the trip it began Friday, losing 34.04 points to finish trading yesterday at 3,449.93. Across the board, leading market indicators fell.

title: American's Drop in Traffic Sends Airline Stocks Lower
description: Stocks of several major airlines fell yesterday, apparently on news that American Airlines' traffic dropped 3 percent in June from the 8.9 billion revenue passenger miles flown a year earlier.

title: In Times Square, Art Conquers Kung Fu
description: "Hey you," purrs the voice that issues from a pair of giant red lips projected onto a screen inside the entrance to the old Rialto Theater in Times Square. "Hey you, want to buy a place in heaven?"

title: Northwest And Pilots In Accord
description: Northwest Airlines and its pilots' union said yesterday that they had agreed to grant each other broad and deep concessions as part of an effort to keep the carrier from filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: Pacific Telesis Dispute
description: Consumer groups and the California Public Utilities Commission staff will seek up to $500 million from the Pacific Telesis Group before supporting its plan to spin off its wireless division into a separate company, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: China in Pact to Help Iran Build A-Plant
description: Iran and China signed an agreement Sunday to build a nuclear power plant near Teheran, Etellat newspaper reported today.

title: ITEMS ON TITANIC BROUGHT TO U.S.
description: Deep-sea salvors sailed into Norfolk, Va., last week with about 800 artifacts newly raised from the sunken hulk of the Titanic, prompting accusations that they are violating the spirit of Federal legislation that sought to make the shipwreck a memorial to the more than 1,500 victims of the sinking.

title: Why Just Drive, When You Can Fax, Dial, Shave, Eat and Brush?
description: In the 11 years he has spent patroling California's freeways, Officer John Marinez of the California Highway Patrol has seen more than his share of fender benders and high-speed chases. But the day he saw a driver use her left hand to hold a bowl and her right hand to scoop cereal into her mouth he thought his eyes were playing tricks on him.

title: Scott's Hospitality reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Included losses of $ 979,000 from discontinued operations and $ 30,274,000 from the sale of discontinued operations.c-Included income of $ 1,201,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $ 1,334,000 for the sale of discontinued operations.d-Included a net gain of $ 13,061,000, or 22 cents a share, on dispositions and restructuring.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: At $14.5 Million, Bledsoe Is a Patriot
description: Drew Bledsoe interrupted his own real-life version of Route 66, abandoning a Ford Surburban full of buddies in Sioux Falls, S.D., to fly to Boston for a business appointment that made him one of the wealthiest quarterbacks in the National Football League.

title: U.N. Said to Reject Hearing on Iraqi Compliance
description: The United Nations has rejected an Iraqi request to present evidence that it is complying with the terms of the agreement that ended the Persian Gulf war, the Iraqi delegate to the United Nations said today.

title: Iowa Women's Coach Signs
description: Iowa women's basketball coach, VIVIAN STRINGER, who guided the Hawkeyes to their first Final Four appearance this year, has signed a new five-year contract.

title: Gooden's Bases-Loaded Triple Spearheads Mets' Hit Parade
description: Doc Gooden enjoys throwing strikes and setting down batters, and he loves shutouts and complete games and all of that stuff.

title: Albany Lawmakers Give Up On Hospital Finance Revision
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the state's legislative leaders conceded defeat tonight in their efforts to forge an agreement on revamping the state's hospital financing system, meaning the Legislature will have to return to Albany in the fall to deal with the issue.

title: Very Few Standouts So Far
description: When the midterm report cards are issued in baseball during the break for the All-Star Game next week, you can figure that the Philadelphia Phillies and San Francisco Giants will be leading the class in the National League, and a half-dozen teams will be close in the American. The Yankees should go home with a high grade (A-) and the Mets with a low grade (F).

title: ConAgra Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to May 30
description: b-After a loss from an accounting adjustment of $ 121,200,000.Year-ago quarter and fiscal year results were for 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Genital Herpes Drug Found Safe for Daily Use
description: THE drug commonly used to treat outbreaks of genital herpes infections can safely be used on a daily basis for years to prevent recurrences of this distressing viral disease, according to a five-year study published recently in Archives of Dermatology.

title: Pros in the Caddy Shack: Country Club Recession; An Engineer Learns to Carry Golf Clubs
description: Until Pentagon budget cuts crippled production of Trident submarines, Tom Kingsley worked as a mechanical engineer at the Groton Naval Base in Connecticut, teaching officers how to operate the nuclear reactors that power the subs. Two years ago his employer, General Dynamics, dismissed him.

title: Better Living (Perhaps) Through Palm Readings
description: "PSYCHIC Readings by Gena," said the flier handed out by the dark-haired boy. "Do you have problems through law, health, marriage and success? Come, see this gifted lady and let her solve your problems today."

title: Nets and Reed Show Off Their Modest Draft Prizes
description: There were no fans, no fanfare, not even a drumroll as the Nets introduced their top two draft picks to the news media today at a hotel across the road from their offices at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was just as well, for neither Rex Walters nor John Best is expected to make that much of an impact next season.

title: Pollution-Curbing Plan Is Set in Albany
description: Faced with the threat of losing $1 billion in Federal transportation funds, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders agreed today on a plan intended to reduce air pollution in New York City and its suburbs sharply by 1996.

title: Nigeria's Ruler a Puzzle to His People
description: Compared to the palatial style that seems to be the vogue among African rulers these days, the newly built personal residence here of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida is remarkably modest. It is a spartan, ranch-style house devoid of the grandiose touches some expect of the leader of black-ruled Africa's wealthiest and most populous country.

title: Canada's Leader Enters Global Arena
