description: b-Included a gain of $ 300,000, or 1 cent a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Chris Steinbrunner, 59, an Expert On Mystery Films and TV Shows
description: Chris Steinbrunner, an authority on mystery films and mystery shows on radio and television, died on Wednesday night at his home in the Middle Village section of Queens. He was 59.

title: Crushed Between Two Worlds
description: During the American attack on Baghdad on June 26, Leyla al-Attar, a celebrated Iraqi painter, and her husband were killed by a stray rocket that struck their temporary residence. Their previous home had been demolished in the American bombing of Jan. 17, 1991, and was being rebuilt.

title: Agassi Has Streisand But Loses Bollettieri
description: Since bizarre behavior and Zen moments seem to be his touchstones, it doesn't come as a great surprise that Andre Agassi, in a polar twist on the usual severance methods for coach-player associations, was fired yesterday by his longtime mentor, Nick Bollettieri.

title: A Swastika in Vermont
description: On the Fourth of July, just before 10 A.M., a swastika was painted on a storefront on Main Street here in my town. Tom Bailey, a house painter, said two guys he had met in a bar happened by while he was working and paid him $30 to do the deed. "It didn't really bother me to put it up there," he said later. That afternoon, a man called The Associated Press and claimed responsibility in the name of the unknown Ethan Allen Coalition.

title: Clinton and Yeltsin to Meet in Moscow
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia announced today that they will meet in Moscow for their second formal summit conference, probably later this year.

title: Bosnia Refuses 3-Way Partition And Appeals to U.S. for Support
description: The Muslim-led Bosnian Government announced today that it would reject a Serbian and Croatian proposal to end the 15-month-old war in this former Yugoslav republic by dividing it into three ethnic states.

description: In percent

title: Esiason Predicts Easy Transition to Jets
description: Of all the veteran quarterbacks who have switched teams this offseason, Jets quarterback Boomer Esiason thinks he might be in the best position to hit the ground running. The reason is simple: his familiarity with the system that New York Coach Bruce Coslet employs.

description: Orchestrate an uplifting team meeting before the game, send the reliable Jimmy Key to the mound, cross your fingers and pray for a homer by Danny Tartabull.

description: b-Net income and the 6 months is after a gain of $ 9,836,000, or $ 1.50 a share.

title: Youths With Potential Honor a Helping Hand
description: IT was the year that both the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy were slain, the musical "Hair" enthralled Broadway and defiance marked attitudes. It was also the year that 14 male New Yorkers gathered to consider being young, gifted, black and Catholic in a time of turmoil.

title: Sports of The Times; Same Game, But With New Players
description: AS major league baseball prepares to celebrate All-Star week, the nation's pastime continues to be haunted by the legacy of segregation, which it formally brought to an end in 1946 with the signing of Jackie Robinson.

title: Haskell Cohn, Lawyer, 91
description: Haskell Cohn, a past president of the Boston Bar Association and a founder of the Boston law firm Mintz, Levin, Cohn, Ferris, Glovsky & Popeo, died on Sunday at his home in Westwood, Mass. He was 91.

title: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $ 17,350,000 for a change in the method of accouting for postretirement benefits.Year-ago figures are restated to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split July 17, 1992.

title: Dutoit Gets Post in Tokyo
description: Charles Dutoit, the music director of the Orchestre Symphonique de Montreal, will take on the post of principal conductor of the NHK Orchestra in Tokyo, beginning in 1996. His contract calls for him to spend eight weeks each season with the Japanese orchestra. Mr. Dutoit is also the music director of the Orchestre National de France and the artistic director and principal conductor of the Mann Music Center in Philadelphia and the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., the two summer residencies of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: Bridge
description: All tournament players know about lead-directing doubles, like the Lightner double in slam situations. Many know about lead-directing bids, which can occur in a number of competitive situations. But what seems to be an entirely new lead-directing action was invented on the diagramed deal during the international playoffs in Memphis in June, which determined the American representation in the 1993 world championships.

title: No Headline
description: We're in a weather system that doesn't want to change. -- CHRISTA TUCKER, a National Weather Service meteorologist. [ 1:6. ]

title: Cotton and Soybeans Soar As Unusual Weather Holds
description: Soybean and cotton prices surged yesterday in reaction to the abnormal weather across the country.

title: Gay Cause Is the Same as Black Cause; Prominent Supporters
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE WICKED WEATHER: HEAT'S GRIP BEGINS TO STRANGLE

title: Review/Music; From Half a World Away, Tuva's Unearthly Songs
description: On a plateau in southern Siberia, at the border of Mongolia and Russia, lies Tuva, a region surrounded by mountains and largely populated by nomadic herdsmen. Tuvan music is filled with natural sounds: the twitter of birds, the clip-clopping of horses, the lowing of livestock, the hiss of wind through a mountain pass. Six musicians from Tuva, which is now an autonomous part of Russia, performed on Thursday night at the World Financial Center; Ted Levin, an ethnomusicologist, provided commentary between songs.

title: Hofstra Law Professor Is Found Fatally Beaten in Queens Home
description: A Hofstra University law professor who was a former Federal prosecutor was found bludgeoned to death yesterday in a bathroom of his house in Queens, the police said.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Democrats Report Another Burglary
description: The Democrats suggested dirty tricks. The Republicans dismissed it as a third-rate burglary.

title: Searching for a Clean, Well-Air-Conditioned Place
description: The room was cool, one of the few places on campus that was air-conditioned. Erik Sullivan, a volleyball player from San Diego, lay in a corner on a bare mattress. He opened his eyes occasionally to see what was on MTV on a big-screen television set, but mostly he just lay there, relaxing in the cool air.

title: Boddie-Noell Restaurant Properties Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Horizon Healthcare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago share earnings included a one-time tax credit of 1 cent a share.

title: Review/Film; Bon Vivant Still Lives. Or Is It Dies?
description: Easily the funniest performance in the frantic sequel to the 1989 hit comedy "Weekend at Bernie's" is Terry Kiser's droll impersonation of a dead bon vivant who becomes a lurching, limbo-dancing zombie whenever calypso music is in the vicinity.

title: From Bad to Worse in Albany
description: Conventional wisdom holds that legislatures get their most difficult work done in years when they're free from the tyranny of the ballot box. But the unimpressive New York State Legislature got even less done in this non-election year than usual.

title: STAKE IN 14 HOTELS IS SOLD TO PAY DOWN BANK DEBT
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has sold its stake in 14 hotels to Davidson Hotel Partners L.P. of Memphis as part of the liquidation of real estate assets to pay down billions of dollars in bank debt. Davidson Hotel Partners paid Westinghouse $90 million to $100 million for the properties, said Sherri Harrell, vice president of marketing for the Davidson Hotel Company, a partner in a joint venture. The other partners include Starwood Capital Partners of Chicago and Blackstone Capital Partners of New York.

title: Pope, Evans & Robbins reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Steel of West Virginia reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of approximately 6 cents a share from lost production due to severe electrical storms in the last week of June.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Q & A column of the "Your Money" pages on July 3, about reporting profits on convertible bonds, misstated the effective date of a change in how their profits are taxed. For bonds issued after July 18, 1984, and purchased at a market discount, the gains are taxed as ordinary income, not capital gains, to the extent of the discount.

title: Russian Parliament Votes a Claim to Ukrainian Port of Sevastopol
description: The Russian Parliament passed a resolution today declaring the Crimean port city of Sevastopol, which is within Ukraine, to be a Russian city.

title: T. Harris Jackson, Editor, 74
description: T. Harris Jackson, a retired Associated Press editor who shaped the news agency's foreign report for 33 years, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 74 and lived in Ocean Bay Park on Fire Island, L.I.

title: Short-Term Investing
description: What's the best way to invest money that might be needed in three to five years? Most experts say the stock market is too risky, except in small doses, so they recommend conservative stock or bond funds.

description: To the Editor:

Observer; Still, Papa Was Right
description: People who believe in U.F.O.'s demonstrated at the White House the other day demanding that the Government come clean. Their placards said the Government knew U.F.O.'s "are real," and they want it to quit pretending they're not and tell what it knows about these visitors from out yonder.

title: President Clinton on Summit Conference: 'We Have Made a Serious Start'
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference yesterday in Tokyo after the 19th summit meeting by the Group of Seven industrial nations, as recorded by the Associated Press: STATEMENT

title: John Murray Reynolds, Shipping Executive, 92
description: John Murray Reynolds, a retired New York shipping executive, died on Tuesday at his retirement home in Deerfield Beach, Fla. He was 92.

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The G.O.P. Pioneers a New Loophole
description: The Republican National Committee has chosen a strange way to appeal to voters attracted by Ross Perot and his flaying of Washington influence-peddling. It is creating a sly new way for corporations, labor unions and wealthy individuals to make unlimited, undisclosed political contributions for party purposes.

title: Hunt to Enter Another Hall
description: Hall of Fame inductions aren't exactly new to LAMAR HUNT. The Texas businessman was enshrined in the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1972 for helping to found the American Football League. A decade later, the National Soccer Hall of Fame tapped him for helping to establish the North American Soccer League. Today, Hunt will take his place in the International Tennis Hall of Fame as founder of World Championship Tennis in Newport, R.I.

title: Battle Likely Over Nominee fro Surgeon General
description: Another battle appears to be brewing over a top nominee of President Clinton.

title: Megawatts Falter, and Blackouts Begin
description: In an exceptionally chilly room atop a major electric substation on Manhattan's West Side, Charles Weliky is watching you turn on your air-conditioner.

title: BAXTER INTERNATIONAL SEES OPERATING DROP OF 5%
description: Hurt by increased manufacturing expenses and a stronger dollar, Baxter International Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter operating income might be as much as 5 percent below results a year ago. Shares of the world's largest hospital-supply company fell $1.625, to $26.875, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday. Baxter expects to report a 5 to 10 percent second-quarter sales increase and an increase in net of 8 percent to 12 percent from a year earlier, said a company spokesman, Geoffrey Fenton. The company said manufacturing costs had increased in the second quarter as it adjusted factory output to reduce inventories and meet increased demand.

title: The Airwaves, Up for Grabs
description: If confirmed, will Reed Hundt, President Clinton's nominee to head the Federal Communications Commission, seize an opportunity to stimulate the growth of small business in the field of personal communications systems and thus benefit consumers?

title: Signing Day in Green Bay
description: The Green Bay Packers signed first-round draft pick GEORGE TEAGUE yesterday, along with a number of other draft picks and free-agent running back ALAN PINKETT.

title: Beliefs
description: In late February 1992, Bishop Gerard O'Keefe, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Davenport, Iowa, opened a letter marked "Personal and Confidential." It came from Jeffrey R. Anderson, a Minnesota lawyer with a national reputation for suing what he recently called "the rats" in the church's basement -- priests accused of sexually abusing minors.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Longstreet Hinton, a former banker who died on June 24, misstated the year of his retirement. It was 1967, not 1976.

title: Weather, Piazza, Managers Hot. Mets Not.
description: The Mike Piazza story isn't a bad one. It begins modestly, but gains quickly in plot and momentum.

title: Crew Keeps Close Watch On Hydrants
description: The chatter kept coming over the radio in Larry Sypowicz's truck.

title: DeOssie and Guyton Signed by Giants
description: The Giants, with the start of training camp and a new era just over a week away, signed two veterans yesterday -- linebacker Steve DeOssie and safety Myron Guyton.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Pep Rally for Jobs; Clinton Plan for Unemployment Conference Is Aimed at Stirring Up Public Support
description: President Clinton's international conference on job creation, announced on the eve of the economic summit meeting in Tokyo, is shaping up as part educational seminar, part public relations for the White House and part pep rally to get people and governments to support new and perhaps expensive strategies to fight unemployment.

title: CHRONICLE
description: "There was a reason why people had sewing circles," EMILY LLOYD, the New York City Sanitation Commissioner, said the other day. "There is something wonderfully soothing about sewing and talking."

title: Court Names Trustee for Concrete Company
description: A court trustee has been appointed to oversee a bankrupt concrete company that was created by New York City and sustained by more than $3 million in city subsidies over the last seven years.

title: Fine Sought For Insurer In Bias Case
description: The California Insurance Department is seeking to fine the California Insurance Group $2.5 million, contending that the insurer refused to sell policies in gay, minority and low-income neighborhoods of southeast San Francisco.

title: Helionetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Board of Education Defends Selection Process for Chancellor
description: As the Board of Education revived its search for a new schools chancellor for New York City, board members yesterday defended the process that led to an informal agreement to select Bernard R. Gifford, a California professor, who then turned down the job.

title: George J. Daly, Foundation President, 85
description: George J. Daly, the president of the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens for the last 10 years, died on Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

description: Leo I. Higdon Jr., co-head of investment banking at Salomon Brothers Inc., has been named the dean of the Darden Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Virginia.

title: Printronix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 25

description: As the humanitarian crisis in Bosnia worsens, two classified Administration reports say the international mediators in the Balkans are holding out the threat of seeking United Nations withdrawal from the country unless the Bosnian Muslims agree to negotiate on a partition plan.

title: Sports Betting Proposal Declared Dead in Trenton
description: Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian declared sports betting in Atlantic City casinos a dead issue today, saying he would not bring the measure before the full Assembly for a crucial vote.

title: Boston Acoustics reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
It's Johnson Against Reynolds, With the 400 Mark in Danger
description: Michael Johnson, two sprinters in one, has rebounded from the ignominy of Olympic failure by taking charge of the 400 meters and making it this year's marquee event in track and field.

title: SUMMIT IN TOKYO: The Overview; CLINTON ACHIEVES TRADE FRAMEWORK IN JAPANESE PACT
description: President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa reached a major accord this morning on a hard-fought "framework" for resolving a series of mounting trade disputes between the two nations. Mr. Clinton said it committed Japan to bring about "a highly significant reduction" in Japan's huge trade surpluses with the United States and the world.

title: Miami's Cuban Exiles May Lose TV Station
description: In a striking illustration of the waning influence of an organization that has dominated Cuban exile politics here and in Washington for a decade, Congress is making its most serious effort to eliminate TV Marti and drastically cut funds for Radio Marti, the last vestiges of cold-war broadcasting to the Soviet bloc.

title: Gay Cause Is the Same as Black Cause; In a Double Bind
description: To the Editor:

title: Oleg Kerensky Is Dead; Writer on Arts Was 63
description: Oleg Kerensky, a British-born writer on dance, music and theater, died yesterday at his Greenwich Village apartment. He was 63.

title: Guy Noyes, 79, Dies; Economist for Bank And Federal Reserve
description: Guy Emerson Noyes, an economist who directed research and analyzed trends for the Federal Reserve Board and later for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died on Sunday at the Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 79 and lived in Naples.

title: Body of Missing Transit Officer Is Found at Montauk Lighthouse
description: The body of a troubled Muslim transit police officer has been found on a ledge overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, where he appears to have killed himself with a single bullet.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about flooding on the Mississippi River referred imprecisely to Jefferson City, Mo. The city, the state capital, is on the Missouri River, not the Mississippi.

title: Fed Leaned Toward Higher Rates in May
description: The Federal Reserve announced today that its main policy-setting committee voted in May to lean toward raising interest rates if inflation did not slow. Many economists said the committee probably maintained that position when it met again on Tuesday and Wednesday.

description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 9,623,000.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 229,000.

title: Immigration Board Rejects Sheik's Plea for Asylum
description: Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the radical Islamic cleric whose followers have been linked to two bombing conspiracies in New York City, suffered a setback yesterday in his efforts to stay in the United States as the Board of Immigration Appeals in Washington rejected his request for political asylum.

description: PAYNE STEWART said yesterday he has a heart condition that has forced him to make some minor changes in his life style but will not curtail his golf schedule.

JUNK BONDS;
A Sparkling Market, But Watch for a Turn
description: JUNK BOND mutual funds are back in favor. Since the start of the year, individual investors have pumped $250 million weekly into funds that buy high-yield, high-risk corporate debt with low or no credit ratings. At this pace, such investments could top the net cash inflow of $9.6 billion in 1986.

description: Arthur Ashe would have been 50 years old today, and family and friends are planning a weekend tribute in his memory in Richmond.

The article also misstated an analyst's projections for loan-loss provisions at Bankers Trust this year. Paul A. Mackey, first vice president at Dean Witter, expects the bank to set aside $137 million this year, compared with $225 million in 1992.

title: 3 Israeli Soldiers Killed in a Rocket Attack
description: As a team of senior United States officials continued efforts here to give a kick-start to the stalled Middle East peace talks, three Israeli soldiers were killed today in southern Lebanon by rockets fired by pro-Iranian Islamic guerrillas.

title: Charging War Crimes, U.S. Seeks to Revoke Citizenship
description: The United States Department of Justice sought yesterday to have the citizenship of an accused Nazi war criminal summarily revoked on the ground that his audiotaped confession to taking part in a massacre of about 50 Jews at a concentration camp was so incriminating that the charges did not require a formal trial.

description: Saving for retirement has become a critical issue for Americans. Companies are slashing pension benefits; the Federal agency that guarantees corporate pensions, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, is struggling, and the Social Security system faces the burden of an aging population.

description: As sunbathers along the beaches here flip through John Grisham's latest thriller, this quiet Cape Cod town has been caught up in a real summer tale.

Errol Flynn? No, It's a Swashbuckling Rodriguez in Lead
description: With his often nervous putting stroke soothed by a grandmother's putter, Chi Chi Rodriguez withstood the dragon fire in Cherry Hills' greens today to maintain his lead after two rounds of the 14th United States Senior Open.

title: Henry Hazlitt, 98, a Journalist Who Concentrated on Economics
description: Henry Hazlitt, a self-taught economist who popularized the subject as a journalist and wrote a best-selling book about it, died yesterday at the Carolton Chronic Convalescent Hospital in Fairfield, Conn. He was 98 and had lived at the hospital for nearly seven years.

title: Scientists Confirm Identification of Bones as Czar's
description: Claiming to have cracked a 75-year-old mystery, British scientists said today that advanced forensic techniques had proved "virtually beyond doubt" that bones unearthed in a Russian forest two years ago belonged to Czar Nicholas II and his family.

title: Yemen's Democracy Gives U.S. the Jitters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sara Dadourian, Educator, 65
description: Sara K. Dadourian, superintendent of an Armenian day school, died at her home in Manhasset, L.I., on Saturday. She was 65 and also kept a home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Asians Seek To Restrict U.S. Airlines
description: In a spirit of unity never seen in the Asian airline industry, most of Asia's large airlines are banding together to overturn what they consider to be one-sided agreements that give American airlines the right to pick up passengers in Asia and fly them to other destinations in Asia, a right Asian carriers do not have in America.

title: LOW TRAFFIC FIGURES PUSH USAIR'S STOCK DOWN
description: USAir's common stock declined yesterday as the carrier reported a 10.5 percent drop in June traffic figures, a decline steeper than that of its rivals. The carrier reported revenue passenger mile figures for June dropped to 2.99 billion from 3.34 billion in June 1992, while its available seat miles fell 3.1 percent, to 4.92 billion from 5.08 billion. That dropped USAir's passenger load factor to 60.9 percent from 65.9 percent. USAir said the year-to-year figures were distorted because deep industry discounts in June 1992 put more people aboard airplanes, although they produced little money for airlines. USAir's shares were off 62.5 cents, at $14.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Cara Operations reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: b-Included extraordinary gains from early extinguishment of debt of $ 197,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 215,000, or 6 cents a share, in the 6 months.c-Included an extraordinary gain from early extinguishment of debt of $ 56,000, or 2 cents a share, in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: The Struggle For the Soul of Islam
description: The following news stories are all taken from the first half of 1993.

title: The 7 1/2 Cent Solution
description: President Clinton's original deficit-reduction proposal, and the one passed by the House, called for taxing gasoline at 7.5 cents per gallon, based on its energy content measured in British Thermal Units. By a one-vote margin, the Senate replaced the B.T.U. tax with a simple 4.3 cent per gallon gasoline tax. In reconciling the House and Senate versions of the budget, Congress should adopt a 7.5 cents gas tax, to help offset the loss of the broad-based B.T.U. energy tax.

title: Barbarians at the Box Offices
description: Jack Lang, the longtime czar of French culture who once assailed the American entertainment industry as "the immense empire of profit," has departed.

title: Commercial Property: The Flatiron Building; Charm and Favorable Rents Nail Publishers Down
description: SO what if those glittery new office buildings have large open floors, and this quirky relic is laid out in triangles? And so what if the new buildings offer advanced electronics, while this one still depends on a hydraulic system to power its 90-year-old elevators?

title: Biographers United
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus: Tampa, Fla.; Troubled Island Project on the Upswing
description: HARBOUR ISLAND, this city's long struggling mixed-use development off the downtown waterfront, appears to have put its worst days behind it.

title: 'Looming Colossus' of the Library World
description: AN entrepreneurial librarian has led a Bergen County computer consortium across county lines, gathering in thousands of new books, spreading contemporary technology and stirring controversy in the staid world of New Jersey's public libraries.

title: Hanford Nuclear Site Acts to Reduce Risk of Blast
description: After months of frustrating delays, workers at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State have installed a mixing pump in a giant tank of nuclear bomb waste, the first step toward greatly reducing the risk of explosion.

title:
POP VIEW;
How RuPaul Ups the Ante For Drag
description: Rupaul Andre Charles sits in the corner of a SoHo loft, dressed in a T-shirt and chinos, looking for all the world like a shy and lanky graduate student. His head is shaved. On closer inspection, his eyebrows are, too. After a three-hour toilette -- one and a half if time is tight, which is usually the case these days -- he is ready to join the ranks of single-named, single-minded chanteuses like Cher and Madonna.

title: Nudism's Changing Ways: 'Much More Mainstream'
description: THE sky is azure, the swimming pool aquamarine, the well-tended grass lush and green. Dozens of men and women apply sunscreen, chat, laugh and read. A lifeguard looks on with that familiar combination of vigilance and boredom. It's a typical summer scene except for one thing: the lifeguard is the only person wearing a bathing suit.

title: Spectacular Hair Day
description: In the old days, newspapers were fairly straightforward about their weather predictions: "Tomorrow: cloudy, likelihood of thundershowers in late afternoon" was typical, or "Tomorrow: mostly sunny, hot and humid." In the heat of competition from handsome, giggling weather casters on television, however -- with their "Boyoboy, is tomorrow gonna be a scorcher!" and "Get out those galoshes, Charlie and Joan, it'll be pouring down cats and dogs" -- the too-dignified print medium has had to enliven its prose.

title: Corrections
description: The Food column last Sunday, about peaches, carried an incorrect byline. The writer was Moira Hodgson.

title: Artists' Life In Paterson Mills
description: The article on the artists' residence in Paterson ("Dream of Creating Artists' Colony Meets Reality," June 6) paints a somewhat limited portrait of life here in the mills by focusing only on those residents involved with the visual arts. Deeper digging would have discovered a significant number of musicians living here who consistently interact with and support one another.

title: Miss Braddock, Mr. Gerber
description: Jennifer Alice Braddock and Ronald Whitney Gerber, 26-year-old graduates of Princeton University, were married yesterday at Beaulieu Gardens in Rutherford, Calif. The Rev. Harry Mack, a Syrian Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Criticism Without Machinery
description: LITERARY REFLECTIONS A Shoring of Images, 1960-1993. By R. W. B. Lewis. 306 pp. Boston: Northeastern University Press. $24.95.

title:
ART;
Factory Work and Combat
description: SINCE the history of Paterson has been intertwined with industry, the Paterson Museum is an ideal location for the exhibition "Produce for Victory," subtitled "Posters on the American Home Front 1941-45."

title: Russian Entrepreneurial Spirit Steals Into Secret Spy Archives
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex, Triads and Chromaticism
description: BENJAMIN BRITTEN A Biography. By Humphrey Carpenter. Illustrated. 677 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $30.

title: When Bigger Is Better
description: EVEN for reporters, a Presidential campaign can be a life-altering event. Some journalists I know have divorced after covering a campaign, others have married and still others have quit the profession altogether. As for me, I turned to giant vegetables.

title: German Guerrillas Assert Leader Was 'Executed'
description: An urban guerrilla group has accused a member of an elite Government commando squad of killing one of its leaders in cold blood last week in eastern Germany, and the authorities say they fear reprisals.

title: She Knows What She Likes
description: THE ART OF AROUSALBy Ruth Westheimer.Illustrated. 180 pp. New York:Abbeville Press. $35.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Making Industrial Site Cleanups Easier
description: IN an effort to change New Jersey's image as a difficult place to do business and to help shore up its sagging industrial base, Gov. Jim Florio last month signed a law easing the state's tough toxic-waste cleanup regulations.

title: American Winner Becomes Worldbeater
description: American Winner weathered a shaky first turn and then stormed to the wire in world-record style tonight, easily winning the $313,699 Yonkers Trot by 10 1/2 lengths at Yonkers Raceway.

title: JULY 4-10: Keeping the Pressure On; A Standoff in Iraq Raises Nervousnessc About New Raids
description: The air raid sirens that sounded in Baghdad last week proved to be a false alarm, but the Iraqi edginess was only one sign that last month's punitive American missile strike may not be the last.

title: Home-Team Recognition
description: To the Editor:

title: Trapped Weather Pattern Smothers East and Floods Midwest
description: A stubborn weather pattern that settled over the eastern half of the United States last week caused catastrophic floods in the upper Mississippi Valley while plunging the East into a steam bath.

title: JULY 4-10: Counting Fingers and Toes; New Scope Examines Embryos in First Trimester
description: It was inevitable, of course. Once medical instrument makers discovered ways to make a viewing scope so small that it could fit inside a blood vessel, doctors would take a close look at human embryos early in pregnancy. Nonetheless, the world opened by embryoscopy is startling. Tiny embryos in the first trimester of pregnancy, less than an inch long, come into view so clearly that doctors can count fingers and toes.

title: Streetscapes: The Liberty Theater; Unlikely 42d St. Revival
description: THE 42d Street Redevelopment Corporation is confident that it can solve its big problems -- reviving the street temporarily until the office market recovers, keeping the street clean and safe and restoring its majestic collection of theaters.

title: Now Batting . . .
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At Westport Playhouse, Three-Character Farce
description: WALTER, a house painter who is really an actor, arrives to finish a decorating job on Marcia and Reggie's flat. Marcia has been having an affair, 10 days a year for three or four years, with Jane's husband, Brian. Jane appears to tell Marcia that she has found out. She smashes a vase with a mallet and then announces she will reappear that night to tell Reggie about his wife's affair with her husband.

title: Getty's Burger Dress
description: Horsepower and seven years ago our fathers brought four on this continent a new nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that Coleman are created equal.

title: Black Enterprises Grow and Get Noticed
description: MANY black leaders in Chicago were upset last month when the Johnson Products Company, one of the nation's leading symbols of black enterprise, announced that it would be acquired by the IVAX Corporation, an international conglomerate.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'MANITOBA SOUND'

title: Watch Television And Get the Word
description: A LAW TAKING EFFECT this month recognizes a startling fact: Nearly 10 percent of the population is at least partially deaf. The Television Decoder Circuitry Act requires that every television set sold in the United States (except for old stock and small portable models) contain a built-in caption decoder. The object is to make television more accessible to the estimated 24 million Americans suffering from hearing loss.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Safe Area' Perils in Sarajevo

title: New Rules Can't Limit Lure of Shark Fishing
description: In death, the mako shark in the stern of the power boat returning to the Leonardo marina here looked nothing like the deep-water predator of novels and nightmares, just a limp brown carcass waiting to be weighed in a sports fishing tournament.

title: Data Update
'Small' Means Total Collateral
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Patterson and Richard Weston
description: Linda Kay Patterson, a daughter of Mary Patterson of Brooklyn and the late Grant Patterson, was married yesterday to Richard Jeter Weston, the son of Leona and William Weston of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Edward H. Whitaker performed the ceremony at the Emanuel Baptist Church in Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: The Food column last Sunday, about peaches, carried an incorrect byline. The writer was Moira Hodgson.

title: Logistics of Hanging Neuberger Exhibition
description: PLANNING the current exhibition commemorating Roy R. Neuberger's 90th birthday on July 21 was an exercise in nostalgia, said Lucinda H. Gedeon, director of the Neuberger Museum of Art on the campus of the State University of New York here. But borrowing works for the show also illustrated the intricacies of current museum practice, she said.

title: When America Fell in Love With the Art of Antiquity
description: In early 19th-century America, images of the ancient past were very much at home. Statues of Venus proliferated in Boston parlors. Toile curtains depicting George Washington driving a chariot with a Greek goddess in the back seat were fashionable in Richmond. And mummy mania, spurred by gallery shows of Egyptian exports, swept the land.

title: Miss Mackay, Mr. Whittemore
description: Kathleen Ann Mackay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Mackay of Westerly, R.I., was married yesterday to Laurence Frederick Whittemore 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Whittemore of New York. The Rev. Peter J. Andrews performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Watch Hill (R.I.) Chapel.

title: The Patent System Ain't Broke; Don't Fix It
description: To the Editor:

title: Clint Eastwood Cozies Up To the 1990's
description: Many years ago, in an episode of the television western "Rawhide," Rowdy Yates got sick. He got so sick that he had to take off his shirt. The writers were probably searching for ways to get Rowdy's shirt off, because he was played by the very young, very handsome Clint Eastwood. There he was, lying on his bedroll among the cattle, looking all sweaty and shirtless, insisting he was well enough to get up. At that moment Rowdy was tough but vulnerable, and irresistibly attractive.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: YONKERS FROM 1800 to 1900

title:
DINING OUT;
Victorian Charmer's New Sophistication
description: WHEN the Virginia Hotel, a Victorian charmer in Cape May, was refurbished and opened by new owners in 1989, the fare in the inn's dining room was trendy but uneven. Just over a year ago, a new chef took over the range in the Ebbitt Room, as it's called, and the restaurant now ranks among the best of the resort's cosmopolitan dining spots. The food, while still roaming all over the map, is now consistently good, with an emphasis on locally grown produce, and the service has gained polish.

title: Mickey Lacks a Soupcon of Charm
description: Battered by a European recession and still bewildered by European habits, Euro Disney put its entire future development under review last week after announcing disastrous summer losses. Being in the red during the cold winter months was predictable, but an April-June loss of $87 million sent the company's stock into a nosedive on the Paris Bourse.

title: Richie Leaves Rosie and Dies
description: AFTER ALL THESE YEARSBy Susan Isaacs.343 pp. New York:HarperCollins Publishers. $23.

title: For Children of AIDS, New Hope in Newark
description: In a three-story brick building on a quiet corner of United Hospitals Medical Center here, six doctors and nurses from Myanmar are learning how to treat young patients infected with the virus that causes AIDS. Just a year ago, their government did not even officially recognize H.I.V. and AIDS as a national threat.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Long Time at the Bank

title: Mom-and-Pop Is Just Fine by Some
description: To the Editor:

title: The Burden Of Celebrity
description: IN a field of parked Jaguars, Saabs and BMW's at Sag Pond Farm in Sagaponack, L.I., last weekend, beyond the din of the party tent where a fund-raiser for the Hamptons International Film Festival was in progress, Barbra Streisand was in a little huddle with her friends Donna Karan and Stephan Weiss. Having come to see Steven Spielberg only to be told that he wasn't there, Ms. Streisand apparently had lost her will to venture forth.

title: A Blanket of Darkness Prolongs a City's Misery
description: Heat gives the night an edge. At the Monster in the West Village, the bar's doorman, Sacha Loren, was a little nervous asking customers to pay a cover charge on Friday night. In Brighton Beach, residents griped and milled grumpily around Consolidated Edison workers trying to restore power to their homes.

title: Julie Hall, Miles Dinneen
description: Juliette Hammond Hall, the daughter of Richard and Sharon Hall of Loudonville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Miles Terrence Dinneen, a son of Terrence and Dorothy Dinneen of Hawkes Bay, New Zealand. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gailey McIntyre at the home of the bride's parents.

title:
The Executive Life;
Being 'Out' at the Top Finds New Tolerance
description: FOR seven years Bruce Pfrommer, an advertising agency executive in Colorado Springs, Colo., hid his homosexuality from colleagues.

title: Corrections
description: The Food column last Sunday, about peaches, carried an incorrect byline. The writer was Moira Hodgson.

title: Political Memo; Republicans Forget Clinton; the Big Worry Is Perot
description: After slashing Ross Perot as "a walking sound bite," "a great hit-and-run artist" and a free agent who can make a splash then "run back to Dallas on his private jet," Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, denied that he harbored any ill feelings.

title: Taking a Short Cut To the End Game
description: THREE players tied for first place in the Skei-Masters International Tournament in Gausdal, Norway, in early May: Bjarke Kristensen of Denmark; Jonathan Tisdall, an American who lives in Norway, and Ferdinand Hellers of Sweden. For Kristensen, it meant a second norm toward the grandmaster title; for Tisdall, it meant his third norm, but he must still bring his International Chess Federation rating up from 2425 to 2500 before he can be accorded the honor. Hellers is already a grandmaster.

title: The Sheik Will Be Staying Put, for Now
description: A LITTLE more than a week ago, American officials abruptly informed Egypt that Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman could leave the United States for any country that would accept him unless the Egyptians quickly presented an extradition request, which they reluctantly did. That was the bad news. The good news came a few days later, when the Government here learned that the sheik might spend years locked up as an illegal immigrant while his lawyers fought the extradition request in the American courts.

title: Cinema Center Marks Expansion
description: "AN earned miracle" is what Vic Skolnick and Charlotte Sky, co-directors and founders of the newly named Cinema Arts Center in Huntington, call the completion of a $1 million expansion. After 20 years, they have established the sole independent cinema on Long Island and, they say, one of only 12 in the country.

title: Books in the Ears
description: To the Editor:

title: A Judd, Yes. A Country Singer, No.
description: NAME: Ashley Judd.

title: The Struggle for the Book Buyer's Dollar
description: STRAINS of classical music, along with attentive sales clerks, accompanied the dozen shoppers browsing through the wide aisles of a bookstore here on an early summer morning. With its deep-forest-green carpeting, dark-wood shelves, soft lighting, reading tables and chairs, the setting conjured up images of a restful library.

title: Thousands 'Adopting' Highways
description: IN state and county programs and in local grass-roots efforts, thousands of New Jerseyans are clearing litter and debris from the state's roads, beaches, streams and parks.

title: Susan Morrison, James A. Kilfoyle
description: Dr. Susan Signe Morrison was married yesterday to Dr. James Anthony Kilfoyle. The Rev. Jonathan L. King officiated at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. James Coffee, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, took part in the ceremony.

title: Latin America's Oil Rush: Tapping Into Foreign Investors
description: LONG a crusty redoubt of nationalism, the Latin American oil industry is quietly opening to a flood of foreign investment.

title: JULY 4-10: Sincerity Doubted; F.B.I.'s Director Pushes For Gun Control
description: When F.B.I. Director William S. Sessions proposed last week that the Justice Department endorse legislation requiring a five-day waiting period for handgun purchases, senior officials in the department showed little enthusiasm. In fact, the idea has long been urged by law enforcement officials.

title: As He Knew Them
description: HEROES OF MY TIMEBy Harrison E. Salisbury.210 pp. New York:Walker & Company. $19.95.

title: The Fall Softens Its Edge
description: The Fall is one of England's enduring cult bands. Formed in 1976 by the singer and lyricist Mark E. Smith, it evolved into one of the most critically acclaimed and influential groups of the post-punk era. In the mid-80's, the Fall was the prototype for the abrasive British genre of "shambling bands." More recently, its coruscating sound and cryptic lyrics have been a major influence on the "indie" scene in the United States. Pavement, the most prominent band in the burgeoning American lo-fi underground, is indebted to the Fall, as are other up-and-coming groups like Truman's Water, Thinking Fellers Union Local 282 and God Is My Co-Pilot.

title: Pursuing School Choice In a Political Minefield
description: When school reopens in September, a class of gifted sixth-grade students from the Upper West Side will make their school choice by moving crosstown en masse to Robert F. Wagner Jr. High School on East 76th Street, in a neighboring school district.

title: Katherine Hill, J. A. O'Connor Jr.
description: Katherine Renee Hill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Robert Hill of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Jeremiah Anthony O'Connor Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. O'Connor of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. John O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph on the Brandywine in Greenville, Del.

title: Ashley Ammidon, Daniel Quinlan
description: Ashley Elizabeth Ammidon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt Ammidon Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Scott Quinlan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Quinlan of Allendale, S.C. The Rev. Daphne Hawkes, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Blauenburg (N.J.) Reformed Church.

title: Gregg Renfrew, William D. Orr
description: Susan Gregg Renfrew, the daughter of Susan G. Renfrew of New York and R. Bartlett Renfrew of Dallas, was married yesterday to William Dennison Orr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Orr of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Richard Ringenwald performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Manchester, Vt.

title: Toxic Chemicals Make Clean a Dirty Word
description: To the Editor:

title: The Uninsured: 37 Million and Growing
description: "WE have met the uninsured, and they are us," is the message from Hillary and Bill Clinton these days as they try to prepare the public for sweeping health-care proposals this fall. They are not arguing for spiritual unity with the downtrodden. Rather, they are drawing on new evidence that startling numbers of even middle-class Americans are finding themselves without the security of health insurance at least temporarily, most often because they have changed or lost their jobs. And still more say they are suffering from "job lock," afraid to move or quit because they fear for their health coverage.

title: D. L. Hartfelder, Jeffrey Stevenson
description: Deborah Lynn Hartfelder, the daughter of Mrs. Jack F. Hartfelder of Dallas, and the late Mr. Hartfelder, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Taylor Stevenson, a son of Mrs. William Crouse of Chatham, Mass., and Lincoln Stevenson of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ's Church in Rye.

title: Big Girls Don't Cry
description: More than half the women in America wear at least a size 12 dress. Guess how many want to look like a street urchin? Enough with the waif. Too many grown-ups with full breasts, ample hips, large shoulders and baggage-free self-images are tired of the implication that the only way they could be in fashion is wrapped in the shroud of Turin. Less is not necessarily more, though in truth, more should usually wear less. Beaded epaulets, dropped waists and garish prints are not the way to a lovelier silhouette in any size. Large women are flattered by the unemcumbered lines, monochromatic layers, easy fit and minimal jewelry currently in style. In fact, no matter what the arbiters say there are clothes out there for you. In these lean times, fashion could profit from a little largess.

title: Prune, Pinch, Mulch and Transplant
description: Prune rambler roses after flowering by cutting this year's growth back six inches. Ramblers bloom on the previous year's growth, so if you remove too much, you'll reduce flowering next year. Pruning now slows development and helps the plant mature for winter. Remove two-year-old wood and any dead canes, as well as any shoots that appear below the bud union.

title: Spain's Forest of Yesteryear
description: MUNIELLOS, a densely forested preserve of oak and beech trees in the heart of the lush mountainous region of Asturias, is a vestige of Spain as it once looked.

title: Dana Reifler, L. H. Schaefer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Wayne of Niskayuna, N.Y., have announced the engagement of her daughter Dana Jill Reifler to Air Force Capt. Lawrence H. Schaefer, the son of Eileen Schaefer and Henry Schaefer, both of Saugerties, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Calm Before the Next Big Storm?
description: LYNDON JOHNSON was seeking a full term as President, promising a "Great Society" at home and no escalation in Vietnam. The Beatles were the newest music sensation. America felt rich and successful, with economic growth topping 5 percent a year. And the stock market was rising ever so quietly, with virtually no volatility.

title: A Lark With Kids in London
description: SOMETIME last January I noticed an ad for amazingly low air fares to London -- $186 round trip from Boston -- and stuck it on my bulletin board. It was a fantasy, really. The next time the ad caught my eye was the very day the fares expired -- an hour before my travel agency closed, in fact. It occurred to me that we could fly to London for the weekend for less than it would cost to go to Washington. (I knew I could never afford such a trip in the summer.) And though I had not once seriously considered the possibility of such an expedition, I found myself suddenly picking up the phone and booking four tickets -- for myself and my kids, only one of whom, my daughter, Audrey, had ever crossed the ocean.

title: Castles in the Sand
description: Fire Island is a long, thin spit of sand that sits off Long Island like a sea wall, closing the southern shore off from the rambunctious Atlantic and creating the still waters of the Great South Bay. From the air, it looks frail and primitive -- 32 miles long and only a few thousand feet wide, with bridges at its outer limits but no roads in between. It is an unlikely host for urban pleasure-seekers, yet for a century they have come, the famous actors and writers, advertising executives, drag queens, party animals and old-fashioned families, relishing a place where there are no cars, only boardwalks and bicycles and little pull-wagons to transport groceries or luggage. Children roam as freely as the deer, which are everyhere. It could almost be the 19th century.

title: Sports of The Times; A Working Golfer, Wife And Mother
description: HALL of Fame touring golf pro. Mother of three young daughters. Baseball wife.

title: Wingate Re-signs With Hornets
description: The Charlotte Hornets signed unrestricted free-agent forward DAVID WINGATE to a multi-year contract yesterday. Details of the deal were not released, but it is believed Wingate received a four-year contract worth just more than $500,000 a season.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
Annapolis
description: College town, sailing center, home of the United States Naval Academy, Annapolis is a distinctly seasonal city, owing to its institutions as much as to its climate. There are at least four faces to the city, roughly defined by the 90-day winter meeting of the State Legislature; the boat shows in spring and fall; the summer months, and the academic years of St. John's College, and, of course, the Naval Academy. (It is the academy schedule that the visitor should be concerned about: certain academy events require hotel reservations a year ahead). But the summer visitor has only to contend with other summer visitors, and a little planning will smooth the way to a rewarding sojourn, whether it is spent tramping the brick sidewalks to the unparalleled wealth of historic houses, attending one of the Bay-region bacchanalias, or chartering a boat for a sail on the Chesapeake.

title: Game Playing
description: To the Editor:

title: 'End of Summer' at SUNY Purchase
description: IN a memoir published a year before his death, S. N. Behrman (1893-1973) wrote, "Comedy is the saving grace which makes life bearable."

title: SAINT HILLARY
description: Thankfully, my opinion of the First Person was not altered by Michael Kelly's polite exploration of her moral and political philosophy. In fact, I was even more convinced that she is no more a New Liberal than her spouse is a New Democrat. Mrs. Clinton is very, very old wine in a new bottle. And when she finally finds the words to express her political dogmas, I can tell you the kind of laws and executive orders they will translate into: coercive and equalitarian instruments of radical social change that will expand the role of the state at the expense of individual civil liberty.

title:
FILM;
When a Movie Needs A (Very) Familiar Face
description: When "Weekend at Bernie's," a low-budget black comedy, became a surprise cult hit in the summer of 1989, the screenwriter Robert Klane realized that his main character had sequel potential. Audiences developed a bond with Bernie, a New York City executive who dies at the beginning of a wild Hamptons weekend and does things like tumble off sundecks and waterski across Long Island Sound.

title: No Mets' Takers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Labeling Prime-Time Violence Is Still a Band-Aid Solution
description: V is for victory? Some members of Congress would also like V to stand for violence, and to serve as the warning signal the broadcast networks have promised to alert parents to especially bloody prime-time programs starting this fall. Catch No. 1: The networks themselves would judge violence levels. Catch No. 2: They will also devise the warning. The current nebuluous contender, to be broadcast just before a show, is: "Due to some violent content, parental discretion advised." So, in the latest posturings between Government regulators and the networks, V is still very much for victory as far as the television industry is concerned.

title: The Patent System Ain't Broke; Don't Fix It
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Bronzaft, Michael Santoro
description: Susan B. Bronzaft, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, and Michael O. Santoro Jr., an urban designer with the New York City Department of Transportation, were married yesterday. Justice Michael L. Pesce of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated at Fox Hollow, a country club in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Done Fixing? Repair to the Computer
description: MY '65 Caddy convertible has a 26-gallon gas tank and a thirst for premium, so it doesn't go on many outings. These days, it pretty much lives in the backyard, although "lives" may not be exactly the word I am looking for here.

title: The Patent System Ain't Broke; Don't Fix It
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Generous Portions in a Spacious Setting
description: OF the string of short-lived eateries attempting to settle into this pretty space, Focaccia looks like a keeper. Open only a month, this great space is crowded on any evening of the week with tables full of family and friends passing dishes family style, the way food here is presented. Folks come for the bargain prices, unstinting portions of familiar Italian food and the surprisingly elaborate setting. For $28 (not including beverages, tax and tip) a family of four can share a three-course meal (and take home leftovers) while enjoying fine views of a sunset or the sky-reflecting pond from a lofty dining room or one of the roomy decks.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PHILOSOPHICAL NOVELTHE LAWSBy Connie Palmen.Braziller, $18.50.

title: Dreyfus: All Dressed Up, With Few Places to Invest
description: INVESTORS apparently love the Dreyfus Growth and Income Fund five times as much today as they did at the end of December: assets have soared to $703.7 million from $137.1 million on Dec. 31.

title: Kit Schaefer And John Axton
description: Judith Kittredge Schaefer, a daughter of Mrs. Henry W. Schaefer of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Mr. Schaefer, was married yesterday to John Lawrence Axton, the son of Helen C. Axton and John R. Axton, both of Santa Fe., N.M. Michael Howard, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Breckenridge, Colo.

title: Dodger Pride
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
HERS;
Past Perfect
description: I look at the photos again and again, seeking answers. Here we are, four people seated under an umbrella at an outdoor cafe, the golden afternoon sunlight casting a soft glow on our faces as we look at the camera. We are all smiling. I see two younger adults who are tall and tan and look quite alike, and an older man and woman whom they resemble in some ways.

title: Jack Lazorko Doesn't Pitch Here Anymore
description: Maybe you've never heard of Jack Lazorko, the 37-year-old right-handed pitcher who is as compact as a tugboat and is called "Il Bulldog" in Italy, "El Bulldog" in Latin America and "Zork" in the States.

title: A Softer, Gentler Romanticism From Schumann and Brahms
description: Schumann and Brahms have long been subjects of rumor. One didn't know how to orchestrate, they say, and lost his way in larger forms; the other quavered before Beethoven's example, concealing orchestral thoughts in chamber garb. Some listeners still dislike the Brahmsian sound ("India-rubber-like," according to an early critic).

title: Larkin Flanagan, Catherine Stanton
description: Judge and Mrs. Reginald Stanton of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Feehan Lynch Stanton, to Larkin Stepan Flanagan, a son of Joseph P. Flanagan of Chicago and Charlotte S. Flanagan of Winnetka, Ill. An August wedding is planned.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Gramercy Park
description: ONCE home to Edwin Booth, Theodore Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy, Gramercy Park, a relaxed neighborhood at the foot of Lexington Avenue and just a mile south of Grand Central Terminal, seems a bit out of place in bustling New York City.

title: A Bit Too Much Ado About the School Prom
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Food column last Sunday, about peaches, carried an incorrect byline. The writer was Moira Hodgson.

title:
Paterson Journal;
School Continues Its Long Search for a Home
description: WHILE other principals in New Jersey are leaving their classroom cares behind with the start of summer vacations, Maria Lopez, principal of Paterson's Public School 1, is exasperated. Once again, she is packing the contents of her desk and file cabinets into cardboard boxes.

title: Officials Move to Quell Washington Hts. Unrest
description: The police, city officials and community groups stepped up their presence on the edgy streets of Washington Heights in upper Manhattan yesterday, trying to calm tensions that flared on Friday night when three firefighters were injured in a firebomb attack on a fire truck.

title: Lisa Bailey, Bradley Hittle
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Bailey of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Ann Bailey to Bradley Arthur Hittle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Hittle of Old Greenwich, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Copland: 'Lincoln Portrait,' 'Canticle of Freedom,' Other Works; Harris: 'American Creed,' 'When Johnny Comes Marching Home'James Earl Jones, speaker ("Portrait"); Seattle Symphony and Chorale ("Canticle") conducted by Gerard Schwarz. Delos DE 3140; CD.

title: On Prison's Little Acre, Time Is Well Spent
description: "THIS is farmland," Reginald Wiltshire said as he labored in the dark soil. "It is good soil for planting." What is unusual about this farmland is that it is inside the fence of the Westchester County Correctional Facility here.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Go North of the Border for Salmon and Scenery Open to All
description: Flyfishers, like the creatures they so avidly pursue, tend to be creatures of habit. And just as salmon return from the sea to their natal rivers to spawn -- often procreating in the same pools where they were born -- anglers also tend to return to the same rivers, over and over, year after year.

title: Jackets Off! Ties Next!
description: A heat wave is one of the few forces known to alter the dress code of executives and professionals. During last Tuesday's morning rush hour, after the long holiday weekend, a few men were observed carrying their suit jackets on their walk from air-conditioned trains to air-conditioned offices. By Wednesday, many men and women were carrying their jackets, suspended by the finger of an outstretched hand to keep them from wrinkling. One man used a walking stick resting on his shoulder as a place to hang his jacket. By Thursday, neckties were being carried, too. On Friday, the short-sleeve shirt was emerging as a compromise with the weather.

title: Old Bus Passes Become Passports to Culture
description: A PILOT program to increase cultural outings in the county is tapping into a new audience: bus riders on the Bee-Line System operated by the County Department of Transportation. The program, which began June 1, enables people holding monthly bus passes to exchange their previous month's expired pass for a free visit to one of seven sites: the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, Lyndhurst in Tarrytown and three Historic Hudson Valley houses, Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown, Sunnyside in Irvington and Van Cortlandt Manor in Croton.

title: Fishing Cutbacks Stir Widespread Protest
description: A STORM of protest has been whirling about the heads of state and Federal officials who ordered a sharp reduction in this year's catch of summer flounder off the New Jersey coast.

title: Opposition Mounts To West Side Stadium
description: If the Yankees were to relocate to a new ball park upon the West Side railyard, a possibility now being pushed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, local community board members say construction, traffic and mass transportation problems would choke the area.

title: Portraying Idealized Childhoods With Her Children as Models
description: WHEN Betsy Cameron focuses her camera on her three children she sees just the world that she would like them to live in. Set in idyllic landscapes like sun-drenched beaches, misty gardens and rustic front porches, it is, she said, a "clean, warm and slow-moving" world.

title: Whose Vacation Is It, Anyway?
description: ONE of the biggest problems about traveling with kids, at least from a kid's point of view, is that all parents and grown-ups were once kids and consequently think they know what kids like, which means that they do totally ridiculous things like singing about 100 bottles of beer on the wall in the misguided notion that this will make a journey pass quickly.

title: U.S. to Bar Calls to Cuba Through Canada
description: The Clinton Administration plans to close communications services that allow people in the United States to make telephone calls to Cuba through Canada, Administration officials say.

title: DATE RAPE'S OTHER VICTIM
description: Roiphe's lit-based assessment had me wondering if she had read too many 18th-century romantic novels or not enough. Male violence against women exists. It is not a public relations campaign designed by rabid "rape-crisis feminists" to frighten young women into Gibson-girl mode. I respectfully suggest Roiphe spend a year or two volunteering at her local battered-women's shelter or rape-crisis center before she unleashes her considerable intellect on the reality of contemporary women's lives again. KAY LEIGH HAGAN Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Ondieki of Kenya Breaks 10,000 Barrier
description: Yobes Ondieki of Kenya, breaking a newly set world record in the 10,000 meters, tonight became the first man to run the event in under 27 minutes when he clocked 26 minutes 58.38 seconds at the Bislett Games Grand Prix meet.

title: Of Colleges And Race Relations
description: In "A Novelist's Journey in Race Relations" (New Jersey Q & A, June 13), Prof. John A. Williams of Rutgers emerges as an immensely accomplished man. Thus, I am particularly disturbed to find him a proponent of several irresponsible and imprudent viewpoints.

title: Living Color
description: At first glance, it looks like a crash course in color run amok: off-the-chart shades careering from room to room, with a crazy-quilt carpet dashing up the stairs. But color was the only way to go for a space as idiosyncratic as this one: an 1858 five-story former rooming house on a narrow site, with only one or two irregularly shaped rooms to a floor.

title: Deborah Dawson, Joseph Radecki Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Dawson of Greenwich, Conn., and La Quinta, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Anne Dawson, to Joseph Jerome Radecki Jr., the son of Joseph and Katherine Radecki of Beach Haven, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title: HOT TUNA
description: What a tuna does to survive is ultimately what makes it somebody's dinner. In order to live, it needs oxygen-rich water. This induces the tuna, a giant-sized mackerel, to swim at bursts of up to 40 miles an hour, zooming from the subtropics in the winter to the temperate north in summer on a schedule known only to this particular creature.

title: Acoustic Horrors Of the Fitting Room
description: To the Editor:

title: Not a Fairy Tale: Sunday Meant Mail
description: ONCE upon a time, in the Kingdom of Belgium, mail was delivered seven days a week. No special-delivery charge, no Priority Mail stickers. At the turn of the century, mail carriers just worked seven days a week.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Life Before Unisex
description: Before barbershops turned into beauty salons and stylists became celebrities, a good barber could be measured by the number of shaving mugs he had on display over his sink. In turn-of-the-century America, men personalized their mugs to reflect their place in the world. When you went in for your twice-weekly shave, your barber plucked your shaving mug off the shelf. You stepped up into the oak and leather barber chair, a throne for the middle class, and were pampered in a manner that would soon be nearly extinct. Today, shaving mugs are collectibles, selling for as much as $3,000 apiece. Barber chairs are cold chrome. The neighborhood barber is unlikely to have worked his way up from apprentice. In THE VANISHING AMERICAN BARBER SHOP: An Illustrated History of Tonsorial Art, 1860-1960 (Windmill Publishing Company, 2147 Windmill View Road, El Cajon, Calif. 92020, paper, $16.95), Ronald S. Barlow bemoans the loss and gives scavengers some hints about how to make money from the remnants. He pays tribute to a gentlemanly era of high-quality tools and pride in a job well done, but the book itself is a slapdash effort, too long in some places, too short in others. Mr. Barlow, the author of "The Vanishing American Outhouse," includes a rapid history of the barber's profession, and the book is nicely illustrated, with vintage photographs and excerpts from barber-school manuals and barber-supply catalogues. "The Vanishing American Barber Shop" makes a persuasive case for barbering as an everyday art in its twilight. But the book leaves the impression that it is basically a shopping list for collectors.

title: Is School Choice a Real Choice?; New York Citywide Plan Faces Bureaucracy and Shortage
description: Just inside the entrance to Public School 63 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, a large sign, in English and Spanish, informs parents: "You have the right to send your child to the school of your choice."

title: U.N. Troops Begin an Effort To Take Over Somali Streets
description: After weeks of rarely venturing outside their compounds, United Nations troops have begun setting up checkpoints in the streets of Mogadishu as part of an effort to wrest control of the city from Somali militiamen.

title: The Restaurant Is French. Well, Sort Of.
description: A GIANT lemon slice hangs outside Citron, an attractive new restaurant on Main Street in Sag Harbor. It is French, but do not expect hearty bistro fare or haute cuisine classics. The stars of the lineup are bright, fresh and new. Lemon pasta, a bowl of fettuccine in a lush, zippy sauce, is Citron at its best.

title: Memoirs of a Confederate in Paris
description: THE GREEN PARADISE Autobiography: Volume I (1900-1916). By Julian Green. Translated by Anne and Julian Green. 243pp. New York: Marion Boyars Publishers.

title: Clinton in Korea: A Call for a Pacific Community Based on 'Shared Strength'
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address to the South Korean National Assembly yesterday in Seoul, as transcribed by the Federal News Service and provided by the Reuters news agency:

title: In the Region: Westchester; Knicks Sign Pact With SUNY Purchase
description: FOR years, Westchester County has been anxious to attract professional sports teams, both to make use of its existing athletic facilities and to develop new arenas and sports complexes that could generate new revenue.

title: Haiti's Future Can Be Undone Before It's Done
description: FOR many who have followed Haiti's multiple ups and downs since the fall of the Duvalier family dictatorship in 1986, attentions quickly turned -- once the news of a United Nations-brokered settlement of the country's latest political crisis had penetrated -- to speculation over what could go wrong next.

title: Dinkins's Olive Branch: Facing Crown Hts. From Israel
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins traveled nearly 6,000 miles last week to utter words that had eluded him at home during two years of bitter debate over the racial violence in Crown Heights.

description: The court and the news media were at odds again this week in the trial of three white former police officers accused of beating an unemployed black steelworker to death on Nov. 5.

title: Matisse Museum Reopens
description: The Matisse Museum in Nice reopened late last month after six years and a $9.4 million renovation and expansion. A new, two-floor wing designed by the French architect Jean-Francois Bodin has been added to the 17th-century villa, which has housed the museum since its opening in 1963. The addition, built below ground level, includes a bookstore, a 70-seat auditorium and a restaurant with terrace.

title: Iraqi No-Fly Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: A General Store for Light Housekeeping
description: BELLPORT, L.I., the modest 19th-century sailing village tucked behind the malls and diners along Sunrise Highway in Suffolk County, has become Seventh Avenue's summer outpost. Bruce Weber, the photographer; Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue, and Isabella Rossellini, the actress and model, have homes in the area, spearheading an influx of designers, publicists, models, photographers and people in the advertising business.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Kentucky Country Ham: The Secret Is in the Cure
description: A KENTUCKY country ham looks something like a moss-covered boulder, and it smells, well, ripe. Like the flavors of Burgundy wine and Roquefort cheese, the flavor of this traditional ham is not the least delicate. "Country ham has got to have a sharp taste," says Bill Robertson, the proprietor of Finchville Farms, in Finchville, Ky. "I think it's got to have some bite to it. It's an acquired taste."

title: For the Insatiable Collector
description: To the Editor:

title: Marci Alboher and Gary Nusbaum
description: Marci Alysa Alboher, the daughter of Linda Alboher of Wildwood Crest, N.J., and the late Manny Alboher, is engaged to Gary David Nusbaum, the son of Ronni Nusbaum of Hollywood, Fla., and Jack Nusbaum of New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: SURFACING
description: ACCESSORY -- The biker wallet: Given the wildly divergent styles -- biker chic and English fop -- that mesh in this wallet-and-chain set, it makes sense that it is selling well both in downtown stores like East Village Leather ($12-$16) and uptown at Bergdorf Goodman Men (Chrome Hearts model, $1,485). MUSIC -- The Female Band Manager: Janet Billing has Nirvana. Susan Silver has Alice in Chains. Debbie Gordon and Rina Neiman have Babes in Toyland. The management of punkish rock groups is no longer the terrain of not-necessarily-punkish men. DANGER -- Central Park Traffic: The confluence of runners, cyclists and Rollerbladers has created havoc. The park's Medical Unit says accidents are at an all-time high.

title: Terrorism's New Threat Tests Airports' Security
description: With each fresh eruption of terrorism in the United States this year -- the car-bomb explosion at the World Trade Center in February, the bombing plot aimed at the United Nations and the Hudson River tunnels -- the nation's major airports have gone on security alert.

title: Free at Last, N.F.L. Ushers in a New Era
description: In the new era of National Football League free agency, bringing hope for rebirth and resurgence, perhaps there is no more appropriate team than the Los Angeles Raiders to be first out of the gate for training camp.

title:
DANCE;
Ballet Troupe's Signature Is Durability
description: UNLIKE so many of her counterparts in the dance world, Carolyn Clark, the artistic and executive director of the New Jersey Ballet Company, manages to keep her company coming up with performances instead of problems. Despite occasional pay cuts and shortened contracts, the West Orange-based company continues fulfilling Miss Clark's avowed mission to provide audiences throughout the state with top-quality ballet.

title: Cruise Around Greenland
description: The Russian icebreaker Kapitan Khlebnikov will embark this summer on what trip organizers say is the first circumnavigation of Greenland. On Aug. 17, the ship will leave Sondre Stromfjord on the west coast and head counterclockwise around the island.

title: Q and A
description: A Docked Rent Deposit Question: After living from month to month with no lease in the upper apartment of a two-family dwelling in Queens, I informed my absentee landlord by mail on the ninth of the month that I would be leaving at the month's end. He received the letter on the 12th. Because I had not notified him 30 days prior to moving, however, he deducted 12 days rent from my security deposit. I reluctantly cashed his check, but I am continually bothered by what I feel was an illegal act.

title: JERSEYANA
description: ON July 13, 1928 (65 years ago the day after tomorrow), John Carr, a mechanic in the little village of Chatsworth, knocked off work at the garage a bit early. He picked up his wife and his mother in the family car and drove out eight miles or so from the village to an isolated clearing beside the railroad tracks where local people knew the huckleberries were ready for picking.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FREE CONCERTS

title: Cottager's Life: For Young Set, Action Aplenty
description: THE slow-rolling vistas of the Adirondacks were a soothing sight, the mountain air sweet with sap. But what really raised my spirits as we approached our vacation home were less natural phenomena: the 40-foot, striped and star-trimmed statue of a perplexed Uncle Sam welcoming visitors to the Magic Forest, home of the area's only diving horse; the orange and yellow coils of the Steamin' Demon roller coaster snaking into the sky above The Great Escape Fun Park; the House of Frankenstein Wax Museum and Leonelli's Playland Arcade in the happy-to-be-honky-tonk village of Lake George. On a dreary afternoon, these would be the havens of our children's discontent; on a clear evening, like kiddie casinos, they would top off a day at the lake with bright lights and big fun, sending our little high rollers soundly to sleep in the back seat, pinball winnings and silly souvenirs wedged in their fists.

title: Russia's Nuclear Transition Ends Economic Security for Scientists
description: The first to protest were scientists at two top-secret Russian nuclear weapons centers who called thousands of their colleagues into the streets to draw the Government's attention to their demands for a living wage.

title: U.N. Calls Them 'Safe Areas'; Bosnians, a Sick Joke
description: As more than 1,000 French troops began arriving at a former Olympic complex here on Friday to begin a United Nations military buildup, snipers opened fire, wounding one in the neck. So began the process of making Sarajevo what the United Nations calls a "safe area."

title: Clinton Discovers That Even Japan Can Go For a Populist
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON and his Administration kept saying all week that this was a different kind of Group of Seven meeting. The lofty old talk of macroeconomic coordination and stable exchange rates was replaced by the mantras of the 90's: jobs and "structural reform," which means preparing governments, industries and workers geared to cold war prosperity for the new austerity.

title: Getting Medical Transportation in an Emergency
description: "EMERGENCY medical transportation is not a subject you want to learn about during an emergency," advises Peter Savage, a crisis-management adviser to corporations and security companies in Baltimore, and a former Foreign Service officer. Overseas, the anxiety of a sudden illness or injury may be intensified by difficulty with a foreign language, problems with the telephone and a lack of friends and family to help out.

title: Karen Darby and Matthew Scott
description: Karen Linda Darby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Darby Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Thompson Scott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Scott of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Malcolm Sutherland, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Middlesex School Chapel in Concord, Mass.

title:
ART;
Edward Albee's 'Ideas About Sculpture as an Idea'
description: THE quality that identifies an art connoisseur's acumen is known as the "eye," which defines a discernment of visual sensibility. Actually the term is more complex, denoting a commitment that goes deeper than style, often bespeaking a range of taste independent of fashion.

title: Comic Reversals in 'Arms and the Man'
description: EVEN at his most lighthearted, George Bernard Shaw didn't let an audience off lightly. Look at "Arms and the Man," by his own designation a "pleasant play," also an early and a minor one. It leaps into farce and crosses over into operetta, having inspired the libretto for "The Chocolate Soldier," but that doesn't disguise Shaw's insistence on rationality and his contempt for hypocrisy.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Harold E. Robles; Honoring Albert Schweitzer's Philosophy
description: HAROLD E. ROBLES is founder and president of the Albert Schweitzer Institute for the Humanities, which opened its headquarters in a building owned by Quinnipiac College in Hamden earlier this year.

title: Rethinking Deliberately Segregated Schools
description: WHEN New York State's highest court ruled last week that a school district created to accommodate Hasidic Jews was unconstitutional, it stoked a debate about whether specialized public schools represent a disturbing return to segregation or the only way to reach children whom public education has failed.

title: Punch, Conductor
description: To the Editor: The letters under "Tickets in France" (Letters, May 30) reminded me of a similar incident with a French conductor 30 years ago, on our honeymoon.

title: Natalie Wolcott, Hugo Williams
