description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 6,185,000, or 19 cents a share.

title: Review/Music; Kathleen Battle Sings a Custom-Made Cycle
description: One of the more doleful complaints among established composers is the relative ease of getting that first performance but the excruciating difficulty of arriving at a second or a third. "Honey and Rue," with music by Andre Previn to poems by Toni Morrison, has its own regenerative agent almost built into the piece. She is the American soprano Kathleen Battle: these songs were written for her, and she made sure they were at the center of the Boston Symphony's Tanglewood Festival opener at the Shed on Friday, when she was the featured soloist.

title: Marseilles Player's Admission
description: An Olympique Marseilles player has admitted being the middleman in a match-fixing scandal, changing his story yesterday after his wife had said the club's general manager ordered the alleged bribes.

title: Motorola Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Included a charge of $ 123,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: India Orders Safety Steps at Nuclear Plants
description: India's top nuclear safety agency has ordered periodic closings and detailed inspections of atomic power plants beginning July 31. The plan is a result of an investigation of an explosion at a nuclear plant in March, officials said.

description: RICHIE ADUBATO and RON ROTHSTEIN, both of whom had National Basketball Association head-coaching jobs of their own at the start of last season, were hired yesterday to be MIKE FRATELLO's assistants with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

description: Business at the South Street Diner picked up again as returning writers, editors and pressmen stocked up on the coffee and junk food that they needed to put out another issue of The New York Post.

title: BANC ONE WINS F.D.I.C. CONTRACT TO MANAGE 5,000 LOANS
description: The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it had been awarded a three-year management contract from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to manage about 5,000 commercial mortgage loans, valued at $1.7 billion. The Banc One Management and Consulting Corporation of Dallas, a unit of Banc One, the nation's eighth-largest banking company, will service the assets.

description: Now it is a five-team race in the American League East. Now it gets quite interesting for the Yankees. No pretenders allowed.

description: So now boxing, which has always had a sense of the absurd, has a sense of humor.

description: Trans World Airlines is expected to name a chairman as early as today: William R. Howard, the former chairman of Piedmont Airlines, who was widely credited with turning that carrier into one of the more successful airlines of the 1980's.

title: British Open Course Is Like Triple Bogey
description: No one who has competed over its bleak expanse of sand hills has ever been known to like Royal St. George's Golf Club, where the 122d British Open will begin on Thursday in Sandwich, England.

Candor, Conscience and Dr. Elders 1
description: "We cannot afford to let Dr. Elders do to America what she did to Arkansas," thundered Jan Parshall, a spokeswoman for Concerned Women of America, about President Clinton's nominee for Surgeon General. "She believes in comprehensive sexuality education beginning in kindergarten. These are children, may of whom don't know their colors and numbers yet, and she would propose violating their innocence and modesty."

title: Corrections
description: A Pulse chart yesterday in The Metro Section about the Port of New York and New Jersey mislabeled one component in the breakdown of the port's regional economic impact. The category that generates $2.1 billion in annual business through the port is trade-related services, not travel-related services.

description: Kipper's Game By Barbara Ehrenreich 310 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.

title: With Pratfalls, Chevy Chase's Plans For Late-Night TV
description: Looking to revive what he called the "cheeky persona" he created on "Saturday Night Live" 18 years ago, Chevy Chase said today that he was ready to enter the increasingly torrid competition for late-night television comedy viewers.

title: Police List Items From Search Of Home of Suspect in Killings
description: Nassau County prosecutors today released a chilling inventory of items they said had been found in searches of Joel Rifkin's bedroom, garage and pickup trucks. The list included books about serial murders and tying knots and 75 pieces of women's jewelry.

description: TOMORROW Broadway and Seventh Avenue will be closed between 42d and 47th Streets, from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. for the presentation of "On Broadway."

title: Chess
description: It was a small surprise for the strong Russian grandmaster Leonid Yudasin to win the Leon International Tournament in early June in northern Spain. Likewise for another strong Russian grandmaster, Aleksei Vyzmanavin, to take second place. They had to hold the former world champion Anatoly Karpov to a third-place tie to do it. But the greatest surprise of the event was that Peter Leko of Hungary shared third place with Karpov and the grandmaster Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria.

title: U.S. Bond Yields Hit 16-Year Low
description: The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond inched down to another 16-year low yesterday as traders and investors awaited reports today and tomorrow on inflation in June.

description: Sega Enterprises Ltd. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to license the Martin Marietta Corporation's military simulation technology for use in future Sega video games. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

description: Iraqis fighting Saddam Hussein say one American organization in particular helps keep alive their hopes that democracy has a chance in their country. China's dissidents, at home or in exile, know and bless its name -- the National Endowment for Democracy.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,642,000, or 13 cents a share, from change in accounting for income taxes.All per-share results give effect to the 3-for-2 stock split declared June 21, which is payable July 23 to shareholders of record July 9.

description: Paramount Communications Inc. yesterday priced $300 million in debt securities in two equal parts through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

description: "Hinunangan is a paradise created by God and destroyed by man," said Noe Dadap, who grew up on this rural coast.

Private Guards Cooperate in Public Policing
description: His 32 years in blue were well behind him when Richard Dillon was phoned at home by a top police official the night of Feb. 26. The World Trade Center had been bombed, and now law enforcement was reaching out to the private sector for help.

title: U.N. Again Resorts To Diplomatic Move In Iraq Arms Dispute
description: Postponing the use of force, the Clinton Administration and its main gulf war allies turned to diplomacy again today in their effort to defuse a confrontation over Iraqi missile sites.

title: Now Fielder Is Where He Knows He Belongs
description: Cecil Fielder, the player whose absence cast a giant shadow on last year's All-Star Game, arrived as a member of the 1993 team feeling welcomed.

title: Northern Japan Hit By 7.8-Level Quake; At Least 36 Killed
description: An earthquake under the sea followed by 17-foot tidal waves levelled several stretches of Japan's northern coast late Monday night, leaving 36 people known dead and several villages a jumble of shattered homes and overturned cars.

title: Lab Limits Plan to Give Company Discoveries
description: Bowing to criticism, the Scripps Research Institute has decided to cut back on a $300 million agreement that would have given all its discoveries for up to 20 years to a single pharmaceutical company, a Scripps spokesman said today.

title: CHEMICAL IS SAID TO BE IN TALKS TO BUY SHELL OIL CARDS
description: The Chemical Banking Company is in discussions to buy the Shell Oil Company's charge card portfolio, industry sources said. Chemical is seeking to acquire four million accounts from Shell, the sources said. Chemical would convert Shell card holders into Visa or Mastercard holders. The Shell card is used for buying gasoline and other products at the company's service stations.

title: Giants Get 2 More to Re-Enlist
description: The Giants might not have signed any of their 1993 draft choices yet -- plodding along in this area like most National Football League teams -- but they are moving along when it comes to their veteran players.

title: Coach Hospitalized After Crash
description: RICH HACKER, the Toronto Blue Jays' third-base coach, was in serious but stable condition yesterday with injuries sustained in an automobile accident near St. Louis, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: Davey Allison Is Injured In Air Crash
description: Davey Allison, the stock car racer, suffered severe head injuries yesterday when a helicopter he was flying crashed during a landing attempt on the infield of the Talladega SuperSpeedway in Alabama.

title: Machine Technology (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Heading to Florida, Nearer the Homeland
description: After 18 years in the nerve-grinder that is New York, Jean-Claude Sanon decided that he had had enough. So four years ago he sold his home, quit his job as an assistant manager at an insurance company and moved his wife and two children to Miami.

title: Knopf to Publish Book By Bush and Scowcroft
description: Alfred A. Knopf announced yesterday that it planned to publish a book by former President George Bush and his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, in early 1995. Ashbel Green, a vice president and senior editor at Knopf, said the book would diverge from being a standard Presidential memoir in that it would deal exclusively with foreign policy during the Bush years.

title: Time Warner Unit Prices Notes
description: Time Warner Entertainment LP, a unit of Time Warner Inc., priced $1 billion of 40-year notes yesterday through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.

title: Drysdale Services a Tribute to His Humanity
description: Don Drysdale Jr., 6, walked into his father's memorial service this morning and right away found a familiar face: Sandy Koufax. The child, otherwise known as "D. J.," said hello, and Koufax waved a pinky back.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Ticket to Ride If Sydney Can Do It, Why Not New York?
description: That I am not Australian was obvious to the driver of the bus I boarded in Sydney a few weeks ago. The hand that extended the fare was timid; the voice that asked how many stops before Circular Quay was untouched by that distinctive accent known as "Strine." "Are you planning to use the buses much while you're here?" he asked when we reached the harbor. "Or ride the ferries? Because if you are, you'll save a lot of money if you buy a pass."

title: Intel Posts Strong Profits but Stock Slips
description: Investors took shares of the Intel Corporation on a bumpy ride yesterday after the world's largest computer chip producer reported record second-quarter results and forecast strong sales and profit margins for the rest of the year.

title: A Mug's Game With Iraqi Missiles
description: Saddam Hussein is at it again. It seemed that diplomats were about to resolve the dispute over Iraq's missile test sites when Mr. Hussein yanked the rug out from under them. No, said the Iraqi dictator, he would not accept United Nations surveillance cameras at the sites. Nor would he allow the U.N. to seal the sites temporarily.

title: ANDREA IN DISTRIBUTION DEAL FOR NOISE-REDUCTION KITS
description: The Andrea Electronics Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, has signed its first distribution agreement for its noise-reduction products. Technology Services Group Inc. of Lansdale, Pa., will have the right to distribute two Andrea Electronics products using its active noise cancellation technology to the seven Bell regional telephone companies for use in public telephones. The agreement requires Technology Services to buy $10 million in noise-reduction kits in three years to keep its distribution rights. Andrea's stock soared $9.625 a share yesterday, to $38.50, on the American Stock Exchange, where its 33.3 percent gain was the best of the day.

title: Jordan Is the Wrong Star at the All-Stars
description: "Michael's pitching!" a vendor at Oriole Park gushed in excited delight.

title: G.O.P. Only Needs To Court Black Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Tariff Deal Called the Bigger Success
description: President Clinton's agreement with the Japanese on a process for trade talks was a political victory, but it will not mean as much for American businesses and workers as the global tariff reduction deal struck a few days earlier, business executives, economists, legislators and officials said today.

title: More Turmoil in the Drug Industry
description: Top executives have quit at five of the 25 largest drug companies this year, citing a variety of reasons. But whatever their reasons -- personal, philosophical or old-fashioned power clashes -- they have left at a time of industry turmoil.

title: Stock Issue In Australia
description: Investors bid up shares in Woolworths Ltd., Australia's largest food retailer, by 15 percent when the company's stock was traded today for the first time after being heavily oversubscribed at the issue price of 2.45 Australian dollars.

title: Ocean Pioneer Mines Energy That Is Cool, Clean and Free
description: DR. JOHN P. CRAVEN has made a living by taming a part of the planet that few people think much about and almost no one visits: the bottom of the deep blue sea.

title: Electrocon International Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $ 1,262,622, or 16 cents a share.

title: Cable Group Selects Deutsch/Dworin
description: The National Cable Television Association in Washington said yesterday that it had chosen a New York agency, Deutsch/Dworin, to handle its $5 million account, handled by Bozell New York for the last two years.

title: LABOR CONCESSIONS GAINED BY MURDOCH RESTORE THE POST
description: Employees of The New York Post, shut out of the building for two days, returned to put out today's issue after most of the newspaper's unions gave Rupert Murdoch the $6.2 million in concessions he demanded.

title: 3 Clothing Retailers Name Agencies
description: Three clothing retailers said yesterday that they had selected agencies to handle their accounts.

title: Site in Turkey Yields Oldest Cloth Ever Found
description: IN a village near the headwaters of the Tigris River 9,000 years ago, people descended from hunter-gatherers were planting and harvesting wheat and barley. They were among the world's first farmers and over hundreds of years had settled down in houses of some substance. At the same time, by adapting their basket-making technology, they began weaving crude fabrics, which are the earliest known examples of cloth ever produced.

title: Khmer Rouge Hint They May End Rebellion
description: The president of the Khmer Rouge suggested today that the Maoist-inspired rebels were willing to call off their 14-year-old insurgency if they were guaranteed a formal role in Cambodia's new coalition Government.

title: Jack Bittner, 76, Actor and Singer On Stage and TV
description: Jack Bittner, an actor and singer in theater, television and the opera for half a century, died on June 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: When They Can't Live in a Hospital or Outside; Budget Sacrifice
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a 16-year-old boy arrested in the killing of a mother of eight misstated the residence of the suspect, Derek Anderson, based on information supplied by the police. Mr. Anderson lives in the Langston Hughes Apartments.

title: Making Home Dialysis Easier
description: For more than half a million people around the world suffering from chronic kidney failure, life is measured in blocks of time spent hooked to kidney dialysis machines. Survival depends on either an organ transplant or regular and frequent dialysis, a process that mimics the kidneys' cleansing of wastes and deadly toxins from the blood.

title: Personal Health
description: CONCERNS about fragile bones have joined worries about being overweight and at risk for heart disease in prompting millions of women near or past menopause to start exercising. Having heard that exercise can help maintain and even increase bone mass, they are walking, running, swimming, cycling and even lifting weights to ward off the fractures caused by osteoporosis.

title: Judge Allows Stricter Rules on Emissions for New York
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he was wrong in January when he barred New York State from adopting California's strict rules on air pollution from cars -- rules aimed at eliminating the kind of smog that blanketed the region last week.

title: Portrait of Boxer: Artemiev to Be Honored
description: SERGEI ARTEMIEV, the Russian boxer who suffered a cerebral hemorrhage in a March 21 fight against CARL GRIFFITH in Atlantic City, will see his portrait installed tomorrow night at the Manhattan Brewing Company restaurant on Thompson Street.

title: A Summertime Leg Up on a Career in the Arts
description: FOR the last few years, the Institute for Arts and Humanities Education has made a valiant effort to compensate for a decline in arts education in public schools. The institute offers a summer project of arts training for talented high school students, many with relatively little background in the arts.

title: Atmel Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE MIDWEST FLOODING: Fighting the River; Along the Levee As People Fight A Tireless River
description: For 14 days now, through thunderstorms, sweltering heat, swarms of mosquitoes and never-ending mud, the people here have been working side by side around the clock in a war against the elements.

title: BUSH SUBPOENAED IN BANKER'S TRIAL
description: Former President George Bush was served with a subpoena today to appear as a witness at the trial of an Atlanta banker accused of making nearly $5 billion in unauthorized loans to finance Iraq's arms buildup.

title: Review/Rock; Who's Still Rocking? 'Tommy's' Father
description: Pete Townshend was wearing a black suit and white shirt, buttoned to the collar, when he performed at the Beacon Theater on Monday night. He used a third of his three-hour show to perform his latest album-length musical theater work, "Psychoderelict" (Atlantic). But with an electric guitar in hand, the 48-year-old songwriter was still a rocker, singing with fervor, duckwalking and jumping around and, at one point, accidentally careening into a speaker cabinet as he bounded across the stage. The first hard-rock pioneer to win a Tony Award has not succumbed to middle-aged decorum.

title: Comic Reversals in 'Arms and the Man'
description: EVEN at his most lighthearted, George Bernard Shaw didn't let an audience off lightly. Look at "Arms and the Man," by his own designation a "pleasant play," also an early and a minor one. It leaps into farce and crosses over into operetta, having inspired the libretto for "The Chocolate Soldier," but that doesn't disguise Shaw's insistence on rationality and his contempt for hypocrisy.

title: Miscellany
description: * The 1993 Clio Awards ceremony has been rescheduled to Sept. 13 at the City Center Theater in Manhattan. The deadline for entries has been extended until tomorrow. * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, reported that magazine advertising pages for June totaled 13,364.5, down one-tenth of a percent from June 1992. For the first six months of 1993, pages totaled 81,024.8, up 2.5 percent from the first six months of 1992.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: CHRONICLE
description: When DAVID S. GOTTESMAN took over last month as the chairman of the board at Yeshiva University, he was simply upholding family tradition.

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York named Korey, Kay & Partners, New York, to handle advertising and promotional projects meant to combat the recent spate of sexual assaults in swimming pools known as "whirlpooling." Korey, Kay, which has handled other projects for the city, will introduce a print, radio and eventually a television campaign carrying such themes as "Whirlpool ain't cool; Don't dis your sis, and Don't dis yourself." * Childhope, New York, to Merkley Newman Harty, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the nonprofit organization.

title: When They Can't Live in a Hospital or Outside
description: To the Editor:

title: Newspaper Guild Once Again Finds Itself Left Out
description: When 10 unions of The New York Post made their deals with Rupert Murdoch on Monday, it was no surprise in the newspaper industry that there was one newspaper union that was left out.

title: Forget the Tiananmen Fixation
description: The U.S. should stop punishing China for the massacre of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. China is too important to make this the pivot of our policy.

title: ProGroup Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Office Depot reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 common stock split in June 1993.

title: In Cuba, Baseball Is Major but Not Major League
description: Pedro Jova Perez shaded his eyes and shifted his weight in a creative but futile attempt to avoid the heat. Then the Cuban baseball manager stepped into a shaded area beneath a news media tent and braced for an avalanche of reporters' questions.

title: Mother Nature and Ol' Man River
description: Weeks of rainfall in the Midwest have flooded countless acres of open farmland and even cities and towns supposedly protected by dams and levees. Flooding causes more damage each year than other natural catastrophes, and this year's in middle America will set a record of its own when it finally crests.

title: Horoscopes for Humanity?
description: The future can be foretold! And not just tomorrow's events, but humanity's distant fate, according to a Princeton University cosmologist, J. Richard Gott 3d. He claims that within a few centuries, or at most several thousand years, there is a 95 percent chance that humans will become extinct. In an article in the May 27 issue of Nature, arguably the world's leading scientific journal, Dr. Gott wrote that this forecast can be made on the basis of pure mathematics alone.

title: A Free Show On Broadway
description: "Broadway on Broadway," the second annual free outdoor concert in Times Square, will begin at 11:30 A.M. today on the traffic island between 43d and 44th Streets on Broadway. The hourlong concert will feature stars from 16 Broadway shows accompanied by a 28-piece orchestra.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football National Football League BUFFALO BILLS -- Signed Mike Devlin, center; Sebastian Savage, defensive back; John Parella, defensive tackle; Corbin Lacina, guard; Chris Luneberg, tackle; Pat Akos, tight end; and Russell Copeland and Willie Harris, wide receivers.

title: A New Button Can Take a Beating
description: Buttons are the bane of the $2.5 billion men's shirt business. Never mind fine fabrics, microscopic stitching and exquisite tailoring: If shirt buttons crack under pressure or the heat of commercial laundering, that is what customers will remember.

title: Unitrin Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected a $ 39.9 million after-tax charge for the adoption of SFAS No. 106.

title: Telemedia Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Not Quite Hog Heaven
description: Lillehammer's Olympic organizers have dropped plans to make two million disposable plates from potato starch and then feed them to pigs.

title: Preserve Redwoods For Future Inspiration
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEYANA
description: ON July 13, 1928 (65 years ago the day after tomorrow), John Carr, a mechanic in the little village of Chatsworth, knocked off work at the garage a bit early. He picked up his wife and his mother in the family car and drove out eight miles or so from the village to an isolated clearing beside the railroad tracks where local people knew the huckleberries were ready for picking.

title: MCI's Blimp Unlikely to Crash
description: While the crash of a Pizza Hut blimp in New York last week deflated the chain's Bigfoot pizza promotion, the MCI Communications Corporation said a blimp would continue to soar in a campaign for its new collect-phoning service.

title: U.S. Embassy Strikes a Sour Note in Bulgaria
description: Problems between the United States and Bulgaria used to arise from big-power hostility, magnified by Bulgaria's tendency to follow Soviet suggestions beyond minimal requirements. Now a conflict has arisen from Bulgaria's eagerness to please the United States at any cost.

title: Guilty Plea in Fraud Over Check Cashing
description: Robert M. Felzenberg, the president of a large New Jersey check-cashing company, pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to Federal fraud charges involving the loss of $30 million.

title:
DANCE;
Ballet Troupe's Signature Is Durability
description: UNLIKE so many of her counterparts in the dance world, Carolyn Clark, the artistic and executive director of the New Jersey Ballet Company, manages to keep her company coming up with performances instead of problems. Despite occasional pay cuts and shortened contracts, the West Orange-based company continues fulfilling Miss Clark's avowed mission to provide audiences throughout the state with top-quality ballet.

title: Hostetler Shoulders Load Without Looking Over Shoulder
description: Jeff Hostetler wore his Super Bowl XXV shorts to lunch today. He looked like a New York Giant, but this could hardly have been the Giants: Phil Simms and he were not connected at the hip.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC., Sunnyvale, Calif., has begun construction of a semiconductor manufacturing plant costing up to $1 billion in Austin, Tex. SIEMENS A.G., Munich, Germany, sold part of its tube business to the French electrical company Thomson CSF. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 4 Jet Draft Picks in Accord
description: The Jets yesterday said that they had come to terms with four of their nine draft choices, including their second-round pick, Coleman Rudolph, a defensive end from Georgia Tech.

title: Panel Submits List of Nominees for New York's Highest Court
description: A special state panel today gave Gov. Mario M. Cuomo a list of six nominees to fill a vacancy on the state's highest court. The list includes four appellate division justices, a Brooklyn law school expert on criminal law and a former New York City police officer.

title: Gilding the Berry for a Satisfying Finale to Summer Meals
description: PART of the pleasure of berries is their refreshing fragrance in warm weather.

title: U.N. Issue, Again: The Rein on Hussein
description: Iraq may be quarreling with the United Nations over arms inspections again, but the focus of debate has shifted in a way that reflects the monitors' success in shutting down the country's nuclear, biological and chemical weapons programs.

title: JAN BELL MARKETING TO REPURCHASE 5% OF ITS SHARES
description: Jan Bell Marketing Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back 5 percent, or 1.3 million, of its 25.9 million outstanding shares within the next year. The company, based in Sunrise, Fla., distributes jewelry to discount warehouses like Sam's Club, Members Only and Pace Membership Warehouse. Shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $12, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Voices of Japan: Anger at the Old Politicians and Skepticism About the New
description: From the presidents of Japan's largest corporations to small shopkeepers, everyone in Japan seems to be wary over the recent political turmoil.

title: Nigerian's Ruse Fails
description: To the Editor:

title: Hilton Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 3.4 million, or 7 cents a share, from adoption of accounting changes.

title: Sports of The Times; The 'Yards' Plays Small And Loud
description: In the galaxy of last night's All-Star Game, the ball park was as much an attraction as the players. Oriole Park at Camden Yards, with a red-brick warehouse towering behind right field, has a look that is so old, it's new. But if you want to know what a ball park is really like, ask a pitcher.

title: INSIDE
description: Shooting in Bronx Leaves One Dead And 4 Injured

title: Merfin Hygienic reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Coffee Hits a 6-Month High On Reports of Cold in Brazil
description: Coffee prices jumped to a six-month high yesterday amid traders' concerns that near-freezing temperatures in Brazil, the world's largest producer, would damage next year's crop.

title: G.M. Plans To Increase 1994 Prices
description: Amid an increasingly robust automotive market, the General Motors Corporation said today that it would raise the prices of its 1994 models by an average of 1.5 percent for cars and 2.2 percent for trucks.

title: Is 42d St. Development in Hands of 'Professional Crackpots'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Lynch Net at a High; Paine Webber Up Sharply
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage firm, yesterday reported record second-quarter earnings led by double-digit increases in income from trading, commissions, interest and dividends income and asset management.

title: That's a Drift of Fisherfolk, if You Please
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: POACHING seafood in a court bouillon is one of the oldest techniques of French cooking. The classic court bouillon imparts a subtle, herby flavor to all kinds of seafood. The carrots and onions give a touch of sweetness, and even the pinch of cayenne plays an important role in the overall balance.

title: What the AIDS Czar Can't Do
description: By finally settling on Kristine M. Gebbie, President Clinton made good his campaign pledge to install a czar -- that is, a White House AIDS Coordinator -- for the fight against acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.

title: The Pop Life
description: Rod Stewart

title: Big 3 Rebuffed on Minivans
description: Detroit's Big Three auto makers lost another round today in their attempt to convince trade officials that the Japanese were selling minivans below cost in the United States.

title: Eating Well
description: ON May 27, a bank-branch manager in Redmond, Wash., was taken to the emergency room of the local hospital. He had not slept more than an hour on each of the previous 10 nights and had been acting so irrationally -- preaching about visions of rapture and the true meaning of the Bible, screaming at his family -- that he had been locked out of his office.

title: Times Names Editors to Senior Posts
description: Appointments to four senior editing positions at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the executive editor.

title: Judge Reaffirms Award to Reynolds
description: A federal judge in Columbus, Ohio, reaffirmed yesterday the $27.4 million he awarded to BUTCH REYNOLDS, the 400-meter world-record holder, who was banned by track's world governing body for allegedly using steroids.

title: School Reform Gridlock
description: School reform was the buzzword phrase in education for the past decade. But how much of the activity centered on schools brings about real reform? Not much, judging from a recent study by the Public Agenda Foundation and the Charles F. Kettering Foundation.

title: Red, White and Blue, Almost Out of the Blue
description: Surprise, surprise. Only a half-dozen years ago, the male selection of American tennis prodigies offered all the promise of a black hole; this year a half-dozen of these wunderkids reached the Round of 16 at the most intimidating Grand Slam in the world, Wimbledon.

title: After a Short Rest, Tour de France Riders Will Head for the Alps
description: Out there, to the south, under sinister skies, lie the Alps. Only their foothills are visible from Grenoble, the southeastern city that was the hub of the Tour de France today, a day off for the racers as they moved downcountry from Lorraine by nearly every known conveyance except bicycles.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times yesterday misstated the year that Mickey Mantle of the New York Yankees was a rookie. It was 1951, not 1953.

title: Hi-Fidelity is Enlisted In Long-Distance Battle
description: It may not strike rock-and-roll fans as news, but A.T.& T. announced yesterday that it was introducing a "major breakthrough" in sound quality for ordinary long-distance phone calls: more volume and more bass.

title: CELESTIAL SEASONINGS STOCK UP 46.25% IN FIRST TRADING
description: The stock of Celestial Seasonings Inc. jumped 46.25 percent yesterday in its first day of Nasdaq trading. The shares of the herbal-tea maker, which is based in Boulder, Colo., closed at $29.25 on volume of more than three million shares. On Monday, the company raised $35 million through its initial public offering of 1.9 million shares -- slightly less than half the company -- priced at $20 each. Celestial's chief executive, Mo Siegel, and Vestar Capital Partners, which bought the company from Kraft in 1988, will still own about 31 percent of the company. Employees own the remaining shares.

title: Jennifer Convertibles Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 208,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 482,000, or 11 cents a share, in the 9 months.

title: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: The Overview; MORE RAIN SLOWS DES MOINES BATTLE AGAINST THE FLOOD
description: Torrential rains drenched the Iowa capital early today, swelling already bloated rivers and slowing the effort to clear out the contaminated water system that has brought the city to a virtual halt.

title: Unless Situation Improves, U.N. Should Quit Bosnia, Mediator Says
description: The United Nations mediator for the Balkans said today that he might have no choice but to recommend the withdrawal of United Nations forces from Bosnia and Herzegovina unless the situation improved.

title: Bridge
description: An unfortunate combination of circumstances have combined to deprive two players from the New York metropolitan area of world ranking in the Epson World Pairs held on June 4. Julius Fields of Manhattan and Calvin Morris of Rochdale Village, Queens, had a big score at a game in Rochdale Village played under the auspices of the American Bridge Association.

title: U.N. Says It Will Press Effort to Disarm Somalis
description: A day after angry mobs killed four Western journalists in retaliation for a United Nations military strike against a Somali clan leader, senior United Nations officials in Mogadishu said the United Nations would press ahead with its goal of disarming the capital and increasing its forces as it searched for a the fugitive clan leader.

title: One Killed And 4 Hurt In Shooting
description: A man wielding a 9-millimeter pistol opened fire in front of a South Bronx bodega yesterday, killing the young man with whom he had been arguing and wounding four bystanders, the police said.

title: AT DINNER WITH -- Mark Shields; With Sidekick Gone, The Pundit Next Door Still Guards the Left
description: MARK SHIELDS has trouble talking about "the separation."

title: With Congress Back in Town, Supporters of Budget Bill Gear Up
description: With Congress back from a 10-day recess and most Administration officials home from the economic summit in Tokyo, the Government's top policy makers began planning today for the final burst of energy that they hope will lead to enactment of the President's budget.

title: June Drop In Producer Price Index
description: Held down by persistent weakness in economic growth, prices received by American producers fell by three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the biggest monthly decline in more than two years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: U.S. Is in a Quandary as Chinese Wait Off Shore
description: Ten days after the Coast Guard stopped three ships trying to smuggle 659 Chinese into California, senior officials in the Clinton Administration continued to argue over solutions -- none attractive -- to the increasingly difficult and embarrassing situation.

title: New York Will Help Pay for Buffalo Arena
description: The State of New York kicked in $25 million yesterday toward a new arena in downtown Buffalo that the Sabres say they need to remain in the city.

title: 4 Cornerstones of Harlem Life Are Designated as Landmarks
description: Four cornerstones of Harlem's spiritual, social and religious life became official New York City landmarks yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: OVERHEARD by R. Chester Redhead in an outdoor cafe on upper Madison Avenue. Mother to boy, about 6: "Hurry and finish your soup before it gets dirty."

title: Critic's Notebook; Upstaging a New Lloyd Webber Musical
description: In the narrow world of British show business, little short of an earthquake could upstage the opening of a new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical. But as it bizarrely happened, just such a tremor shook the West End on Monday. Hours before the opening of Mr. Lloyd Webber's "Sunset Boulevard," the newspapers gave big play to the unexpected announcement that the West End production of the Broadway hit "City of Angels" would close after only a four-month run.

title: Traffic Alert
description: TODAY

title: Now Older and Wiser, Dickerson Starts Anew
description: For 10 pro football seasons, Eric Dickerson's career has alternated between brilliance and turbulence. He has run with the best and complained with the worst. Something or someone always seemed to upset him and overshadow his big performances.

title: Tiverton Petroleum reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Limited Has Deal on Unit
description: The Limited Inc., which operates several specialty apparel store chains including Express, the Limited and Victoria's Secret, said yesterday that it had a tentative agreement to sell a 60 percent stake in its Brylane direct mail division. The buyer is an affiliate of Freeman Spogli & Company, a Los Angeles-based merchant banking company.

title: Federal Express Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 55,943,000 from an accounting adjustment.c-Net lossFederal Express Corp. attributed the improved performance in its latest fourth quarter to its strategy to replace less-profitable intra-European shipment and non-definite-time air freight with the company's time-definite International Priority packages and International Expressfreight.The company noted that its international operating loss for the latest fourth quarter had narrowed to $ 25.4 million on revenues of $ 539.2 million, from $ 53.2 million on revenues of $ 536.1 million for the same period a year ago.

title: BIG RISE IN BIRTHS OUTSIDE WEDLOCK
description: Highlighting the changes sweeping the American family, the Census Bureau today reported sharp increases in the number of women who become mothers without marrying, an increase that was particularly steep among educated and professional women.

title: Wheat In Your Beer? Thirst-Killer From Europe Catches On
description: A SUMMERTIME thirst for beer usually leads to the nearest frosty can or bottle. But beer drinkers with a taste for tradition are beginning to discover the extra refreshment in wheat beers, long the classic summer beers of Germany and Belgium.

title: Chief Executive Is Resigning From First Boston
description: In a sign of continuing turmoil at the firm, the CS First Boston Group Inc. announced late yesterday that Archibald Cox Jr., the president and chief executive of the First Boston Corporation, had submitted his resignation, effective Sept. 1.

title: It's Another American Midsummer Night's Dream
description: The ghosts of Hank Aaron, Willie Mays and Roberto Clemente shuddered again tonight as the National League limply lost the All-Star Game for the sixth successive season.

title: REEBOK DISCLOSES A NEW STOCK BUYBACK PROGRAM
description: Saying its stock price does not reflect the value of the business, Reebok International Ltd. disclosed yesterday that it would buy back up to $200 million of its shares. The shoe and apparel company, based in Stoughton, Mass., said the repurchase would be in addition to the $200 million buyback program begun a year ago. Under that program, it has already bought 5.6 million shares for about $183 million, the company said. Reebok has 86.4 million shares outstanding. Reebok stock closed at $27.625 a share, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 490 NEW YORK TELEPHONE MANAGERS FACE LAYOFFS
description: As part of continuing efforts to cut costs and become more competitive, the New York Telephone Company told 490 managers yesterday that they might be laid off. The 490 represent 6.3 percent of New York Telephone's 7,700 managers.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
Chubb Builds Emergency Trade Center
description: The international insurer Chubb & Son is building an emergency financial trading center for brokerage firms and banks at the Metrotech Center, a high-tech office park in Brooklyn. It is the first of six such centers Chubb plans globally.

title: Careful Player Moves Closer To the Top at Bear Stearns
description: James E. Cayne's company biography devotes 10 lines to his achievements at Bear Stearns, 13 lines to his achievements at the bridge table. Yesterday, the sum of those achievements helped him to succeed Alan C. (Ace) Greenberg as the company's chief executive.

title: Aspin Reported To Have Settled On Gay Policy
description: Defense Secretary Les Aspin will recommend to President Clinton that homosexuals be allowed to serve in the military as long as they do not make public or private declarations of their sexual orientation, gay-rights advocates said they were told today by senior Pentagon officials.

title: Abrupt Death In Abortion Is Investigated
description: Criminal and civil investigations have begun into the death of a 33-year-old Bronx woman who died during an abortion last Friday.

title: People
description: * Wally Weis was named executive vice president and chief creative officer at Dunn Reber Glenn Marz Advertising, Las Vegas and Reno, Nev., succeeding Bob Browand, who left. Mr. Weis, who will be based in Las Vegas, was previously a senior copy writer at Ally & Gargano, New York. * Irwin Kornfeld was named associate publisher of advertising and marketing at Playboy magazine, New York, succeeding James Spanfeller, who was recently named associate publisher at Inc. magazine, New York. Mr. Kornfeld, who was also named a senior vice president for Playboy's publishing division, was previously director of advertising programs at Forbes magazine, New York.

title: Hans Hopf, 76, Tenor In Wagner Repertory
description: Hans Hopf, a German tenor who specialized in Wagnerian roles during a long career at the Munich Opera, died on June 25 near his home in Germany. He was 76.

title: Eagle Precision reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hartsbeesfontein Journal; South African Commandos: Vigilant, or Vigilante?
description: The sky was a splash of stars above the cold African prairie. A huge orange moon hovered at the horizon.

title: John Codella, 64, Who Helped Build Intelligence Society
description: John J. Codella, the New York public-relations man who brought American Mensa to the country's attention and watched it grow, died on Thursday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 64 and lived in Marlton, N.J.

title: Health-Care Pitch Is Given a Preview By Hillary Clinton
description: Speaking at a heavily scripted community forum here, Hillary Rodham Clinton today previewed the sales pitch she will take on the road this fall to make her case for extensive changes in the nation's health-care system.

title: Notre Dame's Coaching Legends of the Fall
description: The first thing LOU HOLTZ wants you to know is that he really doesn't think he belongs on Moose Krause's list of Notre Dame's greatest football coaches.

title: Abandoned By Clinton, She Finds Acceptance
description: Lani Guinier, the lawyer who only a month ago was jettisoned by an embarrassed President Clinton as his choice to be the Justice Department's civil rights chief, was embraced as a newfound hero today at the N.A.A.C.P.'s annual conference.

title: TWO GERMANS DENY A ROLE IN ATTACK
description: Two Germans who went on trial today for destroying a Holocaust memorial at a former Nazi concentration camp told the court they had nothing to do with the attack.

title: Lukens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,497,000 and $ 1,513,000 in the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included a charge of $ 65,901,000 which represents a charge of $ 67,222,000 for SFAS No. 106 for post-retirement benefits less a credit of $ 1,321,000 for SFAS No. 109 for income taxes.c-Net incomed-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 3,506,000 in the quarter and $ 4,641,000 in the 6 months.The company said the results for the latest quarter and 6 months included the Washington Stainless Group, which was acquired on April 24, 1992.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about airplanes that pull advertising banners over beaches misstated the business commitments of the Aero-Tag Company. The company has been fully booked some weekends, but is not booked for the entire summer. A caption repeated the error.

title: MDC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results are in Candadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about layoffs at the Electric Boat Company in Groton, Conn., misstated the location of the nearby Navy submarine base. It is also in Groton, not New London.

title: David Kirschenbaum, 30, Leader Against Violence to Homosexuals
description: David E. Kirschenbaum, a leader against violence directed at gay people because of their sexual orientation, died on Sunday at home in Manhattan, at the age of 30.

title: International Paper reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for extinguishment of debt of $ 2,000,000 in the quarter and $ 4,000,000 in the 6 months, and the 6 months also include a charge of $ 50,000,000 for change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Nationwide Health Properties Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cuomo Names Ex-F.B.I. Agent Inspector General
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today appointed a former F.B.I. agent to be New York State's top investigator of government corruption.

title: Davey Allison, Stock-Car Driver, Dies at 32 After Helicopter Crash
description: Davey Allison, the 1992 Daytona 500 winner and a member of one of stock-car racing's most prominent families, died yesterday at Carraway Methodist Medical Center in Birmingham, Ala., of head injuries suffered in the crash of a helicopter. He was 32.

title: Thinking Small -- A special report; Is Smaller Better? Educators Now Say Yes for High School
description: The big urban high school, a place of opportunity, anonymity and most recently fear, is under siege by a growing army of critics who want to abolish it.

title: Food Notes
description: Eating U.S.A.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO. (N)
description: Led by its finance, broadcast, appliance, electrical equipment and plastics divisions, the General Electric Company reported a 9.7 percent increase in second-quarter earnings, to $1.33 billion.

title: A Cellular Call
description: Shares of Motorola Inc. have surged since late January, from $51 to a 52-week high of $90 in intraday trading yesterday. Investors have been drawn to the company's strength in cellular communications. On Monday, Motorola posted a rise in second-quarter earnings, to 83 cents a share from 54 cents for the quarter a year earlier.

title: Medicus Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said that the investments made during the first three fiscal periods of 1993 have had the anticipated effect on revenue and earnings performance, as fourth-quarter results demonstrate.

title:
ART;
Factory Work and Combat
description: SINCE the history of Paterson has been intertwined with industry, the Paterson Museum is an ideal location for the exhibition "Produce for Victory," subtitled "Posters on the American Home Front 1941-45."

title: Stein Investigators Need More Time
description: The National Hockey League said the legal team investigating former league president GIL STEIN'S appointment to the Hockey Hall of Fame needs more time.

title: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: Effects on Business; U.S. Economy Too Vast To Be Hurt by Flooding
description: For all the spectacular devastation of the Mississippi flood of 1993, the impact on the huge American economy is likely to be very small, many experts say.

title: A Versatile Marinade
description: A Chinese-style marinade is good not only for lamb, but for pork and beef as well. It penetrates the meat quickly and adds a lot of flavor.

title: On the Trail of the Mob, All Roads Lead to Food
description: FORGET about the plethora of legal and sociological reasons offered for the decline of America's Mafia. Yes, a soupcon of credit is due to unrelenting crackdowns by the F.B.I. and other investigators, but the underlying cause of the mob's deterioration is more simple: the modern mobster talks too freely and eats too prodigiously.

title: Jefferies Sizzles, While Mets Burn
description: It has been two and a half years since Gregg Jefferies wore a Mets uniform, and the repercussions of what his presence meant to the team still fly.

title: A Look at the North American Pact's Added Costs
description: As the Clinton Administration and Congress grapple with the political problems of the North American Free Trade Agreement this summer, one issue keeps coming up: the potential cost of the pact to the Federal budget.

title: 97 Japanese Reported Killed By Quake and Huge Waves
description: As rescue workers and survivors dug through the rubble of coastal communities devastated by Japan's strongest earthquake in 25 years, Japanese authorities said today that 97 people died and upwards of 167 may be missing, many of them victims of towering waves and raging fires.

title: First Fidelity Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,373,000, or 3 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.The bank said that during this year's second quarter it acquired Northeast Bancorp Inc. and its principal subsidiary, Union Trust Co. The results of Northeast Bancorp and its subsidiary are included from April 30 to June 30.

title: C.I.A. Officer Signed Visa For Sheik, U.S. Says
description: In an odd twist to a bizarre tale, American officials said today that the diplomat at the United States Embassy in Khartoum who signed off on Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman's request to enter the United States was an officer of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 EARTHQUAKE TOLL RISES Japanese authorities said that 97 people died and more than 167 may be missing in Japan's strongest earthquake in 25 years. Many of the dead fell victim to towering waves or raging fires. A1 JAPAN: VOICE OF THE PEOPLE The Japanese are looking toward parliamentary elections with a mixture of hope and dread, but some common threads run through the opinions that they voice. A8

title: Value Merchants reports earnings for 13wks to May 1
description: The company changed its reporting period to reflect the predominant retail reporting calendar. Year-ago quarter consisted of 16 weeks.

title: Gibson (C.R.) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Robert McCarthy, 83, A Founder of Law Firm
description: Robert Joseph McCarthy, a founding partner of the law firm of McCarthy, Fingar, Donovan, Drazen & Smith in White Plains, died on Saturday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 83.

title: A Fat Drug: Hopes and Reality
description: A NOVEL type of diet drug has entered the final stretch of clinical testing in the United States and Europe, and, as might be expected with any new strategy on the weight-control front, rumors about its prowess have been greatly exaggerated.

title: T.W.A. Chooses a New Chairman
description: Trans World Airlines confirmed yesterday that it had named William R. Howard, the former chairman of Piedmont Airlines, to be its chairman when the carrier emerges from bankruptcy protection.

title: Marlboro Billboard at Shea Is Target of Group's Lawsuit
description: Opponents of smoking hung yet another target on the tobacco industry yesterday, when a coalition of plaintiffs sued the City of New York in State Supreme Court, demanding the removal of a billboard in Shea Stadium advertising Marlboro cigarettes.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'MANITOBA SOUND'

title: When They Can't Live in a Hospital or Outside; A Necessary Law
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Racist, But Hey, It's Disney
description: Most Americans now know better than to use nasty generalizations about ethnic or religious groups. Disparaging stereotypes -- the avaricious Jew, the sneaky Chinese, the dumb Irishman, the lazy black person -- are now so unacceptable that it's a shock even to hear them mentioned.

title: John Harvard, Meet B. B. King
description: Harvard University is investing $10 million or so to help spread the blues.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO. (N)
description: Second-quarter earnings at the Bank of New York increased 49 percent, higher than Wall Street forecasts for the country's 17th-largest bank.

title: High Hopes in Manchester, England
description: International Olympic Committee President JUAN ANTONIO SAMARANCH lifted the hopes of Manchester, England, yesterday when he toured the city and said its chances of winning the bid to be host of the 2000 Olympic Games were "very, very high."

title: John E. Bordley, 90, Professor and Expert On Treating the Deaf
description: Dr. John Earle Bordley, a Johns Hopkins researcher and educator who worked to improve the treatment of the deaf and hard of hearing, died Monday at his home in Baltimore. He was 90.

title: Metropolitan Golf Report
description: JAL Big Apple Classic The Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament that starts tomorrow at the Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., will have an international field, including 31 foreign players from 12 countries and five continents.

title: In America; Dodgers Deja Vu Again
description: Compared with George Steinbrenner, Walter O'Malley was Mr. Nice Guy.

title: Legent Stock Loses One-Third of Its Value
description: Shares of the Legent Corporation lost more than a third of their value yesterday after the mainframe software developer said third-quarter earnings would fall far short of Wall Street expectations.

title: We All Lose Big at Student-Loan 'Casino'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; A Dark Meditation on Death by Martha Clarke
description: Past and present were united here this week on an unusual program at the American Dance Festival that ranged from a dumbfounding performance by Gary Chryst in a new work by Martha Clarke to major revivals, both rousing and poignant, of 1930's social-protest works by the modern-dance pioneer Helen Tamiris.

title: Personal Health
description: CONCERNS about fragile bones have joined worries about being overweight and at risk for heart disease in prompting millions of women near or past menopause to start exercising. Having heard that exercise can help maintain and even increase bone mass, they are walking, running, swimming, cycling and even lifting weights to ward off the fractures caused by osteoporosis.

title: How to Donate To Flood Relief
description: Across the country, people have seen images of the Midwest on television and in newspapers, and now they are donating money and supplies to flood victims in Iowa, Illinois and Missouri.

title:
DINING OUT;
Victorian Charmer's New Sophistication
description: WHEN the Virginia Hotel, a Victorian charmer in Cape May, was refurbished and opened by new owners in 1989, the fare in the inn's dining room was trendy but uneven. Just over a year ago, a new chef took over the range in the Ebbitt Room, as it's called, and the restaurant now ranks among the best of the resort's cosmopolitan dining spots. The food, while still roaming all over the map, is now consistently good, with an emphasis on locally grown produce, and the service has gained polish.

title: Course Correction Needed in Somalia
description: What started as a humanitarian U.N. mission to feed starving Somalis seems to be turning into something far less benign. The U.N. says 15 people were killed in Monday's raid by U.S. helicopter gunships and ground troops against the headquarters of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid; the Red Cross counts 54 dead. The bodies of four journalists have also been recovered, apparently victims of mob retaliation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MUHAMMAD ALI, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, is in the Middle East, seeking the release of Iranian and Iraqi prisoners of war.

title: After a Long Goodbye, A Time of Catching Up
description: THERE were times in the past week when they both wept. Never in front of each other, though. They found private times and spaces. Both were overwhelmed by joy and melancholy at the same time.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CUOMO, OPPOSING BILL, MANEUVERS

title: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: In the Heartland; In Each Town, People Try to Cope With the River That Runs Through It
description: City Hall is sandbagged. So is the Methodist church, which is now the town's food distribution center.

title: Mobilizing Support For a Stricken Family
description: Like a small Southern town that somehow picks itself up and migrates from one race track to another each weekend, the sport of stock-car racing has developed its own emotional and spiritual support system over the years.

title: Cuban Official Downplays Players' Defections
description: Since arriving at the World University Games, the Cuban delegation has seen three of its athletes -- two baseball players and a fencer -- try to leave the delegation. But at a news conference today, the head of the delegation said there was no problem other than "just craziness" on the part of the athletes.

title: Judge Requires Yonkers To Build 168 Apartments
description: Chastising the city of Yonkers for continuing to avoid integrating its housing, a Federal judge yesterday ordered the city to proceed in building 168 subsidized and market-rate apartments on three sites and to work on plans for scores of additional units.

title: Personal Health
description: CONCERNS about fragile bones have joined worries about being overweight and at risk for heart disease in prompting millions of women near or past menopause to start exercising. Having heard that exercise can help maintain and even increase bone mass, they are walking, running, swimming, cycling and even lifting weights to ward off the fractures caused by osteoporosis.

title: First Charges Are Brought In Inquiries Into Deaths
description: Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper who the police say has confessed to killing 17 women, was indicted today on charges of murdering a 22-year-old Manhattan woman whose body was found here on June 28 in the back of his pickup truck.

title: Campus Journal; Actor-Turned-Teacher Brings Elan to Classroom
description: It could have been a 13-year-old's nightmare: French class on a sunny Saturday afternoon during summer vacation in a classroom without air-conditioning.

title: Paying for Mental Health
description: By approving a bill last week that would funnel more state money to community mental health programs, the Legislature boxed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo into the most awkward of corners: It forced him to threaten to veto a major initiative whose underlying principle he has long supported.

title: Wine Talk
description: GEORGES DUBOEUF has been described as the Pope of the Vine, the General, the Patron, and more commonly, the King of Beaujolais.

title: Fraternization and Friction in the Store Aisles; New York Challenges Wal-Mart Over Dismissal of Two Who Dated Against the Rules
description: The seeds of romance between Laural Allen and Samuel Johnson were sown in a most unlikely place: the sporting goods department of the new Wal-Mart in Johnstown, N.Y. When he first laid eyes on her, she was showing a hunting rifle to a customer.

title: U.S. and Florida Growers Reach Pact on Everglades
description: In an action aimed at ending the biggest environmental debate in Florida history after five years of litigation, the Federal and state governments today announced an agreement with agricultural interests on a $465 million plan to help clean up the endangered Everglades.

title: Resort Income Investors reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Personal Health
description: CONCERNS about fragile bones have joined worries about being overweight and at risk for heart disease in prompting millions of women near or past menopause to start exercising. Having heard that exercise can help maintain and even increase bone mass, they are walking, running, swimming, cycling and even lifting weights to ward off the fractures caused by osteoporosis.

title: No Headline
description: "In the attempts to build the comprehensive, 'we can do everything' high school, we left out something to belong to, to believe in." -- WILLIAM AYERS, professor of education at the University of Chicago. [ A1:5. ]

title: Cricket Is Coming to Manhattan
description: Bowler, batsman, wicket and test may not be household terms when it comes to everyday sports parlance, but a group of local cricketers is trying to change that.

title: Puncturing the Many Pooh-Bahs
description: The Wish for Kings Democracy at Bay By Lewis H. Lapham 213 pages. Grove/Atlantic Press. $22.

title: Whitman Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 24,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Dow Drops 8.94, for First Loss in 5 Sessions
description: Despite the support of low inflation figures, the stock market slipped yesterday for the first time in five sessions. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 8.94 points to close at 3,515.44.

title: Reed's Signings Come Down to Walters and Dudley
description: P. J. Brown was the top draft pick of the Nets last year, but decided against attending New Jersey's summer camp. Instead, he chose to go to Greece and play in the European league. Brown doesn't think that will happen to this year's top pick, Rex Walters.

title: Service Merchandise Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 7,598,000 from early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $ 7,742,000, or 8 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principle.Year-ago share earnings were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1992.

title: Renovations Set for Area Near Yankee Stadium
description: New York City is planning to renovate the Bronx Terminal Market, a hulking collection of warehouses and stores just south of Yankee Stadium, officials said yesterday.

title: Campaign to Fight Attacks in Public Pools
description: Wearing a button that read "Don't Dis Your Sis," Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday announced the start of a public relations campaign aimed at encouraging young men to respect their female counterparts.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Stolt Comex Seaway S.A. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said it has operated as an integrated business since the third quarter of 1992 so there are no directly comparable financial results.

title: Market Place; Debt Still Threatens to Prevent Airlines' Recovery from Taking Off.
description: THE oft-recited bullish formula for airline stocks typically points out that many carriers are cutting costs by means like grounding planes and shedding unprofitable routes. With a little boost from the economy and a break from heavy fare wars, this lean approach should translate into quick profits.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. RICHARD H. SOLOMON, a former United States Ambassador to the Philippines and a former assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, has been selected as the new president of the United States Institute of Peace. He will take over the organization, whose headquarters are in Washington, in September.

title: Stewart Could Buck American Trend for Losing in Britain
description: American golfers have few reasons to feel particularly confident of victory at this week's 122d British Open, despite the fact that no one feels quite at home amid the foreboding dunes of the Royal St. George's Golf Club.

title: High Court Nominee Is Given Bar Association's Top Rating
description: The American Bar Association has given Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg its highest rating on her fitness to be a Supreme Court Justice, Congressional officials said today.

title: Presidential Ball in Spotlight
description: Presidential Ball is feeling like a million. Again.

title: Mortgage Risk Great in 3 States
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut do not fare well in a new analysis of mortgage default rates. The three states are projected to have among the highest default rates over the next five years.

title: Girl, 5, Is Killed by a Hit-and-Run Livery-Cab Driver
description: A 5-year-old girl crossing a street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan yesterday morning with her mother was struck and killed by a livery cab, which then sped off, the police said.

title: Clinton Names R.T.C. Choice
description: The Clinton Administration today nominated Stanley Tate, a Republican who is a Florida real estate developer, to be chief executive of the Federal agency that sells the assets of failed savings and loans.

title: Review/Pop; Tina Turner Turns A Little Softer
description: Tina Turner made one of the more memorable grand entrances at Radio City Music Hall on Monday evening, where she is appearing through Saturday. As her show opened, a flying saucerlike bank of lights floated down from the top of the stage and opened into a staircase, which the star descended, wearing high spike heels and a filmy mini-dress. On alighting, Ms. Turner, accompanied by a seven-man band, flung into her 1989 hit "Steamy Windows," while she and two female dancers flexed and stretched through a strenuous aerobics routine.

title: Executive Changes
description: CHIRON CORP., Emeryville, Calif., a biotechnology company, appointed Renato Fuchs senior vice president. ENVIROFIL INC., Philadelphia, appointed Gerald J. Lynam executive vice president and chief financial officer. MATTEL INC., Los Angeles, appointed Michael L. Durik senior vice president of human resources and administration. NEW ENGLAND INVESTMENT COS., Boston, named G. Neal Ryland executive vice president and chief financial officer. PUTNAM INVESTMENTS, Boston, named Peter Carman senior managing director and chief of global equity investments. PROCTER & GAMBLE CO., Cincinnati, named Erik G. Nelson senior vice president and chief financial officer. RUSSELL CORP., Alexander City, Ala., an apparel marketer, appointed J. T. Taunton executive vice president of sales and marketing. James D. Nabors was named executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Consolidated Papers (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $ 21,854,000, or 50 cents a share, from postretirement benefits and a charge of $ 59,901,000 from cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles.Consolidated Papers said the sales increase resulted largely from increased shipments. The earnings improvement reflects the absense this year of $ 7.4 million pretax start-up costs of the company's $ 495 million expansion program completed last year.

title: Book Notes; Writer Uses Her Plot To Attack an Enemy
description: Martha Grimes's new novel, "The Horse You Came In On" (Alfred A. Knopf) is not only a triple-murder mystery, but also a powerful indictment of literary theft, whose plot turns on a newly discovered Edgar Allan Poe short story that may or may not be the work of a clever plagiarist. At the same time, one of Ms. Grimes's characters, a novelist named Ellen Taylor, confronts her own writerly dilemma: how to deal with another author, Vicki Salva, who she believes has filched much of her material.

title: Sony Purchases a Little Help In a Classical-Video Venture
description: Two major forces in the classical-music world reached agreement yesterday on a transaction that is sure to resonate throughout the field. Sony Music Entertainment, a division of the Japanese electronics conglomerate Sony Corporation, acquired CAMI Video, a production and distribution arm of Columbia Artists Management, which represents many musical superstars.

title: As Heat Expands, Nature Contracts
description: In the heat of the summer, a lot of trees seem to think it is October and are shedding their leaves.

title: U.S. Reviews How to Restore Utilities in Sarajevo
description: President Clinton's top national security aides failed today to agree on how to break the Serbian blockade of basic services to Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, which is in its fifth week without electrical service, tap water and natural gas.

title: Funds Lend Where Others Won't
description: "Come back next year and you'll see a miracle," said Michael Dawkins, muscling a concrete pillar as heavy as the July heat into the gutted row house he is helping to rebuild.

title: Preserve Redwoods For Future Inspiration
description: To the Editor:

title: Microtek Medical (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 229,000, or 6 cents a share, for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Kruk's Nightmare Is Wild And Fast
description: John Kruk hadn't just dreamed about Randy Johnson. He had nightmares about the Seattle Mariners' left-hander and thanked the baseball gods he never had to face the 6-foot-10-inch strong-arm man.

title: English Journalist Is Named Editor of Daily News
description: The Daily News has a new editor in chief, an English journalist who trained on Fleet Street.

title: 4 Israeli Teen-Agers Arrested In Grenade Death of an Arab
description: The Israeli police said today that they had arrested four teen-age members of a militant Jewish group in connection with a grenade attack that killed an elderly Arab in the Old City in November.

title: ITT Studying Ways to Make Wide Job Cuts
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it was conducting a study of personnel in its legal, human resources, corporate relations and controller departments that would result in widespread layoffs.

title: Jets Sign Hentrich, a Notre Dame Kicker
description: The Jets reached an agreement yesterday with punter/place- kicker CRAIG HENTRICH, their eighth-round draft choice, who set two career records at Notre Dame. Terms weren't given. Hentrich, who is 6 feet 3 inches and 200 pounds, averaged 44.4 yards as a punter while with the Irish and scored 294 points. He ranks third among Notre Dame kickers, with 35 field goals.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a movement to create smaller urban high schools misstated the affiliation of Prof. William Ayers, who is helping several Chicago high schools create smaller schools within their walls. He teaches at the University of Illinois at Chicago, not the University of Chicago.

title: An Inquiry Into a Lloyd's Underwriter
description: Inquiries into huge losses suffered by Lloyd's of London took a new turn today when officials said that prosecutors had opened a criminal investigation into the activities of insurance-market underwriters.

title: PNC Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge which represents cumulative effect of accounting changes of $ 19,393,000.c-After a charge which represents cumulative effect of accounting changes of $ 102,501,000.The bank said net income in the second quarter reflected basic core earnings.

title: Suspect in Bombing Plot Denies Role in Conspiracy
description: The 32-year-old Sudanese Muslim charged as a ringleader in the plot to bomb four targets in New York City called the United States Government "highly unjust" and warned it yesterday to cut its ties with "tyrants" abroad. He also issued various denials of any role in the bombing conspiracy.

title: America's Soviet Scientists
description: Aleksei Abrikosov, leader of a theoretical physics group at Argonne National Laboratories, near Chicago, works in a quiet, dark office. The scientist is wearing a plaid shirt like American farmers often wear. From time to time, he gets up and walks about his office in comfortable slippers. Mr. Abrikosov feels at home. He has no intention of changing jobs.

title: BOWATER PLANS TO CUT ANNUAL NEWSPRINT PRODUCTION
description: Bowater Inc., the largest manufacturer of newsprint in the country, said yesterday that it would cut annual newsprint production by 16 percent because demand remained weak and the business was not profitable. The production cut would lower the total amount of newsprint manufactured in North America by about 1.5 percent, according to a Salomon Brothers analyst, Chip Dillon. The move would also cut excess inventories by about 60 percent, he said. The company, based in Darien, Conn., said it would trim production by 264,500 short tons, to about 1.44 million tons.

title: Port-au-Prince Journal; Haitians Get Message: Condoms Are a Fact of Life
description: On a junk-strewn hillside behind an open-air auto garage, Rosanne Auguste, a Haitian health care worker who mixes a forceful personality with a ready smile, encounters nothing but hoots as she holds a wooden anatomical model to demonstrate the use of condoms to mechanics.

title: Farmer Is Released From Hospital
description: RED FARMER, who survived the helicopter crash that killed the Nascar star Davey Allison, was released from the hospital yesterday.

title: Market Place; A Kelley Oil Test Well Doesn't Live Up to Investor Expectations.
description: INVESTORS in the Kelley Oil Corporation who had been speculating for months on hot news from the oil patch were hit instead yesterday with a cold dose of reality.

title: Bad News For Dell Computer
description: Even as its sales continue to surge, the Dell Computer Corporation provided more evidence today that it was having a terrible year, saying it expected to report its first quarterly loss ever.

title: Iowa Offering Short-Term Notes
description: A short-term financing by Iowa was tentatively priced for sale to the public yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Union Stops Highway Work, Delaying New Jersey Projects
description: A widening work stoppage by a union that provides heavy-equipment operators for highway and other construction projects has halted work worth hundreds of millions of dollars from Camden to Bergen Counties and threatened the timely completion of the projects.

title: Five's a Crowd in American League Races
description: In the past month and a half, four American League East teams had these stretches: The Boston Red Sox lost 13 of 16 games, the Detroit Tigers lost 10 in a row and 13 of 14, the Toronto Blue Jays lost 10 of 11 and the Yankees lost 8 of 10.

title: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: The Nerve Center; From Vital to Mundane, A Big Story for WGEM
description: No one who lives along this stretch of the Mississippi or anywhere near it is listening to Rush Limbaugh anymore.

title: Andreas Hellrigl, 61, Innovative Chef and Hotelier
description: Andreas Hellrigl, an international chef, restaurateur and hotelier, died on Sunday at a hospital in Newark. He was 61 and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: 3 Slavic Ex-Soviet Lands to Press Economic Union
description: The three main Slavic states that dominated the old Soviet Union and effectively dissolved it in December 1991 have decided to press ahead with an economics and customs union, including coordinated economic policies.

title: U.N. Finds Peace Elusive With Somali Leader at Large
description: With Mogadishu smoldering in anger and violence, the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Somalia is finding that its fundamental mission to restore order is proving increasingly elusive.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANK OF TOKYO TRUST CO. , New York, named James J. Wallace Jr. executive vice president and Kenneth J. Abere senior vice president and chief credit officer. BEI ELECTRONICS INC., San Francisco, appointed Gary D. Wrench chief financial officer and senior vice president.

title: A Regular From Cult Movies of Old Re-emerges as a Primary Attraction
description: Any number of actors can point to an Oscar on the shelf. Only Conrad Brooks can stand up and say that he appeared in virtually every film by Edward Wood Jr., often acclaimed as the worst director in the history of the cinema, the anti-genius behind "Plan 9 From Outer Space," a film that must be seen several times for full comprehension of its absolute ineptitude in every category of the film-making art.

title: Lance Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 12
description: b-After a charge of $ 378,000 from an accounting adjustment.Lance Inc. said the decrease in net income for the quarter and the year to date is mainly due to operations of Vista Bakery Inc., a refund of a prior year's income taxes recorded in the first quarter and the cumulative effect of accounting changes.

title: Ginsburg Gets Set for Her Most Public Law Exam
description: Each day this week, Ruth Bader Ginsburg has sat at a table in Room 108 of the Old Executive Office Building, fielding questions from a panel of lawyers on a variety of legal issues.

title: An Oversight? No, It's Just Entertainment
description: It's a good thing that the feud between the Toronto Blue Jays and the Baltimore Orioles emerged alive and well from the 64th All-Star Game. Because the one between the National and American League did not.

title: Troubles at Empire Blue Cross Reflect a Failure of Management
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Routines That Avoid the Routine
description: Diquis Tiquis, a two-member dance troupe from Costa Rica, is typical of the foreign companies that have been both nurtured and introduced at the American Dance Festival in recent years. That is, their distinctiveness is immediately apparent but they are also part of a general international trend that, for better or for worse, plays down the very danciness of dance.

title: A $600 Million Georgia Refunding
description: Georgia yesterday priced a $600 million offering of refunding general obligation bonds yesterday through various underwriters.
