title: Jerusalem Journal; Lights! Camera! News! Palestine TV Is on the Air
description: As the anchor signed off, the music came up and credits flashed on the closed-circuit screen, wild applause erupted in the packed performance hall of the Hakawati Theater in East Jerusalem.

title: Politics of Present Snags Remembrance of Past; Plan for Potter's Field Memorial Near African Burial Ground Stalls in Emotional Debate
description: All they wanted, Melinda Hunt and Margot Lovejoy insist, was to resurrect the memory of New York City's forsaken dead. They wanted to erect a sculpture for the nearly 1 million people buried anonymously over the centuries in the city's potter's fields. And they wanted to put it at the site of the city's first, at Broadway and Chambers Street, at what is now City Hall Park.

title: TCF Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $ 7.8 million charge in the quarter and a $ 7.9 million charge in the 6 months, both from merger-related restructuring associated with the acquisition of Republic Capital Group Inc.

title: Water and Fear Start to Subside In St. Louis Area
description: It was only a drop of a tenth of a foot, but the rain-swollen, rampaging mighty Mississippi began to subside here today, and with it some of the fear and destruction caused by the great flood of 1993.

title: Comerica Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossc-Included an after-tax charge of $ 92 million for restructuring associated with merger with Manufacturers National Corp. in the quarter and 6 months.

title: Forget Electric Car and Tax the Gas Guzzlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday comparing historic floods on the Mississippi River misstated the damage estimate for the 1973 flood. It was $1.154 billion, not $11.54 billion.

title: Empire Blue Cross Planning To Limit Its Patients' Choices
description: Battered by years of deteriorating finances, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans to limit the choice of doctors and hospitals for its oldest and sickest customers. The move is intended to hold down costs while making medical insurance affordable for more New Yorkers.

title: Sega to Start Review For New Campaign
description: Sega of America Inc. said yesterday that it was searching for an additional advertising agency to handle a new $8 million to $10 million campaign aimed at children and their parents.

title: Effort Aims to Preserve Patchwork of Rural Life
description: More than three centuries ago, a family descended from Spanish Jews received a cryptic message from Spain's monarch, King Philip 4th: "The onions begin to smell." It was warning that they were in danger from the Inquisition and should leave Spain speedily. The family fled to France, and eventually found refuge in the New World where Louis Moses Gomez became a prosperous fur trader and built a fortress-like stone house in the Hudson Valley north of Newburgh.

title: High Court Nominee Faces Easy Road Through Senate
description: When the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday takes up the nomination of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg to the Supreme Court, the atmosphere will be rich with impending historic change.

title: Amcore Financial (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
As Crest Nears, a Historic Town's Emotions Rise
description: Today was supposed to be crest day on the Mississippi River here, and an eerie quiet hung over this historic river town.

title: Kingsley Morse, 62, Executive Who Led A Commuter Airline
description: Kingsley G. Morse, founder and president of Command Airways and a pioneer in commuter airlines, died on Saturday at his home in Millbrook, N.Y. He was 62.

title: INSIDE
description: North Korea Yields a Little

title: Rooney Didn't Find Marilyn Monroe
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Movie Studio Moves Its Account
description: Savoy Pictures of Beverly Hills, Calif., a movie studio formed last year, said yesterday that it had terminated its three-month relationship with the New York and Torrance, Calif., offices of Saatchi & Saatchi and moved its $15 million to $20 million account to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in Los Angeles and New York, effective immediately.

title: Ex-Officer Shot In Gun Battle With Car Thief
description: A man leaped into a parked Mercedes-Benz -- unlocked, with keys in the ignition -- at East 62d Street near Fifth Avenue yesterday, then shot and wounded a retired police officer who tried to stop him, the police said.

title: Paperhandlers Ratify Pact
description: The Paperhandlers and Straighteners Union No. 1, whose members receive newsprint shipments and prepare rolls of paper for the presses, yesterday ratified an agreement with The New York Times that extends to the year 2000, The Times announced. The agreement was originally reached on Dec. 23, 1992. The paperhandlers' agreement is the last in a series reached between The Times and its major production unions covering production operations in Manhattan and the new automated plant in Edison, N.J. Details of the agreement were not released.

title: Inter-Regional Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hawkeye Bancorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 4,597,000, or 35 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.Year-ago results were restated to reflect the May 3, 1993 acquisition of First National Bank Of Dubuque.

title: 200 Children Are Abandoned In Besieged Bosnian Hospital
description: Nobody could be sure when Edin Lisnjic died. The only witnesses, three other toddlers in a stuffy upper room at a hospital for physically and mentally handicapped children here, were in no condition to say.

title: Torchmark Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bush Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7 IRAQ AGREES TO U.N. MONITORING

title: 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell.' Don't Believe It.
description: The "don't ask, don't tell" policy that President Clinton seems to have endorsed yesterday is a failed attempt to lift the ban on gays in the military. With the issue now shifting back to the courts, the political branches should be aware that the constitutional defense of any policy short of full equality will also fail.

title: EZCorp Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jamesway Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: As expected, the Jamesway Corporation, the struggling discount department store operator based in Secaucus, N.J., filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, succumbing to increasing competition that made many of its stores seem dowdy.

title: Ethyl Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 44,947,000, or 38 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 90,483,000, or 77 cents a share, in the 6 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 34,667,000, or 29 cents a share, and $ 71,456,000, or 60 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included a charge of $ 14,732,000 from cumulative effect of accounting changes for postretirement health benefits and deferred income taxes adopted as of Jan. 1, 1992.The company said it completed the spin-off of its approximately 80 percent interest in First Colony Corp. The discontinued operations refer to First Colony.Year-ago results for both the quarter and 6 months are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Indictment Cloud Hangs Over Administration's Budget Plan
description: If Representative Dan Rostenkowski is indicted, he will have to step aside as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and President Clinton will lose his strongest ally in Congress on many of the issues that are central to his Presidency.

title: First Financial Management Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 9,200,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 17,900,000, or 32 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: U.S.-North Korea Meeting Yields Some Gains on Arms
description: The United States and North Korea agreed tonight to several steps to ease international fears about North Korea's nuclear weapons-making ability but failed to resolve their dispute over an American demand for inspections of two suspected sites of nuclear materials.

title: Hon Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Included a gain of $ 489,000, or 2 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Brister Signs With Eagles
description: BUBBY BRISTER, a free-agent quarterback, signed a one-year contract with the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday. Brister is expected to fill the void at backup to RANDALL CUNNINGHAM created when JIM McMAHON left the Eagles to sign with the Minnesota Vikings. Terms of the contract were not released. (AP)

title: Japan's Leader, Defying Critics, Vows to Keep Power
description: Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa defiantly asserted today that he would remain in office and try to patch together a conservative coalition around his Liberal Democratic Party, which lost its parliamentary majority in elections on Sunday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS India Stuns France Ramesh Krishnan needed less than 13 minutes yesterday to send India past France and into a Davis Cup semifinal against Australia. In a match that had been suspended because of darkness Sunday night, Krishnan quickly won two games for a five-set victory -- 2-6, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5, 6-4 -- over Rodolphe Gilbert in Frejus, France. The victory gave India a stunning 3-2 victory over the French in the three-of-five quarterfinal. India will now be host to Australia, a 3-2 winner over Italy, in the semifinals on Sept. 24-26. Germany will travel to Sweden for the other semifinal. (AP) Novotna Avoids Nightmare No. 2: Jana Novotna, playing her first match since her tearful loss to Steffi Graf in the Wimbledon final, once again blew a big lead before recovering to lead the Czech and Slovak Republics to a first-round Federation Cup victory in Frankfurt, Germany. Novotna, ranked eighth in the world, prevailed in the rain-delayed match, defeating South Africa's Amanda Coetzer, 6-1, 6-4. Earlier, Helena Sukova had outlasted Rosalyn Fairbank-Nideffer, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, to put the Czech and Slovak team ahead in the weeklong, 32-nation tournament on clay. (AP)

title: Finning Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that at the end of 1992, it retroactively changed its method of accounting for the exchange component revenue in its Canadian operations. As a result, 1992 6-month revenues were reduced by $ 26,632,000. It didn't specify the impact of the accounting change on 1992 second-quarter revenues.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Workers of the World, Get Smart
description: Throughout the industrialized world, there seem to be too few good jobs to go around. The problem manifests itself differently in different countries, but the failure of any country to insure good jobs for many able and willing citizens raises a troubling question: Do advanced nations have to choose between good jobs and more jobs?

title: LEGGETT & PLATT TO BUY HANES HOLDING FOR $65 MILLION
description: Leggett & Platt Inc., a Carthage, Mo., maker of furniture and carpet cushioning products, said yesterday that it planned to issue about $65 million of its common stock to acquire Hanes Holding Inc. under a merger agreement signed by the two companies. Hanes, a privately held Conover, N.C., company with annual sales of $150 million, operates the Hanes Converting Company, the Hanes Fabrics Company and the Hanes Dye and Finishing Company. The transaction is subject to several conditions, including approval by shareholders of both companies. Leggett & Platt said it expected to complete the acquisition in late August. The company's stock closed yesterday unchanged at $39.375 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Observer; Get The Boys
description: You've probably forgotten Charlie Spatz. He was one of the boys. The only one, in fact, ever fired for disgracing his profession. It was a big story in those days.

title: 11-Year-Old's Unusual Story
description: An 11-year-old Floridian, CANDICE FUCHS, will play in the Pathmark Tennis Classic today in Mahwah, N. J. But the circumstances surrounding Fuchs's admission into the weeklong exhibition event and her first-round match against her coach, PAM CASALE-TELFORD, remained unresolved yesterday.

title: Macy to Name Chief for West
description: R. H. Macy & Company, the department store retailer operating under bankruptcy-law protection, intends to tell its creditors on Thursday that it plans to appoint Michael Steinberg, the former chief executive of the Foley's division of May Department Stores Inc., as the chairman and chief executive of its West division, people familiar with the company said yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: The 1993 Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, organized by the Greater New York Bridge Assocation, is nearing its end. The last undefeated team, which will now wait for the results of the losers bracket, consists of Michael and Judi Radin, Michael Kopera, Edgar Kaplan, Brian Glubok and Nick Nickell. Playing on Thursday at the Beverly Club, with Glubok and Nickell absent, they defeated a group led by John Solodar by a margin of 45 imps.

title: Dinkins Meets With Leaders In Brooklyn
description: On the eve of the release of a state report that is widely expected to criticize his handling of the Crown Heights disturbances, Mayor David N. Dinkins went to Brooklyn yesterday to try to demonstrate his long-term efforts to bring together people in the divided neighborhood.

title: East German Spy Trader Is Jailed on Tax Charges
description: Wolfgang Vogel, the mysterious lawyer who arranged exchanges of spies and releases of political prisoners in East Germany from 1962 to 1989, was arraigned in a Berlin court today on charges of perjury and tax evasion on income said to have been received through his connections with the Communist secret police.

title: Ondieki Owns the 10K And Covets the Marathon
description: Yobes Ondieki, who owns a world title at 5,000 meters and the world record at 10,000 meters, hopes to complete a distance-running triple by moving up to the marathon and, ultimately, running the 26.2-mile race at the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta.

title: U.S. May Threaten China With Sanctions for Reported Arms Sales
description: The Administration plans to warn China that its weapons exports could bring punitive sanctions, and a debate continues within the Government over whether the message is tough enough, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Sonoco Products (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-After a charge of $ 37,892,000 from the adoption of FASB 106 and 109. Adoption of FASB 106 also resulted in an incremental retiree benefit expense of about $ 3 million, or 3 cents a share, which was charged evenly over the four quarters of 1992.All figures were restated to reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective June 10.

title: Review/Fashion; The Excitement of Versace-Lacroix Counterpoint
description: Gianni Versace put an audacious spin on his collection on Saturday, the first day of the fall and winter couture openings here. It was enough to insure the viability of the season as a whole.

title: Man Kills Sons, Daughter and Himself
description: A 44-year-old Bridgeport man, despondent over his wife's leaving him and his poor health, shot and killed his 13-year-old twin sons and his 22-year-old daughter in their sleep before killing himself early this morning, the police said.

title: Chemical Waste Management reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 3,000,000 for change in accounting for postretirement benefits.Latest quarter's share earnings included gain of 5 cents a share related to merger of Brand Cos. into Rust International Inc.Year-ago quarter's share earnings included a gain of 7 cents a share related to initial public offering by Waste Management International PLC. The gain was offset by a charge related to two of Chemical Waste Management's incineration facilities.

title: Moscow Draws Line on Cigarette and Liquor Ads
description: As the smog of Communism lifted over Moscow several years ago, enabling a market-oriented economy to take root, products like Reebok shoes, Benetton clothes, Sharp electronics and Estee Lauder cosmetics were suddenly available to people who had known only the shoddiness of domestically produced consumer goods.

title: GATT's New Chief Rejects Narrow Pact
description: The man in charge of concluding the world trade talks brushed aside proposals for a scaled-down agreement today, asserting that some countries would back out rather than see certain parts of a broad accord jettisoned.

title: Baldor Electric reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jacobs Engineering Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 2.1 million, or 9 cents a share, relating to the sale of securities.

title: School Psychologist Is Charged With Sex Abuse
description: A supervisor of psychologists for New York City's public high schools was charged yesterday with sexually abusing two teen-age boys, and police and school officials said they were investigating whether other school employees were involved in similar crimes.

title: Penn State's Tarman to Retire
description: JIM TARMAN, who guided Penn State from Eastern powerhouse to Big Ten neophyte, is retiring as athletic director. Tarman, 65, yesterday said he will step down from the post he has held for 11 years as soon as a successor can be installed, probably by Dec. 31.

title: Lilly (Eli) & Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge from cumumative effect of a change in accounting principles of $ 10,900,000 and $ 118,900,000 for the latest 6 months and year-ago period, respectively.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.The company said primary earnings per share has not been presented because it does not differ significantly from the reported earnings per share computed on a fully diluted basis.Sales represented worldwide sales.

title: No Murderers' Row But Plenty of Punch
description: And to think the primary question, in some observers' minds, about the Yankees before the season began was whether or not they would have enough hitting. Would the Rockies have enough fans?

description: b-Included income of $ 230.2 million, or $ 1.39 a share, from an accounting adjustment and after extraordinary charge of $ 26.4 million for the settlement of legal actions in connection with the sale of the Sperry Aerospace Group in December 1986.c-Included tax benefits of operating loss carryforwards of $ 17 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months.

title: Cooper Tire & Rubber reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 64,960,000 from changes in accounting for postretirement benefits and income taxes.

title: The High Risks of Denying Rivers Their Flood Plains
description: FOR decades Americans have insisted on settling next to rivers and streams, like moths drawn to a flame, just as people have throughout history. And to protect their cities and farms, engineers have tried to ward off the inevitable flood waters with levees, flood walls, dams, dikes and diversion channels. To some extent this ambitious attempt to bend nature to human desires has worked.

title: 3 Years Later, Still No Arrests in Huge Armored-Car Robbery
description: Three years after bandits committed the second-largest armored car robbery in United States history, there have been no arrests in the case and little visible progress in solving it, despite intense pressure on two men considered suspects.

title: Tubes of Ice Hold Record of Climate In Past and Future
description: IN a refrigerated van kept in a parking lot at the University of New Hampshire, just outside Durham, lies an archive that assuredly holds many secrets of the earth's past and future.

title: Hungarian Goes Australian
description: Hungarian-born NORBERT ROZSA, who holds the world record in the 100-meter breast-stroke, will be granted Australian residency today and hopes to compete for the country in the 1996 Olympics. Rozsa, the silver medalist in the 100 breast-stroke in the 1992 Olympics, lives in Perth. Rozsa hopes to gain Australian citizenship. (AP)

title: Boatmen's Bancshares (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: Because of a computer processing error, a table in Business Day last Tuesday depicted the stock price movement for the Samuel Goldwyn Company incorrectly. The stock was not among those on the American Stock Exchange with the largest percentage declines in price the previous day.

description: b-Net loss, which included an accounting charge of $ 1,519,000,000 from the adoption of SFAS 106.

description: A Charivari 'Thing' Shop

title: GAY RIGHTS IN TH MILITARY: Chiefs Back Clinton on Gay-Troop Plan; President Admits Revised Policy Isn't Perfect
description: Flanked by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, President Clinton today presented his plan for easing the ban on homosexuals in the military and appealed to his generals and admirals to find in their hearts "the will and the desire" to carry it out.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Hawaiian Electric Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,800,000, or 7 cents a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 228,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 1,037,000, or 5 cents a share, in the 6 months.

title: Ticket Sales Save 2 Shows
description: Two supposedly doomed musicals, one on either side of the Atlantic, have won reprieves, it was announced yesterday.

title: Barbara Whitney, An Administrator And Educator, 56
description: Dr. Barbara Whitney, an expert in sex education and a leader in the battle against AIDS in New York City's public schools, died on Friday at a friend's home on Squam Lake, N.H. She was 56 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Ramirez Gains In Indian Chain
description: Manny Ramirez, the Dominican-born player whose skills attracted pro scouts when he played high school ball in Washington Heights, took another step forward yesterday when the Cleveland Indians promoted him to their Class AAA Charlotte affiliate.

title: Arms Sales to Third World At Lowest Level in 8 Years
description: Arms sales to the third world last year fell to their lowest levels since at least 1985, primarily because Russia's sales hit record lows, the Congressional Research Service reported today.

title: Albert Schlesinger, 88, Civic Leader in West
description: Albert E. Schlesinger, a civic leader and founder of one of the largest automobile dealerships on the West Coast, died on Saturday at the California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 88 and lived in San Francisco.

title: KLLM Transport Services Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: Latest quarter and 6 months' shares outstanding reflects increase in shares outstanding due to common stock offering in February.KLLM Transport Services Inc. said during the second quarter 1993, it changed its estimated salvage value of certain revenue equipment to reflect increases in the prices for used equipment. The change has been applied retroactively to Jan. 4, 1993, and has resulted in a decrease in depreciation expense of $ 326,000 and an increase in net earnings of $ 189,000, or 5 cents a share, which is included in the income for the second quarter and 6 months ended July 4, 1993.

title: Des Moines Water Restoration Stalls
description: City officials refilled part of the municipal water system here today, nine days after it was knocked out by flooding, but unauthorized and premature use of water quickly dealt another setback to their efforts to relieve the suffering of 250,000 residents.

title: Critic's Notebook; Music and Virtue: Is Making Art Good Making Good Art?
description: Music has a hard time doing good. It lifts the spirits of serial killers and social workers alike. It can fall on deaf ears attached to the saintliest of listeners. Its beauty serves evil easily. Note the wartime film clips of SS officers deeply moved by the Berlin Philharmonic in concert.

title: McGraw-Hill Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 124,587,000 from an accounting adjustment on the adoption of FAS 106 and FAS 112.

title: Lawyer, Testifying in Fraud Trial, Gives Details of Bank's Operation
description: Most criminal defense lawyers are reluctant to put their clients on the witness stand. And the fraud and bribery trial of Robert A. Altman seems to be no exception.

title: Midlantic Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 38,962,000, or 80 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.c-Net loss, which was after restructuring charges of $ 25,500,000.Latest results included tax credits of $ 17 million and $ 39 million, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively, reflecting a reduction in FASB 109 for tax valuation reserve.Year-ago results included pretax gains on disposition of assets of $ 9,970,000 and $ 20,170,000, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Chris-Craft Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 121,320,000 on the sale of Time Warner Inc. convertible preferred stock by its BHC Communications Inc. unit.c-Included pretax gain of $ 215,061,000 on BHC's sale of Time Warner preferred stock.Chris-Craft said the increase in net income for the latest quarter and 6-month period reflects both the pretax gain from the sale of Time Warner preferred stock and a substantial increase in the earnings of its television broadcasting business.

title: Youth Faces Arson Charge
description: A teen-ager was arrested yesterday in connection with a fire last week that destroyed six buildings in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and left 75 residents homeless, the police said. The youth, identified as Wilfredo Montes, 16, of 140 Scholes Street in Williamsburg, turned himself in to detectives from the 90th Precinct yesterday after his family arranged for his surrender, the police said. He was charged with arson. The five-alarm fire began behind 108 Scholes Street in Williamsburg about 7:30 P.M. Friday and spread along Manhattan Avenue, destroying 18 apartments.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC GETS CONTRACT FOR JAPANESE PLANT
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its Industrial and Power Systems unit had signed a $1.2 billion contract to build the world's largest power station for the Tokyo Electric Power Company. The contract calls for the company to build a 2,800-megawatt combined-cycle power station in Yokohama, Japan, to begin commercial service in the mid-1990's.

title: Liberty National Bancorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in May 1993.

title: Put Caps on Hydrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Satellite A White Elephant, Some Say
description: As the Clinton Administration prods the $70-billion-a-year Federal research complex into doing more to help American business devise new technologies, experts say it should heed the muddle surrounding a $600 million Federal satellite. The craft is expected to be placed into orbit in the next week or so after the delayed mission of the space shuttle Discovery gets off the ground.

title: Mattingly Puts His Best Foot Backward
description: Don Mattingly prefers not to discuss the intricacies of hitting. He occasionally makes adjustments between pitches, but he is adamant about keeping his hitting secrets a secret.

title: Central Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results were restated to reflect pooling of interests.

title: Honors
description: * Leagas Delaney and TBWA/ Holmes Knight Ritchie, both of London, took top honors at the Campaign Press Awards for print advertisements, sponsored by Campaign, the British advertising trade publication. Leagas won a gold award for the best single ad, for Mothercare, and four silvers. TBWA/Holmes Knight won a gold for the best overall campaign, for Nissan Motor Great Britain Ltd.'s Micra model, and three silvers.

title: Caremark International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said there were no year-ago share earnings because the company's shares weren't traded until its spin-off from Baxter last November.

title: The Pentagon's New Policy Guidelines on Homosexuals in the Military
description: Following is the text of the Pentagon's new policy guidelines to commanders on homosexuals in the military. Accession Policy

title: Raw Steel Output Falls
description: Raw steel output declined one-tenth of a percent last week, to 1.853 million tons from 1.855 million tons for the week earlier, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. The iron and steel factory utilization rate declined to 88.4 percent last week from 88.5 percent for the previous week, according to figures compiled by the industry association. For the year to date, raw steel production has increased 3.9 percent, to 52.297 million tons, from 50.325 million tons for the comparable period in 1992.

title: By Design; Paris Casual
description: Sneakers can be spotted all over town here. Every other Parisian or tourist seems to be sneaker-clad as they sit at sidewalk cafes watching the world go by.

title: PRIMERICA CORP. (N)
description: Low interest rates drove a 25 percent increase in second-quarter earnings at the Primerica Corporation. The growth was led by a strong performance at its brokerage subsidiary, Smith Barney, Harris Upham.

title: Smith Reports to Bills
description: BRUCE SMITH, the Pro Bowl defensive end, closed his holdout by reporting to training camp yesterday, saying this could be his last season with the Buffalo Bills. Smith, bitter over the absence of a new contract, is in the last year of a contract that pays him $1.6 million a year. He is seeking a deal that would pay him $4 million a year.

title: Tweak Without Tears
description: TO tweak a computer system is to try to squeeze the last possible measure of efficiency out of it -- a few more bytes of memory, another megabyte of disk space, an additional split second of response time. A certain amount of tweaking is helpful, but it can become an obsession; after a while, you think you can tell the difference between 5 milliseconds and 10 milliseconds.

title: A Question Mark Is Hovering Over Giants' Moore
description: When Phil Simms spoke to reporters today, there was a smile on his face. And why shouldn't he be happy? Giants Coach Dan Reeves has made him the starter. The Man. But how long that smile remains depends in large part on how healthy the quarterback stays. And how healthy he stays depends on the offensive line. That's where right guard Eric Moore comes in. Or may not come in.

title: Colorado's Anti-Gay Measure Set Back
description: In a decision that is likely to nullify a measure against gay rights passed last year by the state's voters, the Colorado Supreme Court ruled today that "fundamental rights may not be submitted to a vote."

title: Feasting on Topics With Universal Appeal
description: Bertolt Brecht liked to castigate bourgeois esthetes by calling them "culinary." He was more prophetic than he knew. This weekend in Reading and Oxford, west of London and a mere 25 miles apart, were two events that gave Brecht's ideas a fuller meaning. Often quite literally fuller.

title: Clinton in Crossfire
description: In announcing his compromise on homosexuals in the military, President Clinton today sought to close the book at last on an explosive issue that had become a glaring benchmark of the White House's own political naivete.

title: Free-Agent Richer Still a Devil
description: Right wing STEPHANE RICHER, the Devils' leading goal scorer last season, signed a multiyear contract with the team, officials announced yesterday. Richer, 27 years old, had been a free agent, but the Devils had the right to match any offer he received. Richer scored 38 goals and added 35 assists in 73 games last year.

title: Q&A
description: Feeding Birds

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

description: b-Included restructuring charges that reduced income by $ 263 million, or 64 cents a share, and after a charge of $ 1,729,000,000 for the adoption of changes in accounting, for postretiremenet benefits other than pensions, and for postemployment benefits.c-Net income

title: Profit Jumps at McDonnell Douglas
description: Despite big declines in military spending and commercial aircraft orders, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation continued to show improvement, today reporting a big jump in second-quarter profit.

New Material May Be Harder Than Diamond
description: THE hardness of diamond, like the speed of light, has long been regarded as an absolute -- a value that could never be exceeded. But four years ago, theorists calculated that it might be possible to combine carbon and nitrogen atoms in a substance even harder than diamond, and now, at last, such a substance may have been created.

title: On My Mind; The U.S. Smashes A Peril
description: Americans can rest easier. Washington has shown it can protect its citizens against at least one great peril from abroad.

description: YEVGENY YEVTUSHENKO, once the angry young man of Soviet poetry, turned 60 on Sunday, still angry but for different reasons than in the past.

The Hearings On Television
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee's confirmation hearings on Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg's nomination to the Supreme Court will be covered live on three television networks today, beginning at 10 A.M. Eastern daylight time.

title: Critic's Notebook; When Gay Images And Reality Conflict
description: Gay-rights advocates have a television problem. That is surprising, since unlike the yak-radio industry, television news departments have tended to be sympathetic to homosexual causes.

title: Thrifty Drug Stores Narrows Choice to 3
description: Thrifty Drug Stores of Los Angeles said yesterday that it had narrowed the review on the creative portion of its account to three agencies from seven. The account had been at Basso & Associates of Newport Beach, Calif., for nearly two years.

title: BMC Software Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Four Agencies Seek Shoney's Account
description: Shoney's Restaurants of Nashville said yesterday that it had named four agencies to compete for its account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $18 million. The account has been handled by Ogilvy & Mather Atlanta.

title: Wise-Guy Team for Comedy Central
description: Again and again, the irreverent summer air of the Comedy Central cable television network is punctuated by an urgent cry: "Get me the Lampoonies!"

title: Beware Of Orphans In Clones
description: THE financial pages have been reporting bad news about computer companies in recent weeks, and there are signs that more is to come. Profits are down sharply at many companies, and some big names, including Apple Computer Inc., the Dell Computer Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation, are reporting record losses.

title: Genetic Tug-of-War May Explain Many of the Troubles of Pregnancy
description: HAVING babies has never been easy. High blood pressure, nausea and diabetes-like symptoms are common side effects of pregnancy. Despite the heavy toll on the expectant mother, scientists generally view pregnancy as a delicate process of cooperation between a woman and her fetus.

title: After 3 Years, Bulls Finally Sign Kukoc
description: After three years of courting him, the Chicago Bulls finally landed Toni Kukoc yesterday, signing the 6-foot-11-inch guard known as the "Magic Johnson of Europe" to a multiyear contract.

title: Security Strengthened at Hudson River Crossings
description: New security equipment has been installed in the Holland Tunnel since the authorities uncovered what they described as a terrorist plot to bomb the Hudson River crossings, and the police commanders for the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels have increased training to make sure that officers are familiar with safety and evacuation procedures.

title: Dinkins and School Board Call Truce
description: As he runs for re-election, Mayor David N. Dinkins is grappling with a runaway school board that has left him with less influence on school policy than perhaps any modern mayor of New York -- even as the public continues to hold the Mayor accountable for the schools.

title: Romanians and Hungarians Building a Bit of Trust
description: In the end they were so surprised at the agreement they had achieved that they applauded and congratulated each other -- Romanians and Hungarians representing two traditionally hostile countries.

title: 3.9% Increase Is Proposed By A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would increase its rates for some long-distance residential and business calls an average of 3.9 percent.

title: Stocks End Day Mixed as Dow Gains 6.99
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with little news to affect the overall market. Instead, individual stories moved individual stocks, with the technology sector weighing over everything.

title: Northern Trust Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
John Nuveen Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 3,133,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: DEFIANT F.B.I. CHIEF REMOVED FROM JOB BY THE PRESIDENT
description: President Clinton today dismissed William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who had stubbornly rejected an Administration ultimatum to resign six months after a harsh internal ethics report on his conduct.

title: Yanks' Bat-Order Switch Pays Another Dividend
description: Scott Kamieniecki started the season ticketed for the bullpen, Bernie Williams started the season as the leadoff batter and Wade Boggs started the season as the No. 2 hitter. During the first four months of this season, each has seen his role change. The change was for the better last night.

title: Decrease in New York Sour Cherry Crop Caused by Winter Freeze
description: As the harvest of sour cherries began in New York, state officials said that the crop would be less than half of last year's because of freezing weather over the winter.

title: Home Repair or Retail Ruin?
description: Liberty Avenue in Queens, beneath the shadows of an elevated subway line, still resembles one of New York City's traditional neighborhoods, a cluster of Italian delis, Laundromats, pastry shops and a hardware store, called Molbegott's, that draws people precisely because they can ask Mr. Molbegott himself how to fix their plumbing.

title: Japan Businesses See Little Threat in Vote Results
description: One day after voters ended 38 years of conservative rule by the Liberal Democratic Party, Japan's business sector has begun concluding that the election results could turn out to be more of a benefit than a threat to the dominance of their interests in the nation's politics.

title: Market Place; Acquisition by Olsten May Gain It Some Respect on Wall Street.
description: AS No. 3 in the temporary office help market, behind Manpower Inc. and Kelly Services, the Olsten Corporation has gotten little respect from Wall Street. But the company may be on the verge of shedding its Rodney Dangerfield complex.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: COOPER ROLLS, Houston, a joint venture of Cooper Industries and Rolls-Royce P.L.C., received orders worth $70 million for offshore oil and gas platform equipment from Esso Production Malaysia Inc., and Shell U.K. Exploration and Production. RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., won a $14.4 million contract from Oman to modernize its air traffic control systems.

title: Recession's Romantics Fix Up Their Factory
description: IT didn't take long for somebody, probably Adam Smith, to make the connection between the value of a product and the wages of the people who make it. When $350 in raw materials are made into a $15,000 automobile, it equals happiness and high wages. Fifty cents worth of chopped beef flipped into a 75-cent hamburger equals low wages and woe.

title: No Headline
description: Fundamental rights may not be submitted to a vote. -- SUPREME COURT OF COLORADO. [ A8:1. ]

title: A Weak Link in the Yank Lineup
description: With the Yankees on the brink of something exciting, even something great, electronic fans are without a Great Voice to carry us at home, in the car, on the beach, at school, or at work.

title: Benchmark Electronic reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRONICLE
description: There's no such thing as too many opening nights for CHARLES STROUSE, the composer of scores for such shows as "Annie," "Bye Bye Birdie" and "Applause." In less than a month he will have three shows open, and that's just fine with him, he said yesterday.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS PLANS TO LIMIT CHOICES Battered by years of deteriorating finances, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans to limit the choice of doctors and hospitals for its oldest and sickest customers. A1. NEW YORK CITY DRUG ALLEGATIONS IN BOMB-PLOT CASE Some of the 11 men charged in the plot to bomb New York City targets are also suspected of trafficking in drugs, investigators said. Their comments -- challenged by a defense lawyer -- added a new dimension to a multilayered case replete with curious twists. B3.

title: In This Emergency, Agency Wins Praise for Its Response
description: Looking ahead to a multibillion-dollar cleanup in five states, the head of the Federal agency that manages the Government's response to disasters said today that the greatest damage from the Mississippi River flooding was likely to be to roads, bridges, sewers, electrical utilities and other parts of the Midwest's public works systems.

title: Colorado Law in Peril
description: The Colorado Supreme Court ruled that a measure against gay rights appeared to violate the Constitution. Experts said the ruling could be fatal to a law whose passage last year led to a boycott that has cost the state millions in lost convention business.

title: Three at Last: Mets' Streak Hits Milestone
description: In the battle of Joe McIlvaine, somebody had to win, and it was the Mets by a nose tonight, 2-1. McIlvaine, in the same season, has been general manager of the Padres and Mets, and tonight he found himself on the right side when Charlie O'Brien hit a 10th-inning home run for the victory.

title: Dinkins, in Israel, Excelled in Role of Good-Will Ambassador
description: To the Editor:

title: TV to Focus On Crown Hts.
description: New York's Criminal Justice Director, Richard H. Girgenti, will discuss his report on the Crown Heights disturbances at a news conference at noon today. Channels 2, 4, 5, 7, 11 and 13 and New York 1 News are planning to carry the news conference live, as are radio stations WCBS-AM, WINS-AM and WOR-AM.

title: Colombian Climbs Ahead of Pack
description: The Tour de France pack was riding at an exceptionally leisurely pace this morning, arriving about 20 minutes behind its slowest expected time at the bucolic village of Molitg-les-Bains in the outcropping of the Pyrenees. Understandably, the racers appeared to be in no hurry to begin in earnest the first of three days in these mountains.

title: Kelley Oil Downsizes Gas Find
description: The Kelley Oil Corporation, whose stock soared since April on excitement about a natural gas and oil find, announced yesterday that the first well's daily production of gas was a fraction of what analysts had anticipated.

title: Eating Well
description: LAST Wednesday, the White House chef, Pierre Chambrin, was learning how to make sauces without cream and desserts without butter. Is this a sign that beef Wellington and vichyssoise, on the menu at a small dinner given recently by the President and the First Lady, will be banished, replaced by chicken breasts stuffed with mushrooms and fresh tomato consomme?

title: NATIONSBANK CORP. (N)
description: The Nationsbank Corporation, the fifth-largest bank in the country, said its profit grew by 22 percent on strong loan growth and a decline in the amount of bad loans. The bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., said earnings for the second quarter rose to $306 million, compared with $251 million for the comparable period a year earlier. Its earnings of $1.20 a share were slightly higher than the $1.17 analysts had expected.

title: Erixon Retires From Rangers
description: JAN ERIXON, the 31-year-old Swedish-born wing who has played longer for the Rangers and suffered more heartaches -- and backaches -- than any other player on the team, said yesterday that after 10 seasons he had decided not to return to New York.

title: Coastal Corp. Chief Resigns In Dispute
description: James R. Paul resigned yesterday as president and chief executive of the Coastal Corporation in an apparent disagreement with the company's chairman over the pace of restructuring the refineries division.

title: Books of The Times; The Rise of the Right (Read Fascism) in Russia
description: Black Hundred The Rise of the Extreme Right in Russia By Walter Laqueur Illustrated. 317 pages. HarperCollins. $27.50.

title: Sons Killed Parents; Why Is Only Issue
description: Two wealthy Beverly Hills brothers now admit that they walked into their living room almost four years ago, leveled shotguns at their parents seated in front of the television set and fired. But they contend they did so only in self-defense after years of sexual and psychological abuse.

title: Kroger Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 19
description: b-After extraordinary charges from early retirement of debt of $ 2,135,947 in the quarter and $ 11,177,855 in the 6 months; a charge of $ 159,192,961 from cumulative effect of adoption of FASB No. 106, Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions in the 6 months, and a one-time aftertax special charge of $ 15 million for the closing of 15 stores in San Antonio, Texas in the quarter and the 6 months included $ 9 million, or $ 5.4 million aftertax for added quarterly charges from the adoption of FASB 106 and $ 22.7 million, or $ 15 million aftertax, or 12 cents a share, for the closing of 15 stores in San Antonio, Texas.c-Net lossd-After an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 33,895,136 in the quarter and $ 64,165,010 in the 6 months.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Bridge
description: When the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships begin Friday in Washington, the most confident players will surely be Michael Becker, Ron Rubin, Russ Ekeblad, Ron Sukoneck, Bob Levin and Peter Weichsel. They will be defending the Spingold Knockout Team title they won in Toronto a year ago, and they are fresh from victory in the team trials in Memphis last month, a victory that gives them a chance of world honors in Chile in September.

title: Japanese Politics Moves Into Era of Talk Shows
description: This has never been Larry King's kind of country. Political talk shows are usually deadly dull, and the real action has always taken place in Tokyo's most exclusive private clubs, where the $400-a-plate tab pales in comparison to the amount of cash changing hands to make new political alliances.

title: Merck Cuts 2,100 Jobs And Takes Huge Charge
description: Intensifying its cost-cutting to prepare for a riptide of price competition, Merck & Company said yesterday that it had eliminated 2,100 jobs and charged $775 million against second-quarter pretax earnings for the cutbacks. The charge will also cover future reductions.

BIDEN JR. Democrat of Delaware

description: A prolonged and bitter dispute over the value of the late artist Andy Warhol's work was settled yesterday when his estate was valued at approximately $220 million.

title: Risk of Hereditary Breast Cancer Is Reduced
description: In recent years, support groups for women at increased risk for breast cancer have proliferated, filled with terrified women who have a mother or sister who succumbed to the disease. Now a new study suggests that such women, while somewhat prone to breast cancer, are not as susceptible as was previously thought.

description: Bolstered by a strong turnaround in its long-distance business and torrid demand for cellular telephones, the Sprint Corporation yesterday reported that operating profits jumped 55 percent in the quarter that ended June 30.

title: Senate Votes to Allow Civil Servants To Engage in Much Political Activity
description: The Senate voted today to allow most Federal workers to participate in a wide range of off-duty partisan political activities, all but insuring enactment of the first significant change in civil servants' political status in more than half a century.

description: After months of using the anger of Crown Heights to torment Mayor David N. Dinkins at every turn, Rudolph W. Giuliani kept silent yesterday -- at least publicly -- and left the talking to his surrogates and supporters.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Last Saturday evening, as fireworks lit up the skies in East Hampton, L.I., during the annual benefit there for Boys Harbor, GEORGE PLIMPTON asked boaters in Three-Mile Harbor to toot their horns and spectators on land to applaud in honor of the 75th birthday of ANTHONY DREXEL DUKE. Scion of several socially prominent families, Mr. Duke is the founder and president of Boys Harbor, the New York-based educational center for inner-city children that has a summer camp in East Hampton.

title: Union Bank (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Pop Life; 500 Bands, 5 Nights, 7,000 People And a City
description: Mark Josephson recalled setting up a couple of hundred chairs in a rehearsal studio in 1980 for what became the first New Music Seminar. Back then it was a gathering of people from the margins of the music industry who were, as Mr. Josephson, the executive director of the seminar, put it, "campaigning for our kind of music, campaigning for a place for ourselves in the business."

title: Henry Stern, Jr., 80, Ex-Insurance Chief Of New York State
description: Henry Root Stern Jr., a former New York State Insurance Superintendent and trial attorney, died on July 7 at North Shore University Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 80 and lived in Glen Cove.

title: Packers Aim to Revive A Winning Tradition
description: During his first visit to Green Bay, Reggie White was treated by Ron Wolf, the Packers' executive vice president and general manager, to the same tour through Lambeau Field as all the other free agents who came through.

title: MEIKO SCIENTIFIC IS AWARDED LIVERMORE CONTRACT
description: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory said yesterday that it had awarded the Meiko Scientific Corporation of Waltham, Mass., a $17.5 million contract for a Meiko CS-2 Massively Parallel Processor computer system. When the decision was first disclosed in March, concerns were raised over national security and economic competitiveness because Meiko was a subsidiary of Meiko World of Britain. And the company had been criticized for the sale of a supercomputer to Israel. But a Livermore official said yesterday that the same precautions were being taken with respect to Meiko as with other computer contractors who have foreign ownership or foreign sales.

title: Wells Fargo & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Real Estate; After a Long Battle, Three Office Buildings Are Scheduled For Construction at a Los Angeles Site.
description: A SEVEN-YEAR legal battle has preceded the scheduled start of construction next month of three office buildings on a site known as Warner Ridge in the Woodland Hills section of this city.

title: Finding Profit
description: Trimble Navigation Ltd., a maker of satellite-based navigation products, gained attention during the Persian Gulf war by providing more hand-held positioning receivers to the military. Yesterday it reported second-quarter earnings of 4 cents a share, in contrast to a loss a year earlier. Since late last month, Trimble stock has soared about 50 percent.

title: Don't Ask, Don't Drop the Soap
description: To: The President and Appropriate Congressional Committee Heads

title: NCR CONSIDERS MOVING SOME PC ASSEMBLY TO TAIWAN
description: The NCR Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, is considering a plan to shift some personal computer assembly work now performed in Germany to Taiwan, a spokesman for the company's Taiwan unit said. The move, intended to improve the company's competitiveness in Asia and cut costs, would generate annual orders for about 200,000 personal computers worth $200 million for Taiwan contractors, said Grace Chen, a spokeswoman for NCR Taiwan Ltd. A decision is expected by the end of the year, she said.

title: Deposit Guaranty (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Men Linked To Strangling On Park Ave.
description: New York City police detectives have flown to Reno to question two men they believe were responsible for the killings last April of an Indian prince and his wife in their Park Avenue apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: Crown Heights: Shared Failure
description: The portrait of incompetence is breathtaking. There is no other way to read the new state report on the riots in Crown Heights two summers ago. Every level of New York City government failed to recognize the degree of violence, to deal with it at the time, to effectively apprehend and prosecute the lawless afterward.

title: East Germans Occupying Mine They Seek to Save
description: A mine that nobody seems to want but the men and women who work in it has become a symbol of the bitter mood of betrayal that has soured the joy of German reunification, three years after capitalism came here to the eastern part of the country.

title: Norman Andersson, Bass-Baritone, 40
description: Norman Andersson, a bass-baritone who sang at the Metropolitan Opera and with several symphony orchestras, died on Monday at his home in Chatham Center, N.Y. He was 40.

title: THE CROWN HEIGHTS REPORT: The Mayor; For Mayor, a Harsh Light
description: Ever since the Crown Heights disturbances two years ago, Mayor David N. Dinkins has been fending off critics by challenging their most extreme charges.

title: ResultsPlus
description: TENNIS Graf and Germany Out Two weeks after winning her fifth Wimbledon singles title, Steffi Graf returned to competition yesterday in what turned out to be a cameo appearance. Bothered by an inflamed shoulder tendon, Graf, who has been nursing a foot injury since June, was upset in the Federation Cup in Frankfurt, and her defending champion German team was ousted in the first round by Australia. Graf, the world's top-ranked women's player, was beaten by Nicole Provis, 6-4, 1-6, 6-1, in 75 minutes. The German team was beaten, 2-1, and became the first Federation Cup defending champion to lose in the first round of the women's version of the Davis Cup. The United States advanced to the second round with a 3-0 sweep over Switzerland. For the fifth-seeded United States, Lindsay Davenport, making her Federation Cup debut, beat Christelle Fauche, 6-4, 6-3, and Lori McNeil rallied to defeat Emanuela Zardo, 1-6, 6-3, 6-3. Ann Grossman and Debbie Graham completed the shutout by winning the doubles, 6-3, 6-1. (AP) PRO BASKETBALL Knicks in Winter Form The Knicks and the Bullets were in midseason rather than midsummer form last night before 2,790 fans at the Westchester County Center in White Plains. With 1:50 left in the game, following a pair of free throws by Greg Anthony, both benches emptied after Washington's Don MacLean apparently elbowed the Knicks' Irving Thomas. When the court was cleared, double technical fouls and ejections were assessed to MacLean and Thomas. The Bullets won, 111-107, and handed the Knicks their first loss of the Doral Arrowwood New York Summer League tournament.

title:
BASEBALL;
Fire Damages Part of Braves' Stadium
description: A fire erupted in a luxury suite on the third-base side of Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium and quickly engulfed several sections of the club level, delaying the start of the Atlanta Braves' game with the St. Louis Cardinals by nearly two hours tonight.

title: U.N., Easing Somalia Issue, Names Italian to Peace Office
description: In an effort to ease strains between Italy and the United Nations over the Italian role in the peacekeeping operation in Somalia, the Secretary General's office announced today that an Italian officer was being assigned to the Secretariat's peacekeeping operation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Hungarian minority in Romania misstated the position of a political party representing them. The party, called the Democratic Union of Hungarians in Romania, does not demand Hungary's annexation of the Transylvania region in Romania; some of its allies in Budapest do.

title: THE CROWN HEIGHTS REPORT: The Overview; CROWN HEIGHTS STUDY FINDS DINKINS AND POLICE AT FAULT IN LETTING UNREST ESCALATE
description: A chain of leadership failures by Mayor David N. Dinkins, top City Hall advisers and the city's leading police commanders allowed the disturbances in Crown Heights to escalate unabated into a four-day "riot" in which Hasidic Jews were singled out by bands of black youths, according to a state report released yesterday.

title: National City Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share earnings for all periods are not adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split which will begin trading on a split basis July 26.

title: Sales Higher, Philip Morris Widens Cigarette Price Cuts
description: The Philip Morris Companies announced yesterday that Marlboro cigarettes have sold well enough at lower prices during its current promotion to justify making the cuts permanent, and said it would extend lower prices to the company's other premium brands.

title: Change at the Top for the F.B.I.
description: President Clinton finally ended the damaging stalemate over the F.B.I.'s leadership when he dismissed William Sessions, the amiable, proud but ultimately ineffective Director. Mr. Sessions was only halfway through a 10-year term, yet his departure was overdue.

description: As one public official recalled, "I had never seen anything like the fear that was in this city that afternoon. It was like Godzilla was in New Jersey and was coming into New York."

title: No Phone? New Stores Filling Gap
description: Miguel Santos manages to call his wife in the Dominican Republic each day, even though he has neither a phone at home nor a credit card to use at a sidewalk pay phone.

title: Review/Dance; Remembering Nikolais and His Many Gifts
description: Alwin Nikolais's multi-media dance works have been so strongly predicated on abstract design that his own physical presence always seemed relegated to that of a behind-the-scenes magician. Yet barely two months after his death at the age of 82, his personality is felt more strongly than ever.

title: Cuomo Aide and 40 Experts Behind the 600-Page Report
description: The two-volume, 600-page report on the Crown Heights disturbances released yesterday was painstakingly pieced together by a team of 40 state lawyers, analysts and investigators, many of whom worked full-time on the project for eight months.

title: Taylor Isn't Putting Around as Career Wanes
description: Over the last year, Lawrence Taylor has played more golf than football. He will never make any golf hall of fame, but he is destined to make a trip to football's. To many, he is the greatest linebacker in the history of the game.

description: Share earnings for both the latest and year-ago 6-month periods both included a dilution of 9 cents resulting from additional average number of shares outstanding. Second quarter per-share figures included a dilution of 3 cents.

description: Year-ago results are pro forma and reported as though the company were fully taxed, although it did not return to fully-taxed status until late in 1993, as all remaining tax benefit carryforwards were exhausted in late 1992.

description: To the Editor:

description: Warhol Estate Value Settled

Out of the Corners: Letterman-Leno Preliminary
description: Although they won't face each other on the air for six weeks, David Letterman and Jay Leno got a chance to compete this week in the networks' never-ending publicity match.

title: From the Report: On Police Actions and Commissioner Brown
description: Following are excerpts from the report's conclusions about the police response to the violence. From Executive Summary Planning . . .

title: Dhaka Donates To Flood Relief
description: The offers of relief continued to arrive this week in the flooded Midwest. Just as the victims of Hurricane Andrew sent fresh water, the people of Bangladesh, subject to annual monsoons, offered what they could -- jute sacks, like those used for sandbags, and tea.

title: Great Western Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net gain of $ 31 million from adoption of accounting changes for postretirement benefits. Before this gain, net from operations was $ 119,540,000 or 88 cents a primary share.

title: U.S. Expands Bond Inquiry
description: The United States Attorney's office in Baton Rouge, La., is investigating the sale of $604 million State of Louisiana bonds in the latest expansion of a Federal inquiry into the $1.2 trillion municipal bond market.

title: For a Korean Merchant, Holding On to Dreams
description: IN the bright sunlight of morning yesterday, in the week before his 40th birthday, Sang Han stood in his store in Brooklyn, feeling good. The neat display of brazenly colored sneakers, T-shirts and pants in Sneaker King at 298 Utica Avenue gave no hint of the chaos that engulfed him almost two years ago when his store was looted and almost forced out of business during the Crown Heights disturbances.

title: Lewis and Bowe Camps Duke It Out With Words in Regard to Possible Matchup
description: The heavyweight boxing division degenerated into one of its periodic battles royal yesterday with just about everybody but the boxers in the ring and swinging wildly. By day's end, the various managers, lawyers and promoters were bruised but standing, still able to point accusing fingers at one other.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about President Clinton's new policy governing homosexuality in the military referred incorrectly in some copies to Fort McNair, where he spoke. It is in Washington, not Virginia.

title: GINSBURG PROMISES JUDICIAL RESTRAINT IF SHE JOINS COURT
description: Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg, President Clinton's nominee to the Supreme Court, told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that she would be neither a conservative nor a liberal on the Court, but someone who ruled cautiously, without reaching out to write broad principles into the law.

title: A Hamburg Judge Rebuffs Lopez of VW
description: The credibility of an embattled top Volkswagen executive, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, was damaged today when a Hamburg court ruled that Der Spiegel, Germany's most influential news magazine, could continue to report assertions that he took secret documents from the General Motors Corporation.

title: Majkowski Signs With Indianapolis
description: DON MAJKOWSKI, who passed for almost 11,000 yards and 54 touchdowns in six seasons with Green Bay, signed a one-year contract with the Indianapolis Colts yesterday, General Manager JIM IRSAY said.

title: Still a Pigmentocracy
description: The place of race in distributing electoral power is one of the hottest issues that Ruth Bader Ginsburg and her colleagues will face when, as expected, she becomes a Supreme Court Justice.

title: White House Aide Found Dead; Close Associate of the Clintons
description: The deputy White House counsel, an Arkansas native who was recruited for the job by Hillary Rodham Clinton, was found dead of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound Tuesday night at a park in northern Virginia.

title: Optimism Dashed Along Mississippi as River Rises Once More at St. Louis
description: The Mississippi River rose in St. Louis again today, dashing some of the optimism that the worst ravages of the historic floods of '93 might be past.

title: KIWI AIRLINE TO EXPAND NEWARK-TO-FLORIDA SERVICE
description: Kiwi International Air Lines will add evening service on Aug. 1 from Newark to Tampa, Fla., expanding the morning service begun on June 10. The new service includes flights from Newark on Sunday through Thursday evenings, with morning returns from Tampa Monday through Friday. Kiwi began service in September 1992.

title: Teheran Journal; Mobilizing Against Pop Music and Other Horrors
description: The traffic had gradually slowed to a crawl along Africa Street in north Teheran. Prostitutes who had been on the curbside moments earlier nodding discreetly to male motorists from beneath the folds of black cloth suddenly melted into the side streets.

title: Helping the Hungry With Hoes, Not Handouts
description: OVER the last few years, a powerful alliance has been forged as celebrity chefs, restaurateurs and relief organizations have joined forces to help the hungry. At fancy fund-raising dinners, chefs have dazzled contributors with their latest culinary creations and in the process raised millions of dollars.

title: Review/Music; Previn Sits In With the Tokyo String Quartet
description: The second movement of Mozart's String Quartet in E flat is astonishing with its passing dissonances. Brahms's String Quartet in C minor combines rigorous concentration with unsettling rhythms and gestures. And Schumann's Piano Quintet is intoxicating fun, full of swerves and exclamations.

title: Society Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 13.2 million, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of branches and loans required with the March 1992 acquisition of Ameritrust.

title: Seeking Data To Find Rate Of Graduates
description: When Congress passed the Student Right to Know and Campus Security Act three years ago, it was hailed as the most consumer-oriented legislation ever to benefit parents and their college-bound children.

title: Get Serious About Chinese Prison Labor
description: It's illegal for American companies to import goods made by prison labor. But according to human rights groups, China continues to make products for the export market in its prison factories, and U.S. companies continue to buy them.

title: Cincinnati Bell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Cincinnati Bell Inc.'s latest second quarter results included nonrecurring adjustments, but the company said the net effect was not material. The adjustments included a charge of about $ 2 million for a write-down of inventories at Cincinnati Bell Supply, and ''positive adjustments at Cincinnati Bell Telephone to reflect a change in vacation policy and the deferral of certain postretirement expenses.''Cincinnati Bell said revenues fell 5 percent in the latest 6 months as a result of CBT's sale of its residential equipment line in February, and the conclusion of major contracts at CBIS, the company's information management unit.For the latest 6 months, Cincinnati Bell noted that it had a first-quarter gain of 10 cents a share from CBT's sale of the equipment line. The company said its results for the same period a year ago included a gain of 5 cents a share in the first quarter.

title: Metropolitan Golf Report
description: New York State Open Darrell Kestner, in his fourth year as the head pro at Deepdale Golf Club in Manhasset, L.I., was in first place by three shots yesterday after the first round of the $65,000 Michelob New York State Open. He shot six-under-par 66 on the 6,768-yard Albany Country Club course in Voorheesville.

title: Mercantile Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to include results of MidAmerica Corp. and Johnson County Bankshares Inc., acquired in January 1993, which have been accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Citicorp's Income Posts Sharp Gain In Quarter
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, posted sharply higher second-quarter earnings yesterday, continuing its recovery from a disaterous run-in with bad real estate loans.

description: From beginning to end, the investigation into the death of Yankel Rosenbaum during the racial disturbances in Crown Heights was a protracted exercise in how not to solve and prosecute a crime, according to the state report released yesterday.

description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's re-election campaign has decided not to try to knock Roy E. Innis off the Democratic primary ballot by challenging the signatures on Mr. Innis's nominating petitions.

description: At the Lone Oak campground, people arriving for the weekend set to work at traditional camping chores: securing their recreational vehicles, setting up grills and, in a few cases, actually raising a tent.

Blue-Chip Park Plan On Shaky Foundation
description: If George Steinbrenner considers New Jersey a serious bargaining chip in his threat to abandon Yankee Stadium and New York, he probably shouldn't be so quick to take a free ride across the George Washington Bridge.

description: Frank A. Scioscia, a former publishing executive who ran a popular bookstore in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., died on July 10 at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: Final Act for the F.B.I.'s Director Is Painful and Almost Mute
description: In the end there was little left to say. On Monday evening shortly after 7:30, the suddenly former F.B.I. Director, William S. Sessions, dispatched a brief farewell teletype to the agency's 56 field offices and legal attaches overseas.

title: Both Heavy Talk and Weighty Talk
description: Two key Giants' regulars who are no-shows at camp have drawn attention in reports circulating around the National Football League. One is linebacker Pepper Johnson, who has been the subject of trade talk, according to several N.F.L. general managers, though the Giants deny it. The other is the Pro Bowl running back, Rodney Hampton, who several people close to the situation said may be eating himself out of shape.

description: Whole Foods, Whole

title: WARNER-LAMBERT CO. (N)
description: The Warner-Lambert Company yesterday reported lackluster second-quarter results as it continued to await final regulatory approval to market Cognex, its new treatment for Alzheimer's disease.

description: b-Included a net gain of $ 6,100,000 from the sale of Meridian's common stock investment in Fidelity National Financial Inc.Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Nellie I. Teale, 92; Naturalist Assisted In Acclaimed Books
description: Nellie Imogene Donovan Teale, a naturalist who collaborated with the Pulitzer Prize-winning nature writer Edwin Way Teale, her husband, died on Sunday at the Abbey Manor Convalescent Home in Windham, Conn. She was 92 and until a few weeks ago lived at Trail Wood in Hampton, Conn.

title: Star Banc Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to month 00
Daniels's Theme: The Sidewalks of New York
description: Lloyd Daniels played a pick-up game on a playground court yesterday, and you could not help but think that he was home. If there was one place he belonged, this was it.

title: Lollapalooza, Tattoos and All
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 20 — Purple hair! Pierced lips! Tattoos! Souvenir T-shirts that cost $28! They were all on display in the audience for the Lollapalooza Festival, the third annual version of the alternative-rock showcase and package tour, which got under way on Friday afternoon at Thunderbird Stadium here. Primus, Alice in Chains, Dinosaur Jr., Fishbone and Arrested Development are the major names in a lineup that also includes seven other bands. But the audience is also an attraction, as fans in their teens and 20's look at themselves and test their self-image as a community.

title: Nets Cut Four Players
description: The Nets have cut four players, including two players who played college ball locally, JERRY WALKER and STEVE WORTHY.

title: In Break for Clinton, Nunn Lends Support To Gay-Troop Plan
description: Pulling back from his insistence that his own, potentially stricter proposal be written into law, Senator Sam Nunn today lent general support to President Clinton's new policy toward homosexuals in the military.

title: Review/Film; Amid Gay Diversity, A Singleness of Purpose
description: Sadness, sensuality and a defiant militance infuse "Boys' Shorts: The New Queer Cinema," a program of six short films that opens today at the Village East Cinema. Of the film makers, two (Marlon Riggs and Michael Mayson) are black Americans, and one (Mark Christopher) is a white American. The remaining three are Australian (Stephen Cummins), Canadian (Laurie Lynd) and English (Christopher Newby). Despite their diversity of backgrounds and style, their overlapping concerns with AIDS, homophobia and sexual liberation suggest an underlying commonality of spirit.

title: Park Is Classroom but Turtle Is Truant
description: Henry Luce 3d thinks children should know about natural science. Not only is he giving $1.3 million for an education program in Central Park, he gave the first class as well yesterday for a few of the 30,000 children that the program is intended to reach.

title: No Headline
description: "It would be wrong for me to say or preview in this legislative chamber how I would cast my vote on questions the Supreme Court may be called upon to decide. A judge sworn to decide impartially can offer no forecasts, no hints, for that would show not only disregard for the specifics of the particular case, it would display disdain for the entire judicial process." -- JUDGE RUTH BADER GINSBURG. [ A1:3. ]

title: Accounts
description: * Information Synthesis, Minneapolis, to Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, as the first agency to handle the software company's account. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Crazy Eddie Founder Guilty of Fraud
description: Eddie Antar, head of the Crazy Eddie discount electronics chain, was convicted yesterday by a Federal jury in Newark of running an $80 million stock fraud that ultimately produced his business's collapse.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the legal problems of Robert V. Rota, a former House Postmaster, misstated his resignation date in some editions. Mr. Rota, who was the subject of an investigation into corruption in the House Post Office during his two decades as Postmaster, resigned in 1992, not 1991.

title: (Or, You Can't Eat It if You Can't Read It)
description: In the restaurants of Manhattan's Chinatown, the Chinese seem to eat food very different from that offered to non-Chinese.

The company previously reported net income of $ 181,337,000, or 87 cents a share, in the second quarter and $ 360,054,000, or $ 1.73 a share, in the 6 months.

title: Eschel Rhoodie, a South African At Center of Scandal, Dies at 60
description: Eschel Mostert Rhoodie, South Africa's chief propagandist for apartheid until one of his country's worst political scandals brought him down in 1978, died Saturday in Atlanta. He was 60.

title: Public Relations Salaries Slip a Bit
description: The median salary for public relations practitioners decreased slightly last year, to $46,204 from $46,556, according to the eighth annual salary survey by The Public Relations Journal, which is published by the Public Relations Society of America in New York.

title: Sports of The Times; High Stakes; Low Sense Of Values
description: IN launching an investigation into Michael Jordan's gambling habits, the National Basketball Association has embarked, or rather, has been taken on a far-reaching ride across revealing, occasionally treacherous landscape.

title: Yearling Sales Rise
description: For the first time in four years, the horse market showed signs of stabilizing last night when the prestigious July sale of selected yearlings in Kentucky ended with a gain of about 3.5 percent over last year.

title: Becton Dickinson & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said latest quarter and 9 months' share earnings reflects stronger dollar relative to other currencies which reduced net income by 3 cents a share and 5 cents a share, respectively. Also included is a capital gain of 7 cents a share in both the quarter and 9 months.Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split.Becton Dickinson & Co. said foreign currency translation reduced sales by $ 7 million during its latest third quarter and $ 18 million during the nine months.

title: Personal Health
description: CATARACT surgery today is a far cry from the procedure of decades past. Back then, patients waited until their vision was nearly totally obscured by a cloudy lens and were then hospitalized for 10 days or more, their heads immobile with sandbags while their eyes healed. They were then sent home with Coke-bottle spectacles that restored their sight but greatly enlarged and distorted visual images.

title: U.S. Bancorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 59,890,000 from an accounting adjustment.Per share earnings in the latest quarter and 6 months periods followed preferred dividend payments.

title: Wine Talk
description: "ONLY the dead know Brooklyn," Thomas Wolfe once wrote. It's a safe bet that even they don't know Bordeaux.
