Passages printed in boldface type appear that way in the original report. From Executive Summary City Hall: Oversight and Intervention

title: THE SUPREME COURT: Reporter's Notebook; Hearing Without Strife Brings Joy to Senators
description: Drama was not much in evidence as the latest Supreme Court confirmation hearing got under way today, but memory was.

title: Germany Will Free Muslim Who Seized Two in Beirut as Hostages
description: German prosecutors announced today that they would soon release a Shiite Muslim kidnapper who has served half of his 13-year jail sentence here, and deport him to his native Lebanon.

title: Carmichael Lynch Given Score Account
description: The Score Group Inc. of Grand Prairie, Tex., said yesterday that it had moved its Score and Pinnacle brands of sports trading cards to Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis from Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano in New York, without a review. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Top Chefs Try to Develop Taste for Amazon Fish At Rain-Forest Benefit
description: FOR the last few years, we've been inundated with rain-forest products, especially fruits and nuts, to highlight the plight of threatened tropical regions. Now, along come fish.

title: Historic Town Waits Out Crest
description: Newly heightened levees protecting Ste. Genevieve, Mo., held today, but the long-awaited flood crest of the Mississippi River was late in coming to this historic French settlement.

title: Stocks Stage Rebound, With Dow Up 9.50
description: Stocks moved higher yesterday on rebounds in a number of sectors that recently endured selloffs. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.50 points to finish at 3,544.78 in heavy trading.

title: General Signal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of debt of $ 6,576,000 in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net loss and after a charge from adoption of changes in accounting principles of $ 92,400,000.Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 16.Year-ago share earnings for the quarter included charge of 2 cents a share for discontinued semiconductor equipment operations.

title: Nagle Hoping a Contract Is First '93 Completion
description: In a sign that Browning Nagle wants to make a serious push for the starting quarterback job, his agent, Leigh Steinberg, said yesterday that he would meet with the Jets' president, Steve Gutman, in New York today in an effort to get a new contract for Nagle before the start of training camp tomorrow.

title: SouthTrust Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Angrily, Clinton Defends Record
description: As reporters questioned him by satellite hookup today, President Clinton angrily declared that he had built a record of uncommon success in his first six months and accused the news media of blocking his message.

title: Review/Television; Spying and Prying at Work
description: "It's a brave new world of data rape," says Maria Shriver, summing up tonight's accounts of people who say their privacy has been violated at their places of work. The prying pried on in "Big Brother Is My Boss" takes the form of mandatory psychological tests, cameras hidden all over the place, scrutiny of what employees punch into their computers and urine examinations, ostensibly for drugs but potentially for all manner of intimate information.

title: CHANGE AT THE F.B.I.: Man in the News; The New Man for the F.B.I.: Louis Joseph Freeh
description: In nominating Judge Louis J. Freeh to be Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, President Clinton turned yesterday to a man who, the judge's friends say, has been unconsciously training for the job his entire professional life.

title: On The Run With Florence Griffith Joyner; Still Racing Around, But for the Long Haul
description: "Florence can probably do lunch Wednesday, unless she has to give a press conference. Then she'll have to reschedule lunch for Thursday, but that's contingent on whether she's lunching at the White House with the President."

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Baxter International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 81,000,000, or 29 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.c-After a loss of $ 5,000,000 in the quarter and a gain of $ 14,000,000, or 5 cents a share, in the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and the 6 months also included a charge of $ 165,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Racing Asks Lukas to Set Pace
description: Wayne Lukas considered the irony of it, and said: "No, I'm not going to ride up on a white horse and save the racing business. But I'll be there. I'm not broke. I'll be a factor."

title: JUDGE REJECTS INTEL MOTION IN COPYRIGHT DISPUTE
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a motion by the Intel Corporation to reinstate a jury verdict in its copyright-license dispute with Advanced Micro Devices Inc. Judge William A. Ingram of Federal District Court in San Francisco affirmed his April decision that a second trial should be held because Intel improperly withheld key documents that could have influenced the 1992 trial. The jury's verdict had blocked Advanced Micro from cloning the microcode, or underlying software, in Intel's 287 math co-processors, part of a personal computer's brains.

title: 6 Candidates Wrestle for Ground Stein Abandoned
description: When City Council President Andrew J. Stein abruptly withdrew from the Public Advocate's race three weeks ago, politicians wondered who would benefit the most. The answer, analysts now say, is that all the remaining six major Democratic candidates will, but to varying degrees.

title: The Chosen Sex -- A special report; Chinese Turn to Ultrasound, Scorning Baby Girls for Boys
description: Half a dozen barefoot peasants took a break during a fierce storm the other day, and as the rain pounded on the rice paddies outside, they lounged in a crude stone cottage and marveled at 20th-century technology.

title: West One Bancorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Thomas R. Wilcox, 76, a Banker Who Rose From Page to Chairman
description: Thomas Robert Wilcox, who started out as a page at First National City Bank in New York and retired 47 years later as chairman of Crocker National Bank in San Francisco, died Monday at his home in Dering Harbor on Shelter Island, L.I. He was 76.

title: Forlorn, Not Four Straight, For Mets
description: The Mets had their electric razors revving in the clubhouse, but now must shut them down. A simple bet during a steak dinner had temporarily lifted this team out of its season-long stupor, but, in the end, old habits died hard.

title: F.B.I. Chief's Fall From Power
description: He came to the F.B.I. in 1987 as a figure of integrity; he left Monday under a cloud. The tumultuous tenure of William Sessions. Page A10.

title: Campus Journal; Sex Accusations Roil a Liberal Enclave
description: She was a freshman and a little homesick when she went to a dormitory party last December. She became ill after drinking Cisco, a cheap wine.

title: Debates and Speeches, Videos and Dramas
description: Central Park East Secondary School, on Madison Avenue in East Harlem, is a far cry from the type of high school that most Americans remember. Students study a core curriculum -- no shopping around for that easy course on principles of physical education, no shunting students with poor grades off to auto mechanics. Classes routinely run two hours, and no bells ring.

title: Contract Expires on Islanders Sale
description: After two years, the deal to sell the Islanders appears to have lost steam. Yesterday, the owner, JOHN PICKETT, said that the contract for the planned sale of the team to CHARLES DOLAN, a Long Island-based cable television executive, had expired with both parties unable to reach an agreement. Though Pickett said he expected the Dolan family to be involved in future team ownership, the partnership of Walsh, Greenwood & Company and First Long Island Investors will continue to run the team.

title: Decay Threatens Discoveries at Edison's 'Invention Factory'
description: On the upper floors of the Thomas Edison Invention Laboratories, beyond the places tourists go, phonograph records sit in musty darkness, dusty and warping as the seasons change.

title: 'Goodbye Girl' Closing
description: "The Goodbye Girl," the Broadway musical adaptation of the 1977 movie written by Neil Simon, is to close after the matinee on Aug. 15 at the Marquis Theater (1535 Broadway, at 45th Street). The show, which stars Bernadette Peters and Martin Short, opened to mixed reviews on March 5 after a tryout in Chicago. The Aug. 15 matinee will be the 188th regular performance; the show had 23 previews.

title: N. H. Bronner, 79, Atlantan Who Led Cosmetics Company
description: Nathaniel H. Bronner Sr., whose success in selling products from his sister's beauty salon led to the creation of an international cosmetics company, died Monday at a hospital in Atlanta. He was 79 and lived in Atlanta.

title: Aerospace Gets Down to Earth
description: University researchers and a group of companies including Du Pont and Lockheed hope to beat swords into infrastructure by building a bridge in San Diego made of lightweight composite materials similar to those originally intended for the B-2 bomber.

title: Disney Going for the Long Haul
description: In 2093, Mickey Mouse will be 165 years old and probably traveling the cartoon circuit on electronic paths not found on any computer drawing board today. That will also be the year that the 100-year bond that the Walt Disney Company plans to sell today will mature.

title: Louisiana-Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lab Backs Police On Death
description: A state investigator looking into the case of a robbery suspect whose death after a police chase earlier this month touched off unrest in this city's black neighborhoods said today that the man apparently committed suicide.

title: Clinton Names New York Judge As F.B.I. Chief
description: President Clinton finished assembling his roster of top crime fighters today with the announcement that he would appoint Judge Louis J. Freeh of Federal District Court in Manhattan to replace William S. Sessions as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: American Brands reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 201,000,000 for adoption of FASB 106 and 112.

title: Bemis Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
60-Minute Gourmet
description: ANYONE who has traveled through the herb-perfumed countryside of Provence is familiar with one of the region's great delicacies: seafood soup. The ingredients vary from village to village -- some have more shellfish than others, some a greater variety of finfish -- but all are as fresh and uplifting as a Mediterranean dawn.

title: Affiliated Publications reports earnings for 13wks to June 27
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 13,800,000 from a cumulative effect on prior periods of accounting changes.

title: Review/Fashion; Three Cheers for Couture, With Ungaro Leading the Way
description: In a triumphant collection of quiet distinction, Emanuel Ungaro proved that delicacy and luxury can coexist in couture. Karl Lagerfeld showed fashion can happen anywhere, in the elegant couture salons as well as in the street. And Hubert de Givenchy provided the stable factor: clothes in agreeable shapes guaranteed to flatter.

title: A Pasta Sauce With a Middle-Eastern Flavor
description: SMALL pasta shapes combined with bite-size pieces of vegetables is one of those generic dishes that can use almost any assortment of vegetables and any small pasta that is readily available. The mixture can be paired with a variety of sauces, though tomato-based ones are most commonly used.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JONATHAN DEMME, the film director, was involved with the fight to win freedom for the 264 Haitians held at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba. A Federal judge ordered them released last month. A member of the board of directors of the National Coalition for Haitian refugees, Mr. Demme marched, demonstrated and spoke out for the Haitians who were detained for about 20 months because they had H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Tonight, he will be in attendance at a happier occasion, a benefit show and sale of their art at the Cavin-Morris Gallery, 560 Broadway at Prince Street.

title: Temporaries Have to Do Without a Safety Net; Second-Class Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: In Iraq, Hunger Wins
description: Nearly three years after the United Nations Security Council imposed an economic blockade on Iraq, the soaring prices and grinding shortages inflicted on ordinary people finally seem to be influencing Iraq's decision makers.

title: Pride of the Cowboys: 'Winning Is What We Do'
description: Michael Irvin snatched a quick out pass from quarterback Hugh Millen, spun, and sped upfield before turning back to an official.

title: Prescription for Airline Industry: Tinker Just a Bit
description: With Congress making noises about stanching the airline industry's financial hemorrhage and President Clinton going out of his way to lend a sympathetic ear to the industry's pleas for help, free marketeers have been on the defensive.

title: Television Coverage Of Senate Hearings
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee's confirmation hearings on Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg's nomination to the Supreme Court will be covered live today, beginning at 10 A.M., Eastern daylight time, by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Review/Film; Going Back Home, Again and Again, To Find Vietnam and to Find Herself
description: "From Hollywood to Hanoi," opening today at Film Forum, is an intense, personal, supremely self-confident feature-length documentary that owes a lot to the cinema journalism of Michael Moore, the man who confronted General Motors in "Roger and Me." Like the Moore film, "From Hollywood to Hanoi" is as much about the film maker behind it as it is about the subject it appears to be exploring.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BRITISH PETROLEUM P.L.C., London, signed an agreement with Hong Leong of Singapore and Fuzhou Gas Corp. of China to develop a $15.5 million liquefied petroleum gas plant in China's southeastern province of Fujian. BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES, Houston, a waste services company, announced that its jointly owned affiliate, Swire BFI Waste Services Ltd., had been awarded a contract for the Sha Tin waste transfer station in Hong Kong. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Old Kent Financial (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gay Groups Denounce the Pentagon's New Policy
description: Military leaders today described the new policy on homosexuals in the military as an honorable compromise. But leaders of gay groups and homosexuals who have served in the armed forces are casting the directive issued Monday as an overwhelming defeat, a disheartening capitulation by President Clinton and a painful rebuke over an issue that some said they never expected or wanted to become an important rallying cry.

title: CHEMICAL BANKING CORP. (N)
description: Successful trading activities and fewer bad loans helped the Chemical Banking Corporation increase second-quarter profits by 59 percent.

title: If Only Stanley Could Pitch for Yankees, Too
description: Mike Stanley slugged his second grand slam in three games and third in three weeks last night, but his friends from the Yankees' opponent-friendly bullpen squandered a late-inning lead for the fourth time in 14 games.

title: Mary Kramer, 56; Led Effort to Save Mills in New Jersey
description: Mary Ellen Forbes Kramer, who led the campaign to preserve and redevelop the historic mill district in Paterson, N.J., died on Monday at a hospital in Norwalk, Conn. She was 56 and lived in Little Falls, N.J., and Weston, Conn.

title: Georgia Gulf Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from the early retirement of debt of $ 13,267,000 and a gain of $ 12,973,000, or 32 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Oil Off Sharply Over Doubts OPEC Can Control Output
description: Crude oil prices fell sharply yesterday as skepticism grew about OPEC's ability to cut output in the face of renewed Iraqi oil exports.

title: Ex-Detroit Police Officer Testifies He Never Struck Victim of Fatal Beating
description: A former Detroit police officer charged with murder in the fatal beating of a driver told jurors today that he never struck the victim.

title: Cultural Climate Teaches Boys Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribune Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an accounting charge of $ 16.8 million.

title: As Baseball Owners Go, O'Malley Wasn't Mr. Nice Guy Either; Revitalize Stadium Area
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 15,454,000 from the early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $ 200,103,000, or $ 2.62 a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Ismail the Younger Has Pact With Vikings
description: The first Ismail to join the National Football League reported to the Mankato State campus yesterday.

title: At Fort Bragg, Reaction to Gay Policy Is Largely Ho-Hum
description: Around the fast-food restaurants, pawnshops and convenience stores near this military community, soldiers said today that President Clinton's decision to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military would change little in their lives -- and that suited most of them just fine.

title: 'Expert' Babies Found to Teach Others
description: IT was during the blustery days of last March that 10-month-old Russell Ruud taught the other babies in his day-care group a lesson their parents may have wished he hadn't: how to unzip the Velcro chin straps of their winter hats.

title: Greenspan Is Upbeat On Growth
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, gave a surprisingly upbeat assessment of economic growth today but said the news on inflation was disappointing, signaling that the central bank was poised to raise interest rates if inflation accelerated.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a protest by Orthodox Jews concerning the special school district in the village of Kiryas Joel, N.Y., referred incorrectly to the protesters. They were opposing the school district, saying that its secular nature compromises their religious beliefs.

title: Clinton Rallies Party Around Budget
description: His economic program on the line, President Clinton gave a rousing speech today to a group of Democratic lawmakers who are crucial to the success of his plan, demanding that they exercise the political courage necessary to raise taxes and cut spending.

title: BIC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-After a loss from an accounting adjustment of $ 9,816,000.

title: Rebate Offer Should Not Harm G.M.
description: G.M.'s proposed settlement of lawsuits related to the company's pickup trucks is unlikely to create a huge financial liability for the No. 1 auto maker, analysts said today.

title: Bosnian Children's Hospital Cleaned Up by U.N. Troops
description: A team of United Nations soldiers and aid workers reported today that normal food distribution and sanitary conditions had been restored in a hospital for mentally handicapped children that had been abandoned by its staff when the area had been attacked by the Muslim-led Bosnian Army.

title: Where School Is More Than Just Showing Up
description: In this tiny school district in the Philadelphia suburbs, high school students learn at their own pace. But before they can graduate, they have to demonstrate competence in nine academic areas.

description: b-Net incomeMartin Marietta's latest results are the first to reflect the company's April 2 acquisition of General Electric Co.'s aerospace business.Martin Marietta Earnings -3-: Latest 6 Mos Includes Acctg Chg

description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: MANHATTAN JUDGE PICKED TO HEAD F.B.I. President Clinton says he will appoint a Manhattan judge, Louis J. Freeh of Federal District Court, to replace William Sessions as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. A1. NEW YORK CITY THE CROWN HEIGHTS REPORT: LEADERSHIP FAILURES ARE CITED A chain of leadership failures by Mayor Dinkins, top City Hall advisers and the city's leading police commanders caused the disturbances in Crown Heights to escalate unabated into a three-day "riot" in which Hasidic Jews were singled out by bands of black youths, according to a state report. A1.

title: Earnings Rose for Times Co. in 2d Quarter
description: The New York Times Company yesterday reported second-quarter earnings of $22.4 million, or 28 cents a share, up from $14 million, or 18 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1992.

title: Report Says Traffic Increased Plane Crash Toll
description: The massing of emergency vehicles was partly to blame for hours of delays in getting survivors of a 1990 airplane crash to hospitals, which may have raised the death toll by 20 percent, according to a report by Brookhaven National Laboratory.

description: b-After a charge of $ 99.3 million from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net incomeThe accounting adjustment reflected cumulative effect of changes in methods of accounting for postretirement benefits and income taxes.

description: b-Net lossThe bank said second-quarter 1993 results included about $ 3.1 million in reserves for litigation-related expenses relating to a class-action shareholder suit and other suits, all of which Hibernia is contesting.The bank aslo said that neither second-quarter nor 6-month 1993 results included securities gains, compared with gains of $ 6.5 million in second quarter 1992 and $ 17.2 milllion in 6 months 1992.

title: Consolidated Rail reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 74,000,000 from adoption of FASB 106 and 109.Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in September 1992 for both the quarter and 6 months, and earnings for the quarter and 6 months were reduced by 5 cents a share and 7 cents a share, respectively, due to a two-day work stoppage because of a national rail labor dispute.

title: No, America Won't Forget Tiananmen Sq.
description: To the Editor:

title: Grunfeld Gets a Promotion
description: The Knicks made official today what everybody has known for days: Ernie Grunfeld has been promoted to vice president and general manager of the team.

title: Airlines Clash in Court on Fares
description: With videotapes, flip-charts, enlargements of once-secret memos and thousands of documents, armies of lawyers in Federal District Court here are re-enacting the airline fare war of 1992.

title: Two Traders Indicted In Board of Trade Fraud
description: Two traders who rattled Treasury bond markets and nearly bankrupted an old-line clearing firm at the Chicago Board of Trade in October were indicted today on Federal wire fraud charges.

title: Mead Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-Net lossc-After income of $ 34 million, or 58 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been converted from Dutch guilders/florins (NLG) at 1.7809 equaled $ 1.00, the Noon buying rate of May 28. The rate compared with NLG 1.8096 equaled $ 1.00, used at this time last year.

title: Mubarak Is Nominated Again Amid Mounting Discontent
description: Parliament nominated President Hosni Mubarak for a third six-year term today despite growing opposition demands for political changes and mounting discontent.

title: FoxMeyer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings comparisons are affected by FoxMeyer's purchase of 1.5 million shares of its common stock in the first half of fiscal 1993, and the purchase by FoxMeyer of an added 1.65 million shares in a joint tender offer in November 1992 with National Intergroup Inc., its parent company.

title: F.T.C. Stays Deadlocked On Microsoft
description: The Federal Trade Commission remained deadlocked today over whether to charge the world's biggest software publisher, the Microsoft Corporation, with engaging in anticompetitive business practices, according to executives familiar with the outcome of the commission's meeting.

title: Marsh & McLennan reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 40.1 million from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago period was restated to reflect the adoption, effective Jan. 1, 1992, of SFAS No. 106, ''Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions,'' and SFAS No. 109, ''Accounting for Income Taxes.''

title: Victims of the Storms
description: For more than a month now, the Mississippi, the Missouri, the Des Moines, rivers all over the Midwest, have been bursting levees, drowning crops and entire towns, shutting down roads and bridges, and forcing thousands of people from their homes.

title: Review/Pop; For Whitney Houston, Showy Doesn't Count: The Show Is the Voice
description: Whitney Houston is one of the few contemporary pop stars of whom it might be said: the voice suffices. While almost every performer whose albums sell in the millions calls upon an entertainer's bag of tricks, from telling jokes to dancing to circus pyrotechnics, Ms. Houston would rather just stand there and sing. When not standing still, she either paces back and forth across the stage or sits on a stool. She doesn't tell jokes. When she talks, her patter has the clunky ring of predigested interview responses.

title: M. Birnbaum, 48; Leader in Financing Independent Films
description: Malcolm A. Birnbaum, a leader in the financing of independently produced movies, died on Tuesday at his summer home in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 48 and lived in Manhattan.

title: McKesson Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included special credit after taxes of $ 24.5 million, or 60 cents a share. The special credit is equal to $ 37.4 million before taxes and included a gain of $ 55 million on the sale and donation of Armor All stock, partially offset by a contribution to the McKesson Foundation of $ 4.3 million and a loss on the termination of interest rate swap arrangements of $ 13.4 million.The latest first quarter also included charge of $ 4.2 million reflecting the retirement of $ 50 million of 8.625 percent debt, and an extraordinary charge of $ 15.8 million reflecting the cumulative effect of adopting a new accounting method for post-employment benefits.

title: Swedish Conductor Joins Manhattan School
description: The Swedish conductor Sixten Ehrling has been appointed chief conductor and musical adviser to the three orchestras at the Manhattan School of Music, the school's president, Marta Istomin, has announced. In addition to his work with the Symphony, the Philharmonia and the Chamber Sinfonia, he will work with opera productions at the school. Starting in 1994, he plans to accept a limited number of graduate students in conducting.

title: 3 COMPANIES JOIN TO SEEK $2 BILLION CONTRACT
description: GM Hughes Electronics, International Business Machines' Federal Systems unit and BTG Inc. said they had teamed up to try to win a $2 billion Navy computer contract.

title: A survey shows that Tina Brown's New Yorker is attracting more, and wealthier, readers.
description: ONE might reasonably contend that The New Yorker's Valentine-week cover illustration of a black woman and Hasidic man kissing was a little too provocative. Or that this week's cover, showing an Arab boy at the beach jumping into sand figures shaped like lower Manhattan, might perpetuate a stereotype.

Proceeds from certain litigation reflect the company's May 1993 settlement of a patent lawsuit for $ 105 million.c-Included a gain of $ 15 million, or 11 cents a share, to reflect the adoption of SFAS 109.

title: American Stems Tide Of Losses
description: American Airlines yesterday reported its first quarterly profit in almost two years, and a top executive took the occasion to invite the airline's unions to discuss an equity stake. It coupled the invitation with a threat to eliminate service in less-profitable markets.

title: Bishop Germanos Polizoidis, 95; Held High Greek Orghodox Posts
description: Metropolitan Germanos Polizoidis, the senior Metropolitan Bishop of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, died on July 13 at Astoria General Hospital in Queens. He was 95 and lived in the Lyden Nursing Home in Astoria.

description: b-Included a one-time, after-tax charge of $ 30 million to cover anticipated additional costs associated with promotional programs in the U.K.c-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 307 million from an adjustment in accounting.

title: THE CROWN HEIGHTS REPORT: The Overview; Reno Seeks Quick Inquiry On Civil-Rights Charges
description: As pressure arrived at her doorstep yesterday, Attorney General Janet Reno said her department would decide "as expeditiously as possible" whether to seek Federal civil-rights prosecutions stemming from the four days of violence in Crown Heights two years ago.

title: Chubb Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 20 million for changes in accounting for income taxes and for postretirement benefits other than pensions.

description: b-Reduced by $ 2,671,000 or 53 cents a share, for the net cumulative effect of change in two accounting principles recorded in the first quarter.Latest quarter's declines in revenues were primarily attributed to the downturn in the aerospace market, which makes up about 60 percent of the company's operating revenues.

title: Price Tag: Quitting Smoking
description: In 1965 about 40 percent of adults in the United States smoked cigarettes; today the figure has dropped to 25 percent. A study by the Centers for Disease Control found that in 1990 and 1991, 42 percent of daily smokers tried to quit for more than one day. Eighty-six percent of them failed.

title: Ecolab Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss related to retirement of debt (net of income tax benefit of $ 2,528,000) of $ 4,018,000 in both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6 months also included a gain of $ 4,733,000, or 15 cents a share, from change in accounting for income taxes.

title: THE CROWN HEIGHTS REPORT: Covering the Unrest; Press Had Blind Spots, Too
description: The state report this week on the Crown Heights violence two years ago told a story about the crisis different from the one told by New York City news organizations at the time.

title: No Headline
description: I saw a glimmer of light a while back, but that's only turning out to be a pause. At this point there's no light at the end of the tunnel. -- FRED GADOMSKI, a Penn State meteorologist, on prospects for the Midwest. [ D22:5. ]

title: Protest Sends President on Retreat From Sofia
description: A noisy band of his former backers prevented President Zheliu Zhelev from entering his office for nearly three weeks in June by setting up a tent camp in front of it.

title: Johnson & Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 595,000,000 from adoption of FAS 106, 109 and 112.Johnson & Johnson said net income in the year-ago second quarter was restated to include an after-tax $ 12 million charge as a result of the adoption of FAS 106, 109 and 112. Net income for the first half of 1992 included a $ 24-million charge as a result of the adoption.The company said year-ago results have been restated to reflect a one-time after-tax charge of $ 595 million due to the company's early adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 106, No. 109, and No. 112. In addition, results have been restated to include an after-tax charge of $ 24 million attributable to these accounting changes.

title: More Ways to Stay Cool
description: To The Home Section:

title: Rebellion Flares Anew in Northeast of India
description: When guerrillas ambushed a military convoy in the Northeast of India recently, killing more than 25 soldiers, they signaled a resurgence of their 40-year campaign for independence.

title: Next Israeli Skirmish: Breaking Bureaucratic Grip
description: A traveler at Ben-Gurion Airport stood as a symbol last week of the distance some Israelis will go to evade the tangle of Government regulations, tariffs and penalties that rule their lives.

title: Arkansas Best (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 162,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary charge from extinguishment of debt of $ 329,000 in the 6 months.c-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $ 15,853,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $ 15,853,000 in the 6 months, and the 6 months also included a charge of $ 3,363,000 from an accounting adjustment.Latest quarter and 6 months' share earnings reflects preferred stock dividends of $ 1.1 million and $ 1.8 million, respectively.

title: Television Coverage Of Senate Hearings
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee's confirmation hearings on Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg's nomination to the Supreme Court will be covered live today, beginning at 10 A.M., Eastern daylight time, by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Where Once Only Garbage Grew, a Secret Garden
description: There's a new buzz coming to a Bronx neighborhood that stands on the cusp between urban disaster and revitalization. It is not the buzz of summers past, the sound of windows shaking with the violent vibrations of a passing car's stereo at full blast, or the buzz teen-agers feel from the marijuana sold openly in their streets.

title: Pakistan's Pas de Trois
description: Pakistan appears to be staggering toward the resolution of a five-month crisis. Politics in that country is intensely personal, as strongly spiced as the national cuisine. Incompatibility has been nearly total between President Gulam Ishaq Khan and Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif. So both have now resigned, thus opening the way for Pakistan's sixth election in as many years, a consummation devoutly sought by the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto, who threatened to paralyze Islamabad with protest demonstrations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Monday about technological changes at the Cahners Publishing Company omitted part of the role of Reuters in the newly formed Reuters/Variety Entertainment News Service. Besides distributing information for the service, Reuters will supply information, along with Variety.

title: Corrections
description: A caption yesterday with a picture by The Associated Press showing Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg and supporters at a hearing on her nomination to the Supreme Court misstated the relationship of an audience member, Lisa Brauston, to Judge Ginsburg's son, James. She is a friend, not his wife.

title: Flaw Is Discovered In Crucial Research On AIDS Treatment
description: Three months into a national trial of a combination of three drugs that experts have called the best hope for treating AIDS, new laboratory findings have cast serious doubt on the validity of the scientific premise of the studies.

title: Executive Changes
description: BLOOMINGDALE'S, New York, named Christine Miller executive vice president of marketing. MICROSOFT CORP., Redmond, Wash., named Nathan Myhrvold, vice president of advanced technology and business development, as senior vice president of the group.

title: A Sense of Judicial Limits
description: After two days of her Supreme Court confirmation hearing, Ruth Bader Ginsburg has emerged as something of a rare creature in the modern judicial lexicon: a judicial-restraint liberal.

title: Southern National reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 3,571,000 to reflect the cumulative effect of change in accounting principles.Results are restated to reflect the acquisition of FedFirst Bancshares Inc. on January 29, 1993.

title: Rate Rules Won't Hurt Cable Giant
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's biggest cable television company, said today that new Federal rate regulations would cut no more than $160 million from its annual revenues -- a smaller bite than many industry experts had been expecting.

title: Avon Products reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 10,000,000 and a charge of $ 107,500,000 from cumulative effect of changes in accounting for postretirement benefits and income taxes.c-Net income and included a restructuring charge of $ 64.4 million.

title: Dow, in 10.62 Rise, Reaches a High
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed at an all-time high yesterday on a day when all other market indicators moved in the opposite direction.

title: Strong Surge In Earnings For Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation proved yesterday that it was the personal computer maker doing best in the industry price war, reporting that its profit tripled in the second quarter.

title: Dinkins Requests Reports From Wary School Board
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has asked the New York City Board of Education, an independent agency, to report to him regularly on basic issues from tightened school security to the opening of 34 small high schools.

title: Taking a Spill
description: Stock of Bell Sports Inc., which makes bicycle helmets, set a 52-week high of $36.25 on Tuesday. But yesterday, its stock fell after it was removed from the recommended list at Goldman, Sachs. Traders said the ratings adjustment was largely because the stock had done so well and might have become too expensive. Higher sales are still expected, as several states move to require bicycle helmets for children.

title: White House Aide Leaves No Clue About Suicide

title: CAESARS WORLD TO INVEST IN INDIAN CASINO
description: Caesars World Inc. said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to help the Agua Caliente band of Cahuilla Indians build and operate a $25 million casino in Palm Springs, Calif. Under the agreement, Caesars World will finance construction of the 80,000-square-foot facility and manage it. About 50 percent of the space will be devoted to nongambling activities.

description: The news deluge began at noon Tuesday, on schedule.

title: Trial on Tax Evasion Opens For Ex-Kingmaker in Tokyo
description: At the opening of what could prove the most explosive political trial in the post-war era, the former political kingmaker Shin Kanemaru pleaded not guilty to tax evasion charges this morning. He also said that the $50 million in gold bullion, bearer bonds and cash that investigators had found in his home and offices was for political, not personal purposes.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CLAPBOARD siding has been used on houses for centuries and can last the life of a house if maintained regularly and repaired promptly. Clapboards, which are arranged in an overlapping horizontal pattern, were originally split from tree trunks rather than sawed, and splitting produced the characteristic wedge-shape profile, thicker at the bottom than at the top. As a result, clapboard siding is sometimes called bevel siding.

title: THE CROWN HEIGHTS REPORT: The Prosecutor; Brooklyn District Attorney Defends Handling of Crown Heights Prosecution
description: District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn yesterday attacked a state report that said lapses by his office had contributed to the acquittal of the lone youth prosecuted in the slaying of a Hasidic man during the 1991 Crown Heights violence.

title: M.T.A. Plan Is Held Up By Albany
description: A fight in the State Legislature over the distribution of transportation money is holding up a $9.5 billion plan to improve mass transit in the New York City area and causing cash-flow problems for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, officials say.

title: Von Stade Cancellation
description: The mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade has canceled her scheduled appearance with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra on Saturday evening because of illness, and the concert program has been changed. Yoav Talmi will conduct an all-orchestral program of Dvorak's "New World" Symphony, Bizet's "Arlesienne Suite" and Ravel's "Daphnis et Chloe" Suites Nos. 1 and 2. Tickets are $15 and $20. The concert is at 8:30 P.M. in Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J. Information: (201) 347-4700.

title: The Chair Woman For the Bored

"Painted furniture dates back to the Venetians, whose gold treatments were sophisticated yet whimsical," Ms. Morgan said. "That's what I'm after." Her designs are bold: speckled trout in a butter-yellow stream, oak and maple leaves on a scarlet lawn, the Queen of Hearts and Ace of Spades.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A few years ago, VINCENT SARDI Jr. had to tell ROBERT GOULET that a caricature of him, drawn in 1960 by Don Bevan when Mr. Goulet first opened in "Camelot," had disappeared from the walls of Sardi's. After the actor finishes tonight's performance in the current Broadway production of "Camelot" at the Gershwin Theater, the restaurant will present him with a new portrait by Richard Baratz, who has been the resident caricaturist at Sardi's for the last 17 years. Then, said Max Klimavicius, the general manager of the restaurant, according to Sardi's tradition, Mr. Goulet will sign it and his portrait will hang once again.

title: Bothered and Bewildered
description: Murphy Brown's baby apparently has a lot of real-life company. A just released Census Bureau report tells us that among white women and women with some college education, the percentage who have become mothers without marrying has more than doubled in the last decade, to 14.6 percent and 11.3 percent, respectively; among women with professional or managerial jobs, it has almost tripled, to 8.3 percent. While the numbers are small -- most unwed mothers are poor and thus disproportionately black or Hispanic -- they show that single motherhood cannot be explained by words like "inner-city," "welfare dependency" and "pathology."

title: Kukoc Woos Jordan and Pippen
description: Unforgettable for Toni Kukoc was the first time he played against the Dream Team in Barcelona, Spain, last year -- which consisted, in this case, primarily of him trying to play one-on-two against Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen, a feat that even Hercules might have found taxing. PARENT & CHILD
description: FOR many children and adolescents, experimenting with petty crime is a part of growing up. It may be a way to fit in with a group or to test the limits of acceptable behavior. To the child, taking a "five-finger discount" on some makeup at the drugstore or spray-painting a name on a wall may seem relatively harmless, especially when compared with violent crimes.

title: Woman, 84, Found Slain
description: An 84-year-old woman, her throat slashed, was found dead in a bathtub in her Brooklyn apartment yesterday, the police said. A mattress was on top of the woman, Anna Bernstein, who was lying fully clothed in a small amount of water, said Sgt. Frances Haimeck, a police spokeswoman. There were no signs of forced entry or robbery in the apartment, on 85th Street in Bensonhurst, and the police said they did not know why the mattress had been placed on her. Mrs. Bernstein's son, who lives out of state, became concerned when his mother did not answer her phone for more than two days. He called a cousin, who found the body. The police had no suspects or motives for the killing.

title: South Africa Envoys Reflect Apartheid's End
description: They cannot vote in national elections in South Africa and are still classified as a black, a colored and an Indian in South Africa, but the three officials at the South African Embassy here emphasize that they are the visual signs abroad of the end of white rule at home.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER U.S. Wins and Advances to Gold Cup Final Cle Kooiman's goal 13 minutes into overtime last night gave the defending champion United States a 1-0 victory over Costa Rica and a spot in the finals of the CONCACAF Gold Cup soccer tournament. Kooiman took Roy Wegerle's crossing pass seven yards from the Costan Rican goal and knocked the ball over the head of goaltender Eric Lonnis with his right foot. The United States will meet the winner of today's semifinal between Mexico and Jamaica in Mexico City's Aztec Stadium, also the site of Sunday's final. The United States had a scoring opportunity in the 73d minute when Eric Wynalda went in alone on goal, but Lonnis covered the point-blank shot to keep the game scoreless. Wynalda had another opportunity in the 21st minute, but his shot from 15 yards out skidded past the left goal post. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Bubka Returns to Form and Clears 19-5 1/2 Sergei Bubka returned to form yesterday, winning the pole vault at 19 feet 5 1/2 inches in the Nikaia Grand Prix meet in Nice, France. Bubka made three attempts at a world-record 20-1 3/4. He was able to get his legs over the bar on each attempt but hit it hard with his body. Bubka had been in a slump lately, winning only one of his last four meets before Nice and had a jump of only 18-4 3/4 on Monday at Barcelona, Spain. The Ukrainian has broken the world record 16 times outdoors and 18 times indoors. Igor Potapovich of Kazakhstan was second with Olympic champion Maxim Tarasov of Russia third. (AP)

But Orsulak trying to throw plastic to home plate provided one more reel for their 1993 blooper highlights film.

title: GTE Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a provision of $ 74 million ($ 46 million after taxes, or 5 cents a share) in connection with the company's voluntary separation programs in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net loss and after a charge of $ 2,441,000,000 which represents cumulative effect of changes in accounting for postretirement health care and life insurance benefits (FAS No. 106) and income taxes (FAS No. 109) retroactive to Jan. 1, 1992.The company said that results for the first three quarters of 1992 were also restated to give effect to the adoption of FAS No. 106. The second quarter and 6 months 1992 effects reduced net income by $ 34 million, or four cents a share, and $ 68 million, or 8 cents a share, respectively.

title: Coca-Cola Names Marketing Officer
description: The Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta said yesterday that it had named Sergio Zyman to the new position of chief marketing officer. He will assume responsibilities of Peter Sealey, who announced that he was resigning as senior vice president and director of global marketing to open his own marketing consulting business, effective Aug. 20.

title: Bill Would Exempt Navy From Environment Law
description: Three weeks after a Federal judge barred the Energy Department from storing any more spent fuel from the Navy's nuclear-powered vessels at an atomic reservation in Idaho, the Senate Armed Services Committee yesterday began considering a bill that would override the judge's order by exempting the Navy from one of the nation's leading environmental laws.

title: Protecting Children's Eyes From the Sun
description: FOR many adults, summer means wearing sunglasses. And many parents, concerned about the effects of ultraviolet radiation on the eye, are seeking to protect their children's eyes, too. As a result, the market for children's sunglasses has exploded, reaching even into baby carriages.

title: Wrong Place, Wrong Time
description: When the Bush Administration virtually forced the United Nations into Somalia to be rid of its own unilateral intervention, it was taken for granted that a functioning Government would soon be formed to take over. Some months would be needed to muster a new national police and army, but once they were reasonably organized the U.N. withdrawal could begin. That plan was based on the assumption that the likes of Mohammed Farah Aidid were political leaders, willing and able to govern. Actually, they are bandit chiefs, interested only in loot.

title: 'Jail' for Pakistan Politicians Isn't So Rough
description: Muzaffar Sial Khan flipped the tails of his kameez, the traditional knee-length baggy pajama top worn by Pakistani men, and patted his stomach.

title: INSIDE
description: The C.I.A. and the Sheik

title: Bruno Agrees to Oct. 1 Bout With Lewis
description: Passing up a chance to make far more money by facing a more renowned champion, FRANK BRUNO, the popular British heavyweight, has agreed to fight LENNOX LEWIS, the World Boxing Council champion, in Cardiff, Wales, on Oct. 1.

title: Lazaro Cardenas Journal; A Mystery for Mexico: Was Acid Spilled at Sea?
description: Where the long, white beaches slip down from groves of coconut palm and by the weathered wooden shacks that line the Balsas River, the fishing boats are all pulled up idle.

title: Brother of Bomb Suspect Held In Case Tied to Fake Passport
description: The brother of a man charged in the foiled plot to bomb New York City targets has been arrested for using a fake passport and will be moved from Brooklyn to Virginia to face trial, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EMANUEL UNGARO, 60, finished showing his latest fashion collection in Paris Tuesday night, then entered the American Hospital there for a heart bypass operation. He had learned of his condition while working on the collection but had postponed treatment until after the show. He told friends he expected to be out of the hospital at the end of next week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GEORGE HARRISON has gone to court in Hawaii to prevent people from traipsing by the house he built on Maui, The Associated Press reported. The former Beatle said he was unaware when he bought the land that it included a right-of-way so others could get to the beach.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Arrow Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 2,400,000 which reflects redemption of 133/4 percent debentures.The company said the latest results included Spoerle Electronic, a electronics distributor in Germany, which was accounted for under the equity method prior to January 1993 when Arrow acquired an additional 15 percent share, increasing its holding to a majority interest. Excluding Spoerle, sales for the quarter were $ 493 million. The additional interest in Spoerle, after financing costs, did not have a significant impact on net income. Results also included the electronic component distribution and value added service businesses of Zeus Components Inc. from their date of acquisition in May. Zeus did not have a significant impact on the quarter's consolidated sales or net income.

title: Some Jewelry for the Home
description: ROBERT LEE MORRIS, the jewelry designer, makes objects for the home that are sensuous and organic. A bowl (left) looks like petals unfolding. A platter is a gentle undulation. On Aug. 3, he will introduce these and other objects of aluminum and pewter at Bloomingdale's nationwide. They are not his first metal home accessories, but, at $35 to $80 each, they are the first priced to reach a market larger than two.

title: NORDSTROM PLANS TO ISSUE VISA CARDS
description: Nordstrom Inc., the retailer based in Seattle, announced yesterday that it planned to issue Visa bank cards through its affiliate bank, Nordstrom National Credit Bank. The company already has its own Nordstrom credit card. But use of the Nordstrom card has declined because customers have increased their use of bank cards with incentive programs, like the Citibank Visa card that awards holders points in American Airlines' frequent flier program based on their purchases, a company spokeswoman said.

title: U.S. Offers 350 Troops to U.N. Force for Haiti
description: The United States has offered to send about 350 troops and military engineers to Haiti as part of an international force to help retrain Haiti's army and work on military construction projects as the country returns to democracy, senior American officials said today.

title: Melville Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 22,551,000 reflecting the adoption of SFAS No. 106, Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.

title: Agassi Is Named to Davis Cup Team
description: ANDRE AGASSI and MALIVAI WASHINGTON in singles and PATRICK McENROE and RICHEY RENEBERG in doubles will make up the 1993 United States Davis Cup team that will face the Bahamas at the Olde Providence Racquet Club in Charlotte, N.C., Sept. 24-26. In announcing the lineup for the qualifying-round match for 1994 World Group play, the United States captain, TOM GORMAN, played down the absence of top-ranked PETE SAMPRAS and No. 2-ranked JIM COURIER, Wimbledon's finalists this year.

title: U.S. Won't Act in Bosnia Until the Europeans Do
description: With Serbian forces advancing near the Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, the Clinton Administration has decided to do nothing more to help Bosnia and has blamed the Europeans for the mounting crisis .

title: Synovus Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Robert M. Estes, 81, G.E.'s Chief Lawyer
description: Robert Mason Estes, who retired in 1976 as a senior vice president and general counsel of the General Electric Company, died Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. He was 81 and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Long and Straight at Crooked Stick
description: More than its male counterpart, the United States Women's Open is about power. In recent years, its winners have included exceptionally strong hitters like Laura Davies and Betsy King. And even though the defending champion is the moderately long hitting Patty Sheehan, the grueling Oakmont Country Club course near Pittsburgh that she won on last year featured several par-4 holes that much of the field could not reach in two shots.

title: Advo Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: The company said year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for 5-for-4 stock split effective March 5.

title: 2 More Leave Fieldcrest
description: Fieldcrest Cannon Inc. today announced the resignation of two more board directors, raising to four the number of board members who have quit since Friday. The members who resigned -- William C. Bullock Jr. and Frank Gerrity 2d -- were added to the textile company's board on June 16, when the board was expanded to 17 from 12 by the Amoskeag Company, Fieldcrest's largest and controlling shareholder. Fieldcrest is striving to remain independent in the wake of an unsolicited takeover offer by Springs Industries.

title: When Crime Invades a Backyard, a Neighborhood Is Shocked
description: It was a setting that any family in America would be comfortable with: children playing house in a fenced-in backyard on a Sunday afternoon, within earshot of their parents inside the home.

title: The Home of Gilbert and Sullivan Reopens After a Fire. With a Ballet.
description: The Savoy Theater, built by Richard D'Oyly Carte as a home for Gilbert and Sullivan's operettas and opened in 1881, was gutted by fire in February 1990. On Monday night, lovingly restored, it reopened with a black-tie gala, complete with free Champagne for all and a banquet afterward in the Savoy Hotel, overlooking the Thames. The only oddity was that the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company was nowhere in sight.

title: A Crimean Question: Whose Navy Is It, Anyway?
description: The marching melody of "Moscow Nights" blared from ships docked at harborside here as young sailors hoisted and then saluted the pale-blue-and-white naval ensigns, emblems of the Russian czars. The early morning ceremony on support vessels of the Black Sea Fleet appeared routine enough.

title: Federal-Mogul Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 4.7 million, or 17 cents a share, from previously announced sale of Federal-Mogul Westwind Air Bearings Ltd. in the both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net loss and after a charge of $ 88,100,000 from adoption of accounting changes.Year-ago results are restated to reflect adoption of accounting changes for postretirement benefits other than pensions.

title: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: The Water Police; Mark Twain Would Understand the Water Crisis That's Corrupting Iowans
description: Though Mark Twain traveled the world, he understood Midwestern river towns best of all and would have grasped perfectly the wounded pride now of Iowa's capital.

title: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: The Fallen; Friends and Family, Lost to Mean Rivers
description: A month later, people here still talk about how suddenly the storm came up that mid-June afternoon, and how hard it rained: Three inches in 30 minutes.

title: The Wet-Sheet Trick
description: To The Home Section:

title: McGinniss Adds Explanation to His Book
description: In a newly added note to the reader at the end of "The Last Brother," his forthcoming book on Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Joe McGinniss attempts to explain his somewhat unorthodox style of biography and to mollify early critics by saying that the book is "at least as much a 'rumination' as a biography."

title: Iraq Justly Rejects Surveillance Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinal Distribution (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 10,000,000 from the adoption of SFAS 109.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $300 million of medium-term notes due in 1998 at 100 to yield 5.27 percent through Merrill Lynch. The issue is callable in one year. * Pacific Gas and Electric Co., San Francisco, is offering through Goldman, Sachs $1.25 billion of debt securities in three parts. The first, which is not callable, consists of $400 million of 5.375 percent first- and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1998 at 99.635 to yield 5.459 percent. The second part, which is also not callable, consists of $400 million of 6.25 percent first- and refunding mortgage bonds due in 2003 at 99.892 to yield 6.264 percent. The third part, which is callable in 10 years, consists of $450 million of 7.25 percent first- and refunding mortgage bonds due in 2026 at 99.181 to yield 7.315 percent. The three issues are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by S.& P. and Duff & Phelps.

title: Market Place; Group Approves Use of Derivatives
description: A group of leading financial experts gave a relatively clean bill of health yesterday to the rapidly growing set of financial products called derivatives that some have suggested make the global financial system vulnerable to a widespread crisis.

title: Fearful of Bullpen, Yanks Take a Loss Anyway
description: Even Jimmy Key is allowed a dreadful performance every two months. Even Jimmy Key surrenders a crushing three-run homer once or twice a season. Even Jimmy Key loses.

title: Man Facing Eviction Attacks 2 in Family, Then Kills Himself
description: On the brink of eviction from his home in Rumson, N.J., a 56-year-old man used a shotgun to shoot his mother and to fracture the skull of his daughter yesterday before shooting himself, the police said.

title:
COMPANY REPORTS;
Northern Telecom Reports a Deficit
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. yesterday reported a second-quarter loss of $1.03 billion, or $4.13 a share, and said it would lay off 9 percent of its workers.

title: Thomas Campbell; Scholar, 57, Wrote On Foreign Policy
description: Thomas Moody Campbell, a scholar and author on 20th-century American foreign policies and relations, died on July 11 at a hospital in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 57 and lived in Tallahassee, where he taught at Florida State University for 30 years.

title: Anchor Away: Elliott Is Still Unsigned
description: One could easily argue that Giants lineman Jumbo Elliott may be the most critical player on the offense. Anchored at left tackle, he protects quarterback Phil Simms from defenses that are trying to blindside him. Running back Rodney Hampton has had back-to-back 1,000-yard seasons and Elliott is a big part of the reason why. The Giants desperately need him in camp. But when will they get him?

title: Time Warner Audio Book Plan
description: Time Warner Inc. plans to set up an audio book operation, to be known as Time Warner Audiobooks, the company announced this week.

title: Racial Remark Stalls Job Seeker
description: A finalist for the presidency of Michigan State University has run into trouble over a remark he made in 1989: "A black athlete can actually outjump a white athlete."

title: Hi-Lo Automotive Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Scott Paper Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Included income of $ 21.7 million, or 29 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.The latest periods' share earnings included a charge of about 4 cents a share for the potential settlement and associated legal expenses in connection with securities litigation begun against the company in 1990.Results were also negatively impacted about 2 cents a share due to the adjustment of the company's effective 1993 income tax rate to 38.5 percent.

title: Washington Heights Violence Has Deep Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: First Bancorp of Ohio (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Marion Merrell Dow Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included previously reported restructuring charge of $ 180 million in the quarter and 6 months.c-After income of $ 54 million, or 19 cents a share, from the effect of change in accounting principles for income taxes, and a charge of $ 33 million from the effect of change in accounting principles for postretirement benefits.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Gap Shuffles Its Management Team
description: The Gap Inc., the first specialty retailer to make fashion statements of blue jeans and T-shirts, yesterday announced several management changes. The moves reflect the effort by the company to give its four divisions distinct identities and streamline its corporate office.

title: Get Albany Legislature To Legislate Rationally
description: To the Editor:

title: Northrop Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Northrop said that the latest quarter reflected a $ 5 million loss provision for the Tri-Service Standoff Attack Missile program. In the year-earlier quarter, the company's results included a $ 9 million loss provision for a previously undisclosed secret military contract in the missiles and unmanned vehicles business segment.

title: Barnes Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included pretax charges of $ 4.3 million for the closing of the company's Associated Spring plant in Dayton, Ohio; and $ 2.6 million for cost overruns on contracts at its Jet Die aerospace facility in Lansing, Mich., in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Gabbers
description: Three out-of-towners boarded a Manhattan bus one morning last week, and asked a nearby passenger where they should get off to go to Port Authority. She told them. She also gave them her thoughts about the old Penn Station, the proposed new Penn Station, Grand Central Terminal and urban transportation in general. The peroration ended with "I'm a train person myself."

title: Japan's Leader Steps Down As New Battle Lines Form
description: Under intense pressure to quit or face ouster from office, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said this afternoon that he would resign to take responsibilty for the Liberal Democratic Party's loss of control over Parliament in Sunday's election.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BCE INC., a Canadian telecommunications holding company, said it sold Case-Hoyt Corp., a printing company based in Rochester, to Avanti Press Inc., Miami. Terms were not disclosed. LONRHO P.L.C., London, said it would sell its 50 percent stake in the international trading group, Krupp Lonrho G.m.b.H., to its joint venture partner, the steel group Fried. Krupp G.m.b.H., Essen, Germany, for $166.2 million cash.

title: Fleet Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that in the latest quarter it recognized $ 114 million in gains on the sale of securities, and a charge of $ 100 million within Fleet Mortgage Group related to the accelerated amortization of purchased mortgage servicing rights.Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Indian Effort On 88 Acres Has Setback
description: The Golden Hill Paugussetts' efforts to reclaim lands they once occupied in Fairfield County were dealt a severe blow today by a Federal judge who ruled that the claims cannot be heard until the Indians win recognition as a tribe from the Federal Government.

title: Review/Dance; Stravinsky's 'Sacre' as a Ritual for the New Age
description: Those who think a banana is a phallic symbol will have no trouble with Marie Chouinard's choreography. Three years ago, she broke a ram's horn off her forehead and pasted it on her body as a penis. The effect was as provocative as intended. But it was a solidly archetypal image that took Miss Chouinard's version of "L'Apres-midi d'un Faune" into the realm of the fantastic and the primal.

title: Ariel Rubstein Dead; Operatic Soprano, 41
description: Ariel D. Rubstein, a soprano who performed throughout the United States and Europe, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 41.

title: Queens Jury Awards Record Judgment in Suit on a Turnpike Accident
description: An accident on the New Jersey Turnpike on a rainy night in 1987 has produced the largest judgment for a case of its kind in New York State history: $163.9 million for a plaintiff who was almost completely paralyzed in the accident.

title: Events: Art Tours, Crafts, Gardens
description: Art Tours Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street at Central Avenue, Newark; (201) 596-6550.

title: No Motion For Jets On Key Contracts
description: It looks as if the Jets will open training camp today without their first-round draft pick, linebacker Marvin Jones, and fifth-round pick, running back Adrian Murrell. But they could have an agreement with last year's starting quarterback, Browning Nagle, before all the players are due to report to Hofstra University at 6 P.M.

title: Gordon Gray, Scottish Cardinal Influential in Rome, Is Dead at 82
description: Gordon Cardinal Gray, the spiritual leader of Scotland's 800,000 Roman Catholics since 1969, who was influential over the years in the liturgical policy of the Roman Catholic Church and its press relations, died Monday in Edinburgh. He was 82 and lived in Edinburgh.

title: Economic Scene; Japan's powerful civil servants resist a dose of deficit spending.
description: "WHAT the world needs from Japan is a sustained period of domestic demand-led growth," Lawrence H. Summers told a group of movers-and-shakers from the Japanese business community.

title: Long-Term Debt Rules the Day
description: Investors seemed to be hungry for higher yields and willing to take more risk to get them yesterday as they opened up and swallowed one of the largest mouthfuls of long-term debt ever.

title: Charles W. F. Smith, 88, Author, Educator and Episcopal Minister
description: The Rev. Charles W. F. Smith, an Episcopal minister, educator and author, died on Sunday at a daughter's home in Belleair, Fla. He was 88 and lived in Bridgewater Hill, N.H.

title: Lakers Won't Give Scott New Contract
description: BRYON SCOTT, who teamed with MAGIC JOHNSON in the backcourt during the glory years of the Los Angeles Lakers, won't be re-signed by the team and is an unrestricted free agent.

title: National Medical Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included pretax charges of $ 93.4 million in the quarter, which included: $ 59.3 million in realignment costs; $ 65 million in unusual legal fees; a gain of $ 18.9 million on sales or disposals of facilities and long-term investments; and a gain from other adjustments of $ 12 million.The year included pretax charges of $ 85.5 million, which were: $ 59.3 million in realignment costs; $ 65 million in unusual legal fees; and a gain of $ 38.8 million on sales or disposals of facilities and long-term investments.c-Net loss, which included pretax charges of $ 187.2 million, which were: $ 4 million in realignment costs; and a $ 183.2 million charge for divestitures and realignment, and extraordinary charge of $ 24,119,000 from costs of litigation and early extinguishment of debt.d-After extraordinary charge of $ 28,441,000 from costs of litigation and early extinguishment of debt, and included pretax charges of $ 186.7 million, which were: $ 32.7 million in realignment costs; and a $ 154 million charge for divestitures and realignment.

title: Utility's Rate Rise Is Limited
description: The State of Arizona has decided to grant the Citizens Utilities Company a $2.6 million rate increase for electricity; the company had requested $7.7 million.

title: On-the-Spot Hearings for Aliens Are Considered
description: As part of its effort to crack down on illegal immigration, the Clinton Administration is expected to announce a plan this week to create a kind of night court for aliens, dispensing instant justice for those who arrive without proper documents and request political asylum.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: In Somalia, Machiavelli Vs. Rambo
description: The United Nations has been painting Italy as a troublemaker, a disobedient child who thinks it knows better than its elders. When Rome dared to raise its concerns about the increasingly bloody course of the humanitarian mission in Somalia, it was quickly and publicly slapped down by U.N. officials from ground commanders to the Secretary General. Such high-handed behavior does little for the U.N.'s image and, worse still, it risks obscuring the real issue: that the methods and scope of the peacekeeping operation need to be reviewed.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB CO. (N)
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that declining sales of Capoten, its banner heart drug, led a 1 percent decline in pharmaceutical sales in the second quarter, compared with a strong showing in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Valley National Bancorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Daimler-Benz Job Cuts
description: Germany's biggest industrial group, Daimler-Benz A.G., said today that it planned to cut a further 100 to 200 jobs at its administration headquarters in Stuttgart. The additional round of job cuts follows a recent decision to cut 350 administrative jobs at the headquarters, a company spokesman said. He said there would be no layoffs and the cuts would be achieved though attrition.

title: Johnson & Johnson Reshuffles Accounts
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it had completed the long-awaited series of product account shifts among its agencies. The move, part of a worldwide realignment, elevated DDB Needham Worldwide in New York to a more vital role as its fourth worldwide agency.

title: REWARD IS STYMIED IN TOWERS BOMBING
description: A plan to offer up to $2 million in Government money for information about a missing suspect in the World Trade Center bombing has been stymied since mid-April by a dispute over what agency should foot the bill, officials acknowledged today.

title: Hear That? It's the Still-in-the-Bronx Bombers
description: The first one was a neatly placed shot, drifting high and barely landing deep enough to climb the right-field fence. The next one was awesome, zooming toward the deepest part of Yankee Stadium and disappearing over the 408-foot sign. Then there were two three-run bullets -- one barreling to left field and the other rocketing to right -- before one more prodigious blast to left completed the power picture.

title: GINSBURG DEFLECTS PRESSURE TO TALK ON DEATH PENALTY
description: Despite increasing pressure from Republican senators to spell out her positions on controversial issues, Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg today resisted giving her views on the death penalty and gay rights as she completed her third day of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about Tuesday's stock market trading misidentified the products made by the Amtech Corporation. They are electronic identification tags for vehicles, not anti-shoplifting devices.

title:
Luxury Condominium;
Sale Gives A Building 2d Chance
description: Begun in the giddy days of the 1980's and finished in the dour economic realities of the 1990's, Le Grand Palais, a luxury condominium sitting empty on Manhattan's East Side, has been given a second chance.

title: Fed Abandons Policy Tied to Money Supply
description: The Federal Reserve said today that the main yardstick it used in guiding the economy's growth for more than 15 years had become so unreliable that it would largely abandon it.

title: Giants' Remaining Draft Picks Sign On
description: Dan Reeves will of course be happy to know that his two remaining draft choices, defensive end Mike Strahan and linebacker Marcus Buckley, have reached agreement with the team and will soon report to camp. But he wasn't ecstatic about the most recent biting remarks made by his former quarterback John Elway.

title: Illinois Tool Works Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMOCO CORP. (N)
description: The Amoco Corporation announced yesterday that second-quarter earnings more than doubled from the period a year earlier.

title: Today's Hearing Will Be Closed
description: When the Senate Judiciary Committee reconvenes Friday morning to consider the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg it will do so in a session closed to the press and public.

title: Medicare Choice for Old Means Rationing
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Forces a Vote on Scandal Records
description: In an attempt to embarrass the House Democratic leadership and win a leg up on the 1994 elections, Republican Representatives forced a vote today on a resolution to make public all evidence gathered last year in an internal probe of the House Post Office scandal.

title: At Home Abroad; No Longer Quiet
description: "It used to be a quiet country," Dr. Vichit Suraphongchai said. "We opened the door, and in came the wind of change. Do we want to close it again?"

title: Free Trade's Fine, as Long as It's Really Free
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League SEATTLE MARINERS -- Placed Norm Charlton, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Activated Rich DeLucia, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CLAUDE MONTANA, the French fashion designer, and WALLIS FRANKEN, a former model, were married yesterday in the town hall of the seventh arrondisement in Paris. The couple first became engaged 18 years ago.

title: Change in 'Aladdin' Lyrics Looks Like Cowardly Censorship; A Hopeful Sign
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Terminating Outside Sales Staff Proves Costly to WD-40.
description: TIME was, if a company had cash to spare, a takeover artist or two would be at the door faster than you could say "Stick 'em up."

title: No Headline
description: We must get racism behind us. We must move forward. We must realize we live in America today. -- SENATOR HOWELL HEFLIN of Alabama, opposing the symbolic use of the Confederate flag. [ B6:6. ]

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jacquet's Big Band

title: Reviews/Art; In Connecticut, Clothes, Photos and a Yale on Yale
description: From Stamford to Hartford and at points in between, the summer art season in Connecticut includes a provocative look at contemporary art that uses clothing as a metaphor, an examination of the influence of the 19th-century photographer Eadweard Muybridge, a celebration of an important university art program and a consideration of the work of an American master. Ridgefield

title: Home Video
description: Imagine walking into the average video store and finding both older foreign films like "Madame Rosa" and a mix of specialized nonfiction titles like "L. B. J.," "A Calf Grows Up" and "The Rise and Fall of the Soviet Union."

title: INVESTCORP FILES SUIT OVER PARTNERSHIP IN GUCCI
description: In the opening salvo of what promises to be a fiery legal battle, the Investcorp Group, the investment company that owns Saks Fifth Avenue, Carvel and Color Tile among others, filed suit yesterday against Maurizio Gucci, its partner in the holding company that owns the various businesses of the Gucci luxury goods empire. Investcorp also filed a request for an arbitration agreement with the American Arbitration Association that would force Mr. Gucci and an investment fund allied with him called Seaton Hills Holding N.V. to sell their 50 percent stake in Gucci to Investcorp. Justice Stanley Sklar of State Supreme Court granted Investcorp a 10-day injunction.

title: Daughter of Slavery Hushes Senate
description: The Senate's only black member, Carol Moseley Braun, made the chamber listen today as freshmen seldom do. Her oratory of impassioned tears and shouts, stopped Jesse Helms in his tracks as he defended the Confederate flag.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a record judgment in a lawsuit involving a 1987 traffic accident referred incorrectly to the scene. The collision occurred on Interstate 95 in New Jersey; the stretch of road involved, in Englewood near the George Washington Bridge, did not become part of the New Jersey Turnpike until 1991.

title: American Cyanamid Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included one-time charge of $ 383.6 million related principally to write-off of acquired research and development from acquisition 53.5 percent interest in Immunex Corp. June 1. No significant tax benefit was available on this charge. Accordingly, earnings were reduced by $ 378.4 million, or $ 4.20 a share.c-After a charge of $ 552,400,000 from an accounting adjustment.d-Net income

title: Texaco's Earnings Double Despite Decline in Revenue
description: Texaco Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings more than doubled. It attributed the performance to higher domestic natural gas prices and an increase in the production of international oil.

title: New York City Accuses Three of Deceptive Investment Ads
description: New York City accused two mutual fund companies and one brokerage firm yesterday of engaging in deceptive advertising. The funds, Dreyfus and Franklin, and the brokerage firm, Charles Schwab, misrepresented investment risks or fund fees, the city's Consumer Affairs Department said.

title: Different Sides of Street; Response to Crown Heights Unrest Showed Divergent Paths of City Hall and the Police
description: When he was questioned by state investigators about a lack of coordination between City Hall and the police during the violence in Crown Heights two summers ago, former Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch responded this way: "My position was always, whether that was good or bad, was that we worked different sides of the street."

title: Emlen Etting, Artist, 88
description: Emlen Etting, a painter, sculptor and illustrator, died on Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 88.

title: Arco Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
