description: b-Included charge of $ 56 million related to divestiture of Korean joint venture in both the quarter and 6 months.c-After a net charge of $ 2,000,000 which included charge of $ 20 million for change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions and a gain of $ 18 million from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Dinkins Counterattacks; Giuliani Hammers Away
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, continued to hammer away yesterday at Mayor David N. Dinkins's handling of the Crown Heights racial violence, while Mr. Dinkins counterattacked by evoking the image of a peacemaker that was a key to his victory over Mr. Giuliani in 1989.

title: For Children
description: South Street Seaport Pier 17 South Street Lower Manhattan (212) 669-9400 Recommended for all ages

title: Walter D. Fackler, 71, Economist Known for Accurate Predictions
description: Walter D. Fackler, an economist known for the accuracy of his annual forecasts of national trends, died yesterday at a hospital in Chicago. He was 71 and lived in Chicago.

title: Reviews/Art; In the Hudson Valley, Three Moderns, One Age 91
description: In the Hudson Valley are surveys of the works of three very different contemporary artists: the eccentric self-searchings of Jonathan Borofsky are at the Hudson River Museum, the modernist drawings and sculptures of Dorothy Dehner at the Katonah Museum of Art, and the cerebral, architecturally derived constructions of Siah Armajani at the Storm King Art Center. Yonkers

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "THE DESIGN SHOW: EXHIBITION INVITATIONS IN THE U.S.A.," Exit Art/ The First World, 548 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo. Closes today. Free. Hours: 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: (212) 966-7745.

title: Gas Leak Disrupts Trains
description: Thousands of rush-hour commuters were delayed yesterday when a high-pressure gas main began leaking in Brooklyn and disrupted train service for more than an hour, the authorities said. The leak happened about 3:20 P.M. as Brooklyn Union Gas workers were repairing a 20-inch underground main at the intersection of McDonald Avenue and Avenue X, said Bob Loftus, a spokesman for the company.

title: Mets Get Lots of Gifts in 10-5 Victory
description: Somebody committed four errors tonight, and it was not the Mets. Los Angeles Manager Tom Lasorda, before the game, delivered one of his patented I-Bleed-Dodger-Blue pep talks, and his team ended up bleeding all right -- in the infield.

title: Justice Dept. to Stay on Case of Aide's Death
description: The Justice Department said today that it would continue investigating the death of Vincent W. Foster Jr., a senior White House lawyer and a close friend of President Clinton, until it could find a reason for his apparent suicide.

title: McDonald's Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represented total revenues.Systemwide sales in the latest periods totaled $ 5,958,900,000 in the quarter and $ 11,194,000,000 in the 6 months, compared with $ 5,386,900,000 and $ 10,302,500,000 in same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: New Jersey Blue Cross Reverses Policy
description: Under mounting pressure from the Legislature, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey today reversed its decision to offer only managed health care in the state and said it would also offer a range of contracts for people who buy their own insurance.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP. (N)
description: The tumult in European currency and bond markets helped Bankers Trust increase its earnings by 35 percent in the second quarter.

title: Cash Incentives for Human Rights
description: The new Caucasus republics of Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia are beset by human rights abuses. They are also desperate for foreign capital. This puts Western businesses in a strong position to demand a good human rights record before investing.

title: Awe and Acceptance of Their Ruinous River
description: Scrambling through cornfield flotsam into a borrowed boat, Richard Frakes ignored the terrible beauty of what the river had done. He was too intent on reaching his mother's inundated house a mile distant on the watery horizon and wading into the upstairs in search of a computer disk.

title: Alfredsson, Okamoto Share U.S. Open Lead
description: Using her power game on the course John Daly made famous and finishing with a flourish, Helen Alfredsson of Sweden took the first-round lead among the early finishers today in the 48th United States Women's Open.

title: Tiriac Gets the Boot
description: BORIS BECKER has parted with ION TIRIAC, his manager, ending a 10-year relationship that included three Wimbledon titles and numerous lucrative endorsement deals.

title: Donnelley (R.R.) & Sons (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 69,500,000 from an accounting adjustment.c-Net incomeLatest 6 months' income from continuing operations of $ 30,663,000 included a $ 90 million restructuring charge ($ 60.8 million net-of-tax) related primarily to the shutdown of the company's Chicago manufacturing facility following a customer's decision to discontinue its catalog operations.Share earnings results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Sept. 1, 1992.

title: Rikers Guard Is Accused Of Arranging to Be Shot
description: At first, Correction Officer Tommy Jones sounded like a hero.

title: The Midwest Flooding; In the Flood, Many Hear a Call to Serve
description: After watching enough flood coverage on television to feel waterlogged himself, Dave Culver decided it was his turn to help.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: BICKERING STALLS BOMB PLOT REWARD

title: Free Trade's Fine, as Long as It's Really Free; Pulling Workers Down
description: To the Editor:

title: The Refugee Panic Act of 1993
description: America, true to its tradition of sheltering the oppressed, guarantees due process to all who claim asylum here. Recently, however, America has devalued that guarantee. Public anxieties about job competition and terrorists as well as plain racism have so frightened Washington that it's been intercepting shiploads of Haitians and Chinese on the high seas before they can get a fair hearing on their claims of persecution.

title: BellSouth Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge on early extinguishment of debt of $ 55,400,000 in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Included a gain of $ 32.9 million, or 7 cents a share, on a regulatory settlement in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: A White House Death: Grief Wrapped in Confusion
description: A few months ago Amy Stewart asked her former law partner, Vincent W. Foster Jr., how he liked his new work. Mr. Foster, the deputy White House counsel, summed up his feelings like this: "Interesting, yes. Fun, no."

title: Black Journalists Talk of Gaps In Newsroom Advancement
description: Citing a striking difference between the way black journalists and their mainly white managers view questions of race in the newsroom, the National Association of Black Journalists is using its 18th annual convention here to examine the issue of not just getting blacks onto the staffs of the nation's newspapers and broadcast news outlets, but moving them up.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: 'Fool Moon' to Close

title: Mortgage Mover
description: Stock in the First Financial Caribbean Corporation, Puerto Rico's leading mortgage banker, has risen sharply since June. The company plans further expansion on the United States mainland and is awaiting approval to acquire Catano Savings Bank of Puerto Rico. Yesterday, the company reported record second-quarter earnings.

title: Review/Film; Along Some Mean Streets In Unlikely Locations
description: The single modern film most likely to put film schools out of business is Martin Scorsese's "Mean Streets," since it serves as a blueprint for so many new film makers eager to emulate Mr. Scorsese's fierce, boisterous brilliance. The mark of "Mean Streets" is all over "Amongst Friends," Rob Weiss's showy, energetic debut feature about (of course) boyhood buddies intoxicated by a life of crime.

title: Plan to Insure Abortion Survives an Early Vote
description: Using an arcane procedure and careful vote counting, Democratic abortion-rights supporters won a skirmish today over whether Federal employees' health insurance could cover abortions.

title: Sunbeam Will Settle Lawsuits
description: The Sunbeam-Oster Company said yesterday that it would pay $173 million in cash to Paul B. Kazarian and two of his partners to settle litigation over Mr. Kazarian's ouster as chairman and chief executive last January.

title: Review/Film; A Fake Mom and Dad And the Boy Next Door
description: "Another Stakeout" is made for the kind of person whom television drives out of the house to the movies but who doesn't want surprises when he arrives at the theater. It's big-screen television fare. Directed by John Badham, written by Jim Kouf and starring Richard Dreyfuss and Emilio Estevez, the film is not only a sequel to the same team's "Stakeout" (1987), but also to approximately 9 out of every 10 comic-cop movies made.

title: Now If He Can Cajole Ditka to Just Be Ditka
description: Jim Lampley sounds unconcerned about succeeding Bob Costas as the host of "N.F.L. Live" on NBC this fall, unworried about the nine-year reputation of credibility, facility and wit carved out during Costas's football run.

title: Lockheed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Net loss, which inluded the cumulative effect of a change in accounting. The amount of the accounting charge was not immediately available.

title: Scott Salmon, 50, Choreographer For Radio City's Seasonal Shows
description: Scott Salmon, director and choreographer of Radio City Music Hall's Christmas and Easter shows since 1990 and a Tony Award nominee, died on Saturday at Granada Hills Hospital in Granada Hills, Calif. He was 50 and lived in Studio City, Calif.

title: Long-Distance Giants Find Strength Amid Price Wars
description: After years of brutal price wars, the once viciously competitive long-distance telephone business is turning into a surprisingly cozy and profitable industry.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP. (N)
description: The BankAmerica Corporation reported essentially flat results yesterday, reflecting the slow California economy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Rohm & Haas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a net charge of 11 cents a share for unusual items. These included a gain on the sale of the company's Supelco subsidiary and write-downs linked to cancelling construction of a plastic facility in England and the restructuring of emulsion plants in the U.S.

title: Article 999093 -- No Title
description: If security is having money in the bank or a package of chocolate chip cookies carefully stashed away, knowing of a charming and affordable little restaurant not too far from the theater district can make one feel positively smug.

title: Genuine Parts reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a net charge of $ 1,055,000 from net effect of adoption of FAS 106, of a charge of $ 5,055,000 - net of income taxes of $ 3,095,000 - and an increase in net income of $ 4,000,000 for the adoption of FAS 109.The company also noted that financial statements for 1992 have been restated to reflect the issue of 9.6 million shares in January 1993 for all of the common stock outstanding of Berry Bearing Co. and certain affiliated companies. The transaction has been accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Dow Falls From Heights, Off 30.18 Points
description: Stocks retreated yesterday, a day after the Dow Jones industrial average set an all-time high. The average fell 30.18 points, to 3,525.22, in heavy trading.

title: Man Charged With Murder In Shooting In Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn man has been charged with murder in the shooting of a man who was the third of three brothers gunned down on the streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant during the last six years, the police said.

title: The Museum Exhibitions
description: Here is information about the museum exhibitions reviewed. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. Long Island "LONG ISLAND COLLECTIONS: THE GILDED AGE TO THE 1990's." (Through Sept. 12.) Nassau County Museum of Art, Northern Boulevard and Museum Drive, Roslyn Harbor, (516) 484-9337. Tuesday through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; closed Monday. Admission: $3; free on Fridays.

title: COMPANY REPORTS: As Firms Shift Strategies, the Old Order Moves On; Top Trader to Quit; Salomon Net Soars
description: The wrenching transformation of Salomon Brothers that began with a huge management shake-up following the 1991 Treasury markets scandal appears far from over. A series of announcements yesterday indicated that the firm might be shifting its emphasis from reliance on in-house trading decisions to business generated by its customers.

title: Brown-Forman Gets New Chief
description: The Brown-Forman Corporation said yesterday that Owsley Brown 2d, its president since 1983, had been named chief executive.

title: As Firms Shift Strategies, the Old Order Moves On; Perella Severing Wasserstein Link
description: Breaking up one of the most influential teams from the takeover battles of the 1980's, Joseph R. Perella will end his long-running partnership with Bruce Wasserstein and resign as chairman of their investment firm, the Wasserstein Perella Group.

title: U.S. Sees Side Accords Set For Trade Pact by August
description: With the pace of negotiations quickening, the environmental and labor side accords to a North American Free Trade Agreement should be completed by early August, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said here today.

title: Chris DeBlasio, Composer, 34
description: Chris DeBlasio, a composer best known for his song cycles, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 34.

title: Suffolk Chief Backs Amended Financing Measure
description: Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County Executive, backed a measure today that would pointedly tell voters that their taxes would pay the candidates' bills under a proposed local public campaign financing law. His critics called Mr. Gaffney's move a cynical attempt to sabotage campaign reform in Suffolk County.

title: Free Trade's Fine, as Long as It's Really Free; Environmental Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last: Chiappucci Stops Spinning His Two Wheels
description: Claudio Chiappucci, the nonstop attacker, finally won a stage of the Tour de France today.

title: Tax Fight Protects Lautenberg's Seat
description: Fifteen months before he comes up for re-election in New Jersey, Senator Frank Lautenberg is already running hard for a third term. His chief opponent at the moment appears to be Bill Clinton.

title: U.S. Says It Foiled Killings Plotted by Drug Chief
description: The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration said yesterday that the agency had headed off a series of killings and possible car bombings in New York City ordered by Pablo Escobar, one of the most violent Colombian drug traffickers.

title: TV Listings
description: On Fridays, television and radio news and listings now appear at the end of section D, with Home Video. Today, pages D15-16.

title: Morgenthau Says Release Was an Error
description: A woman who was accused of pushing two people onto subway tracks on Wednesday was arrested for a similar assault in May but was freed last month because of an error by prosecutors, the office of Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, acknowledged yesterday.

title: Reviews/Art; In New Jersey, Works From the Pacific and Tibet
description: A trip to New Jersey offers the best of several worlds this summer. At the Newark Museum, one can travel from the splendors of a vanished Tibet to the multicultural beauties of the South Pacific and myriad points in between, while an adventurous program at the Jersey City Museum offers up-to-the-minute contemporary art. Newark

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Good Ol' Steve Earle

title: Bogey, Bogey, Bogey, But Kestner Survives
description: Just when it looked as if the six-stroke lead he held at the beginning of the day was about to evaporate amid a streak of bogeys by himself and a run of birdies by his closest challenger, Darrell Kestner righted himself today and went on to capture the $65,000 Michelob New York State Open at Albany Country Club.

title: Ryder System Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 162,948,000 in the quarter and $ 158,658,000 in the 6 months, with both including a one-time after-tax charge of $ 169.4 million to restructure the aviation business and to provide for costs associated with the spinoff. The 6 months also was after a charge of $ 25,433,000 reflecting the adoption Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 106, ''Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.''Net sales from discontinued operations in the latest periods were $ 288.3 million in the quarter and $ 565.3 million in the 6 months, compared with $ 292.2 million and $ 579.8 million for the same year-ago periods, respectively.c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,849,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 8,014,000, or 11 cents a share, in the 6 months.Certain year-ago periods' amounts have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: 72 Hours of Relief; Center Tackles Family Crises
description: Shatava Barnes, a recovering drug addict, was at the end of her rope, close to a nervous breakdown. Her 3-month-old daughter, Raven, seemed to sense it, and was screaming and shaking in her mother's arms.

title: At the Bar; Temporary lawyers and the price of prosperity: when a job agency puffs, the competition huffs.
description: Lesley Friedman would not have thought of knocking her competition six years ago, when she began her business finding temporary jobs for lawyers. There was next to no competition, to begin with. And she had more serious problems on her hands, like an opinion from the New York City bar association that her entire operation was unethical.

title: Pentagon Keeps Silent on Rejected Gay Troop Plan
description: Back in April, the Defense Department commissioned two studies on how to carry out President Clinton's intention to lift the military's ban on homosexuals. One, conducted by a panel of generals and admirals, led to the new policy. But the Pentagon is refusing to make public or even talk much about the other one, a $1.3 million report by the influential Rand Corporation.

title: CLASHES INTENSIFY IN LEBANON ZONE
description: In their most intense fighting in months, Israel and pro-Iranian Islamic guerrillas repeatedly shelled each other's positions in southern Lebanon Thursday, raising concern that the violence there may soon spread.

title: Bare-Bones Health Plans Are Found to Attract Few
description: Wherever affordable bare-bones health insurance has been offered nationwide, the policies have been a disastrous market failure, according to a new study.

title: PEPSI TO INCREASE ITS STAKE IN INDIA VENTURE TO 92%
description: Pepsi-Cola International said it would increase its stake in its operations in India to 92 percent by buying out Voltas Ltd., its primary equity partner there, for $16 million. Pepsi's stake had been 51 percent. The buyout is subject to the approval of the Indian Government and the boards of Pepsico Inc. and Voltas. The remaining 8 percent of the India venture is held by Punjab Agro Industries.

title: Frances R. Grant, 96, Champion Of Rights in Latin America, Dies
description: Frances Ruth Grant, who spent her life opposing dictatorships and promoting human rights in the Americas, died on Wednesday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 96.

title: Sex Is Leading Cause of AIDS in Women
description: For the first time, more women have developed AIDS as a result of heterosexual intercourse than intravenous drug use, Federal health officials said yesterday, reporting on figures from 1992.

title: A. Oakley Brooks, 81, An Investment Banker
description: A. Oakley Brooks, a retired investment banker, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Falmouth, Mass. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan and Edgartown, Mass.

title: CHRONICLE
description: "Where do cows go on vacation?" HENRY G. CISNEROS, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, whispered to his 6-year-old son at Children's Hospital in Philadelphia. "Moo York City," the child replied, according to a report by The Associated Press, and it was a jubilant moment.

title: The Spoken Word
description: POETRY READING, Nuyorican Poets Cafe, 236 East Third Street, East Village. Samantha Courbell, Anna Bernstein and John Farris read from their work. Tonight at 10. Admission: $5. Information: (212) 505-8183. EXPLORING THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM, Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. "Italian Renaissance Panel Paintings," by Martha Usdin, today at 2 P.M.; "Women in American Art," by Maribeth Flynn, tomorrow at 2 P.M. Admission: $4; $2 for students; $1.50 for the elderly. Information: (718) 638-5000.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: INSIDE
description: How Women Get AIDS

title: Store Founder Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
description: Stew Leonard Sr., the Connecticut milkman who parlayed a hardworking, aw-shucks image into a sprawling dairy bazaar that has won acclaim as a paragon of American entrepreneurial spirit, pleaded guilty today to conspiring to defraud the Federal Government of taxes on more than $17 million.

title: Pennzoil Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 4,724,000 in connection with the early retirement of debt in the quarter and 6 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 3,176,000, or 8 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 4,829,000, or 12 cents a share, in the 6 months. The 6 months also was after a gain of $ 115,703,000, or $ 2.85 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS U.S. Team Is Ousted For the second time in two days, Lori McNeil was upset in the Federation Cup in Frankfurt, Germany. This time, though, the United States team could not survive her defeat and was ousted by Argentina. Florencia Labat won the last nine games to beat McNeil, 5-7, 6-3, 6-0, yesterday. In the first singles match, Ines Gorrochategui beat Lindsay Davenport, 6-7, 7-5, 7-5. That gave Argentina the two victories it needed to advance to the semifinals. McNeil lost in three sets on Wednesday to Fang Li of China, but the United States managed a 2-1 victory. (AP) Pierce Triumphs: In last night's quarterfinal at the Pathmark Tennis Classic in Mahwah, N.J., 16th-seeded Mary Pierce easily defeated 13th-seeded Shawn McCarthy in straight sets, 6-0, 6-0. Pierce's strong volley and corner shots overpowered McCarthy and gave her trouble throughout the match.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in Business Day yesterday about executive changes at the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation referred incorrectly to the company's chairman and chief executive in some editions. He is Charles W. Moritz.

title: China, Barreling Along the Capitalist Road, Now Posts Strict Speed Limits
description: China's new economic program may or may not succeed in bringing down inflation, but it is already having one far-reaching effect: it is making many ordinary workers spitting mad.

title: Serbs' Attack on Sarajevo Keeps Bosnians From Talks
description: Serbian heavy artillery pounded Sarajevo today with one of the heaviest bombardments in months, prompting the Bosnian Government to delay attending a new round of peace talks with Serbian and Croatian nationalists in Geneva.

title: Major Is Rebuffed in Parliament In Vote on the European Treaty
description: Prime Minister John Major lost a crucial vote on the Treaty on European Union tonight, further weakening his hold on power and leaving the treaty's final approval in limbo.

title: Twain Said It First
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Look Within for Pitching Help
description: Befuddled by a bullpen that has betrayed them over and over and frustrated by their inability to trade for a pitcher, the Yankees acted on a seemingly inevitable move yesterday by summoning Mark Hutton from their Class AAA Columbus team.

title: FPL Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Conferees on Budget Agree To Raise Tax Rate on Rich
description: Inching toward a final deficit-reduction bill, House and Senate conferees agreed today to a steep increase in the top Federal income tax rate and to leave the capital gains tax rate unchanged.

title: A Democracy Grapples With a Point of Honor
description: THE Newtown Board of Selectmen was rolling smoothly through its agenda at last Monday night's meeting: a printer for the ambulance corps, approved; applications from various community groups to march in the Labor Day parade, of course; a request from one Joel Tower of Litchfield for a permit to sell "educational books" door-to-door, denied.

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net lossc-Included a net charge of $ 171,000,000 showing cumulative effect of accounting changes in postretirement benefits other than pensions of $ 148,000,000 and change in accounting for income taxes of $ 23,000,000.Year-ago results are restated to reflect accounting changes for postretirement benefits other than pensions and for income taxes effective Jan. 1, 1992.

title: Reviews/Art; Long Island Shows Off Paintings of and From Itself
description: This summer, painting is the medium of choice among most of Long Island's major museums, and the preferred format is the one-artist exhibition. There's one slight exception to the first generalization: a retrospective of prints by the painter Wayne Thiebaud at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington. And diverging dramatically from the second is a large and almost hilariously diverse selection of works from private art collections at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn. But tally it all up and the bottom line says "painting." Roslyn

title: Crown Heights Officers Say They Feel Betrayed
description: "We're the ones who have to go back out there," the officer from the 71st Precinct in Crown Heights was saying. "We're the ones who have to make the split-second decisions. If we turn to a commander and he turns away, I mean if that happens again, where does that leave us? We'll be blamed no matter what."

title: Picnic and Concert
description: The Manhattan School of Music Brass Quintet is to play works by Gabrieli, Ewald, Bach, Brahms and Janacek in an outdoor concert tomorrow evening at 5:30 at the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard in the Bronx. The program is part of a series of Sunday Supper Serenades; visitors may carry a picnic supper and blankets or lawn chairs. The concert is free, but admission to the grounds is $3 ($2 for students and the elderly). Parking is $4. Directions: (718) 817-8779. Information: (718) 817-8700.

title: Restaurants
description: What kind of restaurant is Soleil? Well, the decor is Provencal by way of California. The food is American with Asian, French and Mediterranean influences. The manager is English. The crowd is Upper East Side, dressed for the country. The din is as loud as it is in any downtown restaurant of the moment.

title: Union Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 175 million due to changes in accounting methods resulting from the adoption of SFAS 106 ($ 271 million net charge), adoption of SFAS 109 ($ 125 million net gain), and a change in revenue recognition methods ($ 29 million net charge).c-Included one-time $ 42 million benefit of a Windfall Profit Tax settlement recorded at Union Pacific Resources.

title: Robert M. Kossick, Chief Executive, 53, At New Jersey Bank
description: Robert M. Kossick, chairman and chief executive officer of the National Community Bank of New Jersey, died on Tuesday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 53 years old and also had a home in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: Penn Central Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $ 18.5 million pretax gain from sale of limited partnership units of Buckeye Partners L.P., and $ 29.3 million tax benefit from $ 45 million increase in net deferred tax asset because of revision to estimated future taxable income during loss carryforward period, in the quarter and 6 months. The 6 months also included income from discontinued operations of $ 2.8 million, or 6 cents a share.c-Included a $ 7.2 million tax charge in the quarter and 6 months, losses from discontinued operations of $ 200,000 in the quarter and $ 3.4 million in the 6 months, which included income of 13 cents a share from defense services businesses and loss of 20 cents a share from operations owned by General Cable Corp., which were spun off to shareholders in July 1992. The 6 months was also after a gain of $ 252.8 million, or $ 5.33 a share.

title: Luxor Journal; The Muslims' Wrath Doesn't Spare the Mummies
description: Pity the indignities suffered by the Pharaohs.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: TV Weekend; Equal Injustice for All In Political Spoof Show
description: The new series "Politically Incorrect," having its premiere on Comedy Central on Sunday, describes itself as a funny version of "The McLaughlin Report." That's odd. Perhaps what's needed is a "McLaughlin Report" that isn't laughable. Actually "Politically Incorrect," obviously working on a weekly budget of $3.98, has the look of a "Saturday Night Live" sketch about how political correctness might be handled on a small-town public-access channel. The effect is curiously endearing.

title: The Buzzwords For New-Music Fans And Budding Moguls
description: SQUALLING guitars, booming drum samples, proffered business cards, promiscuous handshaking: the New Music Seminar is back in town for its 14th year. Anyone in the neighborhood of the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in Manhattan by day, or outside many of the city's rock clubs at night, can expect to see crowds of well-scrubbed music moguls in training, with their laminated seminar passes around their necks, hanging over T-shirts chosen to make that indelible first impression.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8 BRITAIN SETS BACK UNITY TREATY The British Government of John Major lost a crucial parliamentary vote on the European unity treaty, further weakening his hold on power and leaving the treaty's final ratification in limbo. A1 JAPANESE POLITICIANS' INVECTIVE Politeness was abandoned in Japan's political process as a meeting of the Liberal Democratic Party dissolved into a spectacle of name-calling after the Prime Minister said he would resign as party leader. A2

title: CHRONICLE
description: Ask E. L. DOCTOROW about the interaction between television and literature, and he waxes poetic. Perhaps that is because he and two colleagues are deep into plans for a 24-hour cable network called Booknet that will be -- no surprise -- about books.

title: CHICAGO EXPRESS AIRLINES TO BEGIN REGIONAL SERVICE
description: Chicago Express Airlines plans to begin regional service from Midway Airport in Chicago to Milwaukee and Madison, Wis., and South Bend, Ind., on Aug. 9. The new short-haul carrier, which plans to expand into other Midwest areas later this year, will offer nonrefundable fares as low as $39 one way.

title: Hamilton, a Sophomore, Expects More
description: Be confident. That's the attitude of Giants defensive end Keith Hamilton. And no more settling for a backup job. Be ready to be a starter. In fact, if necessary, be a little bit cocky.

title: Now if X Sues Y, What Would Happen? A, B, C or D?
description: Questions on the bar examination are typically convoluted, presenting a fictional case that improbably but conveniently raises a set of legal doctrines for the test-taker to identify and weigh. Here is a sample question, from the BAR/BRI Multistate Testing Book:

title: Racing Off To New Athletic Titles
description: Able-bodied people look at a wheelchair and see confinement. Mike Savicki sees the road race ahead.

title: Goldman Band Concert
description: The Goldman Memorial Band is to end its series of free concerts on Sunday at 7 P.M. in Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, with a program of waltzes, marches and band classics by Richard Strauss, Johann Strauss, Boito, Stravinsky, Grainger, Goldman and Sousa. Information: (212) 886-9887.

title: Free Music Outdoors
description: The Naumburg Orchestra is to play Rossini's "Turco in Italia" Overture, Haydn's "Military" Symphony, Schumann's Cello Concerto and Leo Weiner's Serenade tomorrow evening at 8 in a free concert in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center. Jens Nygaard is to conduct, with Leslie Parnas the soloist in the Schumann. Information: (212) 799-1259.

title: Review/Film; They're From Another Planet (Another Medium, Actually)
description: You'd have to visit the planet Remulak to find anyone who really thinks the Coneheads needed to be brought to the big screen. Based on the string of gleefully absurd "Saturday Night Live" sketches about a family of queasy extraterrestrials going native in America, "Coneheads" is not conspicuous for its wide-ranging wit. Nonetheless, the idea has been stretched out to feature length and propped up with sight gags, "Saturday Night Live" cameos and special effects. These visual tricks allow the Coneheads to broaden their horizons in expensive and not-terribly-necessary ways. They are actually seen visiting the planet Remulak, for example.

title: GERMAN SOLDIERS HEAD FOR SOMALIA
description: In an action intended to show that reunified Germany is not hamstrung by inhibitions about the use of military forces outside its borders, Germany began flying 1,700 soldiers to Somalia this week on a mission that many fear could prove the opposite instead.

title: Who Wants to Know?
description: We've got no numbers to prove it, but lately we've begun to wonder if the five most overheated words in the media-speak lexicon are "According to a recent poll." Not that polls are inaccurate. Or unscientific. But it's getting hard to separate what's useful from what's merely intriguing.

title: Excerpts From Senate Hearings on the Ginsburg Supreme Court Nomination
description: Following are excerpts from the third day of hearings yesterday by the Senate Judiciary Committee on the nomination of Ruth Bader Ginsburg to become Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service: On Discrimination

title: A.T.& T. Shifts Officers And Picks Finance Chief
description: The American Telephone and Telephone Company named a new chief financial officer and shuffled the assignments of seven top executives today, in an effort to sharpen the company's push into global markets and new multimedia services.

title: Nagle Signs With Jets and Doesn't Even Miss Dinner
description: While players were checking into the dormitories at Hofstra University for the start of the Jets' training camp this afternoon, the team's president, Steve Gutman, and Leigh Steinberg, the agent for Browning Nagle, were locked behind closed doors nailing down a contract that would get the quarterback in camp before dinner.

title: Review/Music; Pianist Accepts a Brahms Challenge
description: The B-flat Piano Concerto is perhaps the only piece in the Brahms corpus big enough to hold all the contradictions in his composing style. On Wednesday night, Garrick Ohlssen helped Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic continue their summer series at Carnegie Hall by playing the solo parts of this four-movement work. He did it with remarkable confidence and command.

title: DELTA AIR LINES INC. (N)
description: Accounting changes related primarily to future retirement benefits resulted in a $20.4 million loss for the fiscal quarter and a $1 billion loss for the fiscal year for Delta Air Lines.

title: Reggie! Bar Returns
description: REGGIE JACKSON isn't making a comeback, but his candy bar is. A Pittsburgh candy manufacturer, which has sold 5 million MARIO LEMIEUX candy bars, will bring back the Reggie! bar. The candy will be introduced at Cooperstown, N.Y., during Jackson's Hall of Fame induction on Aug. 1. (AP)

title: Kirtilal M. Mehta, 86; Built a Gem Company
description: Kirtilal M. Mehta, who worked in the gem industry for nearly 75 years and built an international wholesale diamond business, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Antwerp, Belgium. He was 86 and lived in Antwerp and Tel Aviv.

title: TRW Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 4 million, or 7 cents a share, from sale of an investment in the quarter and 6 months.c-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 350 million from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Pitney Bowes Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss, which was after a one-time after-tax charge of $ 214,631,000 from the effect of a change in accounting for nonpension postretirement benefits.Year-ago periods were restated to reflect a change in accounting for nonpension postretirement benefits.Revenue represented total revenue.

title: Hamptons' New Places for Dining Out Have a Close-to-Home Appeal
description: Basking in the summer sun, this year's crop of new Hamptons restaurants is putting America first, forsaking Tuscany to find culinary inspiration closer to home on eastern Long Island.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ACME ELECTRIC CORP., Olean, N.Y., an electrical equipment company, announced that it had signed a contract with L. C. Whitford Co., Wellsville, N.Y., to construct a $6 million electronic products manufacturing facility in Cuba, N.Y.

title: Treasury Bond Yields Rise Again
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell again yesterday as yields rose for the third day in a row. And as on Tuesday, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, was the catalyst for the rise in yields, traders and analysts said.

title: Indian Monsoon Brings Floods and Landslides; Death Toll Is 500
description: India's monsoon, the summer rains whose arrival is anxiously awaited by farmers, came with a vengeance this year. More than 500 people have been killed, hundreds of thousands driven from their homes and farms, and perhaps hundreds of millions of dollars in agricultural production lost.

title: Prosecution Rests Case In Bank Fraud Affair
description: After calling 45 witnesses and introducing about 300 exhibits into evidence, prosecutors from the Manhattan District Attorney's office yesterday rested their case against Robert A. Altman.

title: In the Margins of 2 Minorities: A Double Fringe
description: Until very recently, to be a black gay man in America meant being relegated to the margins of two minority cultures, each with its own agenda. But in the last three years, the invisibility of this dual minority has been strikingly challenged on several fronts. Jennie Livingston's documentary about voguing, "Paris Is Burning," Marlon Riggs's video movie "Tongues Untied," Madonna's tour film "Truth or Dare" and most recently, the rise of the black drag-queen pop star RuPaul have brought the black gay experience proudly and sassily out of the closet. Not everyone is pleased.

title: Coke Takes the Fizz Out of Campaign Doomsayers: For Now, at Least, It's 'Always Coca-Cola.'
description: AS soon as the Coca-Cola Company announced on Wednesday that Peter S. Sealey was resigning as the senior vice president to create his own marketing consulting firm, speculation arose that officials of the company might have grown dissatisfied with its "Always Coca-Cola" campaign, which Mr. Sealey had helped coordinate with Creative Artists Agency.

title: Change in 'Aladdin' Lyrics Looks Like Cowardly Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Illuminating Gang Life in Los Angeles: It's Raw
description: Monster The Autobiography of an L.A. Gang Member By Sanyika Shakur, a k a Monster Kody Scott 383 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.

title: In a Day-Care Case, New Questions, Few Answers
description: In the curious way that the camera eye sometimes finds itself in the view finder, a new public-television documentary about this town's notorious day-care sexual-abuse case has now become a central part of the story.

title: Now Takeover of Canal Makes Panama Uneasy
description: Until recently, there was still no greater act of nationalist faith among Panamanians than to declare that the 51-mile canal that cuts through the psyche of this country as completely as it bisects its geography must revert to full local ownership and control.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The Milieu of Hogs

title: Malcolm Birnbaum, 48, Leader In Financing Independent Films
description: Malcolm A. Birnbaum, a leader in the financing of independently produced movies, died on Tuesday at his summer home in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 48 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Redskins Start Post-Gibbs Era
description: The Washington Redskins struggled to a 9-7 record last season. Mark Rypien's passing was erratic, and his offensive line was hobbled by injuries.

title: Inside Art
description: De Kooning's Sculptures

title: American Calls Rival Mismanaged
description: Lawyers for American Airlines counterattacked Continental Airlines today in Federal District Court here, asserting that mismanagement at Continental, and not American's pricing, was to blame for the staggering losses that almost sank Continental last year.

title: 41,000 Graduates Await the Test of a Lifetime
description: "This is war," said Brad Call, who had just graduated from George Washington Law School. "It's war, man."

title: Those on Death Row Don't Ride a Carousel
description: To the Editor:

title: Not the Catskills of Yore
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Debate: Athletes as Role Models
description: IT has become something of a common practice for major league baseball to borrow from the successes of the National Basketball Association. Rookie development seminars, All-Star weeks as opposed to a single-day event, even All-Star N.B.A. home-run hitters come to mind. So it seems natural that the game also delve into the N.B.A.'s pet issue of the year: should players be role models?

title: What the Mayans Could Teach The Joint Chiefs
description: The fear that military men feel in the presence of gays may involve some hidden considerations not talked about or even thought about.

title: Japanese Forget Politeness As Political Wrath Flares
description: The Japanese political process is traditionally described as an elaborate effort to achieve harmony and consensus. But politeness was abandoned today at a nationally televised meeting of the Liberal Democratic Party, which dissolved into a spectacle of name-calling after Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said he would resign as party leader.

title: Clinton Urges Haitian Leader To Appoint a New Premier
description: President Clinton urged today that Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, move swiftly toward restoring democratic institutions in his country as part of an agreement that is to return him to power on Oct. 30.

title: On My Mind; What the Hasidim Know
description: Let's all put Crown Heights behind us -- certainly, but not now, not yet.

title: Summer Air Fares Are Up Sharply Despite Return of Multiple Prices
description: In a turnabout that has surprised even airline officials, the average ticket price is sharply higher this year -- not only compared with air fares last summer, when a half-price sale helped put 24 million Americans in the air, but with those in the first six months of 1991.

title: Road Race of the Stars At Lime Rock Park
description: The only major auto racing series with an Academy Award winning actor, a National Football League Hall of Fame running back and one of the most promising young American drivers rolls into Connecticut this weekend. The eighth race in the Sports Car Club of America's Trans-Am Tour is scheduled for tomorrow at the 1.53-mile Lime Rock Park road circuit in Lime Rock, Conn.

title: Money Funds Gain
description: The total assets of the nation's 642 retail money market mutual funds increased $644.1 million, to $392.00 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. There were $308.91 billion in taxable retail money market funds and $83.09 billion in 240 retail tax-exempt funds.

title: Silver Lining Dept.
description: Students of history will find one small note of cheer in this week's otherwise depressing report about the collective failure of New York City's leadership that turned the 1991 disturbances in Crown Heights into a four-day riot.

title: Voyage to Life of Shattered Dreams; At Cost of $30,000, Woman Goes From Poverty in China to Prostitution in Chinatown
description: It was just about dawn that day more than a year ago when the smugglers' van left her on East Broadway in Chinatown and sped off. A. W. Chen, a 20-year-old illegal immigrant from Fuzhou, China, had made it, she believed, and the anxious weeks that she had spent aboard the rusty freighter that delivered her to America's shores would soon be a fading memory.

title: German Prosecutors Link Lopez to Secret G.M. Papers
description: German prosecutors said today that documents belonging to General Motors that were found in the home of an aide to Volkswagen's production chief, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, included secret plans expressly copied for Mr. Lopez before he left G.M. for VW.

title: A Summer's Art For the Faithful: Pilgrimages In the Region
description: LIKE all others, this summer art season has its special pleasures. Could there be any better time or place to see the paintings of Fairfield Porter than right now at the Parrish Art Museum in Southhampton, L.I., not far from the very beaches that Porter captured once and for all in images bathed in the summer's brilliant light?

title: A Strategy on the Budget: Go After the Greenhorns
description: Looking over the political landscape as a Senate-House conference committee began debating the budget reconciliation bill this week, the deans of Washington's lobbying forces collectively settled on a new strategy for getting their way: make targets of Congress's freshman Democrats.

title: The Midwest Flooding; Like Sandbags, Flood Losses Pile Up
description: With heavy rains and overflowing rivers continuing to inundate the Midwest, many companies and individuals are canceling construction plans, postponing car purchases and asking creditors for deferrals of payments as they assess their losses.

title: Review/Film: Poetic Justice; On the Road To Redemption
description: FROM time to time throughout "Poetic Justice," John Singleton's new romantic melodrama, a pretty, button-nosed South-Central Los Angeles beautician named Justice, played by the pop superstar Janet Jackson, muses about life and loneliness on the soundtrack. It might be better if she sang the words accompanied by a loud backup group, so we couldn't hear them.

title: Prison Term in Fraud by Asbestos Monitor
description: A 37-month prison sentence was imposed yesterday on the president of a company charged with submitting fraudulent bills and using unqualified workers to monitor asbestos in public schools in New York City.

title: Review/Film; From Japan, Animated Views Of the Future
description: For those whose ideal movie is a sophisticated extension of Nintendo, the Japanese animated films "Silent Mobius" and "Neo-Tokyo" are the next best thing to diving into a video game and becoming part of the electronic landscape.

title: A Sensible Look at the Airline 'Crisis'
description: For the last three years, anyone scanning the headlines could easily have concluded that America's airline industry was on its last legs, trapped by inexorable forces it could not control. A commission appointed by President Clinton to fix the industry rightly rejects this dismal scenario.

title: Blue Cross 'Profits' Are Security Reserve
description: To the Editor:

title: Subaru Parts With the Creators of Its Quirky Ads
description: Sluggish sales and a new management team can be a scary mix for an auto maker's advertising agency, especially one with the counterculture tendencies of Wieden & Kennedy. Subaru of America, which has experienced both, announced yesterday that its two-year relationship with the agency would not continue beyond the end of the year.

title: Exxon Posts A 33% Gain In Earnings
description: The Exxon Corporation reported a 33 percent gain in second-quarter profits yesterday, attributing the sharp increase primarily to cost-cutting, increased demand for gasoline in Europe and lower crude oil prices.

title: Lifetime Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossc-Included a non-recurring restructuring and severence charge of $ 11.7 million, and $ 1 million in expenses associated with new government mandates that reduced net income by $ 7.7 million, or 84 cents a share.Lifetime said that second quarter 1993 included a retroactive revenue adjustment of $ 1.4 million, pursuant to a revised reimbursement methodology from one of its state contracts.The latest quarter also included $ 1.7 million in costs associated with the anticipated merger of Lifetime into Olsten Corp., which is scheduled to close July 30, as well as legal and financial fees incurred as a result of unsolicited proposals for an acquisition of Lifetime by Abbey Healthcare at prices substantially below the $ 33 per share that Lifetime shareholders will receive in the Olsten merger.

title: Alleghany Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a credit of $ 20 million, or $ 3.00 a share, from adjustment of tax reserves.c-Included a gain of $ 9,100,000, or $ 1.37 a share, from adoption of FASB 109; 1992 figures are restated to reflect the change.Share figures are adjusted to reflect stock dividends declared in March 1992 and March 1993.

title: Review/Pop; A Blend of Influences, With Dissonance
description: Performances associated with the New Music Seminar, which ends today at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers, are often a means for independent record labels to display their wares. Homestead Records took over the Pyramid in the East Village on Thursday night, and the major news was the first New York appearance of Trumans Water from San Diego. The crowd had thinned considerably by 2 A.M., when this three-year-old, apostrophe-free quartet finally came on, but those who remained saw a band that thoroughly lived up to its hype.

title: F.D.A. Approves a Multiple Sclerosis Drug
description: The Chiron Corporation and Berlex Laboratories Inc. announced yesterday that Federal regulators had approved Betaseron, the first treatment for multiple sclerosis to get marketing approval in the United States.

title: Blind Woman's Subway Death Exposes Platform Safety Flaws; Install Warning Strips
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Frees Manville Funds
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday authorized a $154 million disbursement from the huge Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust, which was created in 1988 to compensate thousands of asbestos disease claimants.

title: McDermott International Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 245,624,000 from the adoption of FASB 106, a new method of accounting for employees' postretirement benefits.

title: Kendall International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for the early redemption of the company's 10.5 percent subordinated notes of $ 2,800,000 in both the quarter and 6 months.c-After an extraordinary gain on forgiveness of debt as a result of restructuring of $ 277,300,000 in both the quarter and 6 month.Year-ago share earnings were not provided because they represent a prerestructuring period that is not comparable.

title: Stew Leonard's Is Cited For Shorting Customers
description: Stew Leonard's Dairy, the Connecticut supermarket that built its reputation on customer-comes-first friendliness, suffered another blow yesterday when the State Consumer Products Commissioner said that it had short-weighted items like chicken, walnuts and tomatoes.

title: Caterpillar Financial Services Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2.6 million from the adoption of SFAS No. 109.

title: Schlumberger Ltd. (N reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 248 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle for postretirement benefits.

title: Amerada Hess Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Inventory write-down of $ 80,200,000, and refinancing charge of $ 10,500,000 in the quarter, and a gain of $ 29,500,000 from adoption of accounting changes for income taxes in the 6 months.c-Net incomed-Included income tax refunds and related interest of $ 12,300,000, or 15 cents a share, and $ 25,400,000, or 31 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.Amerada Hess Corp. said the charge of $ 80,200,000 in the latest quarter was for the write-down to market value of refining and marketing inventories, reflecting the recent decline in selling prices.

title: Scuttled Archivist
description: To the Editor:

title: Lauritzen, 36, Rides On, Ignoring That Old Sunset
description: When a group of 20 riders detached themselves from the Tour de France field and attempted a breakaway this morning, Dag-Otto Lauritzen made sure he was among them. He was dreaming -- and who isn't -- of a stage victory before the bicycle race ends Sunday in Paris.

title: Emlen Etting, Artist, 88
description: Emlen Etting, a painter, sculptor and illustrator, died on Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 88.

title: Custody Case Affirms Biological Ties That Bind
description: To the Editor:

title: For New Entries, Europe Is Popular
description: New funds that invest in Europe are popping up everywhere. Many analysts say that the economic cycle in Europe is a few years behind the United States and that Europe is on the edge of a big bull market.

title: Trinity Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 7.9 million, or 30 cents a share, from cumulative effect of accounting change resulting from the adoption of FAS 109.Year-ago first quarter was restated to reflect the acquisition of Syro Inc. The acquisition was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Let the Truth Pour In
description: As Sarajevo totters, Americans and Europeans can agree to little more than hand-wringing about the dismembering of the former Yugoslavia. Yet without putting lives at risk, and at modest cost, the West could strike an important blow against nationalist bullies in Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. It can challenge the media monopoly by the warlords who foment tribal hatreds.

title: Out on a Limb on Job Data
description: They say that politics runs in cycles, but these days the cycles seem to spin faster and faster.

title: I.B.M. Narrows Field in Ad Review
description: The IBM Personal Computer Company said yesterday that it had narrowed the review on its estimated $80 million United States and European account to 12 agencies from 50 or 60, according to a report by Advertising Age, an industry publication.

title: Joseph J. Palisi, 67; Brooklyn Historian Restored Monument
description: Joseph John Palisi, a history professor, research specialist and former official historian of the Borough of Brooklyn, died on Wednesday at his home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. He was 67.

title: Armco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $ 7.4 million of additional post-retirement benefits expense associated with adopting SFAS 106, and income tax benefits of $ 2.5 million and other income of $ 2.2 million in the quarter, and the 6 months included a net charge of $ 304,400,000 from the adoption of SFAS No. 106 and No. 109. The adoption of SFAS 106 resulted in a charge of $ 440 million (net of tax), while the adoption of SFAS 109 resulted in a gain of $ 135.6 million (net of tax), or $ 1.31 a share.c-Included income tax benefits of $ 4.9 million and other income of $ 5.8 million, related to the settlement of income tax issues. Period also included the reversal of a federal tax reserve of $ 4.3 million as a result of the resolution of state income tax issues and equity losses of $ 19.5 million.d-Included pretax charges of $ 21.6 million, including $ 20.4 million for expenses related to closing the melt shop at its Stainless and Alloy Products plant, and $ 1.2 million to increase a reserve for the divestment of an investment castings plant, which the company discontinued in 1991 in both quarter and 6 months.Armco Inc. said that it had an operating loss of $ 6.2 million in the year-ago second quarter, which included tax refunds of $ 39.1 million, offset by special charges and equity losses of $ 38.3 million.The company also said that it had an operating profit of $ 1.3 million in the year-ago 6 months, which included tax refunds of $ 39.1 million, offset by special charges and equity losses of $ 63.6 million, including the $ 21.6 million plant-closing and divestiture charges.

title: Viacom Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 10,338,000, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.c-Net loss, which included extraordinary losses of $ 13,681,000 in the quarter and $ 17,120,000 in the 6 months, both from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Senate vote on the patenting of the Confederate flag as a design symbol -- a use opposed by Carol Moseley Braun of Illinois -- misstated the number of nonwhites in the Senate besides Ms. Moseley Braun. There are three: Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado, and Daniel K. Inouye and Daniel K. Akaka of Hawaii.

title: Santa Fe Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included non-cash gain of $ 108.3 million, or 58 cents a share, from asset exchange gain in the quarter and 6 months.c-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 163 million from the adoption of changes in accounting principles for postretirement and post-employment benefits.

title: Bridge
description: The United States Congress went from voting in the Capitol to dealing at the Capitol Hill Club here Thursday afternoon, and came within a touch of a famous victory. Their representatives, not to mention senators, were hoping to avenge earlier bridge defeats at the hands of an experienced team representing corporate America and were in the lead by 4 imps going into the final deal. But a game swing left them losing by just 7, though one of the losers felt like a winner: Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, received an impromptu donation of $10,000 from the corporate players toward flood disaster relief in his state.

title: Olin Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 45.6 million from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Blind Woman's Subway Death Exposes Platform Safety Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Italian Business Leader, Tied to Scandal, Is Found Dead
description: One of Italy's best-known tycoons was found dead of a gunshot wound in his Milan apartment today as the country's huge and ever-broadening corruption investigation moved closer to the core of his business dealings.

title: Woman's 1990 Seaside Death To Be Treated as a Homicide
description: The death of a 20-year-old woman in 1990 whose body was found bruised, bloodied and partly nude in a New Jersey resort town will be investigated as a homicide, not an accident, state officials said yesterday.

title: Union Camp Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected $ 40,806,000 benefit of changes in methods of accounting for postretirement benefits and income taxes, and $ 1,273,000 loss on early retirement of debt, net of tax.

title: B. W. Bates, 85, Princeton Professor And Conservationist
description: Blanchard W. Bates, a scholar of Romance languages and literature and a conservationist, died at home on Wednesday. He was 85 and lived on Chebeague Island, Maine.

title: New York State Electric & Gas Corp.  reports earnings for 12mos to June 30
description: Per-share figures follow preferred dividend payments.In late 1992 the company began reflecting on its income statement the value of energy consumed but not yet billed. The company said that if it had been allowed by New York regulators to include the unbilled revenue factor during all of 1992, the latest trailing 12 months earnings would have been $ 2.32 a share.

title: Kellogg Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 251,600,000 which reflects cumulative effect of a change in accounting for nonpension postretirement benefits. Results for 1992 have been restated to reflect the adoption of FAS 106 during the first quarter.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation in Chicago, the talk was on a lofty plane this week. The appointment of CATHARINE R. STIMPSON, University Professor at Rutgers University, to be director of the MacArthur Fellows Program was announced there yesterday.

title: Textron Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 679.5 million from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles.In the fourth quarter of 1992, Textron adopted retroactively to the beginning of 1992 Statements of Financial Accounting Standards No. 106, ''Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions''(FAS 106), with respect to its U.S. retiree health care and life insurance benefits, and No. 109, ''Accounting for Income Taxes'' (FAS 109).Textron recorded the cumulative effect of these changes in accounting principles as a one-time charge in the first quarter of 1992 and restated previously reported 1992 interim results.

title: Jail? Must Be Houston
description: Houston Rockets guard VERNON MAXWELL became the latest professional athlete to see the inside of a Houston jail yesterday when he was arrested for allegedly assaulting two off-duty police officers at a nightclub.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Custody Case Affirms Biological Ties That Bind; Origins Do Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Wim Mertens Pianist Serious Fun Lincoln Center

title: An Outsider Gets Bally in Shape
description: When Arthur M. Goldberg took over the Bally Manufacturing Company in October 1990, the company was dangerously close to defaulting on $1 billion of its $1.9 billion in debt. The health and fitness division was in disarray and up for sale. Bally's casino resort in Las Vegas, Nev., had been forced into bankruptcy by bondholders. And Bally's shares had plunged to $1.87, from $27.95 the previous December.

title: The Customers Are the Show; Night Life at a Pharmacy
description: Friday, 10 P.M., and Barry from California was desperate for an antibiotic. Two women in midtown needed pain killers. An elegant Argentine couple was on the hunt for a good hairbrush.

title: Official Dismissed in Dispute At Disabled Veterans Group
description: A top executive of the Disabled American Veterans has been dismissed for "dishonesty and misconduct" after using $80,000 from the group to settle a claim against him made by the wife of an employee, D.A.V. officials said today.

title: Maytag Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a one-time, after-tax charge of $ 30 million to cover anticipated additional costs associated with promotional programs in the U.K.c-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 307 million from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Brown's Perry Returns After 2-Day Walkout
description: Cleveland Browns defensive lineman MICHAEL DEAN PERRY was back in camp yesterday after a two-day walkout. Perry missed morning workouts but returned in time for afternoon practice.

title: 2 Arrested in Slaying of Prince
description: Reaching across a continent in a bid to solve four murders, New York City police detectives arrested two men in Reno yesterday and are returning them to New York to face charges of killing an Indian prince and his wife and two others.

title: Threat of Statehood in Puerto Rico Leads to a Restored Tax Break
description: Worried about reopening the debate on Puerto Rican statehood, budget negotiators agreed today to reinstate $2.6 billion in tax breaks for big American companies that do business on the island.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Taipei Artists Chorus Taipei Theater

title: President's Policy on Gay Troops Is Backed in Vote of Senate Panel
description: As it approved a Pentagon budget for the fiscal year 1994, the Senate Armed Services Committee today endorsed President Clinton's policy to allow homosexuals to serve in the military.

title: Integrated Device Technology Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Corrections
description: A brief report in Weekend yesterday about an outdoor concert at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx misstated the day. The Manhattan School of Music Brass Quintet is to play at 5:30 P.M. tomorrow, not today.

title: Rehabilitation Chief Arrested
description: The president of a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center was arraigned today on a minor drug charge after the police said he tried to pick up a package of cocaine that had been sent to an air express mail office.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a settlement of the disputed value of Andy Warhol's estate referred incompletely to an appraisal underlying the agreement. The appraisal, by Christie's, at $220 million, was made in 1991. In reporting that the agreed value was signicantly less than some earlier estimates, the article failed to take the 1991 timing into account. It attributed the decline in estimates only to a drop in values in the art market, as shown by the falloff of Warhol's work at auction in May.

title: TEXACO CHEMICAL SAYS IT WILL CUT 260 JOBS
description: The Texaco Chemical Company, which is based in Houston, will eliminate 260 jobs and shift its focus to higher-margin products to offset pressure from the depressed chemical market, the company said yesterday. Texaco Chemical, a unit of Texaco Inc., will also shut down the ethyleneamine business at its Conroe, Tex., operation by the end of 1993, resulting in the loss of 51 jobs. Ethyleneamine is used to make lubricant additives, textile treatment chemicals and agricultural and surfactant products.

title: Sports of The Times; Take Me Out of the Ball Game
description: STEPHEN SCHREINER knows the exact date and time he decided that he had had enough: "June 24, 1993," he said yesterday from his San Diego law office. At 10 A.M. that day, Schreiner said, his partner called from his car phone and broke the news: the Padres had traded Gary Sheffield. Suddenly, the frustration that began last year when San Diego parted company with other standout players -- Craig Lefferts, Benito Santiago and Tony Fernandez -- had turned to anger.

title: Dumas and Suns Agree
description: Rookie forward RICHARD DUMAS, who helped the Phoenix Suns reach the National Basketball Association finals last season, agreed in principle to a long-term contract, the team said yesterday. Terms of the deal weren't given. (AP)

title: Duke Power Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included 15-cent-a-share charge due to a reserve set aside for a refund to customers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 BRITAIN CLEARS UNITY TREATY

title: Horace Mann Educators reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain on the early retirement of debt of $ 2.4 million, or 8 cents a share, and $ 5.1 million, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Marriott's Shareholders Back Plan to Split in 2
description: The Marriott Corporation overcame a major obstacle to its reorganization plan when shareholders at its annual meeting yesterday overwhelmingly approved its proposal to split the company in two. Eighty-five percent of those attending the packed meeting, in the ballroom of the J. B. Marriott Hotel in downtown Washington, voted in favor of the plan.

title: Jumping From Student to Entrepreneur
description: Bill Neely, 22, of Silver Spring, Md., founded B.G Graphics in 1990 as a sophomore at Howard University. "My father was doing a seminar and he needed a brochure. He took it to someone , and it didn't look that good. I looked at it and I said, 'Dad I could do that.' So he let me do that brochure."

title: MOBIL CORP. (N)
description: The Mobil Corporation reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings more than doubled, to $579 million, because of higher natural gas prices, strength in its Far East markets and gains in tax-related benefits.

title: Unions Rebuff American on Equity Stake
description: Two of American Airlines' major unions today rebuffed suggestions by the airline that they request an equity stake. They said they feared that American would try to extract big concessions on wages, benefits and work rules in exchange.

title: Friendship No Factor, Say Coslet, Esiason
description: Jets Coach Bruce Coslet doesn't want to hear anyone whining, "Teacher's pet!" when it comes to his relationship with quarterback Boomer Esiason. So he spent time this morning dispelling any notion that the quarterback would be treated favorably just because they have a friendship dating back to their days together in Cincinnati.

title: Marsh & McLennan Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 40.1 million from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago period was restated to reflect the adoption, effective Jan. 1, 1992, of SFAS No. 106, ''Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions,'' and SFAS No. 109, ''Accounting for Income Taxes.''

title: Nash Finch Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 19
Owens & Minor reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $ 706,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Included a loss of $ 3,126,000 in the quarter and income of $ 6,930,000, or 35 cents a share, in the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. The 6 months also included a charge of $ 730,000 from an adjustment in accounting.Results were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March 1993.Results for the second quarter and first 6 months of 1993 reflected the acquisition of Lyons Physical Supply Co., recorded as of Jan 1, 1993, and accounted for as a pooling of interests.The results also reflected the cash-for-stock acquisition of A. Kuhlman & Co., accounted for under the purchase method of accounting.

title: Schwab and Fidelity Vie As Fund Supermarkets
description: AT a recent luncheon in New York that the Charles Schwab discount brokerage firm gave to promote its mutual fund services, the rhetoric soared higher than the 64th- floor Rainbow Room setting.

title: What Reeves Doesn't See Bothers Him
description: He's not going to lock the gates to training camp and prevent some of his veterans from getting in, but Coach Dan Reeves had some choice words today for two of his key AWOL players, linebacker Pepper Johnson and running back Rodney Hampton.

title: U.S. Increases Fund To Outbid Terrorists For Afghan Missiles
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's covert operations division will spend $55 million in a new effort to buy back more than 300 Stinger antiaircraft missiles it gave to guerrillas fighting the Soviet-backed Government of Afghanistan in the 1980's, Government and intelligence officials say.

title: MAJOR WINS VOTE INSURING APPROVAL OF EUROPEAN PACT
description: In a do-or-die move on which he staked his political future, Prime Minister John Major won a vote of confidence today that insured the British Parliament's final approval of the Treaty on European Union.

title: Tecumseh Products (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 95.5 million reflecting the adoption of accounting changes for postretirement benefits and income taxes.Per-share amounts have been adjusted to reflect the 100 percent stock dividend paid June 30, 1993.

title: Frederick A. Sundermann, Bank President, 74
description: Frederick A. Sundermann, a former president and chairman of the National Bank of Westchester, died on Thursday at a hospice in Derwood, Md. He was 74. A Westchester resident for nearly all his life, he most recently lived in Kensington, Md.

title: Cipsco Inc. reports earnings for 12mo to June 30
World and Pathmark Are Raymond's Oyster
description: It seems that Lisa Raymond has complete control of her life. For a while she wanted to be a normal teen-ager, hang out with friends, party a little, listen to music and go to college. So she did. The past two years she attended the University of Florida, majoring in criminology, while advancing in the collegiate tennis ranks.

title: Smith's Food & Drug reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Included pretax charges for LIFO accounting of $ 750,000 in the second quarter, and $ 1.5 million in the 6 months.

title: Ametek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Browning-Ferris Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a reorganization charge of $ 27 million in both the quarter and 9 months.Year-ago results are restated to conform with the 1993 figures.

title: Lawmakers Add to Defiance of Yeltsin
description: The Russian Parliament recessed for the summer today after rushing through an extraordinary string of measures. If put into force, they threaten to disrupt the economy, undermine the turning over of public property to private interests, fracture relations with Ukraine, jail a key Yeltsin aide and, among many other things, expand the privileges of the legislators.

title: When Selling Stocks, Monday's Child Fares Less Well
description: Say you're spending a quiet weekend reviewing your stock portfolio, deciding what to sell. You hope to place the order before the busy workweek begins, using the toll-free lines that so many brokerage houses operate 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

title: Compueter Associates International (N)
description: Computer Associates International Inc., a leading maker of software, reported that its net income rose 60 percent for the first quarter that ended June 30, an increase that exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Q & A
description: A Menu of Benefits

title: Europe's Social Dumping
description: Everybody agrees on the principle that economic growth winds up to the benefit of all, and that zero-sum games of beggar-thy-neighbor are an illusion. Eventually, all lose. But when times are hard, everybody looks to the home front and the right-now -- leave principle to the long term. What they remember about John Maynard Keynes is that he said, "In the long term, we are all dead."

title: The Dicey Game of Commodities Trading
description: The floods in the Midwest have devastated many farmers and sent the prices of some agricultural products soaring.

title: VW Chief Discusses Lopez With German State Official
description: The chairman of Volkswagen A.G., Ferdinand Piech, met today with Gerhard Schroder, the Premier of Lower Saxony state, which is VW's largest shareholder, to discuss the trade-secrets dispute involving General Motors and a top VW executive, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua.

title: Stern Test for Devil His Due
description: Devil His Due, the 4-year-old colt who has won four stakes in his last five starts, will meet his biggest test today when he races seven rivals in the $500,000 Philip H. Iselin Handicap at Monmouth Park.

title: Executive Changes
description: E. W. BLANCH CO., Minneapolis, a reinsurance intermediary, named Barbara Bufkin and Michael Wybar executive vice presidents for national sales. GOLDEN VALLEY MICROWAVE FOODS INC., Edina, Minn., a unit of Conagra Inc., named John S. McKeon president.

title: Shock Therapist for Eastern Europe
description: Leszek Balcerowicz is a hero of Polish economic reform. Now he's a candidate to lead the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which was formed to spur market reform in Eastern Europe and the old Soviet Union by pumping Western capital into new private enterprise. The bank's board could not make a better choice.

title: Dry St. Louis Is Furiously Battling a Flood of Misperception
description: In this city that has been at the epicenter of the Mississippi's soggy wrath for the last week, a lot of people are desperate to get a simple message out: they're dry.

title: Trying a Talking Cure In a Young, Ailing World
description: THEY sat in a semicircle and talked about what was on their minds. One girl was mournfully pregnant and mostly quiet. A boy with a Caribbean lilt painfully picked out words to describe friends shot dead. When the conversation moved to relationships, one girl allowed that the only real answer was to give men 24 hours to get out of New York City.

title: Monson Wins Lawsuit
description: DON MONSON, a former Oregon basketball coach, was awarded $292,000 by a jury in his breach-of-contract lawsuit against the university.

title: Still Seeking Answers, Detectives Bury Baby Hope
description: Two years after they found her abandoned body, the only family that ever claimed her -- the detectives of the 34th Precinct -- buried the girl they called Baby Hope yesterday.

title: Springs Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-After a charge of $ 72,543,000 from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net income

title: Chris DeBlasio, Composer, 34
description: Chris DeBlasio, a composer best known for his song cycles, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 34.

title: Norman S. Weiser, 73, Chappell Music Head
description: Norman Sidney Weiser, a music publishing executive, writer and editor, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: Commonwealth Energy System reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $ 2.3 million in after-tax severance costs, offset by the reversal of a contingency reserve related to the company's Seabrook investment in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Included a one-time write-down of $ 1.49 a share associated with termination of energy project.

title:
FINANCIAL PLANNING;
Advice for Deaf Takes More Accessible Forms
description: HENRY BUZZARD, a 70-year-old retired librarian from White Plains, tries to stretch his savings through savvy investing. A bit uncomfortable selecting mutual funds and stocks himself, he relies heavily on his broker, Stephen Hopson of Merrill Lynch.
