description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 111,570 in the quarter and $ 344,645 in the 9 months, both from amortization of non-compete agreements connected with the acquisitions in 1990 of Bliss Manufacturing Co. and other companies.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 125,600 and $ 380,800 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both from amortization of non-compete agreements connected with the acquisitions in 1990 of Bliss Manufacturing Co. and other companies.All share earnings information have been restated to reflect the effects of the 3-for-2 stock split paid in the form of a dividend Sept. 22, 1992.

description: b-Included a $ 950,000 charge relating to previously capitalized costs associated with the company's efforts to locate sites for future communities.c-Included loss from discontinued operations of $ 12,810,000 reflecting write-down of carrying value to market value on two commercial land holdings, an extraordinary gain of $ 458,000, or 3 cents a share, on the extinguishment of debt, and after a gain of $ 20 million, or $ 1.25 a share, from the adoption of accounting change for income taxes.d-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 3,039,000, or 24 cents a share, on the extinguishment of debt.

title:
SCIENTIST AT WORK: Luigi Luca Cavalli-Sforza;
A Geneticist Maps Ancient Migrations
description: THE genes of modern populations carry the encoded history of humans' remote past and their early wanderings around the globe. Deciphering that history has been the preoccupation of population geneticists for a century, but key pieces of information have begun to fall quickly into place only in the last 10 years, since the advent of rapid methods for working out the chemical sequences of genes.

title: Detroit Pushes Leasing but May Pay Later
description: Over the last century Detroit has pushed durability, tailfins and apple pie to persuade Americans to buy new cars. But now the nation's auto makers are enjoying their first surge in sales after three bleak years thanks in part to a fresh approach: persuading Americans not to buy at all.

title: Sihanouk, After U.S. Shift, Lets Government Talk to Khmer Rouge
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, having apparently won concessions he wanted from the Clinton Administration, agreed today to allow Cambodia's newly formed coalition Government to resume negotiations with the Khmer Rouge to end their civil war.

title: Long-Lost Spanish Fort Found in St. Augustine
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS have found buried traces of a 16th-century fort in St. Augustine, Fla., and are confident that this establishes for the first time the exact site where the Spanish planted the earliest permanent European settlement in what is now the United States.

title: Secondhand Smoking
description: Secondhand smoke is at the very least a nuisance, and at the very worst a health hazard. So Americans can be grateful that the Environmental Protection Agency announced guidelines last week on smoking in public buildings. The guidelines, however, are voluntary -- which means that it's up to states and localities to make them stick. Some states -- among them California, Hawaii, Vermont, North Dakota and Utah -- already have regulations on environmental tobacco smoke.

title: Crane Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included an after-tax effect of special charge of 78 cents a share in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: German Company Got Crematorium Patent
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Arrest Man In Subway Shooting
description: It was a New York nightmare come to life. A gang of robbers preying on people aboard the subway picks as its target a man who refuses to be victimized, and instead the man is shot.

title: HOME DEPOT AND MCDONALD'S IN JOINT-VENTURE TALKS
description: Home Depot Inc. said yesterday that it and the McDonald's Corporation were discussing the possibility of a joint venture to open McDonald's fast-food restaurants inside Home Depot stores. Home Depot of Atlanta, now operates 227 stores in 21 states and expects to have 645 outlets in the United States and Canada by 1997. McDonald's of Oak Brook, Ill., the world's largest restaurant chain, has expanded into non-traditional sites for years. Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's biggest retailer, is testing scaled-down versions of McDonald's restaurants in two outlets in California.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Small Agencies Protest; American Express Skids In Shift on Car Insurance
description: The American Express Company has made a screeching U-turn about restrictions on car rental insurance it extends to its card users.

title: Dinosaur Institute Keeps Digging
description: UNDAUNTED by a year of F.B.I. raids, subpoenas, the prospect of Federal indictments, pressure from half a dozen Government agencies and uneven support from academic paleontologists, a South Dakota fossil dealer is still digging for dinosaurs and has just bagged a new Tyrannosaurus rex, its third in two years.

title: Petroleum Concern Sale
description: The American National Petroleum Company said today that its shareholders had approved a plan to sell the company to the Patrick Petroleum Company for $35 million in cash and stock. The petroleum producer's shareholders would receive $3.40 a share in cash and $2.60 a share worth of Patrick Petroleum stock on completion of the acquisition, which is set to close Thursday, a day after Patrick Petroleum's shareholders are to vote on the merger. The acquisition would roughly double Patrick Petroleum's reserves, U. E. Patrick, president of Patrick Petroleum, said in January.

title: America's Best, but He's Off to Budapest
description: Darrick Heath settled down under a tree outside of his dormitory room and contemplated his final 48 hours before leaving the United States.

title: Howell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Faith in Multiple-Drug AIDS Trial Shaken by Report of Error in Lab
description: MISTAKES in laboratory research are embarrassing and more common than generally recognized. Only a few make headlines, such as the serious error acknowledged last week by scientists at the Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School.

title: Gunmen Rob 14 on a Bus In the Bronx
description: Fourteen people on a shuttle bus bound from Washington Heights to Providence, R.I., were robbed yesterday on the Major Deegan Expressway by three fellow passengers who produced pistols and forced the driver to pull over at the Van Cortlandt Park exit in the Bronx.

title: RPM Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: Per share figures have been restated to reflect a 50 percent stock dividend issued on Dec. 4, 1992.

title: ABC Head Rises at Cap Cities
description: With his retirement nearing, Daniel B. Burke, the chief executive of Capital Cities/ ABC, announced a set of promotions today that established Robert A. Iger, president of the ABC Television Network Group, as his heir apparent.

title: MacDonald Harris Is Dead at 71; Novelist and Literature Professor
description: MacDonald Harris, a novelist and a teacher of comparative literature, died on Saturday at his home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 71.

title: What's a Woman to Wear?
description: Just when you thought it was safe to send your miniskirts to the thrift shop, they made a comeback on Paris runways.

title: Too Often, New York's Mentally Ill Get Swept Under a Bridge; Republican Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Launches Invasion Of Latin America, to Push For Cultural Preservation
description: Against a landscape of rolling fields and grazing cows, church columns of pink stone rise unfinished. Work stopped in 1768 when a decree arrived here from King Carlos III of Spain, ordering the expulsion of all Jesuit missionaries from this distant corner of empire.

title: Minerals Technologies Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,362,000, or 5 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting change.Year-ago periods ended June 28.

title: Too Often, New York's Mentally Ill Get Swept Under a Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: As America grows older and grayer, are companies becoming any wiser about their marketing?
description: IF recent advances in medicine and health care are not evidence enough that the passage from middle age to maturity has moved farther along the lifeline, please consider this: Mick Jagger turned 50 yesterday.

title: Candidly Broadway
description: There's Richard Rodgers, briefing the cast of "Carousel." And Leonard Bernstein, coaching the dancers in "West Side Story." Carol Channing holds forth in her dressing room during the run of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," and the young Jerome Robbins looks ready to leap into a dance routine in "The Straw Hat Revue of 1939."

title: Chevron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net special charges of $ 515 million in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Included net special charges of $ 39 million in both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6 months also included a $ 641-million charge for the cumulative effect of two accounting principles.

title: Perez Hoping That He's Not Penciled Into the Pen
description: There is a huge pitching calendar hanging in Manager Buck Showalter's office at Yankee Stadium that lists his daily starters. For Sunday's game, Showalter had Melido Perez written in, but he also had Domingo Jean printed beside Perez. Jean, who pitched for Class AAA Columbus Sunday, is hovering around Perez on and off the calendar.

title: No Headline
description: "Once again, we are making fools of ourselves in the eyes of the world. We are using Bolshevik methods of a Stalinist nature to try to resolve economic problems in the context of a market economy." -- BORIS G. FYODOROV, the Russian Finance Minister. [ A3:3 ]

title: LORAL UNIT TO BUILD SATELLITES FOR TELE-COMMUNICATIONS
description: A unit of Tele-Communications Inc. awarded a contract worth more than $400 million yesterday to a division of the Loral Corporation for the construction of two television satellites that will apply digitization and video compression technology to help expand the number of channels broadcast to United States homes. Space Systems/Loral is to deliver the satellites in orbit in June and October 1996 to Tempo, a unit of Tele-Communications. Loral shares closed up 87.5 cents, to $59.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, while Tele-Communications shares rose $1, to $24.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Kansas City Power & Light Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Service Bill Hits Home
description: While Bob Dole is urging senators to defeat the President's national service plan, his wife, Elizabeth, is asking them to support it. Page D22.

title: Apache Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $ 18,500,000, or 39 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interest in a marketing affiliate in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Science Park Plan Offers Vision of Newark's Center
description: An elaborate vision of high-tech offices, homes, parks and shops was put forth today for a desolate 50-acre tract in this city's Central Ward, with Federal, state and community leaders praising the plans as a formula for hope and economic growth during the next 20 years.

title: Internatioanl Recovery reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from operations of discontinued Environmental Services segment, net of applicable income tax benefit of $ 318,000, of $ 476,000.

title: Making the Most of a Rare Clemency in New York
description: Last January, Lawrence Snider found himself in the middle of a trendy Long Island clothing store, clutching a pocketful of money and watching his sister Lori pull jeans off the racks for him.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 6,700,000.c-Net lossd-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 3,142,000, or 9 cents a share, and $ 4,391,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included a charge of $ 198 million from Financial Accounting Standard 106, the accounting change for retiree health care benefits.

title: EAST ASIAN PACT IS BACKED BY U.S.
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher affirmed United States support today for a new security pact that would allow the countries of East Asia to head off conflicts as the region becomes increasingly important in the world economy.

title: Clinton Assails G.O.P. Delays In Bitter Tones
description: President Clinton accused Congress today of returning to old habits of gridlock and said obstructionism by Republicans there was hurting ordinary Americans, including victims of the Midwestern floods.

title: Tecumseh Products (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 95.5 million reflecting the adoption of accounting changes for postretirement benefits and income taxes.Per-share amounts have been adjusted to reflect the 100 percent stock dividend paid June 30, 1993.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN SHIP BUILDING CO., Tampa, Fla., named Allen Zang president and chief executive. CRYOLIFE INC., Atlanta, a developer of human organ transplant technology, named Donald J. Blankers vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Texas Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a gain of $ 7.3 million, or 66 cents a share, from a land sale.

title: APPLE SHIPS LOWER-PRICED FILE SERVERS
description: Apple Computer Inc. shipped two more models of the network server line that it introduced last quarter. The new machines -- the Workgroup Server 60 and 80 -- cost $2,949 to $3,899 and $5,489 to $9,049, respectively, less than Apple's first two servers, the Workgroup Server 95 machines, which cost $7,598 and $12,989. File servers are computers that store files and programs used by all computers on a network. Apple sold no servers of its own until the Workgroup line.

title: American General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 36,680,000 which reflects adoption of SFAS Nos. 106 and 109.American General said that operating earnings, which excluded realized investment gains, were $ 148 million, or 68 cents a share, for the latest quarter, compared with $ 128 million, or 59 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter.

title: Fix, but Don't Kill, the N.E.D.
description: In a surprising turnabout in June, the House of Representatives voted to kill funding for the National Endowment for Democracy. By Washington standards, the money is trivial -- $48 million -- but the principle is scarcely petty. Unless the Senate decides otherwise this week, it will mark the end of the N.E.D., which was established during the Reagan years to promote democracy abroad and is now supported by President Clinton.

title: How to Make Donations To Help Flood Victims
description: Several American charities have established special funds and sent disaster teams to the Midwest. Here is a list of organizations seeking donations:

title: Boeing Net Lower, but Stock Rises
description: The Boeing Company posted lower second-quarter earnings yesterday, but the results exceeded analysts' expectations and buoyed the company's stock.

title: Business Tax Break Put Back on Table
description: After months of negotiating over $500 billion in tax increases and spending cuts, Congress is suddenly having second thoughts about its long-settled decision to reduce the tax break that businesses get for meals and entertainment expenses.

title: Ekco Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-After a charge of $ 3,247,000 which reflects cumulative effect of accounting for postretirement benefits.c-Net incomeThe company noted that a new method of accounting for income taxes was adopted in 1993 by restating prior financial results.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: FOR NEW YORK INMATES, CLEMENCY IS RARE Last December, after almost 11 years in prison on drug charges, Lawrence Snider was one of only two New York State inmates to receive clemency from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The other was Jean Harris, whose conviction for killing her former lover became a cause celebre. Inmate advocates say that while cases like Mrs. Harris's attract attention, prisoners like Mr. Snider -- who developed drug and AIDS awareness programs and organized charity drives in prison -- are more representative of those who deserve to be considered for clemency. But in 11 years, Mr. Cuomo has granted the extraordinary relief only 31 times. A1. NEW YORK CITY HIGHWAY ROBBERY IN THE BRONX Fourteen people on a shuttle bus bound from Washington Heights to Providence, R.I., are robbed on the Major Deegan Expressway by three fellow passengers who produced pistols and forced the driver to pull over at the Van Cortlandt Park exit. The highway bandits took cash and jewelry, then made their escape in a waiting car. B2.

title: H. D. Eberhart, 86; Transformed Design Of Artificial Limbs
description: Prof. Howard Davis Eberhart, who designed artificial limbs and other prosthetic devices, died of a heart attack on July 18. He was 86.

title: Attack on Cape Town Church Keeps a Rattled Nation Edgy
description: Absurdly, the first notion that came to Kara-Anne Harris on Sunday night as the killers kicked in the door of St. James Church and blasted worshipers with automatic-rifle fire and grenades was that they were after the Russians.

title: Accounts
description: * Potter Hazlehurst Inc., East Greenwich, R.I., was awarded three accounts: Mattress Discounters, Upper Marlboro, Md., to handle its account, previously handled in-house; Home Theater Concepts Ltd., Norwood, Mass., as the first agency to handle the maker of home entertainment systems' account, and Marval Marketing Group, Rockland, Me., as the first agency to handle advertising for the marine retailer. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Beating Indurain Is Problem For Rivals
description: The Motorola team went to a Tex-Mex restaurant in Paris. The Banesto team went to a night club. Most everybody who finished the Tour de France went somewhere afterward to celebrate.

title: Market Place; National Medical, recently battered, faces more therapy.
description: ONE of the nation's largest hospital operators, National Medical Enterprises, appears to be heeding the biblical dictum "Physician, heal thyself." But the recovery is likely to be slow.

title: San Marcos Journal; In Nicaragua, No Peace, and Nostalgia for Somoza
description: On the musty walls of her somber dry goods shop just off this small town's central square, Maria-Elsa Palacio pointed to a faded portrait of the longtime dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle and issued a startling judgment.

title: A War No One Wants
description: On the face of it, the fiercest fighting in Lebanon in more than a decade may seem destined to sabotage the latest chapter in the Middle East peace talks and perhaps even to draw Israel and Syria into an all-out war.

title: Coroner Assailed in Detroit Beating Trial
description: Prosecutors in the trial of three former police officers accused in the fatal beating of a man asserted today that a pathologist who had undermined the state's case was bitter toward his former boss and therefore unreliable as a witness.

title: Q&A
description: Avoiding Ozone

title: First Olympic Event: Going for the Green
description: Olympic and TV executives will square off today over the sale of network rights to the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. The networks will try to show how cost-conscious they can be. The International Olympic Committee will push the value of the centennial Olympiad happening live on the East Coast. The Atlanta organizing committee will simply scream for the most money it can get.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another marker of the passage of time: MICK JAGGER turned 50 yesterday and kept right on rocking as he recorded a new album with the Rolling Stones, The Associated Press reported. No, he wasn't deprived of a party on his half-century milestone. His wife, JERRY HALL, the American model, gave him a party with a French Revolution theme on July 16 in West London, where the guests included the actor Eric Idle, of Monty Python fame, and a former British cabinet minister, Paul Channon.

title: Rise Granted On Insurance For Doctors
description: With efforts to tame the rapid rise in health-care costs delayed in both Washington and Albany, the State Insurance Superintendent today approved an average 14 percent rise in medical malpractice insurance rates paid by doctors.

title: Patterns
description: Micro-Minis Make It Big

title: To Give Is Sublime
description: "Paramount Pictures decided to do something quite nice for several people connected to its new film 'The Firm.' The studio bought new $100,000 Mercedes-Benz 500 SL convertible two-seaters for the film makers and star.

title: Lost in a Complex Maze
description: LAST week's column described how a 386 system crashed after installing QEMM 7.01, the Quarterdeck Expanded Memory Manager, although the program absolved itself of any responsibility: "Without QEMM, your system would have crashed without warning or explanation." Without QEMM, the system had not crashed at all. The only thing to do was to turn the machine off and on again. This time, the original error message, Exception 13, did not recur. Nevertheless, as two sections of the manual suggested, I ran the Manifest program.

title: Corrections
description: A list of outdoor concerts in the special SummerTimes section distributed with some copies on Sunday misstated the date of a Central Park performance of Verdi's "Aroldo" by the New York Grand Opera. It is tonight at 8 at the Rumsey Playfield (mid-park at 72d Street); it was not last night.

title: Calendar Crazy
description: Insurance and plumbing supply companies hand them out to customers. So do banks. But it's never been clear why members of Congress need specially imprinted calendars to distribute to constituents. It's harder to fathom why, when Congress ought to be trying to trim spending, taxpayers should continue to pay for this self-promotion.

title: Goulds Pumps (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 29,746,000 from a change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions.The company said 1992 results were restated to reflect the accounting change.

title: His Honor Himself Is Counselor To Pacino
description: Justice Edwin Torres is standing in a familiar place, in a little alcove off a fourth-floor courtroom in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, but he is seeing something highly unusual, and irksome in the extreme. In the courtroom itself, and visible to various technicians and Justice Torres on a camera monitor in the alcove, Al Pacino is mouthing off to a judge, played by Paul Mazursky.

title: Strategic No More, Mohair Loses Its Status in Senate
description: With no debate or recorded vote, the Senate voted today to kill a subsidy dating from an era when wool and mohair were considered strategic materials essential for military uniforms.

title: Giant Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

Feeney Suffers Mild Stroke
description: CHARLES (CHUB) FEENEY, a former National League president, apparently suffered a mild stroke at yesterday's Giants-Dodgers game in San Francisco and was hospitalized.

title: When It's Time to Pay the Piper Electronically
description: THE scientific theory of chaos holds that if a butterfly flaps its wings in China, your household finances will be a mess. That pesky butterfly is particularly busy near the end of the month, leaving the checkbook chaotic and the bills piling up. Fortunately, the financial butterflies can be counteracted by two impressive new household finance programs, one for Windows computers and one for Macintoshes.

title: COCA-COLA TO SELL MERCHANDISE BY CATALOGUE
description: The Coca-Cola Company is set to send out a 32-page catalogue in the United States to market more than 400 products emblazoned with its trademark logo -- from golf balls to clothing, jewelry to a hand-restored Coca-Cola delivery truck from the 1920's.

title: In West, Dinkins Promotes Candidacy and Filming
description: Battered last week by criticism of his handling of the Crown Heights violence, Mayor David N. Dinkins managed to create some positive moments here, spending the last three days raising money for his re-election campaign and drumming up support for filming in New York City.

description: Yeltsin Relaxes Money Plan

title: Comedy Network Narrows Choice to 3
description: The Comedy Central cable television network in New York said yesterday that it had narrowed the review of its $3 million account to three agencies from 11. The account has been handled by Schnurr & Jackson of Troy, N.Y., for a year and a half.

title: GALILEE UNDER FIRE
description: Israeli forces continued bombing strikes and artillery barrages early this morning on targets in southern Lebanon for a third straight day of attacks on pro-Iranian militiamen.

title: Dentsply International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included charges of $ 13.93 million in the quarter, and $ 16.45 million, in the 6 months.c-Net income

title: Gallagher Is Inside Looking Out
description: Danielle Gallagher's lacrosse career started at the age of 10, when she joined a boys' youth league at Manhasset (L.I.) High School. It was a determined beginning for a young athlete who, 16 years later, is a member of the United States team in the Women's Lacrosse World Cup.

title: Political Memo; Health Plan Sits in the Waiting Room
description: Remember health care reform? The Clinton Administration's self-imposed 100-day deadline for producing a plan has long since passed, and some experts in the field worry that a rare moment of political opportunity has been lost.

title: Keeping It to a Low Roar; New York City Tries Electronic Muzzles to Zap Bus Noise
description: Watch out, Klingons, a new cloaking technology is in the field. It helps hide a city bus.

title: 1Big Ten Takes a Penalty
description: The Big Ten Conference will lose $75,000 in grant money because a flawed policy allowed seven member schools to award more scholarships than permitted under National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: On Horizon, the Specter of a Casino
description: FOR 14 years, the Ramapough community that lives on Stag Hill has been tugging at Washington's sleeve, trying to become certified as a duly recognized American Indian tribe.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ARGOSY GAMING CO., Alton, Ill., acquired a lease giving it mooring privileges to riverfront areas on the Mississippi River in St. Louis from St. Louis Concessions Inc. for $33.5 million in stock and $8.3 million in cash.

title: Death in Italy: A Trail of Corruption
description: They died in different circumstances, but when two of Italy's best-known businessmen were found dead last week, apparently after each committed suicide, the trail that joined them led to an unusual joint venture called Enimont that may well have been the greatest of scams, a tale of fraud that could make Italy's vast and still unraveling political corruption scandal seem modest by comparison.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., known as Freddie Mac, is offering $100 million of notes due in 1996 at 100 to yield 4.65 percent through Goldman, Sachs. The issue is noncallable for one year. * Medic Inc., Pennsauken, N.J., is offering $30 million of exchangeable subordinated debentures due in 2003 at 100 to yield 7.5 percent through Dillon, Read. Noncallable for three years, the debentures are rated B-3 by Moody's Investors Service and B- by Standard & Poor's.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 6,150,000, or 35 cents a share, from change in method of accounting for income taxes.c-Net lossd-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 5,512,000 in the quarter and $ 7,247,000 in the 6 months, and the 6 months also included a gain of $ 92,000,000, or $ 5.31 a share, from change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: Quarter? Quarter? Dollar? Sidewalk Charity Lives
description: As she moves each day through the outstretched hands and jingling coffee cups on the sidewalks and subways of New York, Grace Desnoes has to make choices.

title: E&B Marine reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 603,000, or 4 cents a share, which reflects a reduction in income taxes arising from the carryforward of prior years' operating losses in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Dow Climbs by 20.96, to a Record 3,567.70
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged to another closing record yesterday, as all leading stock market indicators climbed.

description: b-After a gain of $ 57 million for major asset sales and a charge of $ 14 million for unusual environmental/litigation costs, and after a charge of $ 130 million from an adjustment in accounting.c-After charges of $ 1 million for major asset sales and $ 14 million for unusual environmental/litigation costs, and a gain of $ 21 million for a tax benefit on foreign exploration. The period was also after a gain of $ 24 million, or 10 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Latest periods are after preferred dividends of $ 9 million in the quarter and $ 18 million in the 6 months.Year-ago 6 months was restated to include the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle for income taxes from the implementation of SFAS 109.

title: Top G.O.P. Couple Splits on a National Service Bill
description: Bob Dole's latest filibuster has its supporters in the Senate, but it has a major opponent at home: his wife.

title: Rain Forests Seen as Shaped by Human Hand
description: FOR decades, La Selva, a lush, dripping jungle filled with towering trees and swinging vines, has served as the quintessential example of the pristine rain forest, untouched and unchanged for millenniums. But scientists who have begun to look more closely into the history of the world's rain forests say they are finding clues that this one and others like it are not the stable museums of biodiversity they were thought to be.

title: Key Continues His Untimely Fall Back to Earth
description: The sight is strange to the Yankees. It was enough of a surprise when Jimmy Key allowed runs earlier this season, but now he has actually lost some games, too. Their most reliable pitcher has been tough on the eyes lately.

title: Review/Performance Art; Gentle Souls of Gay, Black Defiance
description: For a group that straddles the cutting edges of racial and sexual politics, Pomo Afro Homos, a trio of black gay male performance artists from San Francisco, is a remarkably low-key ensemble. Even when mouthing the rhetoric of defiance and challenging black institutions to face up to the reality of the AIDS epidemic, the attitude of Brian Freeman, Djola B. Branner and Marvin K. White remains more friendly than threatening.

title: Criminal Charge Likely in Firecracker Case
description: The Los Angeles District Attorney's office said late yesterday that a formal criminal charge was expected to be filed as a result of last Saturday's firecracker incident outside Dodger Stadium. Vince Coleman, the left fielder for the Mets, has been identified as the person who threw a lighted firecracker from a vehicle, an action that apparently resulted in injuries to at least three persons.

title: It's Our Own Genes We Should Worry About; Predisposed to Be Gay
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Two English Languages, A Vast and Fertile Field
description: A Mouthful of Air Language, Languages . . . Especially English By Anthony Burgess 416 pages. William Morrow. $25.

title: It's Our Own Genes We Should Worry About
description: To the Editor:

title: Accidental Justice for Jessica DeBoer
description: The judges in Michigan who ordered 2-year-old Jessica DeBoer returned to her natural parents, Dan and Cara Schmidt, made the best decision in a tragic case. A child is better off being returned to even a mediocre home with competent natural parents than being left in an apparently superior home with adoptive parents.

title: Deluxe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $ 60 million pretax charge to cover costs of restructuring in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: U.S. Accused Sheik Last Year Of Inciting Violence in Egypt
description: A State Department report on Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman issued last year found that while the Islamic cleric had never been placed at the scene of violence committed by his supporters, "the evidence shows a clear pattern of encouraging others to commit violent acts against Christians in Egypt and against others."

title: Philadelphia Electric reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Congress Is Feeling Pressure To Preserve Meal Deduction
description: In the last days of politically agonizing negotiations over $500 billion in tax increases and cuts in programs like Medicare, Congress is suddenly having second thoughts this week about a long-settled decision to reduce the huge tax break businesses get for meals and entertainment expenses.

title: It's Our Own Genes We Should Worry About; Military's Closet
description: To the Editor:

title: Horses of Coast Islands, A Regional Symbol, Harm the Environment
description: MORE than any other creatures, wild island ponies personify the rugged beauty of the sandy barrier beaches that line much of the East Coast.

title: Smith Still in Critical Condition
description: The stock-car driver STANLEY SMITH showed signs of ending his paralysis yesterday but he remained in critical condition in Birmingham, Ala., with a skull fracture sustained during the DieHard 500 Sunday in Talladega, Ala.

title: REICHMANN FAMILY MEMBERS BUY OLYMPIA LEASING UNIT
description: Philip Reichmann and Frank Hauer said yesterday that they had agreed to acquire the leasing arm of Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the troubled Canadian real estate empire, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Through a company that they own, Mr. Reichmann and Mr. Hauer will acquire Olympia & York's 90 percent stake in O.& Y. Properties Inc. The unit manages 10 million square feet in 10 office buildings in Toronto, Calgary and Ottawa.

title: Japan Wins U.S. Embassy Work
description: The State Department has selected a Japanese construction company to renovate the residence of the United States Ambassador in Tokyo, even though the American trade representative has found that Japan discriminated against American companies in awarding Government construction contracts.

title: Yeltsin Softens a Plan to Withdraw Old Ruble Notes
description: In the face of growing popular dissatisfaction and loud criticism from the Westernized market-oriented wing of his Government, President Boris N. Yeltsin issued a decree today sharply watering down a drastic currency revision that the Central Bank announced on Saturday.

title: CDI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
After Sex Attacks, Fear Spreads in Starrett City
description: Laurie Ramos was simply startled by her 7-year-old son's question two nights ago. "Mommy, what is rape?" the boy asked innocently, she recalled, after he glimpsed a television news report of what had happened to other children in their Brooklyn community.

title: South Korean Plane Crashes in a Storm; 66 Reported Killed
description: A South Korean airliner crashed on Monday in the southwestern coast of the Korean peninsula, killing 66 of the 110 people aboard, airline officials and news reports said this morning.

title: Corrections
description: The "On Sunday" column in the Metro Report on Sunday referred incorrectly to a cemetery in Queens that prompted a new state law banning burials amid landfill debris. It is the Cypress Hills Cemetery.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 4.9 million on asset sales.c-Net loss and included a loss of $ 1,204,000 from discontinued operations and and also included is unusual charges of $ 16.5 million.

title: Bosnian Leader Goes to Geneva for Start of Talks
description: The President of the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government arrived here today to discuss his Serbian and Croatian rivals' proposal to partition the country into three ethnic enclaves, and international mediators planned to press the Serbs and Croats to be more generous to the Muslims in the division.

title: New Orleans Journal; From Gator Fodder to Haute Cuisine
description: Louisianians have tried everything to get rid of nutrias, the big brown rodents that are eating up the marshes. They have shot them. They have trapped them. They have turned them into fur coats. They have even fed them to the alligators. Now they're going to try eating them.

title: Donald McAllister, Top Executive, 91, In Publishing House
description: Donald McAllister, a business-publications executive active in his family's concern for more than seven decades, died on Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 91 and had homes in Manhattan and Centre Island, L.I.

description: Per share amounts do not reflect the 3-for-2 stock split to be issued on July 20.

description: The company said that the 1992 quarter benefited from $ 13 million in royalty income from tuning system licenes and a special $ 4 million tax credit. Royalty income in the second quarter was $ 5 million.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 77,400,000, or $ 1.39 a share, from combined changes in accounting for income taxes and for postretirement benefits other than pensions.c-Net loss

title: Bridge
description: One of the country's most experienced partnerships won the Life Master Pair Championship here Sunday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Dan Morse of Houston and John Sutherlin of Dallas, who have previously won several major team titles but none in pairs, came from behind with a 59 percent final session to win by almost a full board.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Unraveling the Seminar: Call It Culture Thrash
description: It was all about culture of various kinds; yours, mine and ours. The many constituents of the New Music Seminar -- insurgents and members of the business establishment, hip-hoppers, metal heads, rockers who are collegiate, Irish, Japanese or Turkish, as well as those who shun definition -- came together on Saturday to thrash out the wide-ranging topic at the music-business convention's "Culture Summit."

title: Rita Ford, 92, Dies; Owned Shop Serving Fans of Music Boxes
description: Rita Ford, a dealer in antique and current music boxes with a wide array of musical sounds that enchanted visitors to her Manhattan shop for more than four decades, died on Thursday at New York Hospital. She was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Oklahoma Gas & Electric Co.  reports earnings for 12mos to June 30
description: Year-ago period reflected an $ 18 million provision for a potential rate refund.

title: G.M.'s Undeclared European War
description: The dispute between the General Motors Corporation and Volkswagen A.G. goes beyond a scrap over trade secrets into a no-holds-barred, international battle for strategic position in the increasingly competitive European auto market, industry experts say.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with the Market Place column, about the financial contracts known as derivatives, mislabeled some dollar amounts. In the part of the chart showing a breakdown of the types of investors involved in interest-rate and currency swaps in 1991, the figures should have been labeled in billions, not millions. Transactions between dealers totaled $865 billion in 1991, financial institutions $591 billion, corporations $362 billion, governments $111 billion and others $21 billion.

title: Bids by Owners Sought for Control of Gucci
description: Maurizio Gucci, who owns 50 percent of the Gucci luxury-goods businesses, said today that he wanted the Investcorp Group, owner of the other half, to bid against him for full control of the company.

title: Cancel That Summer Vacation for the Phillies
description: The general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies was discussing the difficulty the St. Louis Cardinals encountered during a long weekend in Colorado. The Rockies won two of four games, giving them four victories in seven recent contests with the Cardinals.

title: Officials Seek S.& L. Funds
description: Four Federal banking regulators urged two key House members today to support more funds for the Resolution Trust Corporation, the savings and loan cleanup agency.

title: Justice Refuses to Block Return Of Girl, 2, to Biological Parents
description: A Michigan couple fighting to keep a 2-year-old they have raised since birth were turned down today by a Supreme Court Justice whom they had asked to block an order that they give the girl to her biological parents.

title: Matthew B. Ridgway Dies at 98; Leader of U.S. Troops in 2 Wars
description: Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, who became Army Chief of Staff after leading American forces in Normandy and United Nations troops in Korea, died yesterday at his home in Fox Chapel, Pa., a suburb of Pittsburgh. He was 98.

title: Sports of The Times; Light a Fuse On Coleman's Departure
description: VINCE COLEMAN was hired to be the Mets' firecracker, a leadoff batter with explosive speed who could steal bases and score runs. But he has been mostly a dud. And a detriment.

title: Another Round in Fix Scandal
description: Reopening the second front in the Olympique Marseilles match-fixing scandal, investigators yesterday inquired deeper into allegations that the club owner, BERNARD TAPIE, tried persuading a rival coach to take the fall. The investigating judge, BERNARD BEFFY, questioned BORO PRIMORAC, former coach for Valenciennes, on Primorac's charge that Tapie offered him money and career opportunities to become a scapegoat. The encounter was expected to last several hours.

title: General Binding Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Seeks to Ease Friction in Companies
description: With corporate executives and labor leaders gathered here today to give supporting testimony, the Clinton Administration insisted that more jobs would exist in the United States if only management and workers ran their companies together.

title: One Vote for College
description: Ryan Sittler raised his eyebrows when he heard how much money Alex Rodriguez was demanding from the Seattle Mariners, but he understood the stress in making the decision.

title: Memories From First Coach
description: For Anthony Lewis, the tragedy of Reggie Lewis's death last night was deepened by the fact that they had just spoken the night before.

title: Power Display by Kent Does It All for Mets
description: Dialed in. It's Jeff Kent's turn of phrase for when he is turning hard on everything at the plate. It means to be focused, to swing with intent and execute menace with ease.

title: Richard Assatly, 49, A Fashion Designer Of Ready-to-Wear
description: Richard Assatly, a skilled designer who worked in all facets of ready-to-wear, died on Sunday at New York University Medical Center. He was 49.

title: War and Peace in the Middle East
description: With luck, the deadly exchanges of bombs and rockets now raining down on civilian populations on both sides of the Israeli-Lebanese border won't blow up the Middle East peace talks. Stopping the negotiations would perversely reward the very group that triggered the latest cycle of violence -- the radical Lebanese Party of God, whose guerrillas killed seven Israeli soldiers stationed on Lebanese soil earlier this month in a calculated effort to undermine the talks.

title: U.S. Grants $4.5 Million to Help Military Contractors Shift Focus
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came here today to announce that the Federal Government has awarded the state a $4.5 million grant to help Long Island's sagging military industries convert to peacetime pursuits.

title: Valenzuel Stirs Memories
description: Fernandomania is only a memory in Los Angeles, but the Mexican Mesmerizer has resurfaced in Baltimore.

title: Uniting in Fight Against Crime in 47th Precinct; Bronx Neighborhood Welcomes Community Policing Despite Frustration With Plan
description: On White Plains Road in the north Bronx, they all know their beat officer, John Crowley. Elvira Wyart, a neighborhood civic leader, has the highest praise for him. Kevin Eybergen, owner of the Deli, can't see enough of him. Residents at St. Luke's housing for the elderly gave him a rousing ovation one recent night. Children at Public School 21 wave when the 6-foot-4-inch 220-pound officer passes, and neighborhood drug dealers seek his support when in a bind.

title: Beijing Journal; Whither That Torch? China's Burning to Have It
description: A few years ago, China seemed to have about as much chance of becoming host to the Summer Olympic Games in 2000 as Deng Xiaoping had of winning a gold medal in the pole vault.

title: Wrestling for Rubles
description: In the last two months, the first glimmers of progress have appeared in two central issues for Russia: slowing inflation and stabilizing the ruble. Feeling encouraged, industrial countries pressed ahead with a $43 billion package of aid to help Russia make the transition to a market economy.

title:
Real Estate;
Norwalk, Conn., With a Glut of Office Space, Gets A Fast-Growing Health Care Company As A Tenant
description: A WELCOME addition to the sluggish Norwalk, Conn., commercial real estate market is a 165,000-square-foot lease recently signed by Oxford Health Plans Inc., a provider of health care services.

title: U.S. Says Ukraine Has Begun Dismantling Nuclear Missiles
description: Ukraine has begun dismantling some of its SS-19 long-range nuclear missiles in an effort to address American concerns that it is determined to preserve its nuclear arsenal, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Financial Benefit Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Autistic Find Doubters Prevail
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Seeks More Powers To Stem Illegal Immigration
description: President Clinton asked Congress today for more money and new laws to tighten the borders against illegal immigrants, speed interviews of people seeking political asylum and let the Government have the same tools it uses against organized crime to fight foreign gangs promoting illegal immigration.

title: Bomb Attacks Kill 5 In Milan and Strike 2 Churches in Rome
description: Car bombs rocked historic sites in Milan and Rome late last night and early today, killing at least five people and raising official concerns that Italy's political turmoil has unleashed a new wave of terrorism intended to destabilize the country.

title: Mideast and Bosnia Call Christopher Back to U.S.
description: As the situation in Bosnia continues to deteriorate, the Clinton Administration is considering an urgent French request to use air power to punish Serbian attacks against French peacekeeping troops, a senior Administration official said today.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO LAG IN SPACE RESEARCH
description: A Federal study said yesterday that the United States is in danger of losing its lead to foreign rivals in the $15-billion-a-year business of building communication satellites and related systems.

title: A New 'Tristan' Gives 'Ring'-Less Bayreuth Plenty to Talk About
description: The opening of the Bayreuth Wagner Festival is a great annual German occasion, equivalent to sports events elsewhere like the Super Bowl, the Henley Regatta in England and the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe horse race in France. It is an opportunity for national pride and corporate display, with the richest Germans flaunting their status through the number of guests for whom they can provide Bayreuth tickets. Since there are seven times more requests than tickets, a fistful represents considerable status.

title: Personal Health
description: Cathy M. was in her ninth month of pregnancy when she awakened with a toothache-like pain in her jaw that within hours spread to her ear. Thinking she had an abscessed tooth, she saw her dentist, who immediately referred her to an oral surgeon. But the surgeon's tests showed that it was not a tooth but more likely a facial nerve that was causing Cathy's pain.

title: Review/Film; Mel Brooks Aims His Comedic Barbs At Robin Hood et al.
description: "Robin Hood: Men in Tights" is Mel Brooks's breezy sendup of every Robin Hood movie ever made, with subsidiary references to other movies, most of them made by Mr. Brooks. The new film's favorite target is Kevin Costner's politically correct "Robin Hood, Prince of Thieves," which championed not only the civil rights of serfs but also feminism, racial understanding and maybe even whales, though my memory is now hazy about that. The Costner film remains memorable mostly for the scenes in which the camera sometimes adopted the point of view of an arrow whizzing unerringly toward its mark.

title: Vincent J. Schaefer, 87, Is Dead; Chemist Who First Seeded Clouds
description: Vincent J. Schaefer, a self-taught chemist who invented cloud "seeding" and created the first artificially induced snow and rainfall, died on Sunday at a hospital in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Rotterdam, N.Y.

title: Fast-Food Test: Giving the Children What They Want
description: PARENTS who are sick of mealtime skirmishes have learned that peace reigns under the golden arches, where children are happy to consume vast quantities of Big Macs, fries and shakes -- in short order and with dismaying caloric consequences.

title: John Brooks, Writer, Dies at 72; Specialized in Stories of Business
description: John Brooks, a longtime staff writer for The New Yorker whose best-selling books exposed the excesses of the business world, died yesterday at the Southampton Nursing Home in Southampton, L.I. He was 72 and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Selling the Shreds of the Cold War
description: In a deal that only the end of the cold war could produce, America's largest munitions maker will soon begin cutting up more than 200,000 tons of surplus Ukrainian ammunition, much of it made for firing at United States troops, and selling it for scrap.

title: Louisiana Land & Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 200,000, or 1 cent a share, which included gain of $ 13.7 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income tax and a charge of $ 13.5 million from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for post-retirement benefits.b-Net loss and included $ 27 million in after-tax charges from the reorganization of domestic exploration and production operations and a provision for a gas well blowout.

title: NBC Wins TV Rights to 1996 Atlanta Games
description: With a record-setting bid of $456 million, NBC last night won the right to broadcast 168 hours of the 1996 Summer Olympics from Atlanta, the third consecutive Summer Olympics to be aired by the network. With a bid that exceeds by $55 million its money-losing payment for the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, NBC defeated ABC's offer of $450 million and CBS's of $415 million.

title: Religion Returns to Russia, With a Vengeance
description: The venues are quintessentially Soviet -- the Lenin Stadium, the October movie theater, the Locomotive sports complex -- but what goes on there would have old Bolsheviks turning in their urns.

title: Books of The Times; The Mediterranean, in Glory and in Tragedy
description: The Inner Sea The Mediterranean and Its People By Robert Fox Maps. 575 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Consumer Confidence Slips
description: Consumers' confidence in the economy slipped in July for the third consecutive month, amid poor employment prospects and slow growth in wages.

title: Poll Finds Edge Still for Dinkins
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins appears to have suffered virtually no erosion of his political support in the aftermath of a state report last week that criticized his handling of the racial violence in Crown Heights two years ago, according to a new poll.

title: Altman Trial Nears Its End
description: The judge in the New York fraud and bribery trial of Robert A. Altman said yesterday that he expected to present the case to the jury on Aug. 9.

title: Condom Plan Is Authorized In New Haven
description: Seeking to halt the spread of AIDS in a city that is the center of the epidemic in Connecticut, the New Haven Board of Education has approved a plan to give condoms to students in middle school and high school.

title: All the Leading Men Set for U.S. Open
description: The United States Tennis Association says that all of the top 40 players on the men's tour have entered the United States Open, which will run from Aug. 30-Sept. 12 at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Loral Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 233,377,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: To Serve Justice in Salvadoran Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Journal; An Exchange Program To Escape the Shelling
description: Out past the cornfields and not too far from the grain depot in the center of town here, Alan Walczak, the one-man international studies department at Grand Valley State University, is dialing Sarajevo again.

title: Survivors of Fatal Hike Fault Lack of a Warning
description: A spokesman for the survivors of a deadly hike in a canyon in Utah said today that the party had not been warned that floodgates were open at the head of the canyon's creek, releasing a rush of water that drowned two people.

title: Bombing Suspect Tied to Drugs
description: For more than three years, the latest suspect in the foiled plot to blow up New York City targets regularly supplied heroin to two Detroit drug dealers, Federal drug agents said yesterday.

title: National Guard Joins Puerto Rico Police on Beat as Crime Rises
description: Every weekend now, troops in camouflage uniforms patrol the beaches here, M-16's in hand as they weave through crowds of children playing in the sand and bathers lying on towels. Outside Plaza Las Americas, the biggest shopping center in the commonwealth, and in the theater and restaurant districts, soldiers in military vehicles rove the parking lots and streets.

title: Dinkins Tries to Reassure Starrett City After Attacks
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins went to Starrett City yesterday to try to reassure residents unnerved by three sexual assaults on young girls in the sprawling housing complex over the last six weeks, most recently on Friday.

title: No Headline
description: "There are a lot fewer 'no' votes that are leaning to 'yes' than there are 'yes' votes that are leaning to 'no."' -- SENATOR JOHN B. BREAUX on the budget negotations. [ A1:2. ]

title: Snow Is Optioned to Minors by Angels
description: The rookie first baseman J.T. SNOW, brilliant in April but an offensive disappointment ever since, has been optioned to Class AAA Vancouver by the California Angels.

title: House Approves Flood Relief After Fight on Deficit
description: The House today narrowly approved a $2.74 billion relief package for Midwest flood victims, resolving five days of mostly partisan wrangling in favor of Democrats who insisted that emergency aid took priority over cutting the budget deficit.

title: Ruling Spurs an Industrywide Selloff
description: The unfavorable resolution of some long-running trade disputes involving foreign steel imports sent the stocks of major American steel companies reeling yesterday amid signs that the country's largest steelmaker, USX, had a turbulent quarter.

title: Miscellany
description: * Charles T. Coyle, former advertising director at The New York Times Magazine, opened a marketing, publishing and sales development consulting group, the Charles Coyle Consulting Co., Greenwich, Conn.

title: K.C. Southern Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 6,500,000 from combined effect of changes in accounting for income taxes and for postretirement benefits other than pensions.

title: Abbott Finds His Best Form For 2d Half
description: The Yankees rang up four runs in the second inning tonight, then realized they were playing in Tiger Stadium, that Jim Abbott has had difficulty protecting leads and that it might be shrewd to keep their fingers crossed. The night was still young.

title: 35,000 JOBS TO GO
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the new chairman of I.B.M., began his campaign yesterday to revive the world's largest computer maker by announcing an $8.9 billion program to cut the company's costs sharply, trimming the payroll by 35,000 more people and getting rid of factories and equipment.

title: London Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corporate Foods reports earnings for Qtr to June 12
description: The company said the results in the latest period included the results of McGavin Foods, acquired in December 1992. During the first quarter, the company's ownership in Circlet Foods Inc. rose to 60 percent from 50 percent and the Circlet results are now consolidated.Corporate Foods said the increase in sales in the latest period is due to the consolidation of McGavin and Circlet.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cray Research reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Share Prices Fall at Novell
description: Shares of Novell Inc., whose software is the spine of many computer networks, fell $2.875, to $18.375, yesterday in anticipation of lower third-quarter earnings. After over-the-counter trading closed, Novell said that because of slower sales in Europe, it would report sharply lower earnings, possibly even a net loss.

title: Via Sicily, a Low-Fat Meal of Salmon and Peppers
description: MIMMETTA, a new restaurant in Washington, specializes in Sicilian food. There is a lot that is very low in fat, and delicious.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Tamper with the image of Miss America? Let down her teased and sprayed helmet of hair?

title: Saberhagen Admits to 'Joke'
description: Bret Saberhagen yesterday identified himself as the player who lit a firecracker and threw it under a table near reporters in the Shea Stadium clubhouse on July 7.

title: Consider This a Complaint About a Big Pothole
description: To the Editor:

title: Bacteria in Water Prompts Warnings in Manhattan
description: After finding bacteria in the water supply, city officials last night warned residents and workers in large areas of the West Village, Chelsea and lower Manhattan not to drink or cook with tap water unless it is boiled first.

title: Dodge Pickup Is Priced
description: he Chrysler Corporation said today that prices of its all-new 1994 Dodge Ram full-size pickup would start at $11,824. The most popular model is expected to cost $18,140, company officials said during a ceremony at the Dodge City manufacturing plant, where the first trucks were driven off the line today. The pickups will go on sale in October. The volume leader is expected to be the Ram 1500 Laramie SLT. Standard equipment includes a 5.2-liter V-8 engine, automatic transmission, air- conditioning and power windows.

title: Catholic Church Can't Follow Fashion in Morals; Gay Priests
description: To the Editor:

title: Fernandez Is Out With Shoulder Injury
description: MARY JOE FERNANDEZ seeded second, withdrew from the Acura United States Women's Hard Court Championships in Stratton Mountain, Vt., yesterday because of a right-shoulder injury.

title: Brunswick Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 800,000, or 1 cent a share.c-Net lossd-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 500,000 in both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6 months included a charge of $ 38,300,000 from cumulative effect of change in accounting for post retirement benefits.

title: U.S. Overturns Tariffs on Many Steel Imports
description: Opening huge holes in the protectionist wall that has surrounded the American steel industry for most of three decades, a Federal agency eliminated dozens of steel-import tariffs today, ruling that they were unnecessary.

title: Court Upholds New York Plan On Transportation Borrowing
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice upheld today a state plan to borrow $6 billion for transportation projects, rejecting a taxpayer's lawsuit that has jeopardized major rebuilding programs for roads, bridges, buses and subways across the state.

title: Samuel Kurtz, 89; Architect Designed Hospitals and Bank
description: Samuel Mordechai Kurtz, an architect of hospitals and commercial buildings, died on July 15 at St. Paul's Manor in San Diego. Mr. Kurtz, who was 89, had moved to San Diego from North Miami Beach in December.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: KIMBERLY-CLARK CO., Dallas, signed a joint-venture agreement to build a $33 million tissue mill in Bahrain. ELI LILLY & CO., Indianapolis, said its Cardiac Pacemakers Inc. unit had received an approval letter from the Food and Drug Administration for Endotak, a lead that connects a person's heart to a device designed to stop irregular heart beats.

title: F.T.C. Sets New Rules on '900' Services
description: The Federal Trade Commission imposed tough new advertising restrictions today on companies that sell everything from psychic advice to sports scores over "900"-number telephone services that charge callers a fee.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8 RAIDS ON LEBANON CONTINUE Israeli warplanes and artillery pounded villages in southern Lebanon for the third straight day in attacks intended to drive residents out of the southern part of the country until assaults on Israel by pro-Iranian guerrillas are halted. A1 120,000 LEBANESE LEAVE VILLAGES United Nations observers estimated that 120,000 Lebanese had left their villages in southern Lebanon in the last two weeks. A6

title: Celtics' Lewis Dies After Collapsing in a Gym
description: Reggie Lewis, the Boston Celtics' star who collapsed with a heart ailment during a playoff game last April and was warned by doctors that he would risk his life if he ever played basketball again, died last night after collapsing while shooting baskets at the team's training center at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: INSIDE
description: Tariffs Cut on Steel Imports

title: Inco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net incomeShare earnings amounts are calculated after allowances for preferred dividends.The company said first 6 months of the 1993 results, relative to the first 6 months of 1992, primarily reflected declines in operating results for both of the company's major business segments.First half 1993 results also included a provision, recorded in the first quarter of 1993, of $ 20.4 million, $ 14.1 million after tax, for costs associated with restructuring initiatives in the alloys and engineered products business.Revenue represented net sales and other income.

title: Komag Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included loss of $ 2,079,000 and $ 4,983,000, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from minority interests in loss of consolidated units and a gain of $ 1,068,000 in the quarter and $ 2,475,000 in the 6 months, both from equity in net income of unconsolidated joint venture.c-Included loss for minority interests in loss of consolidated units of $ 2,256,000 and $ 2,781,000, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a loss of $ 623,000 and $ 549,000, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from equity in net income of unconsolidated joint venture.

title: Wheelchair Warrior Lays Siege to Schools
description: School officials hate to see Gregory Solas coming. But to the handicapped he is a champion -- a wheelchair warrior in the fight to make schools accessible to the disabled.

title: Clinton Sought To Cheer Aide, Official Reports
description: President Clinton telephoned Vincent W. Foster Jr. the night before he committed suicide in part because he knew that the deputy White House counsel was "having a rough time" at work, the White House said today.

title: Food Notes
description: Barbecue Grates

title: Family's Battle to Put Child in Regular Classroom
description: Rafael Oberti's parents know their 8-year-old son will never make the dean's list.

title: Oliver Agrees to Another Dolphin Pact
description: Miami Dolphins free safety LOUIS OLIVER signed a one-year contract yesterday and said he would take a chance on the National Football League free-agent market next year. The strategy is risky for Oliver, 27, because the N.F.L. is expected to have a salary cap in place for the 1994 season.

title: LG&E Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $ 2.4 million, or 8 cents a share, from closing of project financing for a New York cogeneration plant.

title: Western Aid Is No Help
description: It has become clear that new Western credits are no longer a remedy for Russia, but a drug helping maintain an unfit system, one accustomed to continual budget overruns and fiscal irresponsibility.

title: Assad's Double Game
description: President Clinton made a mistake yesterday in praising President Hafez al-Assad of Syria for "commendable restraint" in Lebanon. What's needed when Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives in the Middle East this week to try to unlock negotiations is an effort to rein in Syrian brinkmanship.

title: Homophobia Takes a Hit
description: Among the gay-bashing referendums on state and local ballots last fall, Colorado's was one of the most sweeping and punitive. Voters amended the State Constitution to forbid both state and local governments from enacting any laws protecting gay men and lesbians from discrimination. Last week the Colorado Supreme Court, in a creative and thoughtful opinion, struck down the measure as unconstitutional.

title: Book Notes
description: A Big Year for 'Bridges'

title: Youth Guilty in Pool Case
description: A 17-year-old Bronx youth pleaded guilty yesterday to sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl in a municipal swimming pool in Crotona Park during the Independence Day weekend, when a group of youths surrounded the girl in the water, pulled off her bathing suit and fondled her. The youth, Philip Munoz of 1899 Belmont Avenue, told the court that he, acting with others, touched the girl's breasts and buttocks, Bronx District Attorney Robert T. Johnson said.

title: Review/Dance; Nikolais's 'Imago,' Forever Young
description: No choreographer was as adept at turning a prop into a philosophy as Alwin Nikolais; the quintessential Nikolais was on view Monday night with the revival of his 1963 "Imago" at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea).

title: Imasco Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represented net revenues.The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Judge's Optimistic Signature On a Grim-Faced Death Row
description: Charles J. Hearn, a Texas state judge, has been putting a happy face on his signature for years.

title: Catholic Church Can't Follow Fashion in Morals; Alienated Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Drastic Start From Scratch On Financing for Schools
description: Frustrated by its inability to provide residents with property-tax relief, the Michigan Legislature took the ultimate political gamble last week. It repealed all property taxes that support public schools, betting that the pressure to quickly find $6 billion a year for public education would force the lawmakers to make difficult decisions.

title: Wheat Prices Rise to a High On Reports of Rain's Impact
description: Wheat futures prices rallied to a five-month high yesterday after reports that the quality of the American crop had suffered because of persistent rain in some of the nation's largest wheat-producing states.

title: Petty Politics on National Service
description: Two years or three? It's a trivial difference, but Senate Republicans think President Clinton's national service initiative is worth scuttling for the sake of knocking a year off the life of the program.

title: Becker Milk reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: If the Hudson Imitated the Mississippi
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE tradition of cooking with spirits goes back centuries. In the Gascony region of France, for example, Armagnac, the distinctive brandy, is used in all sorts of sauces for game. Similarly, chefs in the Champagne region incorporate their famous sparkling wine into all varieties of dishes.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT was just after 5 A.M. when Simon Judd sped along a darkened road in England, hurrying to Dover, where he planned to catch the 6 A.M. cross-channel ferry that would bring him to this French port.

title: Consolidated Edison Co. of New York reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Consolidated (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $ 116,199,000 from adoption of SFAS 106 and 109.

title: From Whom the Cuban Bell Tolls
description: The Clinton Administration has wisely relaxed the economic embargo of Cuba to allow U.S. telephone companies to share toll revenues with the Castro regime. This could end a cruel and senseless game that has compelled Cuban-Americans in Miami to speak to relatives 90 miles away by routing calls through Canada, which shares tolls with Havana. Yet there is another hurdle before the lines open: Fidel Castro has to agree.

title: Tenneco Operating Net Up but Stock Falls
description: Tenneco Inc. reported yesterday that second-quarter operating earnings more than doubled over the corresponding period last year. But the company's stock fell $2.50, to $48, on the New York Stock Exchange after it announced serious losses in its packaging concern with no sign of relief in the near future.

title: Schuylerville Stakes to Kick Off the Saratoga Scene
description: Saratoga, the home of racing tradition and racing upsets, will open its 126th season today with the 75th running of the Schuylerville Stakes for 2-year-old fillies trying to pass the first milestone on the road to success.

title: Son to Shelter Troubled Man Residents Fear On West Side
description: A mentally ill man who in the past has frightened residents of the Upper West Side and was once convicted of pushing a girl into traffic will be released tomorrow from a state mental hospital in Queens.

title: Dr. Simon Greenberg, 92, Rabbi And Conservative Jewish Leader
description: Dr. Simon Greenberg, rabbi, educator and religious thinker and vice chancellor emeritus of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, died on Monday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 92 and moved to Jerusalem last year from Manhattan.

title: Top Officer At American Will Testify
description: Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines' parent, the AMR Corporation, is not a defendant in the air fare antitrust case being heard here in Federal District Court. Nonetheless Mr. Crandall and his outspoken, fiercely competitive style are on trial.

title: ISRAEL CONTINUES TO BLAST VILLAGES IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israeli warplanes and artillery pounded villages in southern Lebanon for the third straight day today in attacks intended to drive residents out of the southern part of the country until assaults on Israel by pro-Iranian guerrillas are halted.

title: Giants' Meggett Is About Ready to Sign
description: Running back Dave Meggett will probably end his holdout and join the Giants today, according to his agent, Tony Agnone.

title: LEBANON REFUGEES FLEE ISRAELI BOMBS
description: "We could not take the raids and the shelling," Nuhad Olaik said. She had just arrived in Tyre today with three of her children, aged 9, 7 and 2, part of an exodus of Lebanese from areas of southern Lebanon bombed and shelled by Israel.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Sir Terence Conran; The Titled Champion of Democracy
description: WHEN people talk about Quaglino's, the restaurant of the moment here, they talk about the spectacular design, the immense skylight, the Crustacea Altar -- if you please -- where a dizzying array of raw shellfish is indeed to be worshiped before eaten, the cigarette girls, the 65 chefs serving 400 customers per meal, the dance floor in the upstairs bar with a view of the main dining room and most of all, the sweeping staircase down to it. This is an entrance with a vengeance. It teaches sympathy for Oscar presenters.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Jury Selection Starts Today in Beating of Los Angeles Truck Driver
description: A painstaking process of jury selection is to begin Wednesday in the racially volatile trial of two black men charged with beating a white truck driver in the riots here last year.

title: Linebacker Surplus A Strength For Giants
description: Lawrence Taylor stood before reporters and proclaimed that he was actually thrilled about going to practice and attending meetings. He was just tickled to death. The Giants' linebacker spoke as if he had just sunk a 19-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole to win the Masters.

title: For Illinois Town Battling River, a Sense of Doom
description: The 2,000 or so people who live in and around this historic southern Illinois village have pretty much resigned themselves to the likelihood that their levee, under tremendous pressure for weeks, will break when Mississippi River crests here next week.

title: Wellcome Stock Jumps
description: The stock price of Wellcome P.L.C. rose nearly 4 percent today because of an article that is to appear Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine saying that the company's anti-AIDS drug Retrovir, or AZT, is beneficial in early treatment of the disease. Wellcome shares rose 25 pence on the London exchange to close at 665 pence, -- $4.46 -- a gain of 3.9 percent. On Thursday, the results of a clinical study by the European and Australian Collaborative Group on the use of Retrovir will be published in The New England Journal of Medicine, a spokeswoman for the British pharmaceuticals company said.

title: Undefeated but Second Billing on the Card
description: ERNEST MATEEN, who has never been defeated in 19 pro fights, has a reputation for taking on tough opponents, enough anyway that the light-heavyweight boxer from Brooklyn is ranked No. 10 by the United States Boxing Association and No. 13 by the World Boxing Council.

title: American Annuity Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 7,000,000 in the quarter and $ 8,200,000 in the 6 months, and the 6 months also included a charge of $ 3,100,000 from cumulative effect of accounting changes.Year-ago 6-month figures have been restated to reflect accounting change retoractive to Jan. 1, 1992.American Annuity said second quarter income included realized net gains of $ 8.4 million, or 24 cents a share, on investments.The company also said 1993 is the first period in which the operations of its Great American Life Insurance Co. unit are included in its results.

title: Homosexuals in Service Sue Over Clinton's Compromise
description: Just eight days after the White House announced compromise regulations governing their lives, seven gay and lesbian members of the armed services sued the Government today, contending that their treatment was unconstitutional.

title: Faculty Leaders at CUNY Vote to Condemn Chancellor
description: Faculty leaders from most campuses of the City University of New York yesterday passed a strongly worded resolution condemning the university's Chancellor, Dr. W. Ann Reynolds, faculty representatives said.

title: The Road to Recovery: From Drugs to Drama
description: HE remembers it like yesterday. He had gone to visit his 3-year-old son Danny in the projects, and his ex-wife would not allow him in the house. He was at the lowest point of his heroin addiction. He was homeless and he no longer believed in anything.

title: People
description: * Jerry Stahl was named executive vice president and general manager at Bozell Minneapolis, succeeding Ron Benza, who left to join McCann-Erickson San Francisco in the same capacity. Mr. Stahl was previously a consultant in Minneapolis for two years. Before that, he was an executive vice president at Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis.

title: This Jet Tackle Fits the Order for Bulk
description: Ask Siupeli Malamala of the Jets about his weight any time you want. He insists that at 6 feet 5 inches and 300-plus pounds he doesn't have a weight problem.

title: Panel Says Penn Police Overreacted
description: A review panel at the University of Pennsylvania has found that several campus police officers overreacted in April when they tried to stop eight black students from seizing copies of the student newspaper as a protest against a conservative columnist.

title: Amphenol Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: On Dec. 22, 1992, Amphenol acquired LPL Technologies Inc. and its Times Fiber Communications Inc. unit. On a pro-forma basis, as if the acquisition occurred on Jan. 1, 1992, the pro-forma results of operations for the second quarter ended June 30, 1992 were: sales of $ 146.7 million; net income of $ 6.3 million, and earnings per share of 15 cents a share. Both actual and pro-forma results an after-tax gain of about $ 850,000 relating to an interest rate swap transaction.

title: Report on Trade Treaty Is Critical of Companies
description: A report scheduled to be released in Washington on Wednesday accuses several major American companies that are staunch supporters of the North American Free Trade Agreement of having shifted thousands of jobs to Mexico, consistently violated workers' rights here and used Mexican plants to make products that have been banned in the United States.

title: Interface Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
Computer Sciences Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Included a gain of $ 4,900,000, or 29 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Book Notes
description: A Big Year for 'Bridges'

title: The Purposeful Cook; The Forecast: Cool and Crisp
description: WITH this refreshing vegetarian menu, we salute summer while lowering our calorie intake. The fruit and vegetables represented here take advantage of the bounty of the season.

title: A Partner Leaves Follis DeVito Verdi
description: Follis DeVito Verdi of New York and John Follis, a partner and creative director at the agency, announced yesterday that Mr. Follis had left because of "philosophical differences" and had opened his own shop, Follis Inc.

title: NORTHWEST UNION EXPECTED TO ANNOUNCE AGREEMENT
description: Leaders of Northwest Airlines' largest union, the International Association of Machinists, is expected to announce today that the union's members have approved a deal to help Northwest restructure its finances and avoid filing for bankruptcy protection. People familiar with the results of Monday's vote said that turnout was high and that a clear majority was voting to accept the pact.
